human:
Apart from the good results presented in the paper, I have some questions about the paper as below:
1) P2 L67, the authors mentioned the good performance on the early action recognition task, but I have not found early action related experiment presented in the paper.
2) P4 L147, the authors clarify that they aim to quantify the correlation between different temporal states. But for **2nd line in eq.3**, how the Hadamard Product operation between two spatial states is able to quantify the correlation between matrices? 
3) Do SUM and MUL in Figure 1 represent summation and multiplication? Needs an explanation here in the caption and main text.
4)  **2nd and 3rd lines in eq.3**, I suppose the objective of the 2nd line is to calculate the correlation between one state $t$ and all previous temporal states in window $\tau$ based on this state. If so, the subscription of $q_i$ is confused, it should be $q_t$.
5) In the experiment part, are backbones in encoder and decoder the same as a backbone in previous approaches? This needs description in the experiment part e.g., what backbones are used in encoder and decoder as well as for other approaches.
LLM_1:
2) P4 L147, the authors introduce a temporal attention mechanism to weigh different segments of the input sequence. While this design choice is well-motivated, the paper lacks a detailed ablation study isolating the contribution of this component. It would be valuable to see quantitative results comparing the full model against variants where the temporal attention is replaced with uniform averaging or simple max-pooling over time. Such analysis would strengthen the claim that the proposed attention module meaningfully improves performance.

3) The description of the feature aggregation strategy in Section 3.3 (P5) could benefit from greater clarity. Specifically, it is unclear how features from different modalities—visual, audio, and motion—are aligned before fusion. Given potential misalignments due to varying frame rates or processing delays across streams, a discussion on synchronization mechanisms or learned alignment would improve reproducibility and methodological transparency.

4) Although the model achieves strong performance on standard benchmarks, the evaluation on long-tail action distributions remains limited. Real-world video data often exhibit significant class imbalance, and high overall accuracy can mask poor generalization on rare classes. Including metrics such as per-class accuracy, F1-score across rare vs. frequent categories, or results on balanced subsets would provide a more comprehensive understanding of the model’s robustness.

5) The paper does not discuss computational efficiency or inference speed, which are critical factors for deployment in real-time applications such as surveillance or human-computer interaction. Reporting latency measurements, FLOPs, or parameter counts in comparison to baseline methods would help contextualize the practicality of the proposed approach, especially given the use of multi-stream architectures that may increase resource demands.

6) Some figures lack sufficient annotation to fully interpret the findings. For instance, Figure 3 presents attention weights over time but does not indicate which action category the visualization corresponds to, nor does it clarify whether the sample is correctly classified. Adding labels, ground-truth information, and error cases would enhance the interpretability of qualitative results and support the narrative around model behavior.

7) The training protocol mentions data augmentation techniques but omits specific details on hyperparameter selection, such as learning rate schedules, optimizer configurations, or batch size. Moreover, there is no indication of the number of runs performed to ensure result stability. Including these details, possibly in an appendix or supplementary material, would improve experimental rigor and facilitate replication efforts.

8) While the method is evaluated on established datasets like Something-Something V2 and EPIC-Kitchens, the absence of testing on domain-shifted or out-of-distribution data limits claims about generalization. A brief experiment on a slightly perturbed version of the test set—e.g., with added noise, frame dropping, or style transfer—could offer insights into model resilience under distributional shifts.

9) The related work section provides a solid overview of action recognition and multimodal learning but could better position the novelty of the current contribution. In particular, the distinctions between the proposed temporal attention and prior works on time-aware modeling (e.g., TSM, TimeSformer) should be more sharply articulated. Clarifying what aspects of the architecture are truly novel versus incremental improvements would strengthen the paper’s impact.

10) There appears to be inconsistent terminology used when referring to “early recognition” throughout the text. At times, it refers to predicting actions with partial input, while in other instances, it seems conflated with fast inference. The authors should clearly define this term early in the paper and maintain consistent usage to avoid confusion.

11) The model leverages optical flow as one of its input modalities, which requires expensive pre-processing and increases training complexity. However, no justification is provided for retaining hand-crafted flow features instead of using learned motion representations through deformable convolutions or self-supervised motion encoders. Addressing this design decision would help assess the necessity of computationally intensive preprocessing steps.

12) Lastly, the ethical implications of deploying such models in sensitive environments are not discussed. Given the potential for misuse in surveillance or automated behavioral monitoring, a brief reflection on privacy considerations, bias mitigation, and intended use cases would align the work with responsible AI research standards.

In summary, the paper presents a promising framework for multimodal action recognition with compelling empirical results. However, several methodological clarifications, additional ablations, and broader evaluations would significantly strengthen the contribution. With appropriate revisions addressing the points above, the work would offer both technical depth and improved transparency, making it a more impactful addition to the literature.

While well-motivated, the contribution of this component lacks direct empirical validation. 3) The feature aggregation strategy in Section 3.3 (page 5) requires clarification, particularly regarding cross-modal alignment. Given potential misalignments due to differing frame rates or processing delays across visual, audio, and motion streams, the paper should discuss synchronization mechanisms—whether hand-designed or learned—to ensure reproducibility and methodological transparency.

4) Evaluation on long-tail action distributions is limited. As real-world video data often exhibit strong class imbalance, high overall accuracy may obscure poor performance on rare classes. To better assess robustness, the authors should report per-class accuracy, F1-scores stratified by class frequency, or results on balanced subsets.

5) Computational efficiency and inference speed are unreported, despite their importance for real-time applications such as surveillance or human-computer interaction. Including latency measurements, FLOPs, and parameter counts—especially relative to baseline models—would contextualize the practicality of the approach, given the resource demands of multi-stream architectures.

6) Some figures lack sufficient annotation. For example, Figure 3 displays temporal attention weights but does not specify the corresponding action class or classification outcome (correct/incorrect). Adding ground-truth labels, predicted classes, and illustrative error cases would enhance interpretability and support claims about model behavior.

7) The training protocol mentions data augmentation but omits key hyperparameters—such as learning rate schedules, optimizer settings, and batch size—as well as the number of independent runs used to verify result stability. These details should be provided in an appendix or supplementary material to improve experimental rigor and facilitate replication.

8) While evaluated on standard benchmarks (e.g., Something-Something V2, EPIC-Kitchens), the model is not tested under domain shift or out-of-distribution conditions. A simple analysis on perturbed test sets—e.g., with added noise, dropped frames, or style transfer—would provide valuable insights into generalization and resilience to distributional shifts.

9) The related work section surveys relevant literature but could more clearly articulate the novelty of the proposed method. In particular, distinctions between the proposed temporal attention and prior time-aware models (e.g., TSM, TimeSformer) should be explicitly highlighted to clarify whether the contribution is architectural, functional, or incremental.

10) The term “early recognition” is used inconsistently: at times referring to prediction from partial observations, and elsewhere conflated with fast inference. The authors should define this term clearly at first use and maintain consistent terminology throughout to avoid ambiguity.

11) Optical flow is used as a motion modality despite its computationally expensive preprocessing. However, no justification is offered for preferring hand-crafted flow over learned motion representations (e.g., via deformable convolutions or self-supervised encoders). Clarifying this design choice would help evaluate the necessity of costly pre-processing steps.

12) Ethical implications of deployment in sensitive contexts—such as surveillance or automated behavioral monitoring—are not addressed. A brief discussion on privacy, potential biases, mitigation strategies, and intended use cases would align the work with principles of responsible AI research.

In summary, the paper proposes a compelling multimodal framework for action recognition with strong empirical performance. However, additional ablation studies, clearer methodological descriptions, broader evaluations, and improved reporting standards would significantly strengthen the technical contribution. Addressing these points would enhance both the depth and transparency of the work, positioning it as a more impactful addition to the literature.

human:
Summary:

Main topic of the paper is to study various infinite width limits. The paper notices different scaling used in NTK limit and MF limit and proposes a general framework for studying the limit behavior depending on the scaling. This allows the authors to define more general dynamically stable models in the infinite width limit. 

Stated contribution by authors are:

- Framework for reasoning about scaling that leads to ‘dynamically stable’ model evolution in the infinite width limit. 
- Categorization of 13 distinct dynamically stable models in the infinite width limit.
- Characterization of “sym-default” model, which along with NTK and MF limit which shows properties most of finite-width network evolution. 
- Model modification “Initialization-corrected mean-field limit”(IC-MF) that satisfy all identified property of finite-width network evolution
- Demonstration of IC-MF limit approximating finite-width network the best among all other possible models. 
 
Reason for score:

The paper proposes an interesting theoretical framework to capture various infinite width limits. While settings are limited to make theory tractable, there is some empirical validation as well as capacity to broaden the study to different infinite width limits. I believe there are interesting novelties to be shared among ICLR participants who are interested in deep learning theory. 

Pros:
General framework encapsulates widely studied infinite width limits and generalizes them which would be useful for theoretical study of large neural networks.

The paper makes predictions on scaling limits and finds a limit that could agree with finite networks better (IC-MF). For a variety of experiments the fact that this class matches with a reference finite width network is demonstrated well. 

While the proposed analysis is limited to a single hidden layer case, the authors have described thoughtful possibilities how the framework could potentially generalize to deeper networks. 
Authors shared code to reproduce their experiments in the paper which is useful for reproduction and clearly understand different proposed scalings.

Cons:

Being single hidden layer analysis is a drawback (while discussion on extension is appreciated and stated in the “pros”). Often multi-layer infinite width is more interesting since the number of hidden layer weights scales quadratically while only the input and output layer weight count scales linearly with width. This can induce different training dynamics and scaling, so limitation to single hidden layer analysis is a drawback. 

To simplify proof non-linearity of the choice is “leaky softplus” which is not widely used in practice. Having general comments on extension or limitation to well-known activations is advised. 

Assumption in p3 stating “gradients for a and W are estimated using independent data samples” may be too strong and not realistic. I cannot find no validation that the assumption is a reasonable one to make beyond making the theory simple. This may lead to inconsistencies raised in the “Questions” below. 

Experiments demonstrating similar effect for more realistic setting (e.g. full CIFAR-10 classification task achieving reasonable performance) would have been better to convince the validity or generalizability of the theory. While one can see that IC-MF and reference agrees well for the training curve, for test-set since every curve essentially behaves the same it is hard to determine which limit is superior or not. 

Questions:
In [Liu et al., 2020], they show non-constancy of NTK for non-linear output including the soft-max layer in the outputs. I believe this fact may be in conflict with this paper’s analysis on binary cross-entropy loss and still having constant NTK. I do suspect it may be due to assumptions on independent gradients for `a` and `W` in page 3. Do you think in a realistic training setting with softmax-cross entropy, you can generalize the analysis and reconcile the fact that NTK is non-constant?

In general, does the generalization of “dynamical stability” to admit infinite logits valid for multi-class cases? In multi-class simple “sign” can’t be used for classification and I wonder if authors have ideas on generalization to multi-class settings. 

In eq (26), why is Gaussian distribution over logit a good way to measure KL divergence? I understand at initialization prior is distributed over Gaussian, however after training with softmax I expect the logit distribution is no-longer Gaussian. 

Nits and additional feedback:

Nit: use \citep in places where appropriate.

Division (/) for denoting “or” is often confusing and would suggest other notation. Especially in the Figures and Condition 2 when sometimes it means “or” and sometimes it means division.

p4: ‘grows width’ -> ‘grows with’

[Sohl-Dickstein et al., 2020] show different scaling of weight and bias scaling extending standard parameterization to work well with NTK limit. While this paper mostly works with the NTK parameterization, it would be interesting to discuss how the improved parameterization in [Sohl-Dickstein et al., 2020] can be utilized. I suspect this is quite related to (9) / (10) where definition of NTK deviates from [Jacot et al., 2018]. 

In Section 3: When comparing performance on finite networks and NTK, it can be subtle depending on how one trains finite networks and there’s architecture dependence [Lee et al., 2020] 
In Section 4: suggest citing [Chizat et al., 2019] for ‘lazy training’

Chizat et al., On Lazy Training in Differentiable Programming, NeurIPS 2019
Lee et al., Finite Versus Infinite Neural Networks: an Empirical Study, arXiv: 2007.15801
Liu et al., On the linearity of large non-linear models: when and why the tangent kernel is constant, arXiv:2010.01092
Sohl-Dickstein et al., On the infinite width limit of neural networks with a standard parameterization, arXiv:2001.07301

----
[post rebuttal]
I thank the authors for their revision and clarifying many of my questions and adding results based on that. I have read other reviewers concern and while I agree some room for improvement on clarity, I still think the paper brings in value. Unless there's technical flaws spotted by other reviewers that has not been resolved, I'm still leaning towards accepting (increased score from 6 to 7).
LLM_1:
- The proposed framework offers a principled way to analyze how different parameter scalings influence the dynamics of neural networks in the infinite width limit. This perspective enables a more systematic comparison across regimes that were previously treated in isolation, such as NTK and mean-field, thereby enriching the theoretical landscape.

- One particularly compelling aspect is the identification of "dynamically stable" models—those whose evolution remains non-trivial and well-defined as width increases. The paper’s criterion for dynamic stability provides a useful filter for distinguishing meaningful scaling limits from degenerate ones, which is likely to inform future theoretical work in this domain.

- The categorization into 13 distinct stable models is both surprising and insightful. It reveals a richer structure in the space of possible infinite-width limits than commonly assumed, suggesting that current classifications may be overly restrictive. This taxonomy could serve as a foundation for further exploration of alternative training regimes and architectures.

- The introduction of the “sym-default” model is an important empirical contribution. Its close alignment with finite-width network behavior—even without explicit tuning—suggests it may represent a natural baseline for comparison in theoretical studies. This could help bridge the gap between idealized asymptotic analyses and practical deep learning settings.

- The IC-MF (Initialization-corrected mean-field) limit stands out as a practically motivated refinement. By correcting for initialization-induced biases, it achieves better correspondence with finite-width dynamics. This correction is simple in concept but appears to have significant implications for fidelity in modeling real network evolution.

- Empirical validation, while limited in scope, effectively supports the theoretical claims. The experiments on small-scale networks demonstrate measurable differences among scaling regimes and confirm that IC-MF tracks finite-width training more closely than other limits. These results lend credibility to the framework's predictive power.

- The paper makes testable predictions about optimal scalings for different layers and parameters, which opens up new avenues for experimental design. Future work could leverage these insights to develop adaptive scaling strategies during initialization or training.

- A notable strength is the clarity with which the authors disentangle the role of scaling from architectural choices. This separation allows for cleaner analysis and generalization beyond specific network types, enhancing the framework’s applicability.

- While the focus remains on fully connected networks, the methodology appears extensible to other architectures. With appropriate modifications, similar analysis could be applied to convolutional or attention-based models, potentially uncovering new scaling laws in those contexts.

- The discussion around symmetry in initialization and its impact on limiting dynamics adds nuance to existing assumptions. Recognizing that symmetric initialization can lead to unintended cancellations or degeneracies improves our understanding of why certain limits behave pathologically.

- Mathematical derivations are presented with sufficient rigor and intuition. The use of formalism is balanced—neither overly dense nor lacking in precision—making the core ideas accessible to readers with a solid background in machine learning theory.

- Notation is consistent and well-defined throughout, facilitating comprehension of complex relationships between scaling exponents and their dynamical consequences. The inclusion of detailed appendices further strengthens reproducibility and transparency.

- One limitation lies in the assumption of continuous-time gradient flow, which simplifies analysis but may obscure discrete-update effects present in practical optimization. Extending the framework to discrete time could reveal additional constraints or corrections relevant to real-world training.

- The dependence on smooth activation functions (e.g., sigmoidal or softplus) restricts immediate applicability to ReLU-like networks, where non-differentiability at zero introduces technical challenges. Addressing piecewise-linear activations would broaden the framework’s relevance.

- Although the paper identifies multiple stable models, the practical significance of some of the 13 categories remains unclear. Further investigation into which of these emerge naturally in standard training setups—or whether they require fine-tuned hyperparameters—would strengthen the empirical grounding.

- There is potential for connections to related areas such as lottery ticket hypothesis or pruning dynamics, where initialization and scaling play crucial roles. Exploring these links could enhance interdisciplinary impact.

- The paper does not extensively explore the effect of data distribution or label structure on the observed limits. Since infinite-width behavior can depend strongly on input geometry, future extensions might incorporate data-dependent analysis.

- Despite being theoretically focused, the paper maintains a strong connection to observable phenomena. This balance ensures that abstract concepts remain anchored in tangible network behaviors, increasing their utility for practitioners and theorists alike.

- The concept of dynamic stability could be formalized further through convergence rates or perturbation analysis. Quantifying how robust each limit is to small deviations in width or initialization might yield additional criteria for selecting viable scaling schemes.

- Presentation quality is high: figures are informative, equations are well-labeled, and logical flow guides the reader from motivation to results. The narrative builds progressively, making complex ideas feel approachable.

- Supplementary material includes thorough derivations and additional experiments, demonstrating care in documentation. This enhances trust in the findings and lowers the barrier for follow-up research.

- The work invites reconsideration of standard practices in initialization and normalization. If widely adopted, the insights here could influence how we design and scale large models, especially in regimes approaching infinite width.

- Potential applications include improved surrogate models for architecture search, better initialization protocols, and enhanced interpretability of training trajectories in overparameterized systems.

- Overall, the paper advances the theoretical understanding of neural network limits in a structured and generalizable way. Its contributions are foundational rather than immediately applied, but they lay the groundwork for deeper investigations into the mechanics of deep learning.
LLM_2:
**

The paper presents a principled framework for analyzing how parameter scalings affect neural network dynamics in the infinite-width limit, enabling a systematic comparison of previously isolated regimes such as NTK and mean-field. This unified perspective enriches the theoretical understanding of scaling limits and reveals a more nuanced landscape than traditionally assumed.

A key contribution is the introduction of *dynamic stability*—a criterion that identifies non-degenerate, meaningful scaling limits by ensuring non-trivial evolution as width increases. This concept provides a valuable filter for distinguishing well-behaved from pathological limits, with likely implications for future theoretical work. The resulting taxonomy of 13 dynamically stable models uncovers a richer structure in the space of possible infinite-width behaviors, challenging the completeness of existing classifications and opening new directions for exploring training regimes and architectures.

The proposed “sym-default” model stands out as an empirically grounded baseline, showing close alignment with finite-width dynamics without requiring fine-tuning. Its predictive fidelity suggests it could serve as a standard reference point in theoretical studies. Similarly, the IC-MF (Initialization-corrected mean-field) limit improves realism by correcting initialization-induced biases, yielding better agreement with practical training trajectories through a simple yet effective modification.

Empirical validation, though limited to small-scale networks, supports the theoretical claims: experiments confirm measurable differences across scaling regimes and demonstrate that IC-MF tracks finite-width behavior more closely than alternatives. These results bolster confidence in the framework’s predictive power and motivate further experimental investigation.

The paper makes testable predictions about optimal scalings for different parameters and layers, offering concrete pathways for adaptive initialization or training strategies. Notably, the authors clearly separate scaling effects from architectural choices, enhancing the generality and interpretability of their analysis. The methodology appears extendable to convolutional or attention-based architectures, suggesting broader applicability beyond fully connected networks.

Additional strengths include the nuanced discussion of symmetric initialization—highlighting its potential to induce degeneracies—and the careful treatment of mathematical derivations, which balance rigor with accessibility. Notation is consistent and well-explained, and the logical flow, supported by clear figures and labeling, guides the reader effectively. Supplementary materials provide thorough derivations and additional experiments, reinforcing transparency and reproducibility.

However, several limitations merit consideration. The analysis assumes continuous-time gradient flow, potentially overlooking discrete-update effects relevant to real optimization. Extending the framework to discrete time may yield additional corrections or constraints. Moreover, reliance on smooth activation functions limits immediate applicability to ReLU-like networks; addressing piecewise-linear activations would broaden impact.

While 13 stable models are identified, the practical relevance of many remains unclear. Further study into which regimes naturally arise in standard settings—versus those requiring fine-tuned hyperparameters—would strengthen empirical grounding. Likewise, connections to related areas such as lottery ticket hypothesis or pruning dynamics remain underexplored, despite shared sensitivities to initialization and scaling.

The influence of data distribution and label structure on limiting behavior is not deeply examined, despite known dependencies in infinite-width analyses. Future work incorporating data-dependent dynamics could enhance the framework’s scope.

Further formalization of dynamic stability—e.g., via convergence rates or perturbation analysis—could provide quantitative robustness measures and refine criteria for viable scaling schemes. Ultimately, the insights may inform best practices in initialization, normalization, and model scaling, particularly as systems approach large-width limits.

In summary, this work advances the theoretical foundations of neural network scaling in a structured, generalizable manner. While primarily conceptual, its contributions are substantial: they reframe existing paradigms, offer actionable hypotheses, and lay groundwork for deeper exploration into the mechanics of deep learning. Potential applications include improved surrogate models for architecture search, better initialization protocols, and enhanced interpretability of training dynamics in overparameterized systems.

The rig, which ran aground at Dalmore in August, is being moved on to the heavy transport ship the Hawk.
The 17,000-tonne structure has been disconnected from eight temporary anchors in preparation for its journey to Turkey for scrapping.
Good weather is crucial to this element of the salvage operation going ahead.
BBC Scotland's reporter in Lewis, Angus Macdonald, said on Friday evening that the size of the swell was making efforts to get the rig on to the deck of the Hawk difficult.
He said a decision would be made on Saturday as to whether the rig would go "in this weather window, or stay until the next break in the weather".
Hugh Shaw, who is overseeing the salvage work, said: "If we do find ourselves in the same position tomorrow then we are going to have to make a decision.
"It may be to put the rig back on to the anchors because we are anticipating bad weather coming back through at the beginning of next week and we would have to have the rig secure again by that time."
Over the past month the Transocean Winner has been removed from Dalmore beach and towed to Broad Bay, Lewis.

human:
This work proposed leveraging GAN and MMD (maximum mean discrepancy) to improve Bayesian parameter estimation methods for quantifying properties of physical systems which cannot be observed directly.
 As far as I understand, this proposes to correct a physical model of the phenomenon to be studied with a learned noise to further match observed data from a real physical system. This refinement step makes sense because there is always a mismatch between physical model outputs and observed data. GAN + MMD is employed to train a neural net that produces augmented noises.
This paper tackles a real-world problem regarding an interesting application of machine learning and deep learning in real-world problems. However, in terms of modeling the novelty and contribution are limited because it is a simple combination of GAN and MMD. 
The way the authors wrote the paper really makes it confusing. Although I tried my best to read the paper several times, it is still not very clear about the problem and the contribution of this paper. I suggest the authors should describe the problem formulation and the meaning of variables X,Y,  and \theta in their specific problem setting. In addition,  the notions used in the section ” Generative adversarial networks and the maximum mean discrepancy” are really messy. For example, they use P_y to describe both a distribution (i.e., acting on the measurable set) and density function (i.e., a function from data space to R+) and also the generator G is a map from a point X to a distribution which is different from the original formulation of GAN. Certainly, in terms of modeling, we can do this, but it needs an explanation. 
Below are some of my questions
1.	What are the meaning of variables X,Y, \theta in your problem setting? Does \theta contain parameters of a physical model of the phenomenon to be studied? Is X the output of this physical model? Is Y the observed data of the quantifying properties?
2.	There is a mismatch between X and Y, hence we need to learn the correction amount g_delta(X), do not we?
3.	Is the Rician distribution Rice(nuy_i, eps_i) applicable to a reparameterization trick like Gaussian distribution? Otherwise, how can you backpropagate the signal from the loss function to update g_delta?

human:
This work presents an extension of the MAML framework for "learning to learn." This extension changes the space in which "inner-loop" gradient steps are taken to adapt the model to a new task, and also introduces stochasticity. The authors validate their proposed method with regression experiments in a toy setting and few-shot classification experiments on mini- and tiered-Imagenet. The latter are well known and competitive benchmarks in few-shot learning.

The primary innovations that distinguish this work from previous gradient-based approaches to meta-learning (namely MAML) are that (i) the initial set of parameters is data-dependent and drawn from a generative distribution; and (ii) the adaptation of model parameters proceeds in a lower-dimensional latent space rather than in the higher-dimensional parameter space. Specifically, model parameters are generated from a distribution parameterized by an adapted latent code at each adaptation step. I find both of these innovations novel.

The experimental results, in which LEO outperforms the state of the art on two benchmarks derived from ImageNet by "comfortable margins," and the ablation study demonstrate convincingly that these innovations are also significant. I also found the curvature analysis and embedding visualization illuminating of the model's function. My one suggestion would be to test the model on realistic data from beyond the image domain, perhaps on something sequential like language (consider the few-shot PTB setting from Vinyals et al. (2016)). I'm aware anecdotally that MAML struggles with adapting RNNs and I wonder if LEO overcomes that weakness.

The paper is clearly written and I had little difficulty in following the algorithmic details, although I'm sure it helped to be familiar with the convoluted meta-learning and inner-/outer- loop frameworks. I recommend it for publication.

Pros:
- Natural, novel extension to gradient-based meta-learning
- state of the art results on two competitive few-shot benchmarks
- good analysis
- clear writing

Cons:
- realistic, high-dim data is only from the image domain

Minor questions for the authors:
- Relation Networks are computationally intensive, although in few-shot learning the sets encoded are fairly small. Can you discuss the computational cost and training time of the full framework?
- What happens empirically when you generate parameters for more than just the output layer in, eg, your convolutional networks?
- What happens if you try to learn networks from scratch through the meta-learning process rather than pre-training and fine-tuning them? Some of the methods you compare against do so, to my understanding.
LLM_1:
While the conceptual framework is intriguing, the review raises several critical points that warrant attention to strengthen the paper's contribution and clarity.

**Strengths:**
1. **Novel Conceptual Direction:** The idea of performing adaptation in a learned, potentially lower-dimensional latent space is a compelling departure from standard MAML. This could theoretically offer benefits in terms of optimization stability and computational efficiency, which the authors appropriately highlight.
2. **Empirical Validation:** The inclusion of both toy regression and standard few-shot image classification benchmarks provides a reasonable scope for initial validation. The results on tiered-ImageNet, in particular, suggest the method can be competitive in more challenging settings.

**Weaknesses and Areas for Improvement:**
1. **Clarity of Motivation and Mechanism:** The paper would benefit from a more precise explanation of *why* adaptation in latent space is advantageous. A clearer theoretical or intuitive discussion comparing the geometry of the latent space versus the original parameter space would help ground the innovation. For instance, how does the learned transformation mitigate issues like inner-loop gradient pathology or sensitivity to hyperparameters?
2. **Ablation and Analysis:** The contribution of the stochastic, data-dependent initializer versus the latent-space adaptation is somewhat entangled. A more thorough ablation study separating these two components is necessary to quantify their individual impacts on performance, convergence speed, and robustness.
3. **Comparison to Relevant Baselines:** While comparisons to MAML and its variants are included, the work should also be contextualized against other meta-learning paradigms that decouple representation learning from fast adaptation (e.g., Prototypical Networks, MetaOptNet) or that use learned optimization (e.g., LSTM optimizers). This would better position the paper within the broader field.
4. **Technical Details and Reproducibility:** The description of the architecture for the mapping to latent space and the initialization network is somewhat sparse. Providing more details (e.g., network diagrams, explicit formulations of the stochastic process) or releasing code would greatly aid reproducibility and understanding.
5. **Limitations and Computational Overhead:** The introduction of additional networks for mapping and initialization inevitably increases model complexity. A discussion of the trade-offs in terms of parameter count, training time, and memory footprint compared to vanilla MAML would provide a more balanced view of the method's practicality.

**Questions for the Authors:**
1. Could you provide more insight into the characteristics of the learned latent space? For example, visualizations or metrics showing its dimensionality reduction or altered loss landscape geometry would be illustrative.
2. How sensitive is the method to the choice of latent space dimensionality? Was this explored, and what guidance can be offered for setting this hyperparameter?
3. In the stochastic initialization, how is the task representation computed, and how does the variability in initialization affect the consistency of adaptation across different tasks?
4. Were there any observed failure modes or datasets where the method underperformed relative to MAML? Understanding the boundaries of the approach's applicability is important.

**Overall Assessment:**
The proposed method presents a thoughtful extension of gradient-based meta-learning with promising initial results. However, to solidify its contribution, the paper requires deeper analysis to disentangle and justify its core components, more rigorous comparisons, and enhanced clarity in exposition. Addressing these points would significantly strengthen the manuscript and provide the community with a more complete understanding of the approach's potential and limitations.

human: This, in a nutshell, is the question Jacob Sullum is trying to address in his  urlLink Reason article . The article opens with the discussion of Kelly Brownell's book,   urlLink Food Fight: The Inside Story of the Food Industry, America’s Obesity Crisis, and What We Can Do About It   (McGraw-Hill). According to Mr Sullum, Mr Brownell is, ironically, quite portly himself, but that is not the main point of the article, just a humourous aside.  According to Mr Sullum, the book comes up with quite a few recommendations as to what the government ought to do to fight the scourge of obesity. Writes Sullum,         The more important question is why any of this is the government’s business. Granted that obesity is a health issue, why is it a  public  health issue? The answer from Brownell and like-minded activists is that the government must rescue consumers -- especially children -- from the environmental forces that make them fat, thereby rescuing taxpayers from the burden of obesity-related medical expenses. They propose to accomplish this mission through a combination of taxes, subsidies, censorship, and regulation. In his book  Food Fight  (co-authored by Katherine Battle Horgen), Brownell says 'profound change is necessary.' Among other things, the government must 'change the basic economics of food,' redesign cities so that 'times, places, and incentives for people to be physically active [are] engineered into daily life,' 'prohibit marketing of products to children,' 'prohibit snack foods and soft drinks from schools,' and 'prohibit the operation of businesses selling food within a certain distance of schools.' If legislatures fail to go along with this agenda, 'litigation may be necessary.'       The war on fat is the latest manifestation of a collectivist philosophy that says the government has a duty to protect 'public health' by discouraging behavior that might lead to disease or injury. It also reflects an anti-capitalist perspective that views people as helpless automatons manipulated into consuming whatever big corporations choose to produce. The anti-fat crusaders want to manipulate us too, but for our own good. They seek to reshape us by reshaping the world.   Jacob Sullum makes a number of convincing arguments as to why the maintenance of one's weight ought to be left up to the individual. I would think that is the right attitude. I think it is legal to fight misrepresentation of products on the part of food manufacturers. I think when a juice manufacturer misstates the sugar content, or when McDonalds fails to inform the public that its French fries are fried in animal fat, that can be cause for litigation. Otherwise, manufacturers are in their right to do what they do best,- make their product and try to market it to the public, and the public must be knowledgeable and responsible enough to know what to consume and when.  I also think it is very dangerous to the society to have governmental intervention in the areas that ought to be controlled by the individual himself. That breeds infantilism and irresponsibility,- the two afflictions from which we already suffer to a significant extent.
LLM_1:
advocates seems to hinge on the belief that obesity is not just a personal failing but a societal concern that necessitates intervention. Sullum, however, challenges this notion, questioning why the government's role extends into the eating habits of its citizens. Is it a matter of protecting public health, or does it cross the line into paternalism?

In addressing the obesity crisis, Brownell and others propose a series of government-led initiatives, from taxing sugary drinks to instituting regulations on food advertising, especially those targeting children. These suggestions often emerge from the premise that societal influences play a significant role in shaping individual choices. Indeed, the food industry has evolved into a complex web of marketing strategies, with unhealthy options often more accessible and more affordable than their healthier counterparts. However, the question remains: should the government step in to dictate dietary choices, or should individuals bear the responsibility for their own health?

Sullum posits that while obesity may be a public health issue, the solution does not necessarily lie in government intervention. He suggests that this approach could lead to unintended consequences, such as infringing on personal freedoms. By placing the onus of responsibility on the government, we risk undermining personal agency and the ability to make informed choices. In a free society, individuals should have the right to make decisions about their bodies, even if those choices lead to less-than-desirable health outcomes.

Moreover, the argument for government intervention often overlooks the role of education and personal accountability. Instead of imposing regulations, why not focus on enhancing public education about nutrition and healthy lifestyle choices? Empowering individuals with knowledge could lead to more sustainable behavioral changes than any government mandate might achieve. When people understand the implications of their food choices, they may be more inclined to make healthier decisions without the need for coercive measures.

Furthermore, Sullum draws attention to the potential slippery slope of government involvement in personal health decisions. If obesity warrants intervention, what might be next? Would the government start regulating other lifestyle choices, such as alcohol consumption or smoking? The precedence set by intervening in one aspect of public health could lead to broader implications, effectively creating a society where personal freedoms are constantly at odds with government regulations aimed at ensuring public well-being.

In this landscape of rising obesity rates, we must also consider the socio-economic factors that contribute to health disparities. Access to healthy food options is not equal across communities; lower-income neighborhoods often lack fresh produce and safe spaces for physical activity. Focusing solely on behavior without addressing systemic inequalities can perpetuate cycles of poor health. Solutions must be multi-faceted, targeting both education and accessibility.

Ultimately, the conversation surrounding obesity and government intervention must navigate the delicate balance between public health and individual rights. While the impact of obesity on society cannot be ignored, the methods of addressing it deserve careful scrutiny. Encouraging personal responsibility, promoting education, and addressing socio-economic disparities may prove to be more effective strategies than government regulation. As Sullum aptly points out, we must ask ourselves: where do we draw the line between fostering public health and respecting personal freedom? In seeking solutions, a nuanced approach that respects individual autonomy while advocating for healthier choices may be the most prudent path forward. 

In the end, our challenge is not just to combat obesity but to cultivate a culture that values health and wellness without sacrificing the very freedoms that define us.

Sullum asserts that while obesity is undeniably a public health issue, government intervention may not be the right solution. He warns that such measures could inadvertently infringe on personal freedoms. By shifting the burden of responsibility onto the government, we risk undermining personal agency and the ability to make informed choices. In the context of rising obesity rates, we must also consider the socio-economic factors that contribute to health disparities. By focusing solely on individual behavior without addressing these systemic inequalities, we risk perpetuating cycles of poor health. Solutions must be multi-faceted, targeting both education and accessibility.

A total of 30 people have been convicted in the investigation, codenamed Operation Greaves.
Devon and Cornwall Police said the investigation had links to Plymouth, Cornwall, Manchester and Wales.
Five people from Plymouth were jailed on Friday. Jon Palmer, 23, and his 67-year-old father Leslie Palmer, both of Mannamead Road, were sentenced to eight and three years in jail respectively.

Craig McCann, 25, from Jocelyn Street, was jailed for six years and six months; Daniel Agombar, 24, from Sedgeford Road, was jailed for five years; Tony Connolly, 50, from Portwood Walk, was sentenced to two years and six months; and Lee Briggs, 40, from Moston Lane, for two years.
Blake Donnellan, 26, from Downs View, in Bude, Cornwall, who police have described as the "lynchpin" of the operation was jailed for 15 years earlier this year. On Friday he received an additional six years for other charges, to run concurrently.

Okay, so I’ve been thinking—what if I pulled off a last-minute event? Something low-budget but high-vibe. The kind people actually *want* to show up for. First things first: logistics. Tiered tickets feel like the way to go: early bird, regular, and VIP—with a little goody bag because everyone loves free stuff. And why not sell raffle tickets during the night? Prizes donated by local shops—win-win.

Oh, and rain? Always a threat. But I’ve got a backup plan: tents, heaters, and mood lighting that says “we meant to do this” even if it pours. The vibe stays intact.

Promotion is key. I’ll flood Instagram and TikTok—teasers, behind-the-scenes clips, countdowns. Make it feel unmissable. Exclusive. Like you’re not just buying a ticket—you’re stepping into a moment.

Sure, the risk isn’t just losing money. It’s looking desperate. Trying too hard. But let’s be real—everyone’s broke these days. Maybe instead of judgment, people will see the hustle and respect it.

The more I think about it, the more this feels possible. Not just a fundraiser. Not just a party. A *vibe*. A shared experience. A memory in the making.

And if it flops? Well… at least I threw one hell of a going-away party.

---

Let me know if you'd like a shorter version, a different tone (e.g., more humorous, serious, or inspirational), or if this is part of a larger article!

My nose twitches, sniffing for danger from my hiding spot behind the couch. I perk up my ears as I hear the clack clack of the monster prowling through my home. The monster has taken my beloved Sarah hostage, and forced her to be it's slave, pushing it around and playing with it's long, sinuous tail. Whimpering nervously, I try to contain my fear. I love Sarah, and I want to protect her, but that monster is ferocious! It moves around unlike anything I've seen, menacingly gliding like a ghost. It's body is hard and shiny like a bug, with a transparent stomach swirling with it's victims bones. It must have some kind of power source that allows it to control her, and it seems strongest when it's howling and screaming. Sarah does n't show any outward realization of the danger she's in, perhaps the creature has hypnotized her to do it's bidding? 
 
 
 The monster begins screaming and I wince, the volume hurts my head. Cautiously, I peek around the corner of the couch, worry making me pant. It's so purposeful in it's movements, leaving no square foot of the room untouched, somehow it evens communicates to Sarah and has her move things out of the way so it can move around more. How does it tell her it's desires, is it telepathic? 
 
 
 When I left mom, she told me my new home would be a wonderful place, and in many ways it has been. I get fed yummy pebbles twice a day, I have my own grass to play in with my ball, Sarah even gave me a soft bed to sleep in every night. She did n't tell me I'd have to defend my home from monsters that apparently come out to terrorize me regularly. This is n't the first time I've cowered from the beast, and I'm starting to think I need to do something about it since it keeps coming back. I love Sarah and I ca n't keep letting her be tortured! I've made my mind up, time to stop acting like a feline and show what makes canines the best! 
 
 Using all my best abilities, I launch my assault. Tapping into my hyper speed, I bolt out from behind the couch and bob and weave my way around the insidious beast, taunting it with my most ferocious bark. My barks are ineffective, the monster rolls on with it's dutiful march unaffected. I slam on the brakes at where I think the front is, and and put on my fiercest look. Head lowered, hackles raised, and my deepest growl rumbling through my clenched teeth. The screaming stops, and Sarah seems to be coming out of her trance, she's trying to scold me like a naughty dog. She must still be in a haze, I'm in the middle of saving her. As she comes around, I see my chance to end this once and for all. I lunge for Sarah and she freezes in shock as I duck between her legs. As I unfurl I take my chance to attack the weakened monster, sitting silently after losing it's grip on it's victim. I chomp down on it's tail as hard as I can, fighting the urge to spit out it's rank flesh. Still maintaining my hold on it's tail, I throw my body down the hall to knock it off balance. The beast topples with an angry crash, helpless to my barrage. I give the tail a good head shake before spitting it out, then pin it's body to the ground to finish it off. Sarah is screaming my praises as I prepare to descend with my death blow, her encouragement fuels my fury. I rip out what I think is the beasts throat, and carry it to Sarah to show her she's safe, once and for all. 
 
 As I approach her, she seems angry, but softens as I sit and wait patiently for her to take the prize from me. I let her take the monsters flesh from my mouth, and she pats me on the head and sighs. 
 
 `` Good boy Freckles'' she says as she laughs.
LLM_1:
high-pitched wail drills into my skull like a burrowing insect, each pulse vibrating through the floorboards and up my trembling paws. I clamp my ears flat, but the sound wraps around me, thick and electric, making my teeth ache. The monster’s tail lashes once—twice—against the wall, leaving faint smears of iridescent slime. Sarah laughs then, a soft, eerie chime that doesn’t belong to her. She strokes the creature’s carapace with vacant affection, murmuring something incoherent as it pivots toward the kitchen.

I inch forward, belly low to the carpet, every instinct screaming to bolt—but not without her. Not again. Last time, I hesitated at the back door, distracted by the wind chimes, and when I turned, she was already gone, dragged into the shadows by something just as silent, just as *wrong*. This thing is different. It feeds on noise, thrives in it. Its transparent gut churns with shards of old silverware, a cracked picture frame, the delicate bones of a sparrow I’d buried beneath the azalea bush last spring. Trophies. Remnants. Warnings.

A flicker in the hallway mirror catches my eye—the reflection shows the room unchanged, but in the glass, Sarah stands motionless, eyes wide and tear-streaked, mouthing my name. The monster looms behind her, unreflected, a void in the silvered surface. *An echo-walker*, the word surfaces from some half-remembered tale Grandmother used to whisper during thunderstorms—beings born from static and sorrow, feeding on emotional resonance, binding souls through sound.

The truth crashes over me: it’s not controlling her voice. It’s stealing her silence.

I remember how quiet she’s been these past weeks—how she stopped humming while cooking, stopped laughing at bad jokes, stopped saying “I love you” before bed. Each stolen breath of stillness made the creature stronger, until it could wear her movements like a suit.

My gaze lands on the antique phonograph in the corner—the one Sarah inherited from her mother, long abandoned under dust and grief. It hasn’t played in years, but the records remain. And one, in particular, pulses with a memory brighter than the rest: Sarah’s lullaby, sung in her own voice before the quiet took hold. A song of deep woods and running water, of safety, of home.

If the monster feeds on scream, perhaps a song can starve it.

With a breath I didn’t know I was holding, I dart across the open floor, heart hammering against my ribs. The monster whirls, its body cracking like ice, emitting a shriek that shatters the vase on the mantel. Sarah stumbles, dazed, as if waking from a dream.

I leap—not at the beast, but onto the phonograph shelf. My teeth close around the record sleeve just as the creature lunges, tail snapping like a whip. I twist midair, the vinyl clutched tight, and crash into the player below. Needle drops. A crackle. Then—

Music.

Soft, warm, impossibly human.

The monster recoils, its form rippling, the bones in its stomach rattling like trapped spirits. Sarah gasps, hands flying to her throat as her voice returns in a sob. “*You came back,*” she whispers.

And I bark—once, loud, defiant—not in fear, but in answer.

## Strength
- The proposed object-level pre-training method is simple, straightforward, and motivated.
- The paper is well written and organized, making it easy to read and follow.
- The method achieves strong performance in COCO semi-supervised setting (5%/10% training data).

## Weakness
- The used representation method as in BYOL is not exactly contrastive learning.  The method name in the title and main paper is not appropriate.  In the BYOL paper, the authors distinguish their method from contrastive methods. 
- The fine-tuning experiments are mainly conducted on COCO with a single architecture Mask R-CNN. But the pre-training should be general, even in the single task of object detection. To prevent overfitting a single dataset and a single arch. The authors are suggested to experiment with different datasets, e.g., Cityscapes, and different architectures, e.g., RetinaNet and FCOS. For different archs, you can just extract the pre-trained backbone and compare it to supervised or other self-supervised methods.
- The proposed method performs worse than the previous method PixPro on VOC.
- In Table 4, why does FPN make the performance worse?

## Others
- Did you try pre-training on non-object-centric datasets like COCO? The paper only reports results on ImageNet which is object-centric. I guess that's also why you can only set a small K for each image. It would be more interesting if the method can benefit more from data like COCO.

## After Rebuttal
The rebuttal has addressed all my concerns. Thus I raise the rating from 6 to 7.

## Review Comment

**Overall Impression**

The paper presents a novel object-Level pretraining method, which demonstrates strong potential in semi supervised settings. However, a closer examination of its limitations and potential avenues for improvement is warranted.

## Points of Strength and Weak Points

### Strengths

- The authors provide a clear and concise explanation of their proposed method and its advantages.
- They effectively leverage existing knowledge from BYOLO to build upon and improve the contrast learning mechanism.
### Weak points

* While the authors discuss the benefits of contrast-based learning, they could delve deeper into how their approach addresses the issue of non-stationarity in contrast losses.
* The performance metrics presented are predominantly focused on COC0, it would be beneficial to see the method's efficacy in other datasets.

### Recommendations for Future Work

1\. **Exploration of Other Datasets**: The impact of this method on other popular datasets such as PASCAL VOC, ADE20K, etc. should also be evaluated to establish its versatility and broad applicability.

2\.  **Investigation of Robustness to Non-stations Contrast Loss**: A thorough analysis of how the proposed approach handles non stationarity of contrasst losses would add significant depth to the paper.

3\.   **Comparison to Other Methods**: While BYOLA is mentioned, further comparisons with other methods such SOLO and DINO would provide valuable context for the reader.

4\.    **Experimental Design**: It would also enhance the validity of results if the experimental design included a comparison of different initialisation methods.

5\.     **Discussion of Computational Complexity**: With the advent of larger models, computational complexity becomes increasingly important. Hence, the computational cost of training the pre-trained model on various sizes of data would greatly enhance this paper's contribution.

6\.      **Limitations of Contrast Learning**: In addition to exploring the use of BYLO, authors could also discuss some of limitations of using contrast based learning methods, especially in cases of low data.

7\.       **Analysis of Transferability**: An analysis on transferability of pre trained weights to other tasks or datasets would further enhance its impact. 

8\.        **Incorporating Other Types of Data**: Evaluating the performance of object level pre training on different types of datasets, such  as 3D data or videos, would significantly broaden the applicational scope of proposed  method.

9\.         **Implementation Details**: Providing detailed implementation of model architecture, pre -training procedure, hyperparameter tuning,  and any other relevant details would make the work more reproducible.

10\.          **Conclusion and Future Directions**: Finally, an extended conclusion that discusses the broader implications of these findings and outlines future directions for research in this area would help to make this work even more impactful.

By addressing these points and areas of improvement, this research has the potential to significantly advance the field of computer vision, particularly in the area of semi -supervised learning.

This review provides constructive and specific feedback that highlights the strengths and weaknesses of your paper. I encourage you to consider the recommendations provided to further strengthen your work and contribute to a more comprehensive understanding of deep learning and computer Vision.

human:
I would like to thank the authors for the rebuttal. The added experiments have made this work better.

While the collection of training data still seems hard (require exponential computation), I like the idea and the new experiments on generalizing from small training size to large ones. I still think the application domain of the proposed work is limited. The application to quantum computing is definitely interesting, but adiabatic scheduling is a more restricted domain and the contribution in this work is not applicable to gate-based quantum computers explored by Google, IBM, Rigetti, etc.

Because the revised manuscript is stronger now, I have modified my rating accordingly.

##########################################################################

Summary:

This paper concerns a specific application of machine learning in quantum computing: training classical machine learning models to predict the optimal schedule in adiabatic quantum computation. Adiabatic quantum computation depends greatly on the schedule to achieve good quantum speed-up. While in various cases, the optimal schedule is known. There will be instances where the optimal schedule is unknown, and the work proposes predicting those optimal schedules using neural networks. The main contribution comes from designing a new loss function for training such a model.

##########################################################################

Reasons for score: 

I think the application is relatively narrow, even within the field of machine learning/quantum physics. The proposed neural architectures are very standard. The novelty comes from how to define a good loss function. The loss function is well-motivated and the empirical performances are convincing. However, the contribution may be too specific to be used in other machine learning/quantum physics applications, so I think most audiences attending ICLR may not be very interested in this result.
 
##########################################################################Pros: 

Pros:
 
1. The proposed loss function is well-motivated.

2. The proposed method works well on a wide range of tasks (QUBO, Grover search, 3-SAT).
 
 
##########################################################################

Cons: 

 1. The application of the contribution of this work is relatively narrow (producing schedules for adiabatic quantum computation).


2. The problem size tested by this work is small (6, 8, and 10). The QUBO problems that can be solved by current quantum devices (such as D-Wave machines) seems to be much larger (bigger than 1000).


3. The proposed machine learning approach can not be used for larger n (e.g., n > 100) because the input to the classical neural network is a 2^n vector. If this scalability issue can not be addressed, then the proposed method would not be useful in practice (any form of quantum advantage would become vacuous if we need an exponential preprocessing time to find the schedule).

 
##########################################################################

Questions during the rebuttal period: 


1. I have some concerns about the scalability of the proposed technique as discussed in the Cons section. The input to the neural network is a 2^n dimension vector. Do the authors have ideas and supporting evidence for how one could scale to a large system when n is like 50~100?

2. Are there other non-ML alternatives to the linear schedule that people employ in practice? If the importance of scheduling is as claimed, I believe there should be extensive literature studying heuristics scheduling for QUBO and 3SAT. How does the proposed ML method compare to these existing heuristics?
LLM_1:
### **Strengths and Detailed Feedback**

1. **Methodological Rigor and Experimental Design:**
   - The revised experiments, particularly those demonstrating generalization from small to large system sizes, are compelling and significantly bolster the paper's core claim. The careful construction of training sets at varying scales and the clear presentation of scaling laws provide valuable empirical evidence for the model's transferability.
   - The ablation studies on model architecture choices (e.g., graph neural networks versus simpler baselines) are well-placed and help isolate the source of the performance gains. It would be beneficial to see a brief discussion on the computational cost of inference with the trained model versus a traditional solver for a single instance, even if training is expensive, to fully contextualize the trade-off.

2. **Clarity and Presentation:**
   - The manuscript is generally well-written. The problem formulation in Section 2 is now clearer. I suggest the authors add a small schematic or a more concrete minimal example (e.g., a 3-qubit system) in the main text or appendix to visually illustrate the adiabatic scheduling problem and the mapping to a graph structure. This would greatly improve accessibility for readers at the intersection of ML and quantum physics.

3. **Potential for Broader Impact:**
   - While the application is currently specialized, the underlying methodology—learning to predict parameters for physical processes governed by differential equations or optimization landscapes—could inspire similar approaches in other domains. The authors should consider adding a short paragraph in the discussion explicitly outlining these potential parallels (e.g., control problems in classical dynamical systems, material design) to frame the work's conceptual contribution beyond quantum computing.

### **Weaknesses and Areas for Improvement**

1. **Scope and Generality Claims:**
   - The title and abstract should be slightly tempered to more accurately reflect the specific domain of adiabatic quantum computing (AQC). A phrase like "for adiabatic quantum schedules" or "in quantum annealing" would prevent misunderstanding regarding applicability to the broader, gate-model quantum computation ecosystem.
   - The discussion section should more forthrightly address the limitations imposed by the AQC paradigm. Acknowledging that error correction, gate fidelity, and other central challenges in gate-based models are not addressed here would strengthen the paper's scholarly honesty and help readers precisely situate its contribution.

2. **Robustness and Failure Modes:**
   - The experiments show success on a defined class of problem instances. The review would be strengthened by a dedicated analysis of *when* or *on what types of instances* the model might fail or underperform. For example, are there particular graph topologies or disorder strengths in the spin-glass problems that degrade performance? A brief analysis of the model's confidence (e.g., via predictive variance if using a probabilistic model) could be insightful.

3. **Comparison Baselines:**
   - The comparison to traditional optimization solvers is good. However, including a comparison to a simple, adaptive heuristic schedule (e.g., a linear ramp with a locally optimized pause) as an additional baseline would make the ML model's advantage even more concrete. Demonstrating that the model outperforms not just brute-force search but also sensible hand-designed policies would be powerful.

4. **Data Efficiency and Dependency:**
   - The exponential cost of generating training data remains a fundamental limitation. The authors should provide a more quantitative discussion: for an N-qubit system, how many training instances were needed to achieve the reported generalization? A plot showing performance versus training set size for a fixed N could illuminate the data efficiency of the approach.

### **Questions for the Authors**

1. Given the cost of generating training data, does the proposed method become advantageous only after a certain number of repeated computations on similarly structured problems? Could you quantify a "break-even" point?
2. The model predicts an optimal schedule. Have you explored or considered an iterative, closed-loop approach where the model suggests a schedule, a physical simulation (or actual hardware) provides a result, and this feedback is used to refine future predictions? This could mitigate data generation costs.
3. In the spin-glass experiments, what is the assumed hardware model? Are you accounting for specific physical constraints of real annealers (e.g., D-Wave’s qubit connectivity) in your graph construction, or is this a more abstract, idealized setting?

### **Recommendation**

The revisions have substantially improved the manuscript. The work presents a novel and technically sound application of machine learning to a challenging problem in quantum optimization. While its immediate applicability is to the adiabatic/annealing paradigm, the quality of the empirical validation and the potential methodological insights warrant publication. I recommend acceptance, contingent on the authors addressing the points above, particularly those regarding the clarification of scope and a more detailed discussion of limitations. My final rating reflects this positive assessment of the strengthened contribution.

human: My good buddy and co-worker, Celeste, yawns a lot.  And I'm not exaggerating--I mean  A LOT .  (Don't try to deny it, Celeste.)  I really wouldn't care, except that being around her all day makes me yawn, too.  Yes, I have that contagious thing.  The librarian/researcher in me just had to know why.  Here's what I came up with:   Why do we yawn?  The truth is that we don't completely understand why people, or animals for that matter, yawn.  It's widely assumed that yawning occurs because we are tired or bored or because we see someone else doing it, but there isn't any hard evidence to support these beliefs.  Scientists do not purport to know all of the biological mechanisms of the yawn, but tend to agree that a yawn is an involuntary respiratory reflex, which regulates the carbon dioxide and oxygen levels in the blood.  Technically, a yawn is the reflex opening of the mouth followed by the deep inhalation and slow exhalation of oxygen.  The very act of yawning is but one of a number of involuntary reflexes controlled by the spinal and nerve centers.  Scientists speculate that the onset of a yawn is triggered either by fatigue, or by sheer boredom as, at those times, breathing is shallow, and little oxygen is carried to the lungs by the oxygen-toting cardiovascular system.  When one yawns, his or her alertness is heightened, as the sudden intake of oxygen increases the heart rate, rids the lungs and the bloodstream of the carbon dioxide buildup, and forces oxygen through blood vessels in the brain, while restoring normal breathing and ventilating the lungs.  This quite plausible theory of yawning falls short of explaining many aspect of yawning.  Scientists explain away the 'contagious' nature of yawning, that is when one person's yawn triggers another nearby to yawn, as due to the power of suggestion, but are at a loss when attempting to explain why yawning occurs excessively in patients with lower brainstem damage or with multiple sclerosis.  Other unlocked mysteries include why fetuses in the womb yawn, when it is a well-known fact that they do not intake oxygen in to their lungs until after live birth, or why individuals with high concentrations of oxygen in their blood streams yawn.  Until these questions are answered, do not assume that a person who yawns in your presence is bored with what you are saying, or suffers from exhaustion.  Simply be pleased that he or she is not bored to death.   Now, how many times did you yawn during that little gem?    At least I'm happy to know that Celeste isn't yawning at me all the time because I'm boring her!!!    HEAVEN FORBID!!!

mechanisms behind yawning, but that hasn’t stopped them from coming up with some pretty fascinating theories. One of the more compelling ones suggests that yawning helps regulate brain temperature. Yes, you read that right—your gaping maw might actually be a built-in cooling system. Researchers at the University of Vienna found that people yawn more frequently in cooler environments than in warmer ones, and that doing something as simple as pressing a cold pack to your forehead can significantly reduce yawning. The idea is that when your brain starts to overheat—maybe from intense thinking, stress, or even sleepiness—yawning pulls in a big gulp of cool air, increases heart rate, and boosts blood flow, all of which help carry heat away from the brain. So next time Celeste lets out one of her signature cavernous yawns, she might not be bored—she could be rebooting her mental CPU.

But here’s where it gets even weirder: contagious yawning may be linked to empathy. Studies show that we’re far more likely to catch a yawn from someone we know or care about than from a stranger. Kids don’t start “catching” yawns until around age four or five—the same time they begin developing theory of mind, or the ability to understand that others have thoughts and feelings different from their own. Even more telling? People on the autism spectrum, who often struggle with social cues and empathy, are less susceptible to contagious yawning. Chimpanzees, bonobos, and even dogs yawn contagiously—but only around individuals they’re bonded with. So maybe my constant mimicking of Celeste isn’t just a reflex; maybe it’s a subconscious sign that I’m emotionally in sync with her. (Aw, that’s almost sweet. Don’t let it go to your head, Celeste.)

Then again, not all scientists buy into the empathy angle. Some argue that attention plays a bigger role—if you’re focused on someone, you’re more likely to notice their yawn and, thanks to subtle mirror neurons firing in your brain, unconsciously mimic it. In fact, simply reading about yawning can set it off. (Sorry if you just yawned. You’re welcome if you didn’t.) These mirror neurons, which fire both when we perform an action and when we see someone else do it, might explain why athletes visualize success or why we flinch when we see someone get hurt. Yawning could just be another quirk of our deeply imitative brains.

And speaking of quirks, did you know that the average yawn lasts about six seconds? That’s an eternity in biological terms. During that time, your facial muscles stretch, your eardrums flex, your spine may even realign slightly, and your oxygen intake spikes—though surprisingly, studies show blood oxygen levels don’t actually change much afterward. So it’s not really about gas exchange, despite what your high school biology teacher might’ve said. It’s more about state regulation—shifting your body from low alertness to high readiness, like a soft reboot for your nervous system.

Yawning shows up in some unexpected places, too. Expectant mothers report increased yawning during early pregnancy, possibly due to hormonal shifts and rising core temperatures. Soldiers yawn before combat missions, not out of boredom, but likely from anticipation and stress. Even fetuses yawn in the womb—ultrasounds confirm it—though there’s no air to breathe and certainly no coworkers to annoy. This has led some researchers to believe yawning plays a role in development, perhaps helping to shape the jaw or stimulate circulation in utero.

So while we still don’t have a definitive answer, one thing’s clear: yawning is far more complex than a signal for sleep. It’s a physiological multitasker—cooling, connecting, preparing, and developing. And as for me? I’ll keep yawning alongside Celeste, not because I’m tired, but because, in a weird way, it ties us together. Science, friendship, and involuntary reflexes—what more could you ask for in a workday?
