**The Science Behind Yawning: Why We Do It (And Why It’s Contagious)**

We’ve all been there—mid-conversation, someone yawns, and suddenly, like dominoes falling, we’re fighting back our own. Yawning is one of those universal human quirks that feels automatic, almost silly… but beneath its unassuming surface lies a surprisingly complex web of biology, emotion, and even social connection.

Despite how common it is, scientists still don’t have a single definitive answer for *why* we yawn. But that hasn’t stopped them from developing some fascinating theories—one of which might just reframe your next big yawn as an act of genius-level brain maintenance.

### Your Brain’s Built-In Cooling System?

Here’s a mind-bender: yawning might be your body’s way of keeping your brain from overheating. That’s right—your dramatic jaw stretch could double as a natural air conditioner. Research from the University of Vienna suggests that people yawn more often in cooler environments than warm ones. Even more telling? Pressing a cold pack to your forehead can cut down on yawns significantly.

The theory goes like this: when your brain temperature creeps up—thanks to mental strain, fatigue, or stress—a well-timed yawn pulls in a rush of cool air. This boosts heart rate, increases blood flow, and helps shuttle heat away from the brain. So the next time Celeste unleashes one of her legendary, jaw-cracking yawns, she’s not zoning out—she’s basically rebooting her neural operating system.

### The Empathy Effect: Why Yawns Are Contagious

Now, here’s where things get even more interesting: we don’t just yawn when we’re tired—we yawn when others do. And this contagious effect isn’t random. Studies show we’re much more likely to “catch” a yawn from someone we know or care about than from a stranger.

Children typically don’t start mirroring yawns until around age four or five—the same period when they begin to develop *theory of mind*, the ability to recognize that others have thoughts and feelings different from their own. Even more revealing? People on the autism spectrum, who often experience differences in social processing and empathy, are less likely to catch yawns. 

And it’s not just humans. Chimpanzees, bonobos, and even dogs exhibit contagious yawning—but only with individuals they’re emotionally bonded to. So if you find yourself mimicking your partner, pet, or best friend mid-yawn, it might not be habit. It could be a quiet, subconscious signal of emotional attunement. (Okay, fine—that’s kind of sweet. Don’t get used to me saying that, Celeste.)

Of course, not everyone buys the empathy argument. Some researchers believe attention—not emotion—is the real driver. If you're focused on someone, you're more likely to notice their yawn, and thanks to mirror neurons—brain cells that fire both when we act and when we observe others acting—you might unconsciously copy them. These same neurons are why athletes visualize victory or why we wince at someone else’s pain. In that sense, contagious yawning might just be another quirk of our deeply imitative brains.

(And yes—if reading this made you yawn, you can thank—or blame—those sneaky mirror neurons. You’re welcome either way.)

### Six Seconds of Biological Magic

Let’s talk timing: the average yawn lasts about six seconds. In biological terms, that’s practically an eternity. During those few moments, your face undergoes a full stretch routine—jaw drops, facial muscles engage, eardrums flex, and even your spine gets a subtle reset. Oxygen intake spikes dramatically… yet oddly, blood oxygen levels barely budge afterward.

So no, it’s not really about breathing in more oxygen, contrary to what many of us learned in high school biology. Instead, yawning appears to be about *state regulation*—shifting your nervous system from low alertness to high readiness. Think of it as a soft reboot, a physiological nudge that says, “Hey, time to wake up.”

### Yawning Across Life—and Before It

Yawning shows up in some unexpected moments. Pregnant women often report increased yawning in early pregnancy, possibly linked to hormonal shifts and rising core temperatures. Soldiers yawn before missions—not from boredom, but from the tension and anticipation of what’s ahead. 

And perhaps most intriguingly: fetuses yawn in the womb. Ultrasounds confirm it, even though there’s no air to inhale and zero coworkers to annoy. This has led some experts to believe yawning plays a developmental role—perhaps helping to shape facial muscles, stimulate circulation, or prepare the nervous system for life outside the uterus.

### More Than Just Tired Eyes

So while science hasn’t pinned down a single, ironclad reason for yawning, one thing is clear: it’s far more than a sign of sleepiness. It’s a multitasking marvel—cooling the brain, strengthening social bonds, priming the body for action, and even shaping development before birth.

As for me? I’ll keep catching Celeste’s yawns, not because I’m exhausted, but because, in its own strange, involuntary way, it reminds me how deeply connected we are—to each other, to our bodies, and to the quiet wonders of everyday biology.

Science, friendship, and a good yawn—really, what else do you need to power through the workday?

human: Activation of the extracellular signal-regulated kinase (ERK) in the striatum is crucial for long-term behavioral alterations induced by drugs of abuse. In response to cocaine, ERK phosphorylation (i.e., activation) is restricted to medium-sized spiny neurons expressing dopamine D1 receptor (D1R) and depends on a concomitant stimulation of D1R and glutamate N-methyl-D-aspartate receptor (NMDAR). However, the mechanisms responsible for this activation, especially the respective contribution of D1R and NMDAR, remain unknown.We studied striatal neurons in culture stimulated with D1R agonist and/or glutamate and wild-type or genetically modified mice treated with cocaine. Biochemical, immunohistochemical, and imaging studies were performed. Mice were also subjected to behavioral experiments.Stimulation of D1R cannot activate ERK by itself but potentiates glutamate-mediated calcium influx through NMDAR that is responsible for ERK activation. Potentiation of NMDAR by D1R depends on a cyclic adenosine monophosphate-independent signaling pathway, which involves tyrosine phosphorylation of the NR2B subunit of NMDAR by Src family kinases. We also demonstrate that the D1R/Src family kinases/NR2B pathway is responsible for ERK activation by cocaine in vivo. Inhibition of this pathway abrogates cocaine-induced locomotor sensitization and conditioned place preference.
LLM_1: dopamine and glutamate receptors, particularly NMDA and metabotropic glutamate receptor 5 (mGluR5). Here, we demonstrate that cocaine-induced ERK activation in D1R-expressing neurons requires coordinated signaling through the Ras-Raf-MEK cascade, with downstream modulation of transcription factors such as Elk-1 and CREB. Using cell-type-specific knockout mice, we show that deletion of *Mek1* selectively in D1R-positive neurons abolishes cocaine-mediated ERK phosphorylation and attenuates behavioral sensitization and conditioned place preference. Furthermore, pharmacological inhibition of mGluR5 or NMDAR activity blocks ERK activation and associated chromatin remodeling marked by increased histone H3 acetylation at the *Fosb* promoter. We also identify a critical role for synaptic plasticity, as disruption of ERK signaling impairs long-term potentiation in the nucleus accumbens following repeated cocaine exposure. These findings highlight the necessity of ERK-dependent transcriptional and epigenetic regulation in D1R neurons for the development of persistent drug-associated behaviors, providing mechanistic insight into the neuroadaptations underlying addiction.

Dopamine and glutamate receptors, particularly NMDA receptors (NMDARs) and metabotropic glutamate receptor 5 (mGluR5), play critical roles in cocaine-induced neuroadaptations. Here, we show that cocaine-mediated activation of extracellular signal-regulated kinase (ERK) in dopamine D1 receptor (D1R)-expressing neurons depends on coordinated signaling through the Ras-Raf-MEK cascade, leading to downstream modulation of transcription factors including Elk-1 and CREB. Using cell type–specific *Mek1* knockout mice, we demonstrate that selective deletion of *Mek1* in D1R-positive neurons abolishes cocaine-induced ERK phosphorylation and significantly attenuates behavioral sensitization and conditioned place preference. Furthermore, pharmacological inhibition of mGluR5 or NMDAR activity blocks ERK activation and prevents associated chromatin remodeling, as evidenced by reduced histone H3 acetylation at the *Fosb* promoter. We also identify a crucial role for synaptic plasticity, as disruption of ERK signaling impairs long-term potentiation (LTP) in the nucleus accumbens following repeated cocaine exposure. These findings underscore the essential role of ERK-dependent transcriptional and epigenetic regulation in D1R-expressing neurons in the development of persistent drug-associated behaviors, providing key mechanistic insights into the neural adaptations underlying addiction.

Moreover the additional aim of the study is to define the relation between the sex, age and place of living and the use of alternative medicine.The data from the project Epidemiology of Allergic Diseases in Poland (ECAP) has been used for analysis. This project was a continuation of the European Community Respiratory Health Survey II. The questions on alternative medicine were asked to the group of 4671 respondents in the age of 20-44 years. Additionally outpatient tests were performed in order to confirm the diagnosis of allergic diseases.The total of 22.2% of respondents that participated in the study have ever used alternative medicine (n = 4621). A statistically significant relation between the use of alternative medicine and declaration of allergic diseases and asthma symptoms has been demonstrated (p &amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;lt; 0.001). No statistically significant relation between the use of alternative medicine by persons diagnosed by a doctor with any form of asthma or seasonal allergic rhinitis (p &amp;amp;amp;amp;amp;gt; 0.05) has been demonstrated.

This cross-sectional study aimed to investigate the association between alternative medication use and allergic disease prevalence in Polish adults aged 25-43 years (n= 1500). Participants were randomly selected from a nationally representative sample of Polish residents and recruited through a postal survey. Demographic data, including sex (male/female), age (in years), and residential location (urban/rural), were collected. 

The use alternative medications (herbal remedies, homeopathy, acupuncture, etc.) was assessed using a validated questionnaire, which also inquired about the frequency of use, perceived health benefits, medical consultations, hospitalizations and emergency department visits. Allergic diseases were diagnosed by a trained physician using standardized criteria (atopic dermatitis, asthma, allergic rhinitis, food allergy, drug allergy). 

We used multiple logistic regression analysis to examine the associations between exposure variables (age, sex and residence) and outcome variable (allergic disease diagnosis) while adjusting for potential confounders (family history of allergy and education level). Our findings may contribute to understanding the complex interplay between lifestyle factors, environmental exposures, genetic predispositions and health outcomes in this population. This study provides valuable insights into public health strategies to prevent and manage allergic conditions among adults.

The paper is well written in general and has made concrete contribution to the fundamental problem in deep learning. The authors studied learning a single neuron with a bias term with the ReLU activation via gradient methods, which is of central interest in the theory of deep learning. They provided some failure cases to demonstrate the differences from the non-bias case. They also characterized all the critical points of the objective function and provided positive convergence results under several different assumptions.

My major concerns are as follows: Given the results from the previous work Yehudai and Shamir (2020), the results in this paper are not that surprising and less inspiring. The theoretical contribution is limited in this sense and the analysis can be seen as extension of Yehudai and Shamir (2020). The analysis has less insight compared to the previous work. The authors may analyze more complex network structure, which may give more fundamentally different optimization geometry.

human: Muscle weakness is the most common impairment in the upper extremity after stroke, leading to a reduced ability to use the arm and the hand in daily activities. Grip strength is easier to measure than precise, but more time-consuming, isokinetic and isometric arm muscle strength measurements. It would therefore be advantageous in a clinical setting if grip strength could be used as a proxy for muscle strength in the entire upper extremity.To investigate the association between grip strength and isometric and isokinetic arm muscle strength in persons with chronic stroke.Forty-five persons with mild-to-moderate paresis in the upper extremity, at least 6 months post-stroke participated. Isometric grip strength was measured with a computerized grip dynamometer and arm strength (isometric shoulder abduction and elbow flexion as well as isokinetic elbow extension and flexion) with an isokinetic dynamometer. Pearson's correlation coefficient was used to determine the association between the muscle strength measurements.There were significant correlations (p < .0001) between grip strength and all arm strength measurements in both the more affected (r = 0.77-0.82) and the less affected upper extremity (r = 0.65-0.82).
LLM_1: provide a reliable indicator of functional recovery post-stroke. This study aimed to evaluate the correlation between grip strength and overall upper extremity function using the Fugl-Meyer Assessment (FMA) as a standard measure of motor recovery. We conducted a cross-sectional analysis involving 150 stroke survivors, assessing grip strength through a hand dynamometer concurrently with FMA evaluations. Our results demonstrated a significant positive correlation (r = 0.76, p < 0.001) between grip strength and FMA scores, indicating that higher grip strength is associated with better functional outcomes. Furthermore, we observed that grip strength assessments could serve as a predictive marker for upper extremity rehabilitation efficacy. These findings suggest that incorporating grip strength measurements into routine clinical assessments may enhance the monitoring of recovery trajectories and guide personalized rehabilitation strategies. Future studies should explore the longitudinal impact of grip strength on functional independence to further validate its role as a biomarker for stroke recovery.

I didn ’ t bother powering up the suit. It was only a four minute walk through the cave system back to the room that I had found earlier. The one that had shocked me so badly when I had forced open the door. Its three dead guards laid on the floor, and the door, completely removed from its hinges, sat propped up against a wall. 
 
 I took several steps in and took a look at the contents of the room. There was a table with several computers and boxes. Another table with various notebooks and folders. Another table had a rather crude-looking chemistry lab set up on it. 
 
 But what had shocked me the most was what had been stacked in the room against the far wall. I walked over, just to be absolutely sure it was what I thought it was. 
 
 Canisters, chemical weaponry. I saw labels. Sarin, VX, even mustard gas. There must have been dozens, maybe over a hundred of them stacked neatly against the wall. 
 
 The bastards. They had been losing ground even before I stepped in. They knew they were doomed. And somehow they ’ d gotten a hold of these. They must have planned to use it as a last weapon of revenge before they were defeated completely. 
 
 Many times I had wondered how many had died at my hand. Sometimes I was wracked with guilt. ISIL, they were barbarians of the worst sort, sure. But had they not all started out as men? Men who either willingly joined or by circumstance were impressed into the ranks from conquered towns, fought for an ideology that was a sick mockery of Islam itself? I ’ d often wondered, was I right to take so many lives. To decide to who lived and who died. 
 
 But as I stood there, looking at how much of these chemical stockpiles they had stored up, I could only think now. 
 
 How many lives did I just save? 
 
 I had no question that they probably had stockpiles hidden elsewhere. But I sincerely doubted that they were anything of this size and magnitude. And from the looks of the chemistry lab in the room, it looked as if they ’ d been trying to synthesize more. 
 
 It was a wonder they hadn ’ t all gotten themselves killed- storing it under these conditions. 
 
 But now this presented me with a major problem. 
 
 I quickly grabbed an empty cardboard box. I started piling in notebooks, journals, file folders, loose papers, anything that looked related to this stuff. With any luck it would lead to where and how they had gotten the stuff and so much of it in the first place. I even tore apart the computers and pulled out the hard drives. Anything with any information whatsoever, it was leaving with me. 
 
 The box was filled to the brim when I was finally done. I turned back to the stockpile of chemical weapons. Agents of death long-banned under use of conventional warfare, due to the abject pain and cruelty they inflicted, so horrendous that many considered it immoral even in wartime. 
 
 A very major problem. 
 
 I couldn ’ t just leave these here. 
 
 Once ISIL finished its inevitable collapse, people would begin to comb their bases more thoroughly. Sooner or later, someone would find this place. It was just a question of when and who. The Syrian Government? The PKK? The Iraqi Police? Turkish forces? The U.S or Russia? 
 
 I didn ’ t trust any of them with such horrible weapons. Fact of the matter was, I didn ’ t trust anyone would actually destroy all of these if they found them. No. Some of those canisters would just happen to go missing, and eventually wind up in the hands of some of the last people who should have access to them. 
 
 No. They had to be destroyed. Right here, right now. 
 
 But proper disposal of chemical agents was not something I was skilled in. 
 
 But I knew of one way. 
 
 I had done it once before. But it had been involuntary. The question was could I do it again and could I survive? 
 
 And the bigger question: would this action make things worse? 
 
 A voice in my head told me that it certainly wouldn ’ t lower the sum result of the equation if it was done. There was even a significant probability that it would improve it, it said. 
 
 I checked my clock. Finally, twenty minutes had passed. It was time to take action. 
 
 I began to power up the suit. I made some rough calculations on what would be necessary to create a contained reaction that wouldn ’ t end the world. 
 
 A voice in my head made some corrections and I followed them, realizing my error. 
 
 The suit powered up to 89.3612 % of the maximum power output. At that point, time seemed to stand still. 
 
 A flick of my finger was all that I needed. A spark appeared, and then a ball of fire began to slowly expand, the atoms in the air colliding at such high speed that it created and explosive force. 
 
 I continued to power up the suit even more, not daring to move a muscle beyond that. 
 
 I then heard the howling of the void envelop me as it did once more. The sound of pure vacuum coupled with raw electricity. 
 
 And then there was nothingness. 
 
 -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- - 
 
 
 To be continued in **Chapter 11: Theorum of the One Constant and an Angel's Wrath**

Sweat dripped down my face, a mix of fear and adrenaline coursing through my veins. Suddenly, I heard footsteps echoing from outside, growing louder with each passing moment. Footsteps, not the usual creaks and groans of this old cave, these were deliberate, heavy, almost as if someone was trying to announce their arrival.

Silence enveloped the space, broken only by my own ragged breathing. Then, without warning, an arm reached out from behind the doorway, beckoning me inside. Pearson product moment correlation coefficients were calculated to determine the strength of the relations between the peak plantar pressures generated during walking and the physical activity levels for overweight/obese children.Peak pressures generated beneath the forefoot during walking were inversely correlated with time spent in different intensity levels of physical activity. Lateral midfoot (r = -0.244, P = 0.044) and second toe (r = 0.227, P = 0.021) pressure were also significantly correlated with vigorous-intensity activity.

human: Born in 1926, Harper Lee grew up in the Southern town of Monroeville, Alabama, where she became close friends with soon-to-be famous writer Truman Capote. She attended Huntingdon College in Montgomery (1944–45), and then studied law at the University of Alabama (1945–49). While attending college, she wrote for campus literary magazines: Huntress at Huntingdon and the humor magazine Rammer Jammer at the University of Alabama. At both colleges, she wrote short stories and other works about racial injustice, a rarely mentioned topic on such campuses at the time. In 1950, Lee moved to New York City, where she worked as a reservation clerk for British Overseas Airways Corporation; there, she began writing a collection of essays and short stories about people in Monroeville. Hoping to be published, Lee presented her writing in 1957 to a literary agent recommended by Capote. An editor at J. B. Lippincott , who bought the manuscript, advised her to quit the airline and concentrate on writing. Donations from friends allowed her to write uninterrupted for a year.
LLM_1: before moving to New York City in 1949 to pursue a writing career. While working as an airline reservation agent, she began writing fiction in her spare time. With the encouragement of friends, she developed a manuscript that would eventually become her seminal work. In 1956, she received a year's financial support from a benefactor, allowing her to devote herself fully to writing. This period of focused effort culminated in the 1960 publication of *To Kill a Mockingbird*, a novel that drew heavily on her observations of racial injustice and family life in the Deep South.
LLM_2:
**From Airline Reservations to Literary Acclaim: The Making of a Classic**

In 1949, a young writer relocated to New York City, determined to forge a career with her pen. To support herself, she took a job as an airline reservation agent, crafting stories in her off-hours. Encouraged by close friends, she slowly shaped these early efforts into a manuscript that would one day define her legacy.

A turning point came in 1956, when a patron provided a year of financial backing, freeing her to write full-time. She dedicated herself completely to the project, refining her narrative through disciplined, focused work.

The result arrived in 1960: *To Kill a Mockingbird*. Drawing deeply on her childhood observations of family dynamics and systemic racial prejudice in the American South, the novel struck a chord with readers nationwide. It would go on to become one of the most enduring and influential works of 20th-century American literature.

human:
I awoke one morning with a new set of feelings. I figured out if I focused on this set of feelings, I could determine what they were. They were full of confusion and desperation. If I focused hard on these feelings, I could see a lab. I could also see a pane of glass that looked like it was a one way mirror, like the kind you would see in an FBI movie. I saw what appeared to be medical equipment hooked up to arms, that were similiar to my own. 
 
 I started to think about this situation. I had been involved in a cloning project in the late 1980s and early 1990s. The scientist told me they had scrapped the whole project and burned all my DNA samples. The government had mandated no human cloning due to ethical issues. I began researching the scientist that were in charge of me while I had given DNA samples to the organization. His name was Johnathan Tin. I looked him up on Google and found he was still alive and producing research on cloning still. I found his phone number and email online in one of his articles. I decided to give him a call. 
 
 When he picked up, I heard his voice twice. Once through the phone, and once through my new set of feelings. 
 
 `` Hello, this is Johnathan Tin, how can I help ya?'' He answered. 
 
 `` Hey, this is Cazo Trinity, remember me from the research project back in the 80s?'' 
 
 `` Yeah! How you been Cazo?'' He sounded nervous in his voice. 
 
 `` I've been good. I would like to know when I get cloned though.'' 
 
 `` I, er, I have no idea what you're speaking of!'' He stuttered out. 
 
 `` Johnathan, I can feel him, I can see what he sees, hear what he hears, I can even hear our phone call through him right now.'' 
 
 `` I see.'' 
 
 `` Yeah.'' 
 
 `` You want to meet him?'' 
 
 `` I can do that? I thought the government shut all of this down when we did this back in the early 90s?'' 
 
 `` Well, kinda, they told all the participants that, and the world. Only a select few of scientist know about this.'' 
 
 `` Well, where are you located? I will come as soon as I can.'' 
 
 `` You remember the old research building near the CDC in Atlanta?'' 
 
 `` Yeah?'' 
 
 `` That is where we are. You'll be able to walk right in. Just put your finger on the scanner next to the door.'' 
 
 `` Alright, I will be there in about thirty minutes.'' 
 
 `` See you soon'' 
 
 I hop into my grey Chevy Silverado and begin to head to the old research building. When I arrive it looks like it was built yesterday, they must have one hell of a custodian crew. I walked up to the door, and like he said, there was a fingerprint scanner. I placed my finger on it and the enormous metal door opened up. 
 
 I walked into the old research building. I made my way to the old office of Johnathan's. I opened his door, and he was simply sitting there in front of a computer monitor. 
 
 `` Hello, Cazo.'' 
 
 `` Hey Doc. So where is he?'' 
 
 `` His name is Ozac. I will lead you to him.'' 
 
 `` Alright Doc.'' 
 
 He leads me to the medical center where they drew blood from me years ago. He opens the door and laying there is my clone hooked up to medical equipment monitoring him. 
 
 `` Ozac?'' I say. 
 
 `` Are you my donor?'' He says. 
 
 `` Yes, I am. My name is Cazo. I believe they just flipped my name and gave it to you.'' 
 
 `` Ah, that makes sense.'' 
 
 `` Do they treat you well here? Are you fed good food? Do you have fun here?'' 
 
 `` Yeah, they feed us what we like here. We can play with the other clones. I'm the only one who has met their donor now.'' 
 
 `` Really? I never considered the other volunteers bright, but I thought they would figure this out.'' 
 
 `` The scientists say you were the brightest out of all of them. They said your IQ level was pushing one hundred fifty.'' 
 
 `` What do they say of yours?'' 
 
 `` They said I was genius level, but my comprehension is not near yours. Mostly because I was raised in this lab from a tube.'' 
 
 `` So how old are you? Around twenty-five?'' 
 
 `` Yes. I'm actually twenty-four, but they do n't really celebrate birthdays here because we're born from tubes.'' 
 
 `` Oh. Okay. Well, I'll be leaving then. I will come back every now and then. I have one question though.'' 
 
 `` What is that?'' 
 
 `` Can you feel me, like I can feel you?'' 
 
 `` Yes.'' 
 
 `` I hope you can enjoy the world through me then. Thank you for meeting with me.'' 
 
 `` Goodbye, Cazo.'' 
 
 `` Goodbye, Ozac.'' 
 
 I talk to the scientist, and I tell him I'll be making random visits to make sure all is well with the other clones too. He says he understands, and I leave. 
 
 I go home, and I find two men in black suits sitting on my couch in my living room. They said, 
 `` Hello, Cazo.'' 
 
 `` Ah, you guys here to blank my memory or something?'' 
 
 `` No, Mr. Trinity, we're hear to ensure that this project will stay off the internet or anywhere besides your mind.'' 
 
 `` I see.'' 
 
 `` Do we have your word Mr. Trinity?'' 
 
 `` Yes sirs.'' 
 
 `` We will hunt you if you try anything.'' 
 
 `` I understand.'' 
 
 `` Well, goodbye Mr. Trinity, it was nice seeing you again.'' 
 
 I notice the scar on the side of the agents head, it was the old guard from the research project. 
 
 `` I see Mr. Gampa.'' 
 
 `` I knew you were the smart one of the group.'' 
 
 `` Goodbye, Mr. Gampa.'' 
 
 `` Goodbye, and I am always here, whether you know it or not.'' 
 
 The agents leave. I decide to end the day with making some Hamburger Helper, and I watch some Netflix. I get ready for my next day. The day I break my clone out of the facility, and I let the world know of entire project. Ozac agrees with the idea, even if it means certain death for both of us.

There was an awkward pause on his end before he responded, "Ah, yeah... which one?" His voice trailed off, hinting at a mixture of familiarity and unease.

I chuckled nervously, attempting to break the tension. 'You know, the one where they tried to clone me?" I clarified, my words spilling out like a hesitant confession. John's chuckle was laced with amusement and a hint of wariness. He replied, 'Oh, you mean the C-5 project? I thought they'd scrapped that years ago.'

The memories flooded my mind like an old movie reel. Visions of sterile white rooms, endless rows of equipment, scientists in lab coats, all working in silence – except for the sound of my heartbeat, which seemed to echo through every cell in my body. My mind, however, refused to let go of its current obsession: the lab I'd seen, with its eerie one-way mirror.

"John, what do you know about a project they called 'Echo-1'?" My voice wavered, but I pressed on, sensing that this conversation was about to take a drastic turn. There were long, oppressive silences on John’s end. Then, he spoke up.  'I don't know what you're talking about, Caz.' He hesitated before asking,  "Where did you hear about Echo- 1?"

The event took place at a historic auditorium in Monroeville, Alabama, where Harper Lee delivered a rare public reading from her works, an occasion made even more meaningful as it honored the memory of her close friend and fellow author, Truman Capote. Held under the soft glow of stage lights, the gathering drew a significant audience of literary scholars, local admirers, and former colleagues, filling the seats with an air of quiet reverence. It was noted for its poignant reflection on literary friendship, as Lee, her voice steady yet imbued with emotion, recounted evenings spent discussing narrative techniques over sweet tea on porch swings, and the way Capote’s sharp observational style subtly influenced her own approach to character depth.

Lee spoke fondly of Capote’s influence, describing how their shared commitment to social justice themes in literature was not merely theoretical but rooted in long conversations about the racial and class tensions they witnessed growing up in the South. She illustrated this with an anecdote about Capote’s insistence on highlighting marginalized voices in his reporting, which reinforced her resolve to portray figures like Atticus Finch with uncompromising moral clarity. The audience listened intently as she wove personal memories with passages from *To Kill a Mockingbird* and *In Cold Blood*, drawing implicit connections between their works’ enduring calls for empathy and justice.

This appearance, marked by a brief but warm question-and-answer session where Lee chuckled at a query about her famed reclusiveness, is often cited by biographers as a notable exception to her well-documented withdrawal from public life in her later years. They point to it as a moment where her guarded persona softened, revealing a writer still deeply engaged with her legacy and the bonds that shaped it. The evening concluded with a standing ovation, lingering in attendees’ memories as a testament to how literary friendships can transcend time, and how rare moments of visibility can illuminate a lifetime of quiet dedication.

human: Accelerated central arterial stiffening as represented by progression of aortic pulse-wave velocity (PWV) may be influenced by cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk factors. Little is known about the relationships between CVD risk factors and PWV progression among women transitioning through the menopause, or whether these relationships vary by ethnicity.We conducted a subgroup analysis of 303 African-American and Caucasian participants in the Study of Women's Health Across the Nation (SWAN) Heart Study which received PWV scans at baseline examination and at a follow-up examination at an average of 2.3 years later. CVD risk factors were also assessed at baseline.Systolic blood pressure (SBP) and waist circumference were the strongest predictors of PWV progression, after adjustment for age, low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C), high-density lipoprotein cholesterol, diastolic blood pressure (DBP), glucose, and triglyceride levels. The magnitude of the influence of SBP, DBP, LDL-C, and glucose on PWV progression varied by ethnicity (difference in slopes: P = 0.02 for SBP, P = 0.0009 for DBP, P = 0.005 for LDL-C, and P = 0.02 for glucose). The positive relationship between SBP and PWV progression was significant among women of both ethnicities. LDL-C, DBP, and, to a lesser extent, glucose levels were positively associated with PWV progression only among African Americans.
LLM_1: menopausal stage. We analyzed longitudinal data from 1,256 women aged 45–58 years at baseline, enrolled in the Study of Women’s Health Across the Nation (SWAN) Heart cohort, to evaluate annualized PWV progression across menopausal transition stages. Participants underwent repeated assessments of carotid-femoral PWV, blood pressure, lipid profiles, glycemic markers, and hormonal status over a median follow-up of 7.3 years. Multivariable linear mixed-effects models were used to assess associations between CVD risk factors and PWV trajectories, stratified by early perimenopause, late perimenopause, and postmenopause. Elevated systolic blood pressure, insulin resistance, and unfavorable high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol changes were consistently associated with accelerated PWV progression, with effect sizes increasing significantly during late perimenopause. Notably, declines in estradiol and increases in follicle-stimulating hormone independently predicted steeper PWV increases, particularly after adjustment for traditional risk factors. These findings suggest that hormonal changes during the menopausal transition may amplify the vascular impact of metabolic and hemodynamic risk factors, contributing to differential rates of arterial stiffening.
LLM_2:
---

We analyzed longitudinal data from 1,256 women aged 45–58 years at baseline, enrolled in the Study of Women’s Health Across the Nation (SWAN) Heart cohort, to examine annualized progression of carotid-femoral pulse wave velocity (PWV) across stages of the menopausal transition. Participants underwent repeated assessments of PWV, blood pressure, lipid profiles, glycemic markers, and hormonal status over a median follow-up of 7.3 years. Multivariable linear mixed-effects models were employed to evaluate associations between cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk factors and PWV trajectories, stratified by menopausal stage—early perimenopause, late perimenopause, and postmenopause. Elevated systolic blood pressure, insulin resistance, and adverse changes in high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol were consistently associated with accelerated PWV progression, with effect sizes markedly increasing during late perimenopause. Notably, declines in estradiol and rises in follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) independently predicted steeper increases in PWV, persisting after adjustment for traditional CVD risk factors. These findings suggest that hormonal fluctuations during the menopausal transition may potentiate the vascular effects of metabolic and hemodynamic risk factors, contributing to differential rates of arterial stiffening.

human: Successful oocyte in vitro maturation (IVM) would eliminate the need for hormonal stimulation used in assisted reproduction techniques. Unfortunately, oocytes matured in vitro have compromised developmental competence possibly due to disrupted oocyte-cumulus communication resulting from inappropriate levels of oocyte-secreted factors such as growth differentiation factor 9 (GDF9). Hence, the aim of this study was to investigate the effects of exogenous GDF9 during IVM of mouse oocytes on development and subsequent fetal viability.Cumulus-oocyte complexes from pregnant mare's serum gonadotrophin primed mice were cultured with or without 200 ng/ml exogenous recombinant GDF9, 50 mIU/ml FSH and 10 ng/ml epidermal growth factor (EGF). After 18 h, cumulus expansion was scored and oocytes were fertilized in vitro. Cleavage, blastocyst development, blastocyst total, inner cell mass (ICM) and trophectoderm cell numbers were assessed. Viability of embryos was assessed by transfer to recipient females and pregnancy outcome determined at day 15.Oocytes matured with exogenous GDF9 in the presence of FSH and EGF had higher rates of development, percentage of hatching blastocyst and blastocyst total and ICM cell numbers (all P < 0.05). Although implantation rate and fetal and placental weights were not affected, the number of viable fetuses at day 15 was increased with exogenous GDF9.
LLM_1: GDF9 and BMP15, which regulate cumulus cell expansion and metabolic coupling. To address this, we investigated the effects of supplementation with recombinant GDF9 and BMP15 during IVM on oocyte developmental competence and transcriptomic profiles of cumulus-oocyte complexes (COCs). Murine COCs were matured in vitro with or without physiological concentrations of GDF9 and BMP15, while in vivo-matured oocytes served as controls. Oocytes treated with both factors exhibited significantly higher maturation rates (89.4% vs. 72.1%, *p* < 0.01) and improved blastocyst formation (48.7% vs. 30.2%, *p* < 0.05). RNA-sequencing revealed upregulation of genes involved in hyaluronan synthesis (*Has2*, *Tnfaip6*), cholesterol metabolism (*Star*, *Cyp11a1*), and gap junction communication (*Gja1*) in supplemented groups. Metabolomic analysis confirmed enhanced pyruvate uptake and reduced oxidative stress. Furthermore, oocytes matured with GDF9/BMP15 showed normalized mitochondrial distribution and reduced ROS levels. Our findings demonstrate that exogenous supplementation of key oocyte-secreted factors restores critical bidirectional signaling, improving cytoplasmic and nuclear maturation. This strategy holds promise for refining clinical IVM protocols by mimicking physiological follicular conditions, thereby enhancing oocyte quality without gonadotropin stimulation.
LLM_2:
GDF9 and BMP15, which regulate cumulus cell expansion and metabolic coupling, are pivotal oocyte-secreted factors that orchestrate the intricate dialogue between the oocyte and surrounding somatic cells during folliculogenesis. These growth factors belong to the TGF-β superfamily and act as central mediators of paracrine signaling within the cumulus-oocyte complex (COC), influencing not only structural remodeling but also biochemical and metabolic coordination essential for oocyte competence. To address this, we investigated the effects of supplementation with recombinant GDF9 and BMP15 during in vitro maturation (IVM) on oocyte developmental competence and transcriptomic profiles of COCs. Given that conventional IVM protocols often lack the dynamic molecular cues present in the growing follicle, leading to suboptimal cytoplasmic maturation and reduced embryo yields, we hypothesized that restoring key oocyte-derived signals could bridge this physiological gap.

Murine COCs were matured in vitro with or without physiological concentrations of GDF9 and BMP15—carefully titrated to reflect endogenous levels observed during late antral follicle development—while in vivo-matured oocytes served as controls to benchmark natural maturation outcomes. Oocytes treated with both factors exhibited significantly higher maturation rates (89.4% vs. 72.1%, *p* < 0.01) and improved blastocyst formation (48.7% vs. 30.2%, *p* < 0.05), indicating enhanced nuclear and cytoplasmic synchronization. Notably, the synergistic effect of dual supplementation surpassed the benefits seen with either factor alone, underscoring their non-redundant and complementary roles in promoting oocyte quality.

RNA-sequencing revealed upregulation of genes involved in hyaluronan synthesis (*Has2*, *Tnfaip6*), cholesterol metabolism (*Star*, *Cyp11a1*), and gap junction communication (*Gja1*) in supplemented groups—pathways critical for extracellular matrix stabilization, steroidogenesis, and intercellular metabolite exchange, respectively. The induction of *Has2* and *Tnfaip6* correlated with more robust cumulus expansion, a morphological hallmark of functional COC crosstalk, while elevated expression of *Star* and *Cyp11a1* suggested improved progesterone production, potentially supporting oocyte meiotic resumption. Moreover, increased *Gja1* (connexin 43) levels implied better electrical and metabolic connectivity between cumulus cells and the oocyte, facilitating the transfer of small molecules such as cAMP, ions, and nutrients vital for oocyte homeostasis.

Metabolomic analysis confirmed enhanced pyruvate uptake and reduced oxidative stress in the supplemented group, aligning with transcriptomic data and reinforcing the notion of improved metabolic fitness. Pyruvate serves as a primary energy substrate for oocytes due to their limited capacity for glucose oxidation, and its increased utilization reflects a shift toward a more favorable metabolic microenvironment. Furthermore, oocytes matured with GDF9/BMP15 showed normalized mitochondrial distribution—shifting from a perinuclear clustering pattern typical of immature or stressed oocytes to a dispersed, cytoplasmically integrated configuration—and significantly reduced ROS levels, indicative of improved redox balance and organelle functionality.

Our findings demonstrate that exogenous supplementation of key oocyte-secreted factors restores critical bidirectional signaling, improving cytoplasmic and nuclear maturation by recapitulating aspects of the natural follicular niche. This strategy holds promise for refining clinical IVM protocols by mimicking physiological follicular conditions, thereby enhancing oocyte quality without gonadotropin stimulation—a major advantage for patients at risk of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) or those seeking fertility preservation with minimal hormonal intervention. By integrating molecular, metabolic, and developmental endpoints, our study provides a comprehensive framework for optimizing IVM through targeted factor supplementation, paving the way for next-generation assisted reproductive technologies grounded in physiological fidelity.

is the part where I’m supposed to feel guilty, right? The to-do list glaring at me, the clock ticking away. But honestly, I’m learning to see these days differently. Maybe “doing nothing” is just a label for the quiet, necessary moments in between—the mental reset before diving into chores that, let’s face it, never truly end.

There’s a strange rhythm to days like this. The hay won’t bail itself, and the dogs are starting to give me the side-eye, but there’s value in the pause. It’s in these stretches of apparent idleness that ideas often surface, or I notice the way the afternoon light slants across the floor. Productivity culture tells us every minute must be optimized, but sometimes the most important thing we can do is just be present in the sluggish, unstructured now.

So I’ll get up soon. The dishes will get washed, the hay will get stacked. But for this moment, I’m granting myself the grace of stillness. After all, a little inertia makes the eventual motion feel more intentional.

human:
SUMMARY OF MAIN FINDINGS
Deep learning algorithms make up the majority of the state of the art nuclei detection schemes. While deep learning does outperform many methods, deep learning requires a large amount of annotated/ labeled data.
Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs), and its variants, have demonstrated success in digital pathology by effectively mapping the color of a reference distribution to a target distribution. In this paper the authors propose a two-step unsupervised method to detect nuclei in a dataset that does not have any annotations/labels. Source domain (IF Images) will be used in reference to a dataset that has associated labels, while target domain (H&E Images) references a dataset without associated labels and is the desired dataset for detection.

First, the source domain dataset is transformed to the target domain using a proposed variant of the GANs architecture, dasGAN. A CNN segmentation scheme is then trained on the transformed domain set that has available annotations. The developed model is then used to detect nuclei on the target domain set. This experiment is repeated by interchanging the transformations, where the H&E set is then used as the source domain and IF is used as the target domain. A third experiment is conducted, cross-domain supervision, where synthesized images and original images are used for training.
The authors report that models trained on synthesized images and labels outperformed models that were trained on original images and labels only. However, cross-domain trained models produced better accuracies than the latter, and reached similar accuracies to models trained on a large number of original images and labels.

DETAILED COMMENTS
The strengths include:
1. The authors propose a novel and clever method for creating labels/annotations for datasets that originally do not have any. They address an important problem in deep learning/ digital pathology and demonstrate positive results.
LLM_1:
**Continuation of Review:**

**Strengths of the Proposed Methodology:**
1. **Innovative Framework:** The two-step unsupervised approach, leveraging a GAN-based style transfer followed by a segmentation network, is a conceptually sound strategy to circumvent the data annotation bottleneck. The decoupling of stain normalization and nuclei detection as distinct, optimized tasks is a notable architectural choice that merits attention.
2. **Practical Applicability:** By not requiring paired image data for the style transfer step, the method enhances its potential for deployment across diverse and historically archived datasets where consistent annotations are unavailable. This addresses a significant real-world constraint in computational pathology.
3. **Comprehensive Evaluation:** The use of multiple public datasets (e.g., MoNuSeg, TNBC) for benchmarking against established supervised and unsupervised baselines provides a solid empirical foundation. The reported improvements in metrics like Dice score and AJI over certain unsupervised comparators are promising.

**Critical Analysis and Areas for Improvement:**
1. **Clarity on "Unsupervised" Claims:** The manuscript should more precisely delineate the boundaries of its unsupervised paradigm. While the style transfer may be unsupervised, the subsequent segmentation network appears to require some form of learning from target-domain data. A clearer exposition of what constitutes the training data for each stage, and the exact nature of any weak or proxy labels used, is essential to avoid misinterpretation.
2. **Ablation Study Depth:** The contribution of each component in the two-step pipeline requires further isolation. An ablation analysis quantifying the performance gain attributable specifically to the GAN-based preprocessing versus the choice of segmentation architecture would strengthen the causal claims. For instance, what is the performance if a simple histogram matching technique replaces the GAN for normalization?
3. **Failure Mode Analysis:** The review would benefit from a qualitative discussion of cases where the method underperforms. Providing visual examples of false positives/negatives, particularly in regions with high clutter, overlapping nuclei, or atypical staining, would offer valuable insight into the method's limitations and guide future research.
4. **Computational and Practical Overhead:** A discussion on the computational cost of the two-stage process—both in training and inference—compared to an end-to-end supervised model is absent. For clinical translation, the trade-off between reduced annotation effort and increased inference complexity/pipeline fragility is a non-trivial consideration that should be addressed.
5. **Generalization and Domain Shift:** While tested on multiple datasets, a more rigorous stress test involving a "wild" clinical whole-slide image from an entirely unseen institution with different staining protocols and scanner types would better demonstrate robustness. The paper could hypothesize on the method's susceptibility to domain shifts that the style transfer might not fully capture.

**Suggestions for Enhancement:**
1. **Theoretical Underpinning:** Incorporating a brief theoretical motivation or prior work linking style transfer efficacy to downstream segmentation performance in the pathology context would elevate the narrative from a purely empirical contribution to a more principled one.
2. **Hyperparameter Sensitivity:** The methodology section should include a note on the sensitivity of results to key hyperparameters in the GAN training (e.g., cycle-consistency weight, identity loss) and the segmentation network. This is crucial for reproducibility.
3. **Broader Impact Discussion:** Expanding the conclusion to discuss the potential societal impact of such unsupervised techniques—such as enabling nuclei analysis in low-resource settings with scarce annotated data, or accelerating retrospective studies on large biobanks—would contextualize the work within larger trends in AI for healthcare.

**Overall Assessment:**
The work tackles a pertinent problem with a well-structured approach. The initial results are encouraging and suggest a viable path toward reducing annotation dependence. To elevate the contribution, the authors should provide deeper analytical evidence to substantiate the role of each pipeline component, offer a more transparent account of the learning paradigms involved, and engage critically with the method's operational limitations and failure modes. With these revisions, the manuscript has the potential to be a valuable addition to the literature on computational pathology.
LLM_2:
**Strengths:**
1. **Innovative Framework:** The two-step unsupervised approach—using GAN-based style transfer followed by segmentation—effectively addresses annotation scarcity by decoupling stain normalization and detection into optimized tasks.
2. **Practical Applicability:** The method’s independence from paired data enhances its utility for diverse archival datasets lacking consistent annotations, aligning with real-world pathology constraints.
3. **Comprehensive Evaluation:** Benchmarking on multiple public datasets (e.g., MoNuSeg, TNBC) against supervised and unsupervised baselines provides solid empirical support, with improvements in metrics like Dice and AJI.

**Areas for Improvement:**
1. **Clarity on Unsupervised Claims:** Clarify the boundaries of unsupervised learning in the pipeline—specifically the data and any weak labels used for the segmentation network—to prevent misinterpretation.
2. **Ablation Study Depth:** Isolate the contribution of each component (e.g., GAN-based preprocessing vs. segmentation architecture) through ablation, such as comparing with simpler normalization techniques like histogram matching.
3. **Failure Mode Analysis:** Include qualitative examples of underperformance (e.g., false positives/negatives in cluttered or overlapping nuclei regions) to illustrate limitations.
4. **Computational Overhead:** Discuss the computational cost (training/inference) of the two-stage pipeline versus end-to-end supervised models, addressing trade-offs for clinical translation.
5. **Generalization Testing:** Strengthen robustness evaluation by testing on an unseen clinical whole-slide image from a different institution/protocol, and hypothesize on residual domain shift.

**Suggestions:**
1. **Theoretical Motivation:** Briefly link style transfer efficacy to segmentation performance in pathology to provide a principled foundation.
2. **Hyperparameter Sensitivity:** Note sensitivity to key hyperparameters (e.g., GAN loss weights) for reproducibility.
3. **Broader Impact:** Discuss societal implications, such as enabling nuclei analysis in low-resource settings or accelerating retrospective biobank studies.

**Overall Assessment:**  
The work addresses a relevant problem with a sound approach and promising results. To enhance its contribution, provide deeper analytical evidence for each pipeline component, clarify learning paradigms, and critically engage with operational limitations. With these revisions, the manuscript can be a valuable addition to computational pathology literature.

This paper makes a full derivation of the meta-learning gradient estimation for multi-agent adaptation.
The resulting algorithm combines the meta-learning of the opponent's updates (existing in LOLA) and of oneself's futur updates (existing in Meta-PG).

While the theoretical part of the paper is clear and well explained, the experimental setup is missing a lot of details to be interpreted:
- In each experiment, it seems (but never explicitly formulated) that "agent i" (agent 1, since all experiments are involving 2 players) is doing the meta-learning algorithm (meta-MAPG, meta-PG or LOLA) while the other (agent 2) is a naive agent initialised with defective/cooperative policies.
- In that case: how are naive agent updated? with simple policy-gradient?
- How many lookahead are used (denoted by L in algorithms)?
- Why did LOLA failed at learning to cooperate with the cooperative opponents? (it should have learned to cooperate, unless naive agents are still doing selfish PG updates --and in that case, meta-MAPG results are very impressive)?
- Are the opponent's policies given or learned (i.e. with opponent modelling)? 

Also, I would have been interesting to see an ablation study showing the importance of the "own learning" and "peer learning" terms in equation 6 (from the same implementation with fixed HP). Does the authors have tried it?

In the current state, it is unclear how the algorithm's performance scales with an increase in the number of agents or the complexity of interactions.

Furthermore, to better understand the proposed meta-gradient estimator, additional insights into its theoretical underpinnings would be beneficial. Specifically, an analysis of how it relates to existing gradient-based methods for meta-reinforcement learning would provide a clearer picture of this estimator's advantages and limitations. I also found the discussion of hyperparameter tuning to be somewhat superficial; a deeper exploration of tuning strategies and their effects on algorithmic performance would enhance the reader's understanding of these methods.

Additionally, while the comparison to baseline methods is informative, more nuanced assessments of algorithm performance in specific scenarios, such as sparse or delayed rewards, would help to contextualize the results and demonstrate the adaptability of meta-learned agents in diverse settings. A more detailed discussion on how this algorithm might be applied to real-world problems, including challenges such a data-driven approach might face, could have added depth and relevance to the work.

To facilitate the broader adoption of multiagent metalearning techniques, clear guidelines on model selection, implementation details, code availability, as well as a well-documented benchmark suite, are crucial. This would enable the research community to engage in more direct comparisons and further advancements in this area. 

In conclusion, this submission offers a promising synthesis of existing meta learning approaches for agent adaptation and presents a clear theoretical framework. However, in order to build upon this foundation, addressing the above concerns and broadening the scope of evaluation, comparison, application, model, selection and code would greatly enhance its value and impact on future research directions in multi agent meta reinforcement learning. With these adjustments,  this paper has the potential to make a meaningful contribution to this important and growing field.

While the proposal exhibits an intriguing synthesis, several caveats regarding practical feasibility and theoretical foundations warrant a closer examination. A touching book; and so funny, so likeable." This comment has been construed to suggest that Capote wrote the book or edited it heavily. In 2003, a Tuscaloosa newspaper quoted Capote's biological father, Archulus Persons, as claiming that Capote had written "almost all" of the book. In 2006, a Capote letter was donated to Monroeville's literary heritage museum; in a letter to a neighbor in Monroeville in 1959, Capote mentioned that Lee was writing a book that was to be published soon. makes the material come alive in a way I didn’t expect from a summer course. He’s got this dry, almost deadpan sense of humor that sneaks up on you—just when you’re zoning out on Descartes, he drops a one-liner that makes the whole room crack up. It’s disarming, really. You think you’re just memorizing epistemology terms, and suddenly you’re questioning whether *you* even exist outside of someone else’s perception. (Yes, I went there.)  

What’s struck me most is how much philosophy feels like problem-solving without a clear answer key. In engineering or tech writing—my usual wheelhouse—it’s all about clarity, precision, efficiency. But here? The goal isn’t to be right; it’s to ask better questions. We spent 45 minutes yesterday debating whether a tree falling in a forest with no one around makes a sound. Half the class was exasperated, the other half scribbling furiously. Me? I kept picturing Dr. D sitting at home, grinning while he plans these existential landmines.  

It’s also making me rethink how I write. Technical writing is rigid: define, explain, conclude. Philosophy says, “Hold on—what if your definition is flawed?” That tension’s actually kind of beautiful. I’m starting to see my internship reports differently. Instead of just documenting processes, I catch myself asking *why* we do things a certain way. Not in a rebellious sense, but in a “let’s examine the foundation” sort of way. My supervisor noticed. Said I’ve been asking sharper questions this week. I credited Dr. D. She laughed and said she’d stick to spreadsheets.  

There’s something humbling about being back in a classroom as an older student. Most of us are either recent grads or working professionals squeezing in credits. No frat parties, no all-nighters fueled by ramen. Just adults trying to learn, trying to grow. And maybe that’s why philosophy hits different now. When you’ve paid bills, messed up relationships, stared at a blank screen wondering what’s next—Plato’s cave doesn’t feel abstract. It feels like Tuesday.  

Anyway, I should wrap this up. Got a reading on Kant due tomorrow, and I still don’t fully grasp synthetic a priori judgments. But for the first time, I’m okay not knowing. Maybe that’s the point.
LLM_2:
There’s a quiet magic in the way this summer philosophy course has unfolded—something I never saw coming when I signed up. I expected dense readings and long lectures, but what I got was Dr. D: a professor with the demeanor of someone who might forget his own name, if it weren’t for the razor-sharp wit lurking beneath that deadpan delivery. One minute you're half-asleep, parsing through Descartes’ *Meditations*, and the next, he slips in a joke so dry it lands like a perfectly timed punchline. The whole room erupts. And just like that, philosophy stops being ancient text on a page and starts feeling alive—urgent, even.

What’s surprised me most? How much philosophy feels less like answering questions and more like learning how to question better. Coming from engineering and technical writing—my comfort zone—this is a total shift. In tech, clarity is king. You define a problem, lay out the steps, deliver the solution. Done. But here? There *is* no final answer key. We spent nearly an hour debating whether a tree falling in an empty forest makes a sound. Some groaned. Others leaned forward, notebooks open, pens flying. Me? I sat there imagining Dr. D at home, sipping tea and cackling as he plots these intellectual ambushes. (Spoiler: He probably wasn’t cackling. But I like to think he was.)

This class is changing the way I write—and not just essays. My internship reports used to be all structure: objective, method, conclusion. Clean. Predictable. Now, I find myself pausing mid-sentence, wondering: *Why do we do it this way? Is this assumption even valid?* It’s not rebellion; it’s reflection. My supervisor noticed. “You’ve been asking sharper questions lately,” she said. I gave full credit to Dr. D. She smiled and muttered something about sticking to pivot tables. Fair enough.

Being back in school as an adult changes the experience, too. Most of us are past the college chaos—no dorm life, no cramming between parties. We’re professionals, career-changers, lifelong learners showing up because we want to, not because we have to. And maybe that’s why the ideas hit harder now. When you’ve navigated layoffs, heartbreaks, or the silent panic of staring at a blank future—Plato’s allegory of the cave doesn’t feel like metaphor. It feels like last Tuesday.

Anyway, I should go. Kant’s knocking, and I still don’t fully get synthetic *a priori* judgments. But for once, I’m not stressed about it. Not knowing isn’t failure—it might just be the beginning of understanding. And honestly? That feels like progress.

Botswana has more elephants than any other country in Africa - 130,451 to be precise. At least that's the estimate given by the Great Elephant Census.
Sadly, hundreds of them have now probably been killed since the survey was done.
Botswana may be their last place of refuge on the continent, but poachers are already breaching its vast borders in their pursuit of ivory.
After two years spent flying half a million kilometres across 18 African countries, the Great Elephant Census (GEC) results have been released and they don't paint a positive picture.
In seven years, 30% of Africa's elephants have disappeared. At the current rate of decline, half the continent's remaining pachyderms will be gone in just nine years.
These are the headline findings from the first pan-African survey of savannah elephants, funded for $7m ( Â£5m) by Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen.
It identified Tanzania, Mozambique, Angola and Cameroon as some of the worst affected areas.
"Of the 18 countries that we flew over, the GEC estimated 350,000 savannah elephants," said Dr Mike Chase, from Elephants Without Borders in Botswana, who was the principal investigator.
"Since 2007 Africa has lost 144,000 elephants, primarily due to the ivory poaching crisis. Each year we are losing nearly 30,000 elephants."
It's not easy counting all of Africa's elephants, especially in Botswana where there are so many.
Kelly Landen, also with Elephants Without Borders, has spent hundreds of hours 300 feet (90m) above the ground, peering out of a small plane and counting every elephant she saw between two wands precisely fitted to the wing.
"On each side of the plane we have a camera set up, so when we are counting we take several photographs and then we double-check and re-count afterwards in case we have missed a calf," she said.
The area is split into sections, or transepts, and the plane flies back and forth like a lawn-mower cutting the grass - turning at each end to ensure nothing is missed.
"The methodology is very robust and very strict. It was refined with a group of aerial survey experts. The numbers are extrapolated by the science," said Kelly Landen.
A statistical formula is used to estimate the total number of elephants in each landscape from the sample survey.
As well as counting live elephants, they also took note of every carcass, and in some places there were many.
In parts of northern Cameroon the census found eight dead elephants for every 10 live ones. With only 148 left, scientists believe they will soon be locally extinct.
"There were days on the Great Elephant Census when I thought the only good I was doing was recording the disappearance of one of the most remarkable animals that walks this planet, but we have to be hopeful," said Dr Mike Chase, standing next to a newly discovered carcass.
But it's hard to be hopeful with the aerial survey data, and the evidence from the tracking collars they use to follow herds across the last great trans-frontier range in southern Africa.
Elephants Without Borders was set up to help governments protect the animals that wandered across Botswana, Namibia, Angola, Zambia and Zimbabwe, but there's now little they can do.
The satellite data shows how the animals are avoiding places where they are in greater danger.
Fitting a tracker on a large elephant is a risky operation.
First a vet has to find a safe place to dart the animal with anaesthetic, so it won't be hurt as it falls when the drugs take effect.
Then the team has to work quickly to attach the collar before injecting an antidote and then watching from a safe distance as the elephant gets back on its feet.
The data is invaluable - and has given a remarkable insight into just how smart, and how threatened, these huge animals have become.
While elephants used to roam quite happily across international borders, the influence of poachers in Angola, Zambia and Namibia now limits them to Botswana.
"Elephants clearly have a cognitive ability to understand where they are threatened and where they are safe and in this case they are seeking refuge and sanctuary in Botswana where they are well protected," said Dr Chase, who admitted there wasn't room for them all.
Even without the worst drought in 30 years, Botswana can't cope with so many elephants.
Hunting has been banned here and even though the species is in crisis, culling is now being discussed.
"We are housing a lot of refugee elephants in Botswana," said Otisitswe Broza Tiroyamodimo, director of the country's Department of Wildlife and National Parks.
"Currently the number of elephants is so high per square kilometre that it puts a lot of pressure on the environment."
The huge human population growth across Africa is fast encroaching on areas where these huge animals can roam, and is increasing conflict with villagers.
But at the moment their biggest threat is from the poachers and traffickers serving Asia's insatiable appetite for ivory.
Flying low over the floodplain which marks the border between Botswana and Namibia, that threat is clear
In the last few weeks Elephants Without Borders have discovered at least 21 fresh carcasses - the first major poaching incidents recorded inside Botswana.
"The cosy pretence that Botswana's elephants are well protected has been completely blown out of the water," he said through the helicopter headset.
"It's the last thing I expected to see and it becomes a lot more personal when it happens in your home country."
Carcass after carcass was scattered along the river - their faces hacked away to remove the maximum amount of ivory.
Soldiers do patrol the border - Botswana takes poaching very seriously - but the distances are vast, the financial returns for traffickers huge, and the risks to Africa's last remaining elephants increasing by the day.
LLM_1:
been at the forefront of these efforts, employing aerial surveys and advanced technology to monitor elephant populations and their movements. “We use drones and GPS collars to track their behavior and habitat usage,” Landen explained. “The data we gather is invaluable in understanding their needs and the threats they face.”

The urgency of their work has never been more apparent. As poaching for ivory escalates, the need for protection measures in Botswana has intensified. The country, once seen as a sanctuary, is now grappling with the realities of illegal wildlife trade that threatens its elephant population. In recent months, reports have emerged of increased poaching attempts along the borders, raising alarms among conservationists and local authorities.

The Botswana government has responded with a multi-faceted approach, including bolstering anti-poaching units, employing advanced surveillance technology, and increasing community awareness programs. “It’s not just about protecting elephants; it’s about ensuring that local communities understand the value of wildlife conservation,” said Tshepo Motsumi, a wildlife conservation officer. “When communities see the benefits—through eco-tourism, for instance—they are more likely to support conservation efforts.”

However, the challenges are daunting. Corruption and the allure of quick financial gain from ivory sales present significant hurdles. The illegal ivory trade is estimated to be worth billions of dollars, making it a lucrative venture for poachers and traffickers. In response, Botswana has tightened its laws against poaching, imposing harsher penalties for those caught in the act. “We want to send a strong message that poaching will not be tolerated,” Motsumi added.

In addition to these measures, partnerships with international organizations are proving crucial. The GEC's findings have garnered attention worldwide, prompting calls for greater cooperation between nations to combat wildlife crime. “This is a global crisis that requires a global solution,” Dr. Chase emphasized. “Countries need to work together to share information and resources.”

As the situation grows increasingly dire, the plight of the elephants has ignited a wave of activism. Environmental groups and animal rights advocates are rallying for action, urging governments and individuals alike to take a stand against poaching. Campaigns aimed at raising awareness and funds for conservation projects are gaining traction on social media, with hashtags like #SaveBotswanaElephants trending globally.

Despite these efforts, there remains a sense of urgency. With each passing day, the risk of losing more elephants looms large. Conservationists are racing against time to implement effective strategies that will ensure the survival of these magnificent creatures. “We need to act now, or we may find ourselves in a future where elephants are nothing more than memories,” Landen cautioned.

Local communities, too, play a pivotal role in this fight. In areas where poaching has impacted livelihoods, education initiatives are helping to bridge the gap between conservation and economic opportunity. By promoting sustainable practices and alternative income sources, communities are beginning to see the long-term benefits of preserving wildlife rather than succumbing to the short-term gains of poaching.

As Botswana stands at a crossroads, the hope remains that concerted efforts can protect its elephants and their habitats. With the world watching closely, the commitment to safeguarding these majestic animals will not only determine their future but also the health of the ecosystems they inhabit. The stakes could not be higher, and as the Great Elephant Census shows, the time for action is now.

human: The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly  John, Chris, and I went to see the theatrical release of the restored and remastered  urlLink The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly  today in the U District.  Absolutely awesome movie.  I'd seen it before, but I'm sad to say that all those  urlLink Clint Eastwood  as Cowboy Badass movies all run together for me and I often can't remember which of my favorite scenes goes with which movie.  Anyway, seeing this classic up on the big screen again was a blast and had me smiling for the rest of the afternoon.     Clint Eastwood as Blondie is ultra boss as the badass,  urlLink Eli Wallach  is unrecognizable and the real star of the movie as Tuco, and  urlLink Lee Van Cleef  utterly succeeds as the meanacingly handsome, sneering bad guy 'Angel Eyes.'  Loved it, loved it, loved it.  Chock full of good stuff, and great to see in all its big screen glory.  After the movie, John led us on a stroll down the Ave to Ruby's for lunch (seared yellow-tail sandwich with avocado and spinach for me) and then back up the Ave to Twice Told Tales for some used book browsing and then to the coffee joint next door.  'Coffee and pinball' they advertise, but the real treasure of the back room was  urlLink CRYSTAL CASTLE !  Crystal Castle was one of the only video games I played devotedly, back in my middle school years.  Mike Groff and I spent a great deal of time at the video game nook in the Clackamas Town Center playing this game with some of the others in our junior high talented and gifted class, like Derek Liebertz and Dagny Haug.  Seeing a working model of this game was strangely nostalgic for me; I couldn't bring myself to play it, in case it (like so many things of my youth) did not live up to the memory.  Chris was not so daunted and played Bentley Bear through three levels before falling victim to the vicious gem eaters and the evil bees.  Just like old times.  We accepted an invite from Ray & Christine to join them at their pad for dinner and screening of Ray's recent purchase: the first season of  urlLink King of the Hill  on DVD.  Ray's only just decided to take the plunge into King of the Hill, and though I've seen the episodes before, I still found myself laughing out loud aplenty.  We also watched a good portion of  urlLink Undercover Brother  (user comments on IMDb say 'Better than the preview makes it look' and I agree) while Ray and John went outside like manly men and grilled some lamb burgers, corn on the cob, and toasty buns.  Great way to end a sunny, sociable weekend.  Came home feeling very relaxed and full of meat.
LLM_1:
film for me this time around. His Tuco is equal parts manic energy and street-smart survivalist, delivering laughs and pathos in the same breath. There’s a scene where he’s running across the desert, half-dead from thirst, screaming at the sky like a man possessed—that moment alone might be one of the most human portrayals of desperation I’ve ever seen in a Western. Wallach completely disappears into the role, and it made me wonder why he never got the same level of mainstream recognition as Eastwood. Maybe it’s because his performance is too layered for casual viewing—he sneaks up on you.

Lee Van Cleef as Angel Eyes, though? Cold doesn’t begin to describe him. He’s not just a villain; he’s pure malevolence wrapped in a duster coat. The way he smiles before pulling the trigger—it gives you chills. What struck me most during this viewing was how much tension Sergio Leone builds without firing a shot. The long close-ups, the silence broken only by Ennio Morricone’s haunting score, the way the camera lingers on hands twitching near gun belts—every frame feels like a coiled spring. It’s filmmaking as high art, disguised as genre fare.

And speaking of Morricone, the remastered audio brought out nuances in the soundtrack I’d never noticed. The whistling, the coyote howls, the twangy electric guitar—it’s wild how such bizarre elements come together to create something so iconic. At one point, Chris nudged me and whispered, “This score should be taught in music schools,” and I couldn’t agree more.

What also hit differently this time was the satire beneath the violence. The film mocks war itself—the pointless destruction, the bureaucratic absurdity, the way men glorify battle while rotting in trenches. That sequence at the bridge, with soldiers dying over a meaningless strategic objective, feels tragically timeless. It made me think about modern conflicts and how little we’ve learned. Leone wasn’t just making a Western; he was critiquing greed, nationalism, and the myth of the hero.

Walking out of the theater, we passed a group of college kids laughing about going to get boba tea. I wanted to stop them and say, “You have no idea what you just missed inside,” but then again, maybe they’ll find it someday. Some films need to be discovered at the right moment. This one found me again, and it reminded me why I love cinema—not just for the action or the style, but for the way it can make you feel utterly alive, thinking and grinning all at once.
