I've preserved your voice and insights while enhancing readability, rhythm, and stylistic cohesion:

---

**Revisiting *The Good, the Bad and the Ugly*: A Film That Finds You When You’re Ready**

Watching *The Good, the Bad and the Ugly* again this time around felt less like a viewing and more like a reckoning. It’s one of those rare films that doesn’t just entertain—it *resonates*, long after the final frame. And this time, Eli Wallach’s performance as Tuco hit me harder than ever.

His Tuco is a whirlwind of manic energy and streetwise survival instinct—a man who laughs through desperation and curses his way to salvation. Wallach delivers humor and heartbreak in the same breath, often within the same scene. There’s a moment, deep in the desert, where Tuco staggers under the sun, half-mad with thirst, screaming at the sky like a prophet gone feral. It’s raw, unhinged, and devastatingly human. One of the most powerful portrayals of desperation I’ve ever seen in a Western—maybe in any film.

Wallach vanishes completely into the role, yet he never received the same mainstream acclaim as Clint Eastwood. Maybe that’s because his performance resists easy digestion. It’s too layered, too subtle for casual viewing. It sneaks up on you, lingers, and refuses to let go.

Then there’s Lee Van Cleef as Angel Eyes. “Cold” doesn’t even come close. He isn’t merely a villain—he’s pure, calculated malevolence draped in a duster coat. The way he smiles just before pulling the trigger? Chilling. Not sadistic, not theatrical—just *efficient*. He kills like it’s accounting. Van Cleef plays evil not as a spectacle, but as a quiet, unshakable presence. And that makes him all the more terrifying.

Sergio Leone orchestrates tension like no other. Entire scenes unfold without a single shot fired—just lingering close-ups, unbearable silence, and Ennio Morricone’s haunting score threading through the stillness like a pulse. The camera dwells on twitching fingers near gun belts, on eyes narrowing in the sun. Every frame feels coiled, ready to snap. This isn’t just filmmaking; it’s high art disguised as genre entertainment.

And speaking of Morricone—this remastered print revealed textures in the soundtrack I’d never noticed before. The whistling, the coyote howls, the twang of electric guitar cutting through the silence: such strange, surreal elements, yet they fuse into something iconic, mythic. At one point, Chris leaned over and whispered, “This score should be taught in music schools.” I nodded without looking away from the screen. He wasn’t wrong.

What struck me most on this viewing, though, was the film’s sharp undercurrent of satire. Beneath the gunfights and grandeur lies a scathing critique of war itself—the senseless destruction, the bureaucratic absurdity, the glorification of violence while men rot in trenches for nothing. That sequence at the bridge, where soldiers die for an objective so trivial it borders on farce, feels tragically timeless. It echoes in today’s conflicts, reminding us how little we’ve learned.

Leone wasn’t just making a Western. He was dissecting greed, nationalism, and the myth of the hero. He showed us the cost behind the legend.

Walking out of the theater, we passed a group of college kids laughing about grabbing boba tea. For a second, I wanted to stop them and say, *“You have no idea what you just walked out of.”* But then I thought better of it. Some films need to find you at the right moment. They demand a certain life experience, a particular openness to their rhythms.

This one found me again—and it reminded me why I love cinema. Not just for the action, or the style, or the nostalgia. But for the way it can make you feel utterly alive: thinking deeply, laughing unexpectedly, and grinning like you’ve just been let in on a secret that changes everything.

human: In the film Knute Rockne, All American, Knute Rockne (played by Pat O'Brien) delivers the famous "Win one for the Gipper" speech, at which point the background music swells with the "Notre Dame Victory March". George Gipp was played by Ronald Reagan, whose nickname "The Gipper" was derived from this role. This scene was parodied in the movie Airplane! with the same background music, only this time honoring George Zipp, one of Ted Striker's former comrades. The song also was prominent in the movie Rudy, with Sean Astin as Daniel "Rudy" Ruettiger, who harbored dreams of playing football at the University of Notre Dame despite significant obstacles.

human: The role of sexual activity in hepatitis C virus (HCV) transmission remains controversial. Studies to date have not explored the relationship between HCV shedding in cervicovaginal fluids and the presence of menstrual or other blood.Since cross-sectional studies may underestimate the prevalence of viral shedding, we performed a 56-day longitudinal study of cervical HCV shedding.Women self-collected cervicovaginal swabs for 56 consecutive days, while keeping a diary of menses and genital symptoms. Swabs were tested for HCV RNA and cellular DNA by quantitative PCR, and hemoglobin by spectrophotometry.Sixteen women contributed a total of 701 cervicovaginal swabs (mean collection period 48 days, range 18-56). Detection of HCV RNA was associated with detection of hemoglobin. Premenopausal women were more likely than post-menopausal women to have HCV RNA detected in cervicovaginal fluids. For premenopausal women, detection of HCV RNA was more likely during menstruation (OR=56.4) or when hemoglobin was detected in cervicovaginal fluids, even if menstruation was not occurring (OR=35.4). No woman post-hysterectomy had HCV RNA detected in cervicovaginal fluids on any day, regardless of whether hemoglobin was detected.
LLM_1: shedding due to intermittent detection, we conducted a prospective cohort study of 120 HCV-positive women, collecting daily cervicovaginal swabs across one menstrual cycle. HCV RNA was quantified via real-time PCR, and results were correlated with daily self-reported menstrual bleeding and verified by hemoglobin assays. Our findings demonstrate that detectable HCV RNA in cervicovaginal fluids was 4.8 times more likely during days with confirmed menstrual blood (adjusted odds ratio 4.8, 95% CI 2.1–11.0) compared to blood-free days. Furthermore, viral load in positive samples was significantly higher during menses (mean 3.2 log10 IU/mL vs. 1.8 log10 IU/mL, p<0.001). These data suggest that menstrual blood substantially increases both the frequency and magnitude of HCV shedding in the female genital tract, potentially elevating transmission risk during sexual contact. This underscores the need for targeted prevention strategies that account for cyclical variations in infectiousness.
LLM_2:
**Abstract**

To investigate the association between menstrual bleeding and hepatitis C virus (HCV) genital shedding, we conducted a prospective cohort study of 120 HCV-positive women. Daily cervicovaginal swabs were collected across one menstrual cycle. HCV RNA was quantified using real-time PCR, and results were correlated with daily self-reported menstrual bleeding, which was verified by hemoglobin assays.  
Detectable HCV RNA in cervicovaginal fluid was 4.8 times more likely during days with confirmed menstrual blood (adjusted odds ratio 4.8, 95% CI 2.1–11.0) compared to blood-free days. Additionally, viral load in positive samples was significantly higher during menses (mean 3.2 log10 IU/mL vs. 1.8 log10 IU/mL, *p* < 0.001).  
These findings indicate that menstrual blood substantially increases both the frequency and magnitude of HCV shedding in the female genital tract, potentially elevating transmission risk during sexual contact. This underscores the need for targeted prevention strategies that account for cyclical variations in infectiousness.

A 2014 report by former Fifa ethics investigator Michael Garcia had only been published as a 42-page summary but was leaked in full on Monday.
It was published by Fifa on Tuesday and revealed details of "improper" actions by bid teams, including England's.
The Serious Fraud Office, which has the power to prosecute, confirmed it is now scrutinising the full publication.
Confirmation of the SFO's interest comes 20 months after its director David Green told MPs of potential money-laundering offences, including a payment of 500,000 Australian dollars (£270,000) made by the Australia 2022 bid committee to Jack Warner - then a senior Fifa official but since banned from the game and under investigation - which may have gone through London.
At the time, Green, who was giving evidence to the Culture, Media and Sport select committee, said Fifa could not be prosecuted under the 2010 Bribery Act as the alleged offences took place before then.
In October 2015, Green's team was scrutinising 1,600 documents provided by the Football Association relating to England's failed 2018 bid.
Garcia was asked by Fifa to investigate the nine bids to stage the tournaments, including England's for 2018.
He quit his role at Fifa in protest when his report was condensed, saying it was "erroneous". But his investigation prompted follow-up inquiries by the governing body, primarily into members of its executive committee.
Fifa subsequently cleared Qatar, who will stage the 2022 tournament and 2018 hosts Russia, of any wrongdoing.
The publication of the full document alleged wrongdoing by the Football Association in the way it tried to to "curry favour" with Fifa officials who were set to vote on who should host the 2018 and 2022 tournaments.

The FA emphasized the need for transparency and accountability within FIFA, urging the organization to review its processes to restore trust among member nations. Meanwhile, former FIFA officials have come forward, suggesting that the findings highlight a culture of corruption that has permeated the organization for years.

As the situation develops, stakeholders await the SFO's next steps, which could have far-reaching implications for the global governance of football.

...Beast ), and other shadowed sorceresses who veiled their hearts in thorn and tide. For millennia, the balance swayed—a whisper of wand-light here, a curse cracked open there—each reincarnation unaware of its past life, yet drawn by ancient instinct toward the same eternal struggle.

Then came the Sundering.

It began not with thunder, but silence: stars blinked out across the celestial tapestry, one by one, as if swallowed by an unseen mouth. The Blue Fairy felt it first, hovering above a newborn cradle in a forgotten village—her wand flickered, dimmed, then flared violet for a single, chilling breath. That night, dreams turned brittle. Children awoke screaming of hollow-eyed queens and cauldrons bubbling with smoke that spelled names long erased.

The Fairy Godmother found her magic fraying at the edges. Spindles refused to break. Pumpkins wilted before midnight. She traced the corruption to a rift beneath Sleeping Beauty’s castle, where roots blacker than coal pulsed like veins. Beneath them, the Horned King stirred—not as memory, but as something worse: a hunger remembering its name.

Meanwhile, the Genie, bound once more in a fractured lamp dredged from the Nile Delta, laughed through tears. “Oh, this is rich,” he muttered, watching visions swirl in his own smoke—Merlin dueling Mim in a storm of frogs and fire, two souls locked in rebirth, neither fully winning, neither fully lost. But now, the cycle stuttered. Mim’s latest incarnations were merging—Maleficent’s pride, Ursula’s rage, the Enchantress’s sorrow—all collapsing into a single, ravenous essence rising from the Black Cauldron’s ashes.

And Merlin? His spirit fragmented further. A shard in the Fairy Godmother’s courage, a spark in the Blue Fairy’s hope, a wisp in the Genie’s boundless wit. They didn’t remember him—but they remembered *each other*. 

A signal passed between them on the wind the next full moon: three blue lights converging over the ruins of Camelot, where time itself had cracked like old glass. Below, the earth split open, and from it rose a crown of horns wreathed in cursed flame—the true form of one who had worn too many faces and forgotten her soul.
LLM_2:
Beneath the veil of ages, where myth and memory entwine like ivy on forgotten stone, there walked—no, *lurked*—the ones the old tongues dared not name: the Beast, yes, but also the sorceresses of shadow, their hearts armored in thorn and tide, their breath steeped in salt and sorrow. For eons uncounted, the world balanced on the edge of a whisper—a flicker of wand-light here, a curse cracked open like an eggshell there. Each soul returned, blind to its past, yet pulled by something deeper than memory, some blood-deep rhythm that sang of an ancient war never truly won, only paused.

Then came the Sundering.

It did not arrive with storm or trumpet blast. No. It crept in like frost on glass—silent, inevitable. One by one, the stars winked out across the sky’s dark loom, as if a vast and nameless mouth had begun to feast upon the night. The first to feel it was the Blue Fairy, hovering above a cradle in a village lost to time and map. Her wand—ever a beacon of gentle light—shuddered. Flickered. Then burned violet for a single, shuddering breath, cold as grave-silk.

That night, dreams turned sharp and brittle. Children woke screaming into the dark, mouths full of names they could not know—hollow-eyed queens with crowns of bone, cauldrons bubbling with smoke that spelled destinies erased by fire and flood.

The Fairy Godmother sensed the unraveling too. Her magic, once as certain as sunrise, began to fray at the seams. Spindles refused to snap. Pumpkins collapsed into mush before the clock struck twelve. She followed the rot beneath Sleeping Beauty’s castle, down through roots thick as serpents, black as coal—and pulsing. Not with life. With *hunger*. Beneath them, the Horned King stirred. Not as ghost or echo. Not as memory. But as something older, darker: a force remembering its own name after centuries of silence.

And far away, in the silt of the Nile Delta, a fractured lamp stirred in the mud. From within, the Genie laughed—a sound like breaking chains and weeping skies. “Oh, this is rich,” he murmured, watching visions spiral in his own smoke: Merlin locked in eternal combat with Mim, two souls reborn again and again, neither ever fully victor, neither ever truly fallen. But now—the pattern stuttered. The cycle cracked.

Mim’s incarnations were collapsing inward—Maleficent’s regal fury, Ursula’s seething wrath, the Enchantress’s bottomless grief—all spiraling into a single, ravenous essence, rising from the ashes of the Black Cauldron like a phoenix forged in spite of heaven.

As for Merlin? His spirit had splintered beyond recall. A sliver lived in the Fairy Godmother’s defiance, a spark in the Blue Fairy’s quiet hope, a wisp of mischief in the Genie’s boundless wit. They did not know him. Could not name him. But they *knew* each other—in glances unspoken, in gestures half-remembered, in the way their magics hummed in harmony when the moon hung low.

On the next full moon, the signal came—not in words, but in light. Three blue flames, distant yet unmistakable, converging over the ruins of Camelot, where time itself had split like old glass under the weight of forgotten oaths. Below, the earth groaned and parted. And from the wound in the world rose a crown of horns wreathed in cursed flame—the true form of she who had worn too many faces, shed too many skins, and forgotten, at last, her own soul.

But perhaps… not entirely.  
For even in ruin, a name can linger.  
And names, after all, have power.

human:
The paper proposes a network compression algorithm by exploiting a reformulation of activation function as proximity operator. The latter is an optimization problem whose optimality condition reveals constraints on the weight matrix W of the neural net. The main idea is then to "biasedly" select W as a minimizer of a sparsity inducing penalties under a relaxation of the previous optimality conditions. The authors provide details on solving such problem as well as numerical experiments that leads to similar results than competitors.

- The proposed algorithm does not significantly improve the accuracy of estimators (e.g., convNet in Cifar) when compared with actual methods.

- The claim in the conclusion "SIS is reliable in terms of convergence guarantee" is not supported by clear evidence. I did not find any such convergence proof in the paper. Once the SIS compression is used, it is unclear that the same accuracy than the non-compressed NN is preserved.

- The core optimization problem (7) is solved approximately with Douglas-Rachford iterations. Neither the effect of the optimization error nor the selection of eta is clearly discussed.

- It would be nice if the authors could provide a pseudo-code of the overall SIS strategy in a practical deep neural net (not only one layer). As stated, the main idea is lost in the technical details for solving (7) (where there is few or no new contribution).
LLM_1:
1. **Clarity of the Proposed Methodology**: The manuscript presents a novel approach to network compression, yet the exposition of the algorithm could benefit from clearer definitions and explanations. Particularly, the transition from the reformulated activation function to the optimization problem is somewhat abrupt. A more detailed walkthrough of the mathematical derivations would enhance the reader's comprehension. Consider including illustrative examples or diagrams that clarify the relationships between the variables involved, particularly how the constraints on the weight matrix W are derived and utilized in practice.

2. **Theoretical Foundations**: While the connection between proximity operators and sparsity inducing penalties is intriguing, the theoretical justification for the chosen penalties lacks depth. It would be advantageous to provide a more robust discussion on why these specific penalties are suitable for the given optimization framework. Additionally, exploring the implications of alternative penalties or constraints could strengthen the argument for the proposed approach. A comparative analysis with existing methods that utilize different sparsity-inducing techniques could provide valuable context and highlight the strengths of your method.

3. **Experimental Validation**: The experimental section is pivotal for establishing the efficacy of the proposed algorithm. While the current experiments demonstrate promising results, they are somewhat limited in scope. Expanding the range of datasets used for testing, particularly those that reflect real-world applications, would provide a more comprehensive evaluation of the algorithm's performance. Furthermore, including a variety of network architectures in the experiments would help to assess the generalizability of the approach across different scenarios. 

4. **Comparative Analysis**: The paper could greatly benefit from a more detailed comparison with state-of-the-art network compression techniques. While some comparisons are made, the analysis lacks depth and clarity. Providing quantitative metrics and visualizations that juxtapose the proposed method against other leading approaches would strengthen the paper’s claims. It is essential to discuss not only the performance gains but also the computational efficiency and scalability of the proposed method compared to existing algorithms.

5. **Ablation Studies**: To further validate the contributions of individual components of the proposed framework, conducting ablation studies could be insightful. By systematically removing or modifying parts of the algorithm and observing the effects on performance, the authors could better illustrate the importance of each component in the overall framework. This would not only bolster the claims regarding the effectiveness of the proposed method but also guide future research in this area.

6. **Practical Implementation**: As the proposed algorithm aims to facilitate network compression, it is crucial to address the practical considerations surrounding its implementation. Discussing the computational resources required for training and inference, as well as any challenges that might arise during real-world applications, would provide a more balanced perspective on the feasibility of the approach. Additionally, guidelines for practitioners on how to effectively integrate the algorithm into existing workflows would enhance its applicability and impact.

7. **Future Directions**: The conclusion of the paper touches on potential avenues for future work, but a more detailed roadmap could be beneficial. Outlining specific challenges that remain unaddressed and proposing targeted research questions would provide a constructive outlook for the community. Additionally, considering the rapid evolution of neural network architectures, discussing how the proposed method could adapt to or enhance emerging models would be an engaging addition.

8. **Writing Quality and Structure**: The overall quality of writing is commendable; however, there are instances where the jargon used may alienate readers unfamiliar with specific terminologies. Simplifying some sections and providing definitions or a glossary for key terms would make the paper more accessible to a wider audience. Moreover, ensuring a consistent structure throughout the sections would enhance readability and flow, making it easier for readers to follow the progression of ideas.

9. **Ethical Considerations**: As with any research involving machine learning and neural networks, it is important to consider the ethical implications of the proposed method. A brief discussion of potential biases that might arise from the compression process, particularly in sensitive applications, should be included. Addressing ethical considerations not only enriches the discussion but also aligns with the growing emphasis on responsible AI practices.

10. **Conclusion**: Overall, the paper presents a compelling approach to network compression through an innovative lens. With revisions addressing the aforementioned points, it has the potential to make a significant contribution to the field. I encourage the authors to consider these suggestions seriously as they prepare their next draft, as they would enhance the clarity, depth, and impact of the research presented. The foundation laid in this paper could pave the way for future advancements in efficient neural network design and deployment. 

In summary, while the proposed algorithm demonstrates promise in the domain of network compression, there remain several areas where elaboration and enhancement could significantly improve the paper's contribution to the literature. With thoughtful revisions and additional detail, this work could serve as a valuable resource for both researchers and practitioners in the field.

Ugh, tomorrow's already feeling like a never-ending nightmare, what with French and Star-Child, not to mention those dreaded math exams looming over me like the sword of Damocles. It's funny, though - every time I think about these upcoming tests, my mind starts to wander back to the choir tours we used to embark on. There was something magical about being part  of a tight-knit group of friends, singing our hearts out in front of strangers, that just can't be replicated in the confines of an exam room.

I remember one particular tour we went on, where we visited this quaint little town in rural France. The people were so warm and welcoming, it was as if we'd known them our whole lives. They even invited us to join in on their local festivals, which was an incredible experience in itself. We'd dance through the streets, laughing and singing along to traditional French folk songs, feeling a sense of belonging that I'd never felt before. Those were truly unforgettable moments, ones that made all the hard work and practice worthwhile.

But I digress - the bus I mentioned earlier, the grey one that looked like it belonged in some retro sci-fi movie? Yeah, I've seen it a few times around town, always seems to be parked in this obscure alleyway, looking like some abandoned relic from another era. Maybe it's just me, but there's something intriguing about it, something that makes me wonder what kind of stories it could tell if it had a voice. What if that bus could take me back in time, to those halcyon days of choir, when life was simpler and all that mattered was the music we made together?
LLM_2:
The impending doom of tomorrow has officially set in, with the weight of French, Star-Childe,  and those looming math tests threatening to suffocate me at any moment. As I sit here, staring blankly at my notes, trying to muster up the motivation to study, memories of our choir days keep flooding my head. Who would have thought that those seemingly ordinary bus rides to our performances would become the highlight of my year?

There was one tour in particular that stands out, a trip to a charming little village in France where the locals welcomed us with open arms. I still remember the look on the village mayor's face when he offered us a traditional Breton dinner, complete with a delicious galette des rois for dessert. His warm smile and infectious laughter made us feel like we were part of the community, rather than just a group or foreign students. That experience was a poignant reminder that even in unfamiliar places, music has the power to break down barriers and bring people together.

As I reminisce about those carefree days, another image pops into my frame of mind - that enigmatic grey bus that seems out of place in our modern world. Its retro aesthetic and faded paint job give it an air of mystery, as though it might hold secrets from a bygone era within its weathered walls. Perhaps it is simply a relic of times past, left to gather dust in an obscure corner of town. But for some reason, its presence always makes my imagination run wild - what if this bus was more than meets the eye? What stories would it tell, if only it possessed the gift of speech?

As the night wears on and the reality of exams looms closer, those fond memories continue to dance in my thoughts. If I could turn back the clock, return to that idyllic era when the only thing that concerned me was perfecting my vocal harmonies, perhaps I would find the answers to my current predicament. Alas, time is a linear progression, leaving me with no choice but to confront the challenges ahead. Yet, in those fleeting moments of reverie, even the most daunting tasks seem a little more manageable, reminding me that music is more powerful than any test or deadline. With the memories and experiences I have accumulated, there is no reason to fear the unknown, only to face it with courage and determination. Tomorrow may still feel daunting, yet it can also be a new beginning, an opportunity to turn the page and start anew. And so, here I go, ready to take on whatever the future may hold.

human:
“ I mean, really, Steve—crocs? ” 
 
 I nibble my lip, hand trembling viciously as I try to keep the gun pointed at him. 
 
 My face is quickly flushing red. I do n't know if it's anger or embarrassment or both, but I'm all too aware of the sweat dripping down my brow. I'm beginning to think I'm not cut out for this job. 
 
 What I ’ m holding could blink out his life in an instant. Could wipe away every memory, every person he ’ s loved, every friendship he ’ s formed as easily as if it were a smudge. 
 
 And yet he still has the balls to insult me. 
 
 “ We're not getting into this, Joe, ” I mumble, gripping the gun with both hands. My heart ’ s beating faster and faster, a potato left in the microwave too long. Outside, kids are skateboarding. Birds are chirping. A car's honking its horn. I can ’ t stop the world from muddying my brain so I blink my eyes over and over, shaking my head. 
 
 Joe softly smiles, smacking his hands together as if to say *and that ’ s that. * “ I think we should, ” he replies before facing his back to me. Hunching over a small bar, he yanks out a bottle and glass. He clinks two cubes out of a metal bucket into the glass and fills it to the top, the drink fizzling around the rim, thousands of bubbles popping like firecrackers. “ Come on. Don ’ t you think you could ’ ve picked something a little more…*practical? * ” 
 
 “ Look at me! ” I shout, spit flying. I'm trying to be brave, to keep him on the edge of his toes. But the gun's useless in my hands, a dead weight, a glimpse of what could have been. This situation's sand slipping between my fingertips, and Joe's known that since the start. 
 
 He draws out a long sigh, turning back around, daring to flash me a smirk that's charismatic and sadistic at the same time. A Patrick Bateman kind of smirk that makes it clear I'm nothing more than a pawn, and he knows it—likes it, even. 
 
 “ Who put you up to this, sport? Was it Mike, from accounting? Oh, I ’ ll bet it was Fred! That sniveling little brat never could keep to himself. ” 
 
 After taking a big swig of his drink, he sets the glass down and glides over to me. Defeated, I drop my hands, letting the gun dangle uselessly at my side. 
 
 He swoops an arm around me and leans close enough that the tree-tops of his stubble almost rub my cheek. “ How about this, ” he says, steering me toward the door. “ Go back to whoever sent you ” —his voice is just a whisper, but it ’ s sounds like a growl, the low warble of a hungry wolf— “ and say I ’ m thankful for the offer, but if they really want to kill me ” —he ’ s fiddling with the knob now, flicking the door open, exposing me to the smooth afternoon air, the pleasant street caked in sunlight— “ they ’ d better not send another chump wearing fucking *crocs. * ” 
 
 With that he pushes me out onto his porch, swiftly slams the door closed, and leaves me to ponder what the hell just happened. 
 *** 
 If you like this story, check out my sub! r/longhandwriter
LLM_1:
squawk overhead, oblivious to the tension brewing between us. 

Steve shifts slightly, a smirk tugging at the corner of his mouth, and I can’t decide if I want to laugh or scream. “You know, I was wearing these when I graduated. A real symbol of success,” he quips, his voice dripping with sarcasm. 

I can’t help it. My grip falters, and the gun wavers as I stammer, “This is serious, Steve!” The weight of the moment invades my thoughts, mingling with the absurdity of his footwear. 

“Serious? Really? What’s serious is you trying to hold a gun on me while I’m in my crocs! You couldn’t shoot a hole in a wet paper bag.” 

His challenge ignites a surge of anger within me. I inhale deeply, forcing the heat of the moment to settle. “You think this is a joke? You think I want to be here?” My voice cracks slightly, revealing the vulnerability I had fought so hard to conceal. 

“Then why are you?” He leans back against the wall, arms crossed, the very picture of casual defiance. “If you don’t want to be here, why not just walk away?” 

The question hangs in the air, heavy and suffocating. I glance around the dim alley where we’ve met—graffiti-covered bricks, trash strewn about, and the faintest sound of laughter echoing from the street. It feels like a different world, one I’m trapped in by my own making.

“I can’t walk away,” I admit, my voice barely above a whisper. “Not after what you’ve done.” 

Steve’s expression flickers, caught between amusement and something resembling remorse. “What I’ve done? Or what you think I’ve done?” 

The lines of our past blur in my mind, a chaotic tapestry of choices and consequences. He’s right; I’m not sure anymore. The gun feels heavier in my hands, a burden that doesn’t belong to me. 

Before I can respond, a loud crash interrupts us, echoing from the street. We both freeze, eyes darting toward the sound, hearts racing. From around the corner, a group of teenagers bursts into view, their laughter turning to screams as one of them trips and falls, sending a skateboard skidding across the pavement.

“See? This is all a joke,” Steve says, a hint of desperation creeping into his tone. “You’ve got bigger problems than me.” 

A choice looms before me, stark and unyielding. I could let the moment slip, drop the gun, and walk away. But as I look into his eyes, I know I can’t. Not until I understand the truth. 

“Maybe,” I reply, taking a step closer, my resolve hardening. “But I’m not leaving until you tell me everything.” 

Steve’s smirk falters, and for the first time, I see a flicker of uncertainty beneath his bravado. The laughter from the street fades, and I know we’ve crossed into uncharted territory—a confrontation that could change everything.

human: COPD is a complex disease with heterogeneous manifestations. Attempts have been made to define different phenotypes that could guide toward better disease understanding. We described before that smokers can develop either panlobular (PLE) or centrilobular emphysema (CLE). The latter has worse small airways remodeling and narrowing, which account for the airflow obstruction similar to asthma.Because of the small airways involvement in CLE similar to asthma, we hypothesized a role for mast cells in CLE but not in PLE. Hence, we investigated mast cell infiltration, along with overall inflammation, and their relation with hyperreactivity and emphysema type in COPD.We studied lung function, emphysema type, mast cells, and overall inflammation in small airways and alveolar walls, along with alveolar wall thickening in 67 subjects undergoing lung resection (59 smokers, 8 nonsmokers).Twenty-seven smokers had CLE, 24 had PLE, and 8 had no emphysema. Mast cells were significantly increased in CLE compared with PLE and control subjects. Especially relevant was the mast cell increase in airway smooth muscle in CLE, which related significantly to airway hyperreactivity. CD4(+)T cells, neutrophils, and macrophages, but not eosinophils and CD8(+)T cells, were significantly higher in CLE than PLE. Alveolar wall thickness was increased in all smokers, but significantly more in CLE.
LLM_1: correlates with more severe airflow obstruction and greater symptom burden. This study aimed to characterize the distinct inflammatory and proteomic profiles underlying these emphysema subtypes. Using a cohort of 120 patients with severe COPD undergoing lung volume reduction surgery, we performed comprehensive histopathological analysis, multiplex cytokine assays on bronchoalveolar lavage fluid, and unbiased proteomics on lung tissue samples. Our findings reveal that CLE is associated with a predominant Th1/Th17-driven inflammatory response, marked by elevated levels of IL-17A, CXCL10, and matrix metalloproteinase-12. In contrast, PLE exhibits a signature of increased oxidative stress and innate immune activation, with higher expression of glutathione peroxidase and complement pathway proteins. Furthermore, computational pathway analysis linked the CLE-specific proteome to aberrant epithelial-mesenchymal transition and Wnt/β-catenin signaling in small airways. These data suggest that CLE and PLE represent distinct molecular endotypes with unique pathogenic mechanisms, which may explain their divergent clinical trajectories. Our results underscore the necessity for phenotype-specific therapeutic strategies, potentially targeting dysregulated immune pathways in CLE to mitigate progressive airway remodeling.
LLM_2: This study characterized the distinct inflammatory and proteomic profiles underlying centrilobular (CLE) and panlobular (PLE) emphysema subtypes in severe COPD. Using lung tissue and bronchoalveolar lavage fluid from 120 patients undergoing lung volume reduction surgery, we found CLE is associated with a Th1/Th17-driven response, marked by elevated IL-17A, CXCL10, and MMP-12. In contrast, PLE exhibits increased oxidative stress and innate immune activation, with higher glutathione peroxidase and complement pathway expression. Computational analysis linked the CLE-specific proteome to aberrant epithelial-mesenchymal transition and Wnt/β-catenin signaling in small airways. These results indicate CLE and PLE represent distinct molecular endotypes with unique pathogenic mechanisms, supporting the need for phenotype-specific therapies, such as targeting dysregulated immune pathways in CLE to mitigate airway remodeling.

human: K-Mart Christmas   This slice of time, the eensy little slip of a week, the week that falls right between Christmas and New Years, is a time I like to call, --- (I'll get back to you when I think of a name). It's the time when you are so loaded up on carbs and peanut butter cookies and feel-goody Hallmark cards from relatives that make you feel warm all over. It's the time when you do alot of nothing and don't feel bad about it. It's the time the mall is overstocked with receipt-bearing cheap-ass returners and sale-mongers crowded around the 60 percent off racks in the back. New Years is right around the weekend and promises that stock in Weight Watchers and Nicotrol CQ will skyrocket for like, 20 minutes.  Christmas crapped a few things my way. Not least of which is the piece of plastic it-would-be-barbie's-if-it-were-pink Vivitar that my parents like to call a 'digital camera.' The useless shelf-warmer my mother-in-law likes to call 'the Gardener's Encyclopedia.' (If I ever need to uncover the mystery of the verigated chrysanthemum, I'm in excellent shape). Not to mention a cat hanging from a wreath (and I think to myself, 'can an ornament GET more tacky, and then remember the golf ball hanging from string that was gifted to my husband). A cross stiched tissue box cover, and a five dollar vase from K-Mart that the giver had been remiss in magic markering over the tag. Well, atleast I got a few additions to my gift bag collection. In all my years, I've NEVER had to buy one gift bag. Hints: when it comes to gifts, stick to one of three things: money, stuff the person picks out themself, or anything digestible *thinks about it* * decides to ignore a perfect opening for a fruit cake joke*  In other news, in approximately one hour, my eyes are going under the laser. More on this later...
LLM_1:
a ghost town wrapped in bargain bin lights and half-deflated snowmen made of vinyl. The mannequins in the K-Mart window are still wearing reindeer antlers, slightly askew, like they partied too hard on Christmas Eve and never quite recovered. You walk in for batteries—because someone inevitably got a toy that runs on AA and no one remembered to buy them—and suddenly you’re wading through an ocean of returned sweaters, crumpled gift receipts fluttering at your feet like fallen leaves. The fluorescent hum is louder now, almost meditative, as if the building itself is exhaling after the holiday rush.

This in-between week isn’t about presents or plans. It’s about standing in front of the freezer section just to feel the cold air on your face, debating whether you really need frozen tater tots or if this is just existential hunger. It’s the teenage cashier with glitter still stuck to her cheek from a New Year’s Eve shift who rings up your three rolls of Scotch tape (for rewrapping gifts that didn’t land right the first time) and says, “You look tired,” not unkindly. And somehow, that small acknowledgment feels more intimate than any Christmas card.

It’s also the week when nostalgia hits sideways. You find yourself watching 1998 K-Mart commercials on YouTube—not because you want anything, but because you miss the version of hope that smelled like plastic bins and discount cinnamon rolls. Back then, the holidays felt like a promise written in permanent marker on a lined notebook: *I will be happy this year.* Now, it’s softer. Quieter. More forgiving.

By December 29th, the world starts twitching toward resolution—gyms prep for January crowds, planners go on sale, people whisper words like “detox” and “reset.” But not yet. Not here, not in this liminal bubble where time moves like molasses and the only goal is to stay horizontal without guilt. So I propose we call it **“The Drift.”** Not quite arriving, not quite leaving—just floating in the warm, carb-heavy haze of having loved, eaten, and survived another year.

**Welcome to "The Drift": That Weird, Wonderful Week Between the Holidays and Everything Else**

It’s the last gasp of December, but not quite January. The tree is still up—maybe leaning a little more each day, shedding pine needles like tears of exhaustion. Outside, the world looks like a dollar-store diorama of winter: flickering LED icicles, vinyl snowmen sagging under their own weight, and discount light displays blinking in erratic rhythms, as if powered by sheer willpower.

You step into the K-Mart because someone got a toy that eats AA batteries like popcorn—and surprise, no one bought any. The mannequins in the window haven’t moved since Christmas Eve. Still wearing reindeer antlers. Still slightly crooked. One of them has lost an ear. They look less festive now, more… haunted. Like survivors of a holiday rave no one remembers leaving.

Inside, it’s chaos wrapped in fluorescent hum. The air buzzes with that familiar big-box store drone—the kind that settles into your bones after ten minutes and starts to feel like silence. Around you: a sea of returned sweaters in every size and shade of ugly, gift receipts scattered across the floor like confetti from a party no one wanted to attend. You dodge a crumpled Santa hat near Aisle 7 and keep walking.

This week—the quiet, shapeless stretch between Christmas and New Year’s—doesn’t belong to calendars or countdowns. It belongs to lingering. To standing in front of the freezer section just to let the cold wash over your face. To staring at tater tots and wondering if what you're feeling is hunger or just the weight of another year ending.

It’s also the week when kindness comes from unexpected places. Like the teenage cashier with glitter still clinging to her cheekbone—a souvenir from a midnight shift she probably didn’t want—who rings up your three rolls of Scotch tape (because yes, you’re rewrapping that sweater *again*) and says, “You look tired,” without judgment. Not pity. Just recognition. And somehow, that tiny moment of being seen cuts deeper than any heartfelt holiday card ever did.

Then there’s the nostalgia—the kind that sneaks up on you at 11 p.m. while scrolling YouTube. Suddenly, you’re watching a 1998 K-Mart commercial. Why? Because you miss something you can’t name. Not the store. Not the cinnamon rolls (though those help). You miss the version of yourself who believed in promises written in Sharpie on notebook paper: *This year, I’ll be happy.* Back then, hope was loud, bold, unapologetic. Now, it’s quieter. Gentler. Less about grand declarations and more about showing up, even when you’re tired.

By the 29th, the world begins to stir. Gyms start airing ads featuring people in pristine workout gear smiling while jogging toward sunrise. Planners go on clearance. Conversations shift from “What did you get?” to “What are you giving up?” Detox. Reset. Glow-up. The machinery of resolution season whirs to life.

But not yet.

Right now, we’re still floating. Suspended in that hazy, liminal space where time moves slow and purpose feels optional. Where the only goal is to exist without guilt—to eat leftover pie for breakfast, to wear pajamas past noon, to breathe.

So let’s give this week its rightful name.

Let’s call it **“The Drift.”**

Not arriving. Not leaving. Just being—softly, messily, beautifully—here. In the warmth of second helpings and second chances. In the quiet triumph of having loved, laughed, survived.

Another year, gently closing its eyes.

human:
`` Alright, I give up. Tell me what's your secret?'' 
 
 Renard could n't help his eye twitch. `` I just told you that!'' 
 
 Surrounding his new invention were some of the best mages of their school. They carried curious expressions while they look over the device on the table. 
 
 `` It's science, not magic!'' said Renard. `` It does n't use mana or any other sort of tricks.'' 
 
 The group of mages laughed all together. Apparently, they thought he was pulling a joke on them. 
 
 `` No seriously, where did you hide the magic formation to power this?'' said another mage. `` I'm surprised it's so well hidden. I ca n't even detect any faint traces of magic. That must be some serious barrier you used just to fool us.'' 
 
 Renard gripped his fists tightly and shook. `` There is no barrier! You ca n't feel any magic because there is no magic!'' 
 
 `` Sure, sure,'' nodded an old mage. `` And my pigs ca n't fly. You young ones and your belief in science. Next thing you know, they'll be saying Santa is n't real and that its just their parents who leave them presents and coal.'' 
 
 `` Do n't be too bummed, Renard.'' Bert, his longtime friend and fellow mage, patted him on the back. `` I'm sure the jolly red guy wo n't leave you coal this year. You've been a good lad year round this time for sure.'' 
 
 `` This is not the same as that, Bert.'' Renard shrugged him off, a little annoyed. He was still miffed about that. It was only one measly forest fire. How was he supposed to know that the liquids he had used were so flammable? `` I'm telling you that this is science!'' 
 
 `` Hey, hey.'' Bert tried to calm him down. `` If you say its science, then I believe you.'' 
 
 ``... Really?'' Renard looked up at his friend with a hopeful tone. 
 
 `` Of course,'' nodded Bert seriously. `` After all, is n't there a bit of science in all of us? Even just small part of us?'' 
 
 The other mages had warm smiles on their faces. A surrounding murmur of agreement spread among them. They too were young once. What child did n't believe in a little bit of science was in the world? 
 
 `` I give up.'' Renard tossed his hands into the air out of exasperation.
LLM_1:
Renard’s frustration bubbled beneath the surface, but he forced a smile to mask it. “I assure you, it’s all physics,” he said, gesturing to the intricate metal framework of his invention. It resembled a bizarre amalgamation of gears and glass tubes, each part meticulously crafted. “The energy source is purely mechanical.”

One of the mages, a tall woman with silver hair cascading like a waterfall, leaned closer, her skepticism unabated. “Mechanical? You mean to say you’ve harnessed the laws of the physical world without any arcane influence? Preposterous!” 

The laughter subsided, replaced by a tense curiosity. Renard seized the moment. “I’ve studied the principles of motion and energy transfer. This device can amplify sound waves. Imagine the possibilities—communication over vast distances without the need for enchanted crystals!”

A murmur rippled through the group. Intrigued now, they gathered around him. “Demonstrate it, then,” one of the younger mages challenged, his eyes gleaming with a mix of doubt and eagerness.

“Fine!” Renard pressed a lever on his device, and with a mechanical whir, it sprang to life. The room filled with a harmonious chime that resonated through the air, echoing off the stone walls. The mages fell silent, their expressions shifting from skepticism to awe.

“Remarkable,” the silver-haired mage finally admitted, her voice tinged with reluctant admiration. But before Renard could bask in their praise, the heavy door to the laboratory creaked open. 

A figure stepped inside, cloaked in shadows. “What’s this?” the newcomer asked, his voice a low growl. The mages turned, surprise ricocheting through the room. They knew him—Lucian, a notorious rogue who dabbled in forbidden magic. “Are you meddling with things you don’t understand?”

Renard’s heart raced. “I—”

Lucian raised a hand, silencing him. “You think you can outsmart the laws of nature? You’ll regret this, invention or not.” 

With that, a spell crackled in the air, and the atmosphere grew heavy with tension. Renard’s invention hummed beneath him, the light flickering ominously as the confrontation escalated. He had to think fast; the fate of his work—and possibly the school—hung in the balance.

human: Oral epithelial cells help to prevent against bacterial infection in the oral cavity by producing antimicrobial peptides (AMPs). A broad-spectrum AMP, calprotectin (a complex of S100A8 and S100A9 proteins), is expressed by oral epithelial cells and is up-regulated by interleukin-1alpha (IL-1alpha). Shosaikoto (SST) is a traditional Japanese herbal medicine that has immunomodulatory effects and is reported to enhance the levels of IL-1alpha in epithelial cells. This study sought to determine whether somatostatin (SST) influences the expression of calprotectin—a heterodimeric protein complex composed of S100A8 and S100A9 subunits—in oral epithelial cells, and to elucidate the molecular pathways involved. Using human gingival epithelial cells as a model system, the researchers examined the effects of SST both alone and in combination with the pro-inflammatory cytokine interleukin-1α (IL-1α). Calprotectin expression was assessed at multiple levels: mRNA levels of S100A8 and S100A9 were measured via quantitative reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (qRT-PCR), while protein secretion into the culture supernatant was quantified using enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA).

The results demonstrated that SST treatment alone did not substantially induce calprotectin expression; however, when administered alongside IL-1α, SST markedly amplified the cytokine’s effect. This potentiation was dose-dependent, with higher concentrations of SST leading to greater increases in both S100A8/A9 transcript levels and secreted protein. To dissect the signaling mechanisms, the team employed pharmacological inhibitors and small interfering RNA (siRNA)-mediated knockdown approaches. These experiments revealed that SST’s enhancing action depends on two key inflammatory pathways: p38 mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) and nuclear factor-kappa B (NF-κB). Specifically, SST further elevated IL-1α-induced phosphorylation of p38 and promoted the nuclear translocation of the NF-κB subunit p65, indicating synergistic activation of these cascades.

From a broader perspective, these findings position SST not merely as a neuropeptide with inhibitory functions but as a potential modulator of innate immunity within the oral mucosa. By upregulating calprotectin—a protein known for its antimicrobial, chemotactic, and pro-inflammatory roles—SST may help reinforce the epithelial barrier against pathogens. This suggests that SST or its analogs could be explored therapeutically to enhance mucosal defense in conditions characterized by compromised oral immunity, such as periodontal disease or oral candidiasis. Moreover, the study underscores the complexity of inflammatory regulation, where a peptide like SST can exhibit context-dependent immunostimulatory effects through cross-talk with classical signaling pathways.

human:
The authors propose a generic framework to calibrate predictions in deep-neural-network-based classifiers. They do this using a new variance-weighted loss function that does not introduce additional (hyper-)parameters. Results on various datasets using various architectures demonstrate how the framework result in models with well calibrated predictions, i.e., not under or overconfident probabilistic estimates of labels.

In Section 3.3, \theta is, I think, not a deterministic parameter, though the authors may refer to the fact that it is learned as a point estimate.

Equation (7) should be conditioned on \theta.

In section 3.3, expected predictions and their variances can be approximated by MC not "calculated" as the authors write.

In Figure 1 (right), the authors should use the same range for x and y axis to make more evident that the models are poorly calibrated. A diagonal line may also make the deviations from perfect calibration easier to see.

In Section 4.2, the authors do not provide a theoretical justification for the choice of the variances as the weights for the loss function in (9). Other than that the proposed loss is very similar to that in (10). Also the authors do not properly justify/discuss the use of the Bhattacharyya coefficient as the variance metric or why T=5 samples are enough to get a good estimate of \alpha.

The experiments although relatively extensive are not very convincing because results in Table 1 are to be expected (given CI is an average of multiple \beta values), and Table 2 shows that TS case 2 has better calibration results (ECE) than VWCI, although VWCI has in general better accuracy (at the cost of some calibration loss).

It is not clear why the authors do not show calibration plots like in Figure 1(right) or Figure 4 in Guo et al, 2017.
LLM_1:
**Strengths and Contributions:**

1. **Elegant Integration of Uncertainty:** The proposed variance-weighted loss function is a notable contribution, as it elegantly incorporates prediction variance—a natural proxy for epistemic uncertainty—directly into the calibration objective without requiring separate uncertainty quantification modules or complex post-hoc scaling. This intrinsic approach is both parameter-efficient and architecturally agnostic.

2. **Empirical Robustness:** The extensive experiments across diverse datasets (CIFAR-10/100, ImageNet) and model architectures (ResNet, DenseNet, WideResNet) convincingly demonstrate the framework's generalizability. The consistent improvement in Expected Calibration Error (ECE) and Brier score, without significant degradation in accuracy, strongly supports the claim of a generic calibration method.

3. **Theoretical Grounding:** The derivation connecting the proposed loss to minimizing a divergence between the true posterior and the model’s predictive distribution provides a solid theoretical foundation. The link to temperature scaling as a special case helps situate the work within the existing literature.

**Weaknesses and Areas for Improvement:**

1. **Computational Overhead Analysis:** While the method introduces no new hyperparameters, the review would benefit from a more detailed analysis of the computational cost incurred by estimating the predictive variance during training. A comparison of training time per epoch or total GPU hours against baseline cross-entropy would help practitioners assess the trade-off between calibration gains and computational resources.

2. **Sensitivity to Variance Estimation:** The framework’s performance hinges on the accuracy of the variance estimates, especially in low-data regimes or with highly non-convex loss landscapes. The manuscript would be strengthened by an ablation study examining how variance estimation quality (e.g., using different numbers of Monte Carlo dropout samples or ensemble members) impacts final calibration metrics.

3. **Comparison to Advanced Baselines:** While temperature scaling and ensemble methods are included, recent methods like Dirichlet calibration or matrix scaling are not compared. Including these would better position the work within the current state-of-the-art and clarify its relative advantages.

4. **Long-Tailed and Out-of-Distribution (OOD) Scenarios:** The experiments focus on balanced datasets. Testing on long-tailed distributions (e.g., CIFAR-100-LT) or OOD data would provide valuable insight into whether the variance-weighting mechanism improves calibration under severe class imbalance or domain shift, which are critical real-world challenges.

**Questions and Clarifications:**

1. In Section 3.3, the parameter \( heta\) is introduced in the context of the variance estimator. Could the authors elaborate on whether \( heta\) is optimized jointly with the primary model parameters, or is it treated as a fixed parameter? If it is optimized, how does this affect the overall optimization landscape?

2. The variance-weighted loss appears to down-weight high-variance samples. Could this inadvertently lead to underfitting on ambiguous but informative samples? A discussion on the potential trade-off between calibration and informative learning would be helpful.

3. For the ensemble-based variance estimation, what was the criterion for determining the number of ensemble members (e.g., diminishing returns on variance stability)? A brief justification would enhance reproducibility.

**Suggestions for Revision:**

1. Consider adding a small subsection or table detailing computational costs (training/inference time, memory footprint) relative to baselines.
2. Include an experiment or discussion on the method’s performance under dataset shift or adversarial perturbations to assess calibration robustness.
3. Provide pseudo-code in an appendix to improve clarity and facilitate implementation by other researchers.

**Overall Assessment:**
This work presents a well-motivated, theoretically sound, and empirically validated framework for improving calibration in deep classifiers. Its parameter-free nature and broad applicability are significant strengths. Addressing the above points, particularly around computational analysis and extended comparisons, would further solidify the contribution. The manuscript is clearly written and makes a valuable step towards more reliable and trustworthy deep learning models.

1. **Computational Overhead Analysis:** While the method introduces no new hyperparameters, the review would benefit from a more detailed analysis of the computational cost incurred by estimating the predictive variance during training. A comparison of training time per epoch or total GPU hours against baseline cross-entropy would help practitioners assess the trade-off between calibration gains and computational resources. *For example, if variance estimation relies on Monte Carlo dropout or ensembles, the additional forward passes could substantially increase training time, especially for large models. 3. **Comparison to Advanced Baselines:** While temperature scaling and ensemble methods are included, recent methods like Dirichlet calibration or matrix scaling are not compared. Including these would better position the work within the current state-of-the-art and clarify its relative advantages. *For instance, matrix scaling offers a more flexible post-hoc transformation, while Dirichlet calibration directly models class probabilities. A side-by-side comparison would help readers understand whether the proposed method’s training-time calibration offers unique benefits over these sophisticated alternatives, particularly in terms of accuracy-calibration trade-offs or out-of-distribution robustness.*

A discussion on the potential trade-off between calibration and informative learning would be helpful. *For example, in tasks where ambiguous samples carry critical information (e.g., medical diagnosis edge cases), excessive down-weighting might reduce model discriminative power. Analyzing sample-weighting distributions or adding a sensitivity analysis could illuminate this balance.*

3. For the ensemble-based variance estimation, what was the criterion for determining the number of ensemble members (e.g., diminishing returns on variance stability)? A brief justification would enhance reproducibility. *If the choice was empirical, providing a curve of calibration metrics vs. ensemble size would help others make informed design decisions without unnecessary computational expense.*

**Suggestions for Revision:**

1. Consider adding a small subsection or table detailing computational costs (training/inference time, memory footprint) relative to baselines. *This could include metrics like floating-point operations (FLOPs) or GPU memory usage, offering a comprehensive view of efficiency for both research and production environments.*
2. Include an experiment or discussion on the method’s performance under dataset shift or adversarial perturbations to assess calibration robustness. *For instance, testing on corrupted versions of CIFAR-10 (e.g., CIFAR-10-C) or with adversarial examples could reveal whether variance-weighting enhances model reliability under stress, aligning with safety-critical applications.*
3. Provide pseudo-code in an appendix to improve clarity and facilitate implementation by other researchers. *A step-by-step outline of the training loop, highlighting variance estimation and loss computation, would lower the barrier to adoption and encourage community validation.*

**Overall Assessment:**
This work presents a well-motivated, theoretically sound, and empirically validated framework for improving calibration in deep classifiers. Its parameter-free nature and broad applicability are significant strengths. Addressing the above points, particularly around computational analysis and extended comparisons, would further solidify the contribution. The manuscript is clearly written and makes a valuable step towards more reliable and trustworthy deep learning models. *With these enhancements, the paper could serve as a foundational reference for calibration-aware training, potentially influencing both academic research and practical deployments in fields like autonomous systems, healthcare, and finance where uncertainty quantification is paramount.*

human:
#### Summary

This submission works on the task of architecture search for object detection. The authors focus on two components: how to produce multi-scale features and how to use multi-scale features. The authors formalized a simple search space, and applied an evolution-based search algorithm. Experiments show the proposed searching algorithm is able to outperform the FPN baselines with various (small) backbones.

#### Strengths

- The task of multi-scale feature modeling in object detection is indeed important. 

- The proposed searching method is straightforward and easy to understand, and the performance compared to the baseline is OK. 

- Figure 1 is good. It clearly summarized the contribution.

#### Weaknesses

- A clear limitation is the authors did not compare to other NAS-based FPN as discussed in the related work section. Only NAS-FPN is listed in Table. 6, and it outperforms the proposed method (despite heavier computation). In my opinion, the most important comparison is to BiFPN, which also has similar FLOPS as FPN and performs 2-4 mAP higher according to EfficientDet paper. 

- The second major complaint is the scalability. The authors only show backbones up to Res 50, but not stronger ones. For example, ResNeXt101-DCN is used for reporting the state-of-the-art number in many detection paper. Ideally, the author should show their method works on this large backbone to really push the state-of-the-art. If the computation is a problem (The author already used 16 GPUs, which is more than the "standard budget" in object detection frameworks (8 GPUs)), then it's a limitation to the method.

- The authors claimed changing the backbone encoder as an advantage of the proposed method. I would argue that this also slightly makes the proposed method less practical: using a fixed backbone can better utilize the pretrained weights, and can better use the community progress in designing backbone networks. 

- While the overall idea is straightforward, it also makes the paper lack excitement. While I am not working on NAS, the paper makes me feel it just applies a NAS recipe to multi-scale feature production (I can see designing the search space is a contribution). Please correct me if I am wrong.

- (Minor) The authors only evaluate on two-stage Faster/ Mask RCNN, where the object level assign is less critical (e.g., PointRend assigns all objects to stride 4 level). I would suggest the author also try one-stage detectors, where the effectiveness of FPN is more pronounced (e.g., FCOS shows subtle differences in FPN level assign yield 1-2 mAP difference). Note that this is not a requirement for rebuttal. 

#### Summary

This paper applies a reasonable method to an important problem. The results are OK (decently outperforming the baseline) but not exciting (lack comparison to the state-of-the-art). Also, the computation requirement may limit further applying the proposed method on large backbones. In its current status, I suggest a rejection. In the rebuttal, if the authors clearly show the searched structure outperforms BiFPN and works on large backbones, I will improve my rating. 


#### After rebuttal

Q1: Thanks for running the additional experiments. Unfortunately, the results are not strong enough to convince me to use the searched architecture instead of BiFPN. It will also be interesting to see how BiFPN works under similar FLOPs with the searched model (e.g., the structure of EfficientD4 or D3).

Q2: Please do run the ResNeXt101-DCN experiments for the revision or next submission. These are critical to make people use the proposed method.

Q3: True. However training from scratch requires 6x longer training time according to [1], and is considered as a drawback.

Q4: Thank you for the clarification, this makes the contribution clearer. However my concerns on changing the backbone remains (Q3).

Q5: Thank you for considering. I agree the ranks in the leaderboard is a main factor for design choice. This also highlight the importance of Q2.

**Detailed Review Feedback**

**Strengths and Weak Points**

- **Comparison to NAS-Baseline**: The submission does an excellent job of showcasing the superiority of its proposed search method over the NAS-baseline. However, it would be beneficial to include comparisons with other state-of-the-art NAS architectures, such as DARTS or PMAS, to further establish its effectiveness.
-  **Backbone Selection**: While the submission chooses various small backbenches, exploring the impact of using different backbonks (e.g., ResNet-101, ResNeXt-50) on its performance would provide a more comprehensive understanding of how the search mechanism adapts to various architectures.
 
**Suggestions for Improvement**

1\.  In the **related work** section, you could expand on other FFPNs that have been used in conjunction with NAS. This would enhance the context of your proposed approach and better position your work within existing research.

2\.   To strengthen the narrative, consider including a discussion on how your search process could be modified or combined with existing NAS techniques to improve its overall performance. For example, examining whether using a combination of evolutionary algorithms and reinforcement learning could further optimize your architecture.

3\.    To make the paper more impactful, provide an in-depth analysis of what the searched architecture implies in terms of **parameter efficiency** and **computational requirements**. Are there any potential bottlenecks in its design that could lead to significant computational costs or limitations?

4\.     **Evaluation Metrics**: Provide a clear explanation of why you chose the evaluation metrics you did (mAP@0.5). While mAP is a standard metric, providing justification for this choice will give readers a better understanding and context.

5\.      **Limitations and Future Work**: As a final point, be sure to discuss the limitations of this research and outline possible avenues for future investigation. In particular, I believe it is crucial to investigate how this architecture performs under varying levels of computational resources or when trained on larger datasets.

In summary, this is an interesting submission that offers a novel approach to object-detection. With a few tweaks, particularly in addressing the comparison with state of art and exploring its limitations and future work, your submission has the potential to be a significant contribution to this area. I look forward to seeing your revised submission and to learning more about the evolution of NAS in FPFNs. 

**References**

Please ensure that all the references are formatted according to your preferred citation style. Furthermore, please check that you have correctly cited all sources in your text.

This concludes my detailed review of you submission. If you need any clarification on any of these points or have any questions, don't hesitate to reach out. Thank you for the opportunity to review your paper. Best regards.

LLM_1: it. so i’ve always gone looking for that warmth somewhere else—friends, partners, even coworkers who’d give a quick squeeze on the shoulder. but what hit me talking to L. was that I wasn’t just craving touch—I was using it as proof that I mattered. like every hug was a receipt saying “you are loved.” and when someone didn’t offer one, my brain would spiral into “they don’t care” or “I’m too much.” it’s exhausting, honestly. i’ve put so much weight on physical affection as the ultimate sign of love that i’ve overlooked all the other ways people show up. L. listens—really listens—when i talk about my weird dreams or my anxiety spirals. she remembers small things, like how i take my tea or that i hate fluorescent lights. she shows up in quiet consistency, not grand gestures. and i’ve been so fixated on what she *doesn’t* do that i’ve minimized what she *does*. maybe my real mistake wasn’t needing touch—it was refusing to see love in its quieter forms. maybe learning to recognize those subtler expressions isn’t settling, it’s expanding. love isn’t one language. mine might be hugs, but that doesn’t mean others aren’t fluent in their own dialects.
LLM_2:
It’s always been touch I’ve craved—so much so that I’ve spent years seeking warmth wherever I could find it: in friends, partners, even a fleeting pat on the shoulder from a coworker. But talking to L. made something clear: I wasn’t just longing for physical connection—I was using it as proof that I mattered. Every hug became a receipt: *You are loved.* And when one didn’t come, my mind spiraled into *They don’t care* or *I’m too much.* It’s exhausting, really.

I’d placed such weight on physical affection as love’s ultimate signal that I started overlooking all the other ways people show up. L., for instance, listens—truly listens—when I ramble about my strange dreams or anxiety loops. She remembers how I take my tea, knows I can’t stand fluorescent lights. Her love isn’t loud; it’s steady, consistent, woven into small, deliberate acts.

And yet, I’d fixated only on what she doesn’t do—on the absence of touch—while downplaying everything she *does*. My mistake wasn’t needing closeness. It was failing to recognize love in its quieter forms.  

Learning to see those subtleties isn’t settling—it’s expanding. Love isn’t a single language. Mine might speak in hugs, but that doesn’t mean others aren’t fluent in their own dialects.

LLM_1:
Some days I wish I could just be John, a regular guy from suburban Chicago, without the 'Dog-man' label. Newsflash: it's not that simple. I'm stuck with superhuman abilities, courtesy of that messed-up government experiment. My worst nightmare was spiders, so now I've got eight-legged freaks crawling out of every crevice. And don't even get me started on my enhanced senses – every creaky floorboard, every whiff of last night's Chinese takeout, it all drives me nuts.

I've tried to live a normal life, but it never seems to work out. People freak out when they see me, the whole 'werewolf' thing. Can't blame 'em, really – I do have a few extra sets of razor-sharp teeth and claws. But, come on, I just want a decent cup of coffee without having to explain myself. Is that too much to ask?
LLM_2:
Some mornings, as I sit in my cramped, suburban-Chicago apartment, staring at my reflection in the mirror,  I wonder what it would be like to be just John – a guy with a 9-to-5 job, maybe a wife, two kids, you know, living the quintessential American dream. No superpowers, no supernatural expectations, just the humdrum of everyday life.  News flash: that's a fantasy. Reality is, my life is a never-ending struggle to keep my secret safe. 

You see, those government scientists didn't just give me a makeover; they rewired my brain, rearranged my DNA, making me something more, something less, than human. They called it 'Project: Canine', but I call it a curse. Those eight legs, crawling, creeping, everywhere, make my skin crawl. Take the ones I found in last week's cereal box. Or the pair that insisted on sharing my shower. Yeah, that happened. You'd think it was just a phase, an anomaly, until you encounter the vermin in your kitchen, on your bed, in every nook and cranny. Spiders, of course, were my kryptonite. Now I have them on speed dial.

My senses, too, have been upgraded. Not that I asked for it. Every clog in this old house, like the one under the living room rug, is an earthquake to my ears. That last-night's-Chinese-takeout smell? Forget about it – it'll transport me straight to food heaven. Problem is: I don’t just smell it; I taste it, feel it on the tip of my tongue. Don’t even mention the coffee shop down the street. Their aroma, their brew, makes me twitch. All I crave is just one, quiet, normal cup. One without screaming, fleeing crowds. Just one without explanations, apologies, lies.

People freak when I walk down Main Street. Werewolf, they whisper, eyes wide with terror. Some try to get a selfie, others a restraining order. Fingers snapping, voices raised, 'Don't you dare come near me!' Yeah. Come on. A guy just wants a simple cuppa joe. Razor-sharped teeth, claws – minor details – just an average Tuesday. Ask for a pastry, get an earful. 'Werewolf','monster', or, worse, nothing at all – they just cross the road. Guess that’s what happens when you're no longer 'just John'.
