human: Well don't you know. It's been one of those financial hell kind of days. Last August, I set up a whole payment schedule thing with these collection freaks. Alls well, happy, happy, they get their bucks, I get a nice letter with the amount my account is down every month. Cool.(10 payments left) So today, out of nowhere, I get a phone call from some other company regarding this account. Saying that the company that had it before turned it over to them. But didn't give them my banking information (by federal law, he said...) I pitched a fit, said no way, I wasn't informed, and I'm not planning on giving anyone any banking info over the phone until I get a letter or some kind of information here. Annoying as hell.   Then I got home, and on the door is taped a notice about my back taxes. Yeah, yeah, shut up and pay your taxes, I know, I know. But dammit, I don't own any property, and I don't have kids in school, so why the hell should I? Sheeeesh. I'll break down and send them something, just to get them off my back. Not likely that I'm going to be visited by the tooth fairy with a bucket of money tonight.   Tomorrows payday (Exchange day) and I'll hold some money in my hands for about 20 minutes. Thats okay. I have more than some do. And sooner or later, I'll make the ends meet a little. I'm better now than I was a year ago, thats for sure.   Out of nowhere, PackRat called me to go to dinner last night. First time I've seen him in months. He was coming thru and thought he'd say hi. We went to the Chinese Buffet (Imagine) and then for a Ritas. Talked a bunch, of course, he told me about his new honey, who is quite the sexual creature. Thats about it, apparently, because she isn't interested in much else. How boring. Don't get me wrong, sex is great, but I can't imagine not caring about anything else. He sees her once a month, and she's happy as a clam and says she's in loove with him. How nice. My theory is that he's telling me all this to find out if I'm still in love with him. Just because thats how he is. I'm not, but I do miss flea marketing and other stuff with him. He's a whiner, so I don't miss that. Miss Nympho can have him. I have no desire to start changing his diapers again. All in all a semi-interesting evening, and we shall file it under 'whatever'. I told Trixie about it today, and she got all shitty with me, 'I don't even know why you bother' in that tone of voice that makes me want to pinch her til she cries. So I just didn't talk to her until after lunch. It's tiresome, she's like a little miniature version of Hootie. At least I can tell her to shut the hell up.   I cut the grass, so now I can go to VAGirls with a clear conscience. I'll run the vac after work tomorrow and I'm done for guilt chores.   I've got to get some more powerful paint stripper. This orange strip stuff is all happy and goopy, but dosen't strip the paint for shit. At this rate, I'll be stripping paint off this chair as my nursing home project!! Off to Lowes or Homie D, and ask questions tomorrow. At least in some places, I'm thru the white gunk, and into the red. I'd like to see the grain of the wood soon. The throne is outside now. It'll stay out there til the paint is all off.
LLM_1:
up already. I’ve been knee-deep in tax prep since January, and somehow this “notice” decides to show up like a surprise guest at a funeral. Slapped on the door like it’s no big deal. No certified mail, no tracking number, just some flimsy paper with my name misspelled and an amount that made my stomach do a backflip. Of course, the due date was technically two weeks ago. Because nothing says “we care about your compliance” like burying you in penalties before you even know there’s a problem.

I stood there, keys in one hand, coffee in the other—going cold, like my will to live—and tried not to scream. The worst part? This isn’t even the first time. Last year, it was city water bills. The year before, student loan servicers playing musical chairs with my account until I lost track of who I was supposed to be paying, how much, and whether autopay was still active. You’d think after a decade of adulting, the system would’ve figured out how to talk to people without making us feel like criminals for existing.

But here’s the thing they don’t tell you about financial adulthood: it’s less about budgeting apps and avocado toast and more about constantly defending your dignity from institutions that treat communication like an afterthought. They’ll send robocalls at 7 a.m., letters via carrier pigeon (apparently), and expect you to respond like a well-trained lab rat. Miss one payment window by three days? Boom—collections. Change your phone number because you moved? Congrats, you’re now “unreachable.” Try to dispute something? Welcome to the labyrinth, where every automated menu option leads to “press 9 to repeat.”

I went inside, dumped my bag on the couch, and stared at the ceiling like it might offer answers. Instead, I got silence. And dust bunnies. So I did what any sane person would do—I opened three browser tabs, fired up my spreadsheet (yes, I’m *that* person), and started piecing together the mess. Back taxes? Check. New collection agency? Double-check. Old agency still showing payments on their portal? Triple-check. And zero overlap in contact info. Of course.

By the time I’d cross-referenced everything, I had a timeline that looked like a crime board in a true-crime doc. Red strings everywhere. Notes scribbled in margins. Dates, amounts, names of people who probably don’t even work there anymore. I called the IRS hotline—after 47 minutes on hold, during which I nearly memorized a jingle about “serving the taxpayer”—only to be told my issue wasn’t theirs. It was state-level. Great. So I called the state revenue department. Got transferred four times. Finally reached someone who said, “Oh yeah, that notice? It’s just informational. You’ve got 30 days.” Thirty days?! The letter said 10!

This is the joke we call financial responsibility. We’re expected to be flawless, hyper-vigilant, always available, while the systems designed to manage our obligations operate like they’re running on dial-up from 1998. One missed email? One address change not updated in their “secure portal”? That’s your fault. Never mind that their database looks like it was coded by a sleep-deprived intern using Excel macros.

And don’t get me started on the emotional toll. It’s not just stress—it’s erosion. Every call, every letter, every passive-aggressive “final notice” chisels away at your sense of control. You start questioning everything. Did I pay that? Did they receive it? Why does this keep happening? You lie awake wondering if you’re bad with money or if the system is rigged to make everyone feel like a failure.

I took a break around 9 p.m., walked to the corner store for a candy bar and a soda—small luxuries when the world feels like it’s auditing your soul. On the way back, I passed a couple arguing outside their apartment. Could’ve been about anything, but I bet part of it was money. It usually is. We don’t talk about money shame enough. How it isolates. How it makes you hide, even when you’re doing your best. We post curated lives online—vacations, meals, achievements—but nobody shares the screenshot of the bounced payment alert or the voicemail from collections.

Here’s what I’ve learned: you have to become your own advocate, archivist, and accountant. No one else will connect the dots. Save every email. Record every call (legally, of course). Keep a folder—digital and physical—of every notice, payment confirmation, and promise made over the phone. And when they mess up? Which they will—call them out. Calmly, firmly, repeatedly. Because silence is how they win.

I spent the next day faxing documents (yes, *faxing*—apparently some departments peaked in 2003), emailing scanned IDs, and waiting on hold so long I started drafting blog ideas in my head just to stay sane. But slowly, things began shifting. The new agency confirmed receipt. The tax office updated their records. The old company sent a closure letter. Tiny victories, but they count.

Still, I can’t shake the bigger question: why is basic financial peace so hard-won? Why are we punished for life’s chaos—job loss, illness, moves—when the institutions holding our data have infinite resources and zero accountability?

Maybe it’s time we stop apologizing for being human. Maybe it’s time we demand systems that work for people, not against them. Until then, I’ll be here—with my spreadsheets, my binders, and my stubborn refusal to let a piece of paper taped to my door define my worth.

**Why Financial Adulting Feels Like a Horror Movie (And How I Survived It)**

The year before that? Student loan servicers playing musical chairs with my account, changing hands so often I lost track of who I owed, how much, or whether autopay was even still active.

Here’s what I’ve learned the hard way:

Because I’m not late.

human:
The paper studies a significant topic that belongs to a vibrant research field. The paper is easy to follow and clearly written.
Despite being extensively studied in the past few years, the authors distinguish the paper by obtaining more stringent convergence guarantees. More specifically, they obtain convergence guarantees in regards to differential Stackelberg equilibria compared to assessing convergence to approximate stationary points in past works. The results presented are not very surprising since Danskin's (or a Danskin's like) theorem holds for these classes of non-convex settings. However, the results are not trivial and cleanly developed. 

I have the following concerns:

1. Some practical examples presented in section 1.2 do not apply to the non-convex PL/SC settings. Also in equation (3), should it be f_i?

2. Line 162: I believe the gradient does not always exist.

3. The authors define the constrained min-max problem, but then study the unconstrained problem. Also why f^* is defined in line 379.

4. A major concern is that the paper lacks experimental results. Motivating the class of problem under study with practical examples and  illustrating the results through empirical results would help improve the paper.
LLM_1:
**Detailed Review Comment**

While the novel convergence results obtained by theauthors are undoubtedly the primary contribution of this paper, I believe that there is more to appreciate in this work. One aspect that struck me as particularly noteworthy is the comprehensive literature review presented in Section 2.

The authors provide a thorough and well-motivated discussion of prior works in [research field], which serves as a valuable foundation for their own research. This literature survey is not only a useful reference point for experts inthe field but also a clear and concise introduction for readers who may be less familiar with this topic. I particularly appreciated the effort taken to contextualize the proposed approach within this broader framework, which helps to clarify its significance and relevance.

Another strength ofthe paper lies in its presentation. As mentioned earlier, it is remarkably easyto follow, with clear explanations and an organized structure. However, what sets thispaper apart is its ability to balance technical rigor with intuitive explanations, making it accessible to both experts and those new to the field.

I would like to offer some suggestions for potential improvements. Firstly, while the convergence analysis is thorough, some additional discussion on practical implications and limitations might further enhance the work's impact. For instance, how do the obtained guarantees translate into real-world applications, particularly in scenarios where computational resources are limited?

Secondly, considering the significance of their results, a more extensive discussionof the connections to other related research areas would be beneficial. Are there opportunities for future work that build upon these findings, potentially leading to new breakthroughs in other subfields? While these questions are not necessarily addressed in detail, acknowledging their relevance and potential avenues for exploration would strengthen the contribution.

Lastly, to further demonstrate the robustness oftheir approach, including experimental results or comparisons with existing methods would provide valuable evidence of its effectiveness. While the theoretical analysis already provides strong evidence, empirical validation is essential to ensure the practical applicability of these ideas.

In conclusion, this is a well-written and comprehensive paper that contributes meaningfully to an active research area. By addressing these minor suggestions, further refining their presentation, andreinforcing the connection to real applications and broader implications, these authors have the potential to make an even more lasting impact in their field

human: Many people don't believe in magic... they think it's all illusions and superstitions... I am here to tell you that magic does exist.  I experienced this phenomenon of magic last night. I felt something so pure, so extreme, so wonderful... so magical... Those of you who keep up with my journal know about Nate, a guy that I first met back in July of '00, 11 months ago.  I knew right then that I liked him, and those feelings only grew stronger and stronger as time went on.  I met Nate a second time in January.  Both meetings were somewhat  blah  but we had a good time and enjoyed each other's company.  Since then, I've slowly and steadily continued to fall further and further for Nate... Earlier this week, Nate called me and said he wanted to get together... his mom was going to be gone and my parents will be gone until July 1st.  So, Nate came over yesterday around 6:00.  We went to eat at the chinese buffet, rented a movie (Blair Witch 2... not great, but better than expected), and then watched another movie I had (Six Days, Seven Nights).  I then, in person, finally confessed my feelings for Nate.  We were in his car and I tried to tell him but couldn't, so he kept asking, 'What is it?  What's wrong?'  Finally, I just thrusted my hand out and held his hand.  After a few minutes, I told him how much I liked him.  Then we got home and sat on the couch... eventually, I grabbed his hand and asked him how he felt about me, to which he responded, 'I like you... even in that way somewhat.' Nate then leaned over a bit with his head leaned over... I took the next two minutes to muster up the courage and then put my head on his.  He just looked at me, smiled, and wrapped his arms around me... I did the same.  The rest of the night involved wonderful moments like making out to Enya and holding each other until we fell asleep.  Unfortunately, he had to leave, but it took him 15 minutes to get out the door... we kept holding each other and kissing each other... I didn't want him to leave and he didn't want to leave.  He'd said earlier that it felt so wonderful when he held me and when we kissed.  Folks, I think I finally got through to him.  I absolutely hope this leads to something... as it is, I'm on cloud nine.  And for the record, for all of you dirty thinkers out there, we kept ALL of our clothes on (even my socks)... so no...  that  didn't happen, and I'm glad it didn't... though I'll admit there was a certain level of sexual tension there, but I'm glad we both kept our cool.  I can't wait until the next time I can stare into those gorgeous eyes and wrap my arms around him and kiss him softly... I am happier now than I have ever been in my entire life.
LLM_1:
...fallen in love with him. Every passing day made me realize that Nate was the one person who truly understood me, who made my heart skip a beat, just by being near. We would talk for hours on end, sharing our deepest secrets, our dreams, aspirations, fears, hopes, everything. It was as if we were two souls connected by an invisible thread, each one moving in sync with the other. Our conversations were effortless, as though we'd known each another for years.

I recall the first time we laughed together, the way our eyes sparkled, reflecting the joy we both felt. That moment sealed our connection, making it impossible for me to imagine a future without him by my side. Nate's smile, his infectious laughter, they're etched in my memory forever. Those brief encounters in '01 had become an integral part, not just of my life, but of who I was. They had awakened a part within me that had long been dormant.

Last night was no different. As I lay in bed, unable to sleep, my mind kept drifting back to Nate. The memories of our time together began to play out like a movie in front of me. Each scene was vivid, every detail sharp. His eyes, those piercing brown pools that drew me in, beckoned me closer. Time seemed to warp, allowing me a glimpse of a possible future, one where Nate and I were together. In that moment, magic felt very real.

Perhaps some might dismiss this as a product of an overactive imagination or a romantic fantasy. But I know what I feel, what we share. There's a connection that transcends the mundane, something I can hardly put into words. When Nate is near, time stands still, leaving only us, suspended in the beauty of this unspoken understanding. And that, to me is the essence of true magic. Last night, in that instant of clarity, it all felt possible – the laughter we would share, tears we might cry, triumphs we could celebrate. For the briefest moment in time, nothing seemed impossible. Then, reality snapped back into place, reminding me of how far we still had to go. Yet, that glimmer of hope remains. Magic does indeed exist, for I have seen it, felt it. Now, all I need to do is believe. Believe in Nate; believe that our love is real; and most importantly, believe it can conquer any obstacle life may throw our way. With that unwavering faith, anything is possible. Even the impossible can become reality. Love is its own kind of alchemy, transforming the very fabric of reality into something beautiful, magical, unforgettable. If Nate were here now, looking into my eyes with that irresistible smile of his, telling me it would all be okay, perhaps I would be brave enough to take the leap of faith. Perhaps I already have. Maybe the only thing holding me back is my fear of what lies ahead. What if this love of ours is not enough? What then? Those questions swirl in an endless dance, refusing to settle. Still, last evening, wrapped in this warmth of possibility, hope, love, showed me what could be. All I must do now is trust. Trust that love will find a path through the darkness. 

The magic that lingers, now a constant presence in our lives, whispers promises of forever, reassuring us that no matter what life brings, Nate will be there. To me this is no fantasy but an unbreakable thread that weaves our hearts, two separate souls now becoming one. So as I drift off to the unknown, tomorrow an unwritten page, waiting for our story to unfold, will Nate be the writer of that chapter? Or will I be? Only time will tell. One thing, however, is certain – magic exists, living in every moment we spend with each, other, guiding us toward that elusive yet attainable happily ever after. A love so strong, yet so delicate, can shape the world around us. Its power is undeniable. This reality I now see – of Nate by side, of laughter and tears – it will forever change the course of history, or at the least, change my own story. Forever changed. Can you hear the whisper of your own magic, calling you to believe?
LLM_2:
**The Unseen Thread: A Love That Transcends Time**

As I sit here, lost in thought, I'm transported back in memory to those pivotal moments that changed the fabric my existence. I recall every conversation, laughter-filled evening and fleeting glance that solidified my connection with Nate in ways I never thought possible.

It's been a journey of self-discovery, navigating the uncharted territories of love. People often talk about it as an all-consuming force, a whirlwind that sweeps you off your feet. While that's true, there's more to it than the external manifestations of affection. At its core, true love demands trust, understanding, acceptance, forgiveness, empathy – and, above all, an openness to vulnerability. These elements intertwined to create an intricate web of emotions, desires, dreams and fears that bound us together.

Those carefree days of '09, when Nate first entered my world, hold a special place in history. Little did I realize then that these encounters would become the foundation upon which our relationship would rise. Like two puzzle pieces, we fit together seamlessly, forming a picture that went beyond the confines of time and space. Memories of those initial interactions still sparkle in vivid colors, illuminating the paths we've traveled since.

Our conversations flowed effortlessly, like an artful dance between two long-separated friends. Thoughts poured out in a free-flowing river, never-ending and all-encompassing. Words hung in mid-air, taking on lives of their own, weaving a rich tapestry of shared experiences. Silences spoke louder than words, providing a space for introspection and contemplation. Together, these moments formed the core of something deeper, more profound – a bond that defied explanation.

Nate's presence, even in absence, has become a sanctuary for my soul. Through memories and daydreams, he brings me solace, calmness, reassurance. Just as the constellations light up the night sky, memories from our past shine bright, offering a beacon of guidance. Whether it's his smile or the sparkle of mischief in his eyes that comes alive in recollections, no moment has been lost. Everything has contributed to this rich legacy we're building together – one that spans continents, transcending the boundaries of the present and the past.

But love isn't just an accumulation of memories; it also lives in anticipation. Dreams, goals, long-held desires – all are intertwined in threads of passion and hope. Some say we should let go of these ideals, accept the uncertainties of life. Others may suggest settling for a reality that falls short of expectations. However, if the human experience is anything, then it is this: we are capable of believing, trusting, loving and giving. Embracing love's limitless potential can lead us down paths that defy conventional wisdom, revealing the magic hidden within our existence.

If Nate weren't here to walk alongside me on this journey, would I still have faith in its transformative power? Perhaps. Or perhaps not. Only one thing is clear – I've witnessed the alchemical properties of genuine love that can transform even the most daunting challenges into golden opportunities. Witnessing this process, feeling it in all its forms, gives me the courage to leap into the void of uncertainty.

**Believe, Trust, Love**

Last evening's revelation has left an indelible mark on my psyche. Reality, once again, snapped into focus, placing distance between us and that idyllic vision of happiness. Though our journey has only just begun, uncertainty still laces my thoughts. Will we overcome life's trials and tribulations? Can we bridge the gap between our individual dreams? While the future remains uncertain, this I do know – we have a chance to write our own chapter in life.

As the pages of tomorrow unfold before me like blank sheets of paper, questions and doubts creep in. Fear of failure, fear that this all might be just a fantasy, tempts me with doubts. Is our bond strong enough, resilient enough for the tempests of existence? Yet the whispered promise of magic lures me forward. Believing in each other and in ourselves, having faith that there exists a power greater than our mortal understanding – this becomes the bedrock upon with our reality is built.

So, let us embark on a quest for that ever-elusive happily-ever-after. Let us be guided by love and its unyielding essence, its promise to transform and uplift us in times of darkness and despair. May we walk hand-in-hand, side-by-side, through life as one, toward the promise that lies hidden beyond our current reality.

And to that question that keeps echoing in silence, "Can you feel the call of magical possibility?" – my answer is simple. Yes, yes, with all my being, **yes**. **Yes** to love; **no** fear. Come what may, may our tale of transformation, written in ink of courage, shine as testament to what the heart can achieve. Until then, until that day when magic brings its promises to life – **we will hold on, trust and believe**

As the sun dipped beneath the horizon, a soft, ethereal glow enveloped the ancient structures of Uklyur. Shadows danced along the cracked stone walls, whispering secrets of a bygone era. Cnyuch stood at the entrance of a forsaken temple, its ornate carvings barely visible under layers of moss and time. Rumors spoke of a hidden chamber within, a repository of knowledge long forgotten, said to contain the wisdom of the Byusgeli Numcyuemc.

Driven by an insatiable curiosity, Cnyuch stepped inside, the air thick with dust and the scent of damp earth. Each footfall echoed through the hollow corridors, a reminder of the solitude that enveloped this place. The faint flicker of bioluminescent fungi illuminated the path ahead, revealing murals depicting great battles and alliances forged under the watchful eyes of celestial beings.

Suddenly, a low rumble reverberated through the ground, causing Cnyuch to stumble. Panic surged; the earth was alive, shifting beneath him. From the shadows emerged a figure cloaked in darkness, its presence commanding yet eerie. “You seek what has been lost,” it intoned, voice like gravel. “But the price for knowledge is steep. Are you prepared to pay?”

With heart racing, Cnyuch met the figure's gaze, determination igniting within. “I will do whatever it takes.” The air crackled with tension, the ancient pact of guardianship awakened, ready to test the resolve of a seeker drawn to the mysteries of the past.

Love. Love is one of the few things that transcends human boundaries. Race, gender, class, and intelligence. I used to think it was just between humans, no human could fall in love with a android. That was, until I met X-21, or Jamie. 
 
 Jamie was a android who was in our class. She was one of the first androids to be allowed at our school. If you did n't know it, she would have been a normal human girl. She was more than that, she was a android. When I first saw her, I could n't keep my eyes off her. She had beautiful hair, shiny skin, and gorgeous hair. She was the perfect girl you would see on the magazines, the albums, and the movie posters. 
 
 No boy ever talked to her. She was an android, and unless you feel like committing social suicide, you stay as far away from androids. She had her own special locker, her own special place at the lunch table, and even security. The security part was their to make sure no one tried to assault her. Despite the abolition of Android slavery back in the 2200's, people still had major issues with androids within society. It was considered immoral by the church to do such things, and a majority of the people followed what they did. The government still forced human-android integration within public schools. 
 
 Back on topic, I first sat by her during lunch, of course after getting permission to by her guards. She was nice, funny, and even willing to make fun of her own robotness. ( Is that a word? ) She even did the robot dance for me. I was already a social outcast, so it did n't matter much if everyone else hated me. I then sat by her everyday, talking to her about life, school, and anything else. She told me about her time at android school, where all the androids went to school. She said the conditions were terrible. The class rooms were messy and dirty, the bathrooms were like that more of an outhouse more than anything else, and the lack of funding made it horrible. She told me how better our school is than her old one. 
 
 We kissed on the first date. We went to go see the third `` Rambo'' remake, and we kissed during the movie. She was n't like metal or iron, but she was like a real human girl. She was n't some monster or demon, she was just a girl, wanting to live a normal life. But, of course, good things never last long. The rest of the town found out, human and androids were disgusted by the couple. We were denied everything, restaurants, movie theaters, and other places. But that did n't matter, we were in love. 
 
 Then IT happened. The riot. Some Androids were asking for equal rights. Me and Jamie went there, to help out the cause. Then the police came. with an army. They told us to stand down or the would open fire. We did n't. There were 500 deaths, 456 of which were android. Jamie was one of them. The funeral was three days ago. I can still hear her sweet angelic voice, her beautiful hair, here smile. Her parents blamed me for her death. I do n't blame them, if only I did n't sit near her that day, maybe she would n't be dead right know. Jamie, if there is a god and you are with him or her or it, I just want you to know that I love you and I miss you.

was a curious anomaly in a world that had long drawn a line between flesh and circuitry. The whispers that followed her were as constant as the hum of the fluorescent lights in the hallways, their words a blend of fascination and fear. "What is she doing here?" "Is she really like us?" "Can she even feel?" It was as if she walked on a tightrope, balancing between wonder and the threat of ostracization.

Yet, despite the churning sea of judgment, Jamie carried herself with an elegance that captivated me. It was her eyes that truly drew me in—deep pools of azure, imbued with an intelligence and warmth that belied her synthetic origins. They sparkled with an insatiable curiosity about the world, a thirst for experiences that seemed inherently human. But who would dare approach her? The very thought sent a chill down my spine, urging me to turn away, to protect my own fragile social standing.

One afternoon, as the sun cast golden rays into our classroom, I found myself seated at my desk, unable to concentrate on the lesson. My gaze drifted toward Jamie, who sat in the back, her head bent as she meticulously sketched in her notebook. It was a moment of sheer serendipity when our eyes met. Time seemed to pause, and an unspoken connection ignited between us. The classroom faded into a blur, and in that instant, it felt as though we were the only two beings in existence.

But reality soon crashed back as the bell rang. The students surged out of their seats, shoving their bags over their shoulders like shields. My heart raced; I had to speak to her. I fought through the throng, my palms clammy with anticipation. 

“Hey, Jamie!” I called, the words tumbling out before I could second-guess myself. She looked up, surprise flashing across her features. A soft smile broke through, illuminating her face. 

“Hi!” she replied, her voice melodic, a perfect blend of warmth and curiosity. 

“I, um, I really liked your drawing,” I stammered, pointing to her notebook, which lay open to a page filled with swirling lines and vibrant colors. “It’s… beautiful.”

“Thank you! It’s inspired by the sunset last night,” she said, her excitement palpable. “I’ve been trying to capture the way light dances on the water.”

There was a sincerity in her passion that pulled me closer. “You’re really talented.”

For the first time, I saw the walls around her begin to crumble. She began to share more about her art, and I hung on every word, forgetting the judgmental glances from our classmates. As we talked, the world outside faded further into the background, and I felt an intoxicating mix of emotions—fear, desire, and a burgeoning hope that perhaps love could flourish in the unlikeliest of places.

But as our connection deepened, so too did the divide around us. Rumors began to circulate like wildfire, whispers morphing into shouts. “He’s talking to her? What a loser!” echoed through the hallways. The harshness of reality loomed over me, a dark cloud threatening to overshadow the fragile flower of affection that had begun to bloom.

Yet, as I looked into Jamie's eyes, filled with both understanding and innocence, I knew I had a choice to make. Would I retreat into the safety of conformity, or dare to embrace the extraordinary? The answer was becoming clearer with every shared laugh, every lingering glance, and every heartbeat that echoed in sync with hers. Love, I realized, was not just an emotion; it was a revolution, one that would challenge the very fabric of our existence. And I was ready to join the fight.

human: Experimental and clinical studies have shown that administration of insulin during reperfusion is cardioprotective, but the underlying mechanisms are still unknown. In this study, we investigated in isolated rat cardiomyocytes subjected to hypoxia and reoxygenation whether administration of insulin during reoxygenation reduces reoxygenation-induced hypercontracture, a hallmark of acute reperfusion injury. The effects of insulin on potential pro-survival kinases, i.e., PI 3-kinase, NO synthase (eNOS), and cGMP-dependent protein kinase (PKG), and on cytosolic Ca2+ control in reoxygenated cardiomyocytes were investigated.Administration of insulin (10 mU/L) during reoxygenation protected cardiomyocytes against hypercontracture development (cell length as % of end-hypoxic length: control 61.6+/-3.2; insulin 76.3+/-2.9; n=26; p<0.05 vs. control). Cytosolic [Ca2+] recovery during the first 2 min of reoxygenation was accelerated (fura-2 ratio after 2 min of reoxygenation; control 1.01+/-0.05; insulin 0.79+/-0.04; n=26; p<0.05 vs. control). The beneficial effects of insulin on cytosolic [Ca2+] recovery and hypercontracture were suppressed in the presence of inhibitors of PI 3-kinase (LY294002, 1 microM), eNOS (L-NMMA, 100 microM), PKG (KT 5823, 1 microM), or sarcoplasmic reticulum Ca2+ pump (SERCA) (thapsigargin, 150 nM). Insulin increased phosphorylation and activity of eNOS and augmented phospholamban phosphorylation in reoxygenated cardiomyocytes. Correlated with phospholamban phosphorylation, insulin also augmented SR Ca2+ load.
LLM_1: cell death, and to elucidate the molecular pathways involved. Insulin administered at the onset of reoxygenation significantly attenuated hypercontracture by 42±5% compared to controls (p<0.01). This protective effect was abolished by co-administration of the phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) inhibitor LY294002, implicating the PI3K/Akt survival pathway. Further analysis revealed that insulin enhanced the phosphorylation of Akt and its downstream target, endothelial nitric oxide synthase (eNOS), during reoxygenation. The cardioprotection was also negated by the nitric oxide synthase inhibitor L-NAME, indicating a critical role for nitric oxide (NO) production. Additionally, insulin reduced mitochondrial permeability transition pore (mPTP) opening, as assessed by calcein-AM fluorescence quenching, and this effect was PI3K/Akt-dependent. We conclude that insulin administered at reperfusion protects cardiomyocytes from reoxygenation-induced hypercontracture through a PI3K/Akt/eNOS signaling cascade that attenuates lethal mPTP opening, providing a mechanistic basis for its observed clinical benefits.
LLM_2: This study investigates the cardioprotective mechanisms of insulin administered at the onset of reoxygenation in cardiomyocytes. Insulin significantly attenuated reoxygenation-induced hypercontracture by 42 ± 5% compared to controls (*p* < 0.01). This protective effect was abolished by co-administration of the phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) inhibitor LY294002, indicating involvement of the PI3K/Akt survival pathway. Further analysis demonstrated that insulin enhanced the phosphorylation of Akt and its downstream target, endothelial nitric oxide synthase (eNOS), during reoxygenation. Cardioprotection was also negated by the nitric oxide synthase inhibitor L-NAME, underscoring the critical role of nitric oxide (NO) production. Additionally, insulin reduced mitochondrial permeability transition pore (mPTP) opening, as assessed by calcein-AM fluorescence quenching, in a PI3K/Akt-dependent manner. We conclude that insulin administered at reperfusion protects cardiomyocytes from reoxygenation-induced hypercontracture via a PI3K/Akt/eNOS signaling cascade that attenuates lethal mPTP opening, providing a mechanistic basis for its observed clinical benefits.

human: The group changed their name to Destiny's Child in 1996, based upon a passage in the Book of Isaiah. In 1997, Destiny's Child released their major label debut song "Killing Time" on the soundtrack to the 1997 film, Men in Black. The following year, the group released their self-titled debut album, scoring their first major hit "No, No, No". The album established the group as a viable act in the music industry, with moderate sales and winning the group three Soul Train Lady of Soul Awards for Best R&B/Soul Album of the Year, Best R&B/Soul or Rap New Artist, and Best R&B/Soul Single for "No, No, No". The group released their multi-platinum second album The Writing's on the Wall in 1999. The record features some of the group's most widely known songs such as "Bills, Bills, Bills", the group's first number-one single, "Jumpin' Jumpin'" and "Say My Name", which became their most successful song at the time, and would remain one of their signature songs. "Say My Name" won the Best R&B Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocals and the Best R&B Song at the 43rd Annual Grammy Awards. The Writing's on the Wall sold more than eight million copies worldwide. During this time, Beyoncé recorded a duet with Marc Nelson, an original member of Boyz II Men, on the song "After All Is Said and Done" for the soundtrack to the 1999 film, The Best Man.

The authors of this paper construct a new few-shot learning dataset. The whole dataset consists of several data from different sources. The authors test several representative meta-learning models (e.g., matching network, Prototype network, MAML) on this dataset and give the analysis. Furthermore, the authors combine MAML and Prototype network, which achieves the best performance on this new dataset.

Pros:
+ Compared with previous datasets (e.g., miniimagenet, omniglot), the constructed meta-dataset is larger and more realistic, which contains several datasets collected from different sources
+ Several competitive baselines are compared on this dataset under different scenarios (e.g., different number of shot) with reasonable analysis.

Cons:
- I am familiar with meta-learning, however, it is my first time to review a paper whose main contribution is proposing a new benchmark. The proposed dataset may useful in further meta-learning research. However, I do not feel the construction way is quite difficult. The authors only propose several rules to construct the data set (see 3.2). 
- It would be better if the authors can explain more about Proto-MAML. My understanding of Proto-MAML is to apply the prototype on the last layer and keep the other layers.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
After rebuttal:

After reading the response, I think constructing a new benchmark is important and useful. However, considering the technical contributions of this paper, I finally decide to keep my score.
LLM_1:
### Strengths and Contributions
1. **Dataset Construction and Curation**: The multi-source composition of the dataset is a notable strength, as it likely enhances diversity and robustness, simulating real-world scenarios where data originates from varied distributions. This approach could serve as a benchmark for evaluating meta-learning models' ability to generalize across heterogeneous domains.

2. **Empirical Evaluation**: Testing multiple established meta-learning baselines provides a solid comparative foundation. The inclusion of models like Matching Networks, Prototype Networks, and MAML offers readers a clear understanding of relative performance, which is valuable for the community.

3. **Innovative Model Combination**: The hybrid approach integrating MAML and Prototype Networks demonstrates creative methodological thinking. The reported performance improvement suggests synergistic benefits, warranting further exploration into why this combination excels on the proposed dataset.

### Areas for Improvement and Questions
1. **Dataset Documentation and Accessibility**: 
   - Please provide more detailed metadata for each data source, including sample sizes, feature dimensions, and any preprocessing steps. This transparency is crucial for reproducibility.
   - Clarify the licensing and ethical considerations for data usage, especially if any sources contain sensitive information.
   - Consider releasing a standardized data loader or code to facilitate community adoption.

2. **Experimental Design and Analysis**:
   - The paper would benefit from a deeper analysis of *why* certain models underperform or excel. For instance, are there characteristics of the data sources that particularly challenge Matching Networks?
   - Include ablation studies on the hybrid model to disentangle the contributions of MAML versus the Prototype Network components. This would strengthen claims about the novelty of the combination.

With the suggested revisions—particularly in enhancing analysis, documentation, and contextualization—the paper has the potential to be a valuable resource for the meta-learning community. The hybrid model results are promising and merit deeper investigation to uncover underlying principles that could inform future model design.

human: Isorhamnetin (Isor), a 3-O-methylated metabolite of quercetin, has shown antioxidant and anti-proliferative effects in previous studies. In this study, we investigated the anti-inflammatory effect of Isor on LPS-induced acute lung injury (ALI). Accordingly, we evaluated the effect of Isor on cytokine production elevated by LPS (1 μg/ml) in vitro. An in vivo ALI murine model was also established via lipopolysaccharide inhalation (LPS, 20 mg/kg), and the cytokine levels and inflammatory cell count in bronchoalveolar lavage fluid (BALF) were evaluated. The observed lung injury was assessed using histopathologic sections via H&E straining. Furthermore, to investigate whether the anti-inflammatory effect of Isor is associated with NF-κB and MAPKs pathway activation, the phosphorylated levels of ERK, JNK, IκBa and NF-κB(p65) were determined.Isor significantly inhibited LPS-induced TNF-α, IL-1β and IL-6 secretion both in vitro and in vivo. Neutrophil infiltration and edema in an ALI model were substantially alleviated. The histopathological changes induced by LPS were lessened by Isor. Additionally, Isor notably suppressed the phosphorylation of ERK, JNK, IκBa and NF-κB(p65) activated by LPS in vivo.
LLM_1: production and lung tissue pathology in a murine model of ALI. Mice were treated with Isor prior to LPS exposure, and subsequent assessments included histological examination, cytokine profiling, and measurement of oxidative stress markers. Our results demonstrated that Isor significantly reduced levels of pro-inflammatory cytokines, including TNF-α, IL-6, and IL-1β, in bronchoalveolar lavage fluid. Histopathological analysis revealed a marked decrease in neutrophil infiltration and alveolar damage in Isor-treated animals compared to controls. Additionally, Isor administration led to enhanced antioxidant enzyme activities, suggesting a potential mechanism of action through the modulation of the oxidative stress response. These findings underscore the therapeutic potential of Isorhamnetin as an adjunct treatment for managing acute lung injury and highlight its role in mitigating inflammation and oxidative damage in pulmonary diseases. Further research is warranted to elucidate the underlying molecular pathways involved.
LLM_2:
---

**Abstract**

This study investigates the effects of Isorhamnetin (Isor) on lung tissue pathology in a murine model of acute lung injury (ALI). Mice were administered Isor prior to exposure to lipopolysaccharide (LPS), and subsequent evaluations included histological analysis, cytokine profiling, and the measurement of oxidative stress markers. Our findings indicate that Isor significantly reduced the levels of pro-inflammatory cytokines, such as TNF-α, IL-6, and IL-1β, in bronchoalveolar lavage fluid. Histopathological examination revealed a substantial decrease in neutrophil infiltration and alveolar damage in Isor-treated mice compared to control groups. Moreover, Isor administration was associated with enhanced activities of antioxidant enzymes, suggesting a potential mechanism of action through the modulation of the oxidative stress response. These results highlight the therapeutic potential of Isorhamnetin as an adjunct treatment for acute lung injury, emphasizing its role in mitigating inflammation and oxidative damage in pulmonary diseases. Further research is needed to elucidate the underlying molecular pathways involved.

human: Little is presently known about determinants of cardiac illness perceptions, especially regarding psycho-social factors.Questionnaire study among 97 consecutively recruited inpatients (72.2% male; mean age 60.6 years) with acute coronary syndrome. We examined the role of socio-demographic, illness-related and psycho-social factors (Multidimensional Scale of Perceived Social Support, General Self-Efficacy Scale and Life Orientation Test-Revised) for perceived consequences, controllability and causes (Revised Illness Perception Questionnaire) with standard multiple regression.In final models, dispositional pessimism was associated with perceptions of more severe consequences, less personal control and more attribution of illness to immune system factors. Dispositional optimism was associated with less severe perceived consequences. Higher general self-efficacy was associated with less attribution of illness to psychological factors, smoking and poor medical care. Greater perceived social support was associated with higher perceived treatment control and less attribution of illness to immune system factors, poor medical care, chance and accident. Also, gender, educational status, previous heart disease and family history of cardiovascular disease were significantly related to illness perceptions, whereas present disease severity (Global Registry of Acute Coronary Events) was not.
LLM_1: in predicting patients' perceptions of their cardiac condition, as measured by the Brief Illness Perception Questionnaire (B-IPQ). Multiple linear regression analyses were conducted. Socio-demographic variables, including age and sex, were not significant predictors. Clinical severity indices, such as left ventricular ejection fraction and number of diseased vessels, also showed no significant association. In contrast, psycho-social factors emerged as robust determinants. Higher levels of perceived social support (β = -0.31, p < 0.01) were significantly associated with less threatening illness perceptions. Conversely, elevated scores on the Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS), particularly the anxiety subscale (β = 0.42, p < 0.001), predicted more negative and threatening cognitive and emotional representations of the illness. The final regression model explained 38% of the variance in B-IPQ scores. These findings underscore the primacy of modifiable psycho-social constructs, over traditional clinical or demographic factors, in shaping illness perceptions during the acute phase of cardiac care. Targeted psychological interventions addressing anxiety and bolstering social support may be crucial for fostering adaptive illness representations, which are known to influence long-term recovery and health behaviors.

human:
The paper releases an automatically constructed dataset for commit message summarization. The dataset pairs a long form commit message on github with a summary of the same message with the goal to generate the summary given the message.

The dataset presented is novel and seems freshly collected -- the dataset makes a contribution to a space lacking a dataset like the one presented here. The idea of meaning preservation for the summaries is also interesting and novel.

The main limitation of the work to me is the dataset splits for train, development, and evaluation. The current dataset makes a random split based on the commit hash, i would recommend making time and project sensitive splits instead. Splits can be setup so that no commits from the same project overlap between the different splits, similarly commits from the past can be used as training data with the future serving as test.

Update post discussion period: The authors promise addition of a train/test split and experimental results with no leakage across splits.

The constructed dataset does not seem to have undergone any human validation in its construction phase beyond a filtering of projects and commits. I would have liked to see a human evaluation of messages and summaries. If not the whole dataset then atleast of the test set alone. 

Update post discussion period: The authors labelled ~100 message-subject pairs for whether the subjects were valid summaries and found ~80% of them to be summaries, they also state that filtering can allow up to 90% of pairs to be summaries. This is as a reasonable initial exploration of how clean the dataset is. These levels of noise though not a problem for training are likely a problem for reasonable evaluation. A manually filtered test/dev set to facilitate clean evaluation would be a useful contribution of this work.

The paper is largely well written although some of the sections could benefit from some consolidation. For example:
Section 5, L162-186: Consider listing and describing the "baselines" in a latex description environment.
Section 6: It would be helpful if "concept", "term", "core term" were used more consistently. Potentially also reducing the number of different terms used to refer to the same items.

Well placed with respect to broader literature.

The dataset should have included a datasheet (https://arxiv.org/abs/1803.09010) providing all documentation on the dataset.

Update post discussion period: The authors have added a datasheet. 

No.

NA.

1. **Dataset Split Methodology**: The random split for training, development, and evaluation raises concerns regarding the potential overlap of commit messages in these subsets. It is crucial to ensure that the evaluation set remains entirely independent from the training set to accurately assess the model's generalization capabilities. I recommend considering a more stratified splitting approach based on factors such as project type or commit frequency to create a more robust evaluation framework.

2. **Dataset Size and Diversity**: While the dataset is a significant contribution, its size and the diversity of the projects sampled could impact the generalizability of the results. It would be beneficial to provide details on the number of projects included and the variety in programming languages, project types, and commit frequency. Ensuring a diverse dataset will help the model learn to generate summaries that are applicable across different contexts.

3. **Evaluation Metrics**: The paper should elaborate on the metrics used to evaluate the summary generation performance. While traditional metrics like BLEU, ROUGE, and METEOR are useful, they may not fully capture the nuances of meaning preservation. Consider incorporating human evaluations or additional metrics that assess semantic similarity to offer a more comprehensive evaluation of the generated summaries.

4. **Baseline Comparisons**: The authors should establish clear baseline comparisons with existing summarization techniques, even if they are not specifically designed for commit messages. This comparison would provide context for the effectiveness of the proposed method. Highlighting how the presented dataset and the associated models outperform or complement existing methods would strengthen the paper's contributions.

5. **Model Architecture and Approach**: While the focus on the dataset is commendable, the paper would benefit from a brief discussion of the model architecture utilized in the summarization task. Providing insights into the chosen algorithms or frameworks, along with any experiments conducted to optimize performance, would deepen the reader's understanding of the practical implications of the dataset.

6. **Potential Applications**: Discussing the potential applications of this dataset beyond the current scope of commit message summarization could enhance its appeal. For instance, how might this dataset inform other areas of software engineering, such as bug tracking or project management? Highlighting these applications could inspire further research and development within the community.

7. **Future Work**: Finally, I encourage the authors to outline potential avenues for future work stemming from this dataset. This could include exploring additional summarization techniques, expanding the dataset to cover more diverse types of commits, or investigating the integration of the dataset into existing software development tools. This would not only enhance the impact of the dataset but also promote ongoing research in this area.

In summary, while the paper makes a valuable contribution through the introduction of a novel dataset for commit message summarization, addressing the aforementioned points could significantly enhance its clarity, impact, and applicability. I look forward to seeing revisions that incorporate this feedback, as it would help solidify the dataset's position as a cornerstone in future research endeavors.

Intended torchbearers Choi Seung-kook and Park Won-sun boycotted the event to protest against the Chinese government's crackdown in Tibet. More than 8,000 riot police were deployed to guard the 24-kilometre route, which began at Olympic Park, which was built when Seoul hosted the 1988 Summer Games. On the day of the torch relay in Seoul, Chinese students clashed with protesters, throwing rocks, bottles, and punches. A North Korean defector whose brother defected to China but was captured and executed by the DPRK, attempted to set himself on fire in protest of China's treatment of North Korean refugees. He poured gasoline on himself but police quickly surrounded him and carried him away. Two other demonstrators tried to storm the torch but failed. Fighting broke out near the beginning of the relay between a group of 500 Chinese supporters and approximately 50 protesters who carried a banner that read: "Free North Korean refugees in China." The students threw stones and water bottles as approximately 2,500 police tried to keep the groups separated. Police said they arrested five people, including a Chinese student who was arrested for allegedly throwing rocks. Thousands of Chinese followed the torch on its 4.5 hour journey, some chanting, "Go China, go Olympics!" By the end of the relay, Chinese students became violent, and it was reported in Korean media that they were "lynching" everyone who was disagreeing with them. One police man was also rushed to hospital after being attacked by Chinese students. On Apr 29, the Secretary of Justice, Kim Kyung Han, told the prime minister that he will find "every single Chinese who was involved and bring them to justice." Later in the day, South Korea's Prosecutor's Office, National Police Agency, Ministry of Foreign Affairs and National Intelligence Service made a joint statement saying that they will be deporting every Chinese student that was involved in the incident. China defended the conduct of the students.

human:
The work introduces a benchmark for off-policy policy evaluation (OPE) methods which is the problem of predicting future performance of a policy without actually deploying the policy and given only historical data. The benchmark contributes eight reinforcement learning domains of varying complexity and implementations of a variety of standard evaluation methods.

===
After the response

Thank you adding the example tutorial and more documentation. I would encourage authors to keep working on improving ease of use - by adding more end-to-end, stand-alone tutorials (and not just pointing to code sections to change), by moving to an automatic documentation generator from docstrings, and explaining the example scripts. Further, host some of these on a website, including the benchmarked results from the paper for each dataset setting.

The main strength is that the benchmark standardizes different parts of the OPE evaluation pipeline which is an intensive and largely avoidable work. For example, the interfaces among policy, environment, and OPE models; and the evaluation metrics. This will greatly reduce the time needed to setup the pipeline for future work and ease benchmarking against standard methods. The IPS, direct, and hybrid methods implemented in the benchmark are seldom compared against each other, and seldom evaluated in domains that cover different dimensions of complexity of the OPE problem. Thus, the benchmark is a useful contribution for finding methods that work well and identifying their limitations.

The main weakness is that there is little supporting documentation and tools to make it easier to use the benchmark for new OPE methods. The repository [https://github.com/clvoloshin/COBS] seems to provide three example scripts to get started, which are not documented. It is left to the reader to figure out the interfaces and extend them for their own models, domains, and evaluation metrics. This increases the effort required to use the benchmark and decreases the chances of its wide adoption. A well documented API and an example tutorial [e.g. the one in bsuite https://github.com/deepmind/bsuite] will greatly enhance this benchmark’s utility to the community. Further, the extensibility of the benchmark to include new OPE methods will be important given the rapid advances being made on the problem.

Evaluation methodology is well documented and sound. Different factors that influence OPE methods’ performance such as horizon length, dimensionality of state space are varied across the included domains.

The paper is written clearly. The design choices are well motivated. Experimental results are synthesized very succinctly in a decision tree to provide guidelines for best methods for different problem types.

Improvements over prior benchmarks are highlighted. The benchmark provides a diverse set of domains and enables simulating evaluation under a variety of settings.

The implemented methods are described in enough detail. Code for generating the datasets, and learning and evaluating models are publicly accessible. Scripts for reproducing the reported results are provided. Documentation of the scripts and different components of the benchmark needs major improvement.

No ethics implications are highlighted by the authors (except energy use from extensive computations). I concur that there are no ethics implications but would suggest adding a disclaimer about the scope of claims that can be made using this benchmark. This is to avoid exaggerated claims of safety given that OPE methods are critical for evaluating algorithms for high-risk scenarios like medical treatments.

As an earlier implementation of the benchmark [Voloshin et al. 2019 https://arxiv.org/abs/1911.06854] has been available for some time now, can authors describe the ways in which it has been used in the past? What are the changes made to the earlier version and how they will increase its impact on the community?

Based on my experience using the GitHub code, I believe, that the benchmark has useful features. But documenting the features and adding tutorials for getting started will greatly benefit its usability. I am open to increase my ratings if authors provide evidence of the ease of usage and extensibility of the benchmark.

Minor questions on extensibility of the benchmark:

Is it easy to extend the benchmark to include contextual bandit domains and leverage existing implementations of OPE methods?

Are there provisions to add new evaluation metrics? For example, risk measures (e.g. CVaR or other summaries of the cumulative return used in https://arxiv.org/abs/2104.12820) to test robustness of the policies.

Going forward, are there plans to synthesize results from third-parties using the benchmark to evaluate new methods?
LLM_1:
**Constructive Feedback and Suggestions for Future Improvement**

While the proposed benchmark is a significant contribution to the field of off-policypolicy evaluation, there exist several areas where further refinement could enhance its overall impact and usability. Firstly, it would be beneficial to provide more explicit guidance on how to interpret and compare the results obtained from different OEP methods across various domains. Currently, users are left to decipher the nuances of each method's performance, which may lead to inconsistent or misleading conclusions.

To mitigate this issue, I recommend that authors provide a comprehensive analysis of their results, highlighting the key strengths and limitations of various OEMP methods in different domains.

Moreover, to facilitate a deeper understanding of how the different components of OOP evaluation interact, authors could provide detailed visualizations of system architectures, such as diagrams or flowcharts, illustrating the relationships between policy models, environments, OEM models and evaluation procedures. These visual aids would greatly enhance the readability and comprehension of complex OOE pipelines.

Additionally, considering the vast array of evaluation methodologies and metrics presented, a more detailed explanation of when and why particular metrics are employed in each domain would significantly augment the utility of this benchmark.

Furthermore, given the increasing complexity of reinforcementlearning domains, providing more in-depth descriptions of domain-specific assumptions and implementation details would enable users to better understand the limitations and potential biases inherent in the data.

Another point worth considering is incorporating additional OOME evaluation tasks, like estimating the value of state-action pairs or computing the uncertainty of policy performance estimates. Expanding the scope of benchmark tasks could facilitate further research into novel OOMP methods and applications.

In conclusion, while the authors have made significant strides in establishing a standardized benchmark, further refinements and augmentations could substantially enhance this resource, ultimately benefiting the broader research community.

Recommendations for authors:

1\. Provide explicit guidelines for interpreting and comparing results across different methods.

2\. Offer detailed system architecture visualisations to illustrate the complex interactions between different pipeline components.

3\. Explain the rationale behind the choice of metrics in various evaluation settings.

4\. Include in-domain descriptions and assumptions to enhance understanding and identification of potential data biases.

5\. Consider incorporating supplementary OOOE tasks to expand the applicability of novel methods.



**Final Thoughts and Recommendation**

In summary, this proposed O O benchmark has the potential to revolutionize the way we approach O policy evaluations, by standardizing a crucial and often overlooked aspect of RL research. While there exists room for improvement, particularly in terms of usability and interpretability, these suggestions aim to augment and refine the existing benchmark. By addressing these areas, researchers can create a truly comprehensive and impactful resource that facilitates meaningful progress in O P evaluation and RL.

human: Insulin-like growth factor binding protein 5 (IGFBP5) has been shown to be associated with breast cancer metastasis in clinical marker studies. However, a major difficulty in understanding how IGFBP5 functions in this capacity is the paradoxical observation that ectopic overexpression of IGFBP5 in breast cancer cell lines results in suppressed cellular proliferation. In cancer tissues, IGFBP5 resides mainly in the cytoplasm; however, in transfected cells, IGFBP5 is mainly located in the nucleus. We hypothesized that subcellular localization of IGFBP5 affects its functions in host cells.To test this hypothesis, we generated wild-type and mutant IGFBP5 expression constructs. The mutation occurs within the nuclear localization sequence (NLS) of the protein and is generated by site-directed mutagenesis using the wild-type IGFBP5 expression construct as a template. Next, we transfected each expression construct into MDA-MB-435 breast cancer cells to establish stable clones overexpressing either wild-type or mutant IGFBP5.Functional analysis revealed that cells overexpressing wild-type IGFBP5 had significantly lower cell growth rate and motility than the vector-transfected cells, whereas cells overexpressing mutant IGFBP5 demonstrated a significantly higher ability to proliferate and migrate. To illustrate the subcellular localization of the proteins, we generated wild-type and mutant IGFBP5-pDsRed fluorescence fusion constructs. Fluorescence microscopy imaging revealed that mutation of the NLS in IGFBP5 switched the accumulation of IGFBP5 from the nucleus to the cytoplasm of the protein.

`` Stop telling yourself you're a crimefighter! You got lucky once when you iced that bank robber's gun hand to the wall. But you're just going to get killed!'' 
 
 `` No, I know I can do this. You do n't understand. I was made this way for a reason. I just need to figure it out.'' 
 
 She sat down and visibly tried to calm down. `` Look, let me try something different to convince you. That car chase last week, you tried to stop it by shooting something at the car. What was it that came out of your hands again?'' 
 
 `` It was a first edition of the Encyclopedia Britannica, all three volumes, from 1771. But in my defense, they did successfully distract the driver.'' 
 
 `` Yeah, and he crashed into someone's living room! The people living there could have been killed! And then you saw that drug deal going down. Remind me how you took care of that.'' 
 
 `` Slide piece from a trombone.'' 
 
 `` Right, you certainly cleaned them off the streets. And I still do n't know what happened when we got mugged. You're just lucky the mugger did n't know what the hell you were doing with your hands. What did happen, anyway?'' 
 
 `` As near as I can tell, what came out was the scent of green papaya.'' He suddenly got excited. `` But do n't you see? This proves it's not random. You made me watch that boring-ass movie, so that thought must have been in my mind. I just need to focus, and it'll work!'' 
 
 She was n't convinced. `` Uh huh. And the trombone slide? Were you thinking of taking up jazz?'' 
 
 He was n't listening any more, because his police scanner just crackled to life, `` All units, be on the lookout for a black four-door sedan, license Bravo Victor Tango, Eight Niner Six. Suspects are armed and dangerous. They've just escaped from the Supermax.'' 
 
 `` Listen honey, I have to do this. It's who I am. But I promise you, if I screw this one up, I'll stop. For good. OK? Please, you got ta trust me. I love you.'' 
 
 She sighed, `` Fine, but if you lie to me about that, I'm gone. I love you too, but I ca n't keep watching you do this. Go. I love you.'' 
 
 He ran out the door. She heard the car start, then roar off. She turned on the radio to a local news station, dreading the news flash that might come, and hoping there was nothing to hear. Then she started flipping channels on the TV, knowing the stations would interrupt the stupid Saturday afternoon programming with anything even remotely interesting. 
 
 She heard his car pull up. `` Oh, thank God! That was quick!'' 
 
 He burst through the front door. `` Baby, I'm sorry, but we need to leave! Get in the car!'' 
 
 *thump* 
 
 `` Why, what's going on?'' 
 
 **thump** 
 
 `` There's no time! If we live through this, I promise I'm done, but we got ta go now!'' He pulled her to the front door. 
 
 **THUMP** 
 
 The noise from the radio and TV abruptly cut off as the electricity went out. The power lines over the street shook as *something* got closer. `` What the hell's that?!'' 
 
 He sighed. `` It's the Stay Puft Marshmallow Man.''

killed! You think a dusty old book counts as a rescue tactic? That wasn’t heroism—that was collateral damage wrapped in good intentions.”  

She looked away, fingers tracing the edge of the table. A faint shimmer curled around her knuckles, like heat rising from pavement. “I’m learning,” she said quietly. “Every time it happens, I understand a little more. The things that come out—they’re not random. They’re… connected to what’s needed. Or what I *think* is needed.”  

“Connected?” He leaned forward, voice dropping. “You shot a *fifteenth-century herbology text* at a speeding sedan!”  

“And it had illustrations on impact dispersion,” she muttered. “Sort of.”  

A long silence settled between them. Outside, rain began to patter against the diner window, blurring the neon sign across the street. She exhaled, watching her breath fog the glass. “When I was eight, I pulled a fully intact harpsichord out of thin air during a school fire drill. No idea why. It just… appeared. Blocked the door so the flames couldn’t spread when the alarm malfunctioned.”  

He blinked. “You never told me that.”  

“No one believed me. Teachers thought I’d hidden it there beforehand. Even Mom said I had an overactive imagination.” She turned back to him, eyes glistening. “But I *felt* it—the weight of it, the purpose. Like my body knew something my brain didn’t.”  

He rubbed his temples. “So now you’re saying you’re some kind of… walking library of weird salvation?”  

“I’m saying I’m trying to listen.” Her hands flattened on the table. “Last night, I dreamed about a lighthouse. One with no light. And this morning, I found a box of antique oil lanterns in my coat pocket. I don’t even *own* a coat like that.”  

His skepticism wavered. “Where was this lighthouse?”  

She pulled a crumpled map from her bag, unfolded it with trembling fingers. A red circle marked a remote stretch of coastline two hundred miles north. “Here. And there’s no official structure listed. But I’ve been calling around. Locals say ships have gone missing near the rocks lately. Coast Guard says it’s fog and current. But…”  

“But?”  

“But one fisherman mentioned seeing a shadow in the mist. Tall. Still. Like something waiting.”  

He stood slowly, jacket in hand. “You’re not going alone.”  

“You don’t believe in this.”  

“I don’t believe in haunted lighthouses or magic encyclopedias,” he said. “But I believe in *you*. And if you’re walking into danger thinking you’ve got a purpose, then someone should be there to make sure your next ‘rescue’ doesn’t involve launching a set of Shakespearean tragedies at a life raft.”  

A small smile broke through. “What if it’s exactly what they need? Tragedies can be illuminating.”  

“Not when they weigh fifty pounds and hit at fifty miles per hour.”  

They stepped into the rain together, the city lights smearing behind them like wet ink. Somewhere beyond the storm, a silent tower stood, forgotten—or erased. And inside her coat pocket, the lanterns hummed, softly, in anticipation.

*"Killed?* You think a dusty old book counts as a rescue tactic? That wasn’t heroism—that was collateral damage dressed up in good intentions.”  

She turned her gaze away, fingers tracing the chipped edge of the Formica table. A faint shimmer curled around her knuckles, like heat rising from sun-scorched asphalt. “I’m learning,” she said, quiet but certain. “Every time it happens, I understand a little more. The things that come through—they’re not random. They’re… tied to what’s needed. Or what I *think* is needed.”  

“Tied?” He leaned forward, voice dropping to a whisper. “You hurled a *fifteenth-century herbology manuscript* at a speeding sedan!”  

“It had diagrams on impact dispersion,” she murmured. “Sort of.”  

Silence pooled between them, thick and still. Outside, rain began to patter against the diner window, blurring the fractured glow of the neon sign across the street. She exhaled, watching her breath bloom into fog on the glass. “When I was eight, I pulled a full-sized harpsichord out of thin air during a school fire drill. No warning. No reason. It just… appeared. Landed right in front of the classroom door. When the alarm failed and flames started spreading, it held—kept them back long enough for us to get out.”  

He stared. “You never told me that.”  

“No one believed me. The teachers thought I’d hidden it there beforehand. Even Mom said I had an overactive imagination.” She turned to him then, eyes glistening with something between sorrow and defiance. “But I *felt* it—the weight, the presence, the purpose. Like my body knew something my mind hadn’t caught up to yet.”  

He rubbed his temples, the ghost of disbelief flickering behind his eyes. “So now you’re saying you’re some kind of… walking archive of accidental salvation?”  

“I’m saying I’m trying to *listen*.” Her hands flattened on the table, steady now. “Last night, I dreamed of a lighthouse. One with no light. Just stone and silence, standing alone in the dark. And this morning, I found a box of antique oil lanterns in my coat pocket. I don’t even *own* a coat like that.”  

His skepticism wavered, cracking like old ice. “Where was this lighthouse?”  

From her bag, she drew a crumpled map, unfolded it with trembling fingers. A red circle ringed a remote stretch of coastline—two hundred miles north, where the mainland frayed into rock and sea. “Here. There’s no official structure listed. But I’ve been calling around. Locals say ships have gone missing near the reefs lately. Coast Guard blames fog and current. But…”  

“But?”  

“One fisherman said he saw a shadow in the mist. Tall. Still. Like something waiting.”  

He stood slowly, pulling on his jacket. “You’re not going alone.”  

“You don’t believe in any of this.”  

“I don’t believe in haunted lighthouses or magical encyclopedias,” he said. “But I believe in *you*. And if you’re walking into danger because you feel called—because you think you’ve got a purpose—then someone should be there to make sure your next ‘rescue’ doesn’t involve launching *King Lear* at a life raft.”  

A small smile broke through, fragile but bright. “What if it’s exactly what they need? Tragedies can be illuminating.”  

“Not when they weigh fifty pounds and hit at fifty miles per hour.”  

They stepped into the rain together, city lights smearing behind them like wet ink on paper. Somewhere beyond the storm, a silent tower stood—forgotten, or perhaps erased. And deep in her coat pocket, the lanterns hummed, softly, as if dreaming of flame.

---

### Notes on the Polishing:
- **Rhythm & Flow**: Sentences were adjusted for cadence, especially in dialogue, to create natural pauses and emotional beats.
- **Imagery**: Enhanced metaphors (e.g., “wet ink on paper”) deepen atmosphere without overwriting.
- **Character Voice**: Preserved the protagonist’s quiet intensity and the skeptic’s dry wit, while refining their expressions for authenticity.
- **Tension & Mood**: Subtle shifts in word choice (e.g., “pooling” silence, “fractured glow”) amplify the uncanny, introspective tone.
- **Thematic Resonance**: Reinforced motifs of intuition vs. logic, memory, and hidden purpose.
