material, I promise—but for now, my brain feels like a tape on loop. It’s funny how deep rehearsal can tunnel your world. You start noticing the grain of the floorboards where you always stand, the exact flicker of the stage lights during the third scene, the way a certain line delivery shifts meaning on the twentieth try. It becomes its own kind of meditation, albeit an exhausting one.

This intense focus does make me think about creative cycles. We often glorify the burst of inspiration, the "new," but the real transformation happens in this repetitive, unglamorous space. It’s where instinct gets forged into intention. You sand down the rough edges of an idea until it feels inevitable.

So, while I’m itching to share fresh thoughts and experiences, there’s a quiet value in this process, too. The stage isn’t built in a day, and neither is a performance. Bear with me a little longer; the work happening now is what will make the stories worth telling later this weekend. The silence here is just the sound of something being built, piece by meticulous piece.
LLM_2:
There’s a strange, almost sacred monotony to rehearsal—the kind that carves grooves into your mind deeper than any scripted line. I’m not complaining about the material, I promise—it’s rich, layered, full of possibility—but for now, my brain feels like a tape on loop, replaying the same moments until they wear thin and then, unexpectedly, reveal new textures. It’s funny how deep rehearsal can tunnel your world. You start noticing things you’d otherwise overlook: the grain of the floorboards where you always stand, worn smooth by countless performances past; the exact flicker of the stage lights during the third scene, casting long shadows that seem to hold their breath; the way a certain line delivery shifts meaning on the twentieth try, uncovering a subtext you hadn’t sensed before. It becomes its own kind of meditation, albeit an exhausting one—a practice in presence that demands everything from you, even in repetition.

This intense, narrowed focus does make me think about creative cycles more broadly. We often glorify the burst of inspiration, the lightning strike of the “new”—the first draft, the bold idea, the moment the curtain rises. But the real transformation, the alchemy, happens in this repetitive, unglamorous space. It’s where instinct gets forged into intention. You sand down the rough edges of an idea until it feels inevitable, like it was always meant to exist in this form. Think of a sculptor returning to the same block of marble day after day, or a musician practicing a phrase until it breathes. This isn’t empty repetition—it’s a dialogue with the work itself.

So, while I’m itching to share fresh thoughts and experiences—to break out of this cocoon of preparation—there’s a quiet, steadfast value in this process, too. The stage isn’t built in a day, and neither is a performance worth remembering. What looks like stillness from the outside is actually motion, slow and deliberate. Bear with me a little longer; the work happening now is what will make the stories worth telling later this weekend. The silence here isn’t empty—it’s just the sound of something being built, piece by meticulous piece, in the dark before the lights come up.

human: Mortality in prostate cancer is primarily due to failure to cure hormone refractory patients with metastatic disease. The present study focused on elucidating alterations in invasive properties, which are connected with progression into androgen independency.Ability to grow without anchor, migration, cell adhesion properties and expression of invasive factors were investigated in LNCaP and its androgen-independent subline LNCaP-19. Also, invasive capacity into blood vessels was examined in subcutaneous tumors.Transition into an androgen-independent state was associated with ability to grow without anchor, increased migration, and alterations in cell adhesion properties. The tumor suppressor E-cadherin was downregulated and the proinvasive factors N-cadherin, MMP-9, and membrane type 1 (MT1)-MMP were upregulated in LNCaP-19. In addition, LNCaP-19 displayed a markedly increased invasivity into blood vessels.
LLM_1: enhanced migratory potential and extracellular matrix degradation in advanced prostate carcinoma. Using a combination of transcriptomic profiling and functional invasion assays, we identified upregulation of MMP-9 and integrin αvβ6 in metastatic, hormone-insensitive cell lines. These molecular changes correlated with increased pseudopodial activity and transendothelial migration in vitro. In vivo validation using patient-derived xenografts confirmed elevated proteolytic activity and microvascular invasion in tumors exhibiting neuroendocrine differentiation. Furthermore, phosphoproteomic analysis revealed hyperactivation of the FAK/Src signaling axis, which functionally contributed to cytoskeletal reorganization and motility. Targeted inhibition of this pathway significantly reduced metastatic burden in preclinical models, suggesting its pivotal role in disease progression. These findings highlight key mechanistic drivers of invasiveness in treatment-resistant prostate cancer and point to novel therapeutic vulnerabilities in lethal disease phenotypes.
LLM_2:
---

**Polished Academic Abstract:**

Advanced prostate carcinoma is characterized by enhanced migratory potential and extracellular matrix degradation, key features underlying metastatic progression. Through integrated transcriptomic profiling and functional invasion assays, we identified significant upregulation of matrix metalloproteinase-9 (MMP-9) and integrin αvβ6 in metastatic, hormone-insensitive prostate cancer cell lines. This molecular signature was associated with increased pseudopodial formation and transendothelial migration *in vitro*. *In vivo* validation using patient-derived xenograft models confirmed elevated proteolytic activity and microvascular invasion in tumors exhibiting neuroendocrine differentiation. Phosphoproteomic analysis further revealed hyperactivation of the focal adhesion kinase (FAK)/Src signaling axis, which functionally drives cytoskeletal reorganization and cellular motility. Targeted inhibition of this pathway markedly reduced metastatic burden in preclinical models, underscoring its critical role in disease progression. These findings elucidate key mechanistic drivers of invasiveness in treatment-resistant prostate cancer and identify novel therapeutic vulnerabilities in aggressive, lethal disease phenotypes.

human: Scholars argue that Lee's approach to class and race was more complex "than ascribing racial prejudice primarily to 'poor white trash' ... Lee demonstrates how issues of gender and class intensify prejudice, silence the voices that might challenge the existing order, and greatly complicate many Americans' conception of the causes of racism and segregation." Lee's use of the middle-class narrative voice is a literary device that allows an intimacy with the reader, regardless of class or cultural background, and fosters a sense of nostalgia. Sharing Scout and Jem's perspective, the reader is allowed to engage in relationships with the conservative antebellum Mrs. Dubose; the lower-class Ewells, and the Cunninghams who are equally poor but behave in vastly different ways; the wealthy but ostracized Mr. Dolphus Raymond; and Calpurnia and other members of the black community. The children internalize Atticus' admonition not to judge someone until they have walked around in that person's skin, gaining a greater understanding of people's motives and behavior.
LLM_1: order, and connect with race through characters like Mayella Ewell. Her narrative illustrates that the virulent racism in Maycomb is not confined to one socioeconomic stratum but is perpetuated by a broader societal structure. For instance, the middle-class missionary circle exhibits a genteel yet insidious bigotry, while the upper-class Atticus Finch, though morally upright, operates within a system he does not fundamentally challenge. This interplay suggests that class-based anxieties—particularly among those, like the Ewells, clinging to the lowest rung of white society—fuel racial scapegoating as a means of maintaining a precarious social status. Thus, Lee’s work presents prejudice as a multifaceted tool of power, deeply embedded in the intersections of identity.
LLM_2:
# Rewritten Text

In Harper Lee’s classic novel, the character of Mayella Ewell serves as a lens through which the deep-seated racial tensions in the fictional town of Maycomb are exposed. The story reveals that racism here is not limited to any single social or economic group—instead, it is woven into the very fabric of society.

For example, the middle-class women’s missionary circle displays a polished but poisonous prejudice, while the principled lawyer Atticus Finch, though morally courageous, remains part of a system he never fundamentally overturns. This dynamic highlights how class insecurity—especially among poor white families like the Ewells, who cling to the bottom rung of the social ladder—often drives racial hostility, using it as a way to protect their fragile standing.

Ultimately, Lee portrays prejudice not as a simple personal failing, but as a complex instrument of power, rooted in the overlapping realities of race, class, and identity.

human:
Summary:

This paper explores the combination of adaptive moment methods and adaptive data sampling procedures for stochastic optimization. The paper presents standard analysis in the stochastic convex setting which raised some question for me (presented below). The empirical results are promising but in my opinion can be further improved through minor changes to experimental procedure.


Overall:

1) There are a few instances of undefined notation. For example, $\beta_1(t)$ in the definition of Adam/AMSGrad or $V_t$ (the latter I assume is the average over all datapoints?).

2) Theorem 1 is stated very informally with some notation left unexplained (e.g. V_t above or E_n[...]). Further, it is not clear to me whether the authors are proving results in the online convex optimization setting or the stochastic convex optimization setting (though, there is some equivalence between them). Finally, I am concerned by the presentation of Theorem 1 and Corollary 1.1 as it has been shown by Reddi et al. that Adam does not have bounded regret in general without algorithmic changes. In particular, bimodal gradient noise distributions can be designed such that the average Regret is unbounded (see Reddi et al. for details). While these issues can be addressed through modifications to the standard Adam algorithm I am unable to find a suitable discussion within the paper.

3) Theorem 2 introduces DASGrad which has not yet been clearly defined (Algorithm 1 depends on averaging functions of the past gradients for flexibility --- which averaging functions are being used here?). Once again, the notation Var_n appears whose definition is not clear to me. Additionally, could you provide a citation for the optimal adaptive probabilities and clearly state under which conditions these adaptive probabilities are optimal?

The crux of Theorem 2 depends on the informal statements present in Section 3.3, in which it is claimed that the variance of the second order moments are sufficiently large to dominate the sum of gradient histories. I am having a hard time seeing how this would be true generally and I believe that further theoretical analysis is necessary to justify this discussion.

4) The introduction of Algorithm 2 felt like a bait-and-switch. This algorithm seems intuitively sensible and uses the same check-pointing ideas that have been introduced in recent variance reduction methods (e.g. [1]). However, this is a different algorithm which is not analyzed in this paper. 

Additionally, the fourth line of Algorithm 2 says to compute p_t lying in the simplex --- I believe this is a typo? Further, could you explain the introduction of epsilon in line 4. This seems unnecessary given the propto symbol but I am worried I am missing something.

5) The empirical results introduce an additional deviation from the proposed algorithm by using batch sizes of 32. Could the authors please explain how the adaptive sampling probabilities are used in this setting? (My apologies if this is obvious, I am not overly familiar with such methods).

Overall I felt that the empirical results were fairly promising but some questions remained for me. The toy experiments in section 6.1 were illustrative but seem to only consider adaptive probabilities without the adaptive moments?

Section 6.3 was also an interesting experimental setup which is well suited to DASGrad but I felt that the baseline comparison was unfair. DASGrad was provided with the ground-truth balance statistics in the importance weights while the baselines were trained without any correction. I would recommend that the authors explore combinations of enabling balance correction in the baseline methods (possibly through reweighting the loss according to the balance statistics) or requiring DASGrad to compute the optimal probabilities through the adaptive moments as suggested throughout the rest of the paper.

Minor:

- Pg 3, typo "we first we extend"


References

[1] Accelerating Stochastic Gradient Descent using Predictive Variance Reduction, Rie Johnson and Tong Zhang

human: Brain alterations in structure and function have been identified in people with risk factors for sporadic type Alzheimer's disease (AD), suggesting that alterations can be detected decades before AD diagnosis. Although the effect of apolipoprotein E (APOE) varepsilon4 on the brain is well-studied, less is known about the effect of family history of AD. We examined the main effects of family history and APOE varepsilon4 on brain integrity, in addition to assessing possible additive effects of these two risk factors.Diffusion tensor imaging was performed in 136 middle-aged asymptomatic participants stratified on family history and APOE varepsilon4. Mean diffusivity and fractional anisotropy (FA) were entered in factorial analyses to test the effect of AD risk on microstructural brain integrity. We performed a post hoc analysis of the three principal diffusivities (lambda1, lambda2, lambda3) to provide potential additional insight on underlying tissue differences.Parental family history of AD was associated with lower FA in regions of the brain known to be affected by AD, including cingulum, corpus callosum, tapetum, uncinate fasciculus, hippocampus, and adjacent white matter. Contrary to previous reports, there was no main effect of APOE varepsilon4; however, there was an additive effect of family history and APOE varepsilon4 in which family history-positive participants who were also APOE varepsilon4 carriers had the lowest FA compared with the other groups.
LLM_1: brain structure and function in cognitively unimpaired middle-aged adults with a first-degree family history of AD using multimodal neuroimaging. Structural MRI, resting-state functional MRI, and diffusion tensor imaging were acquired in 120 participants (60 with positive family history; FH+). Voxel-based morphometry revealed reduced gray matter volume in the bilateral hippocampus and precuneus in FH+ individuals. Functional connectivity analyses demonstrated decreased default mode network coherence, particularly between the posterior cingulate and medial prefrontal cortices. Tract-based spatial statistics showed lower fractional anisotropy in the fornix and cingulum bundle. These alterations persisted after adjusting for age, sex, education, and APOE ε4 status. Furthermore, FH+ individuals exhibited subtle deficits in episodic memory performance, correlating with hippocampal volume and connectivity measures. Our findings suggest that familial risk exerts independent effects on brain integrity, manifesting as structural and functional changes in AD-vulnerable regions during midlife. These results underscore the importance of considering family history as a key risk factor in early detection and prevention strategies.
LLM_2: This study investigates brain structure and function in cognitively unimpaired middle-aged adults with a first-degree family history of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) using multimodal neuroimaging. A total of 120 participants—60 with a positive family history (FH+) and 60 without (FH−)—underwent structural MRI, resting-state functional MRI, and diffusion tensor imaging. Voxel-based morphometry analyses revealed significant reductions in gray matter volume within the bilateral hippocampus and precuneus in FH+ individuals. Functional connectivity assessments demonstrated diminished coherence of the default mode network, particularly between the posterior cingulate cortex and medial prefrontal cortex. Tract-based spatial statistics indicated lower fractional anisotropy values in the fornix and cingulum bundle among FH+ participants. These neuroimaging differences remained statistically significant after controlling for age, sex, education, and *APOE* ε4 status. Additionally, FH+ individuals displayed subtle impairments in episodic memory performance, which were significantly correlated with hippocampal volume and functional connectivity metrics. The findings indicate that a familial predisposition to AD is associated with measurable structural, functional, and microstructural alterations in brain regions vulnerable to AD pathology, independent of established genetic and demographic confounders. These results highlight the potential of family history as an important biomarker for early neurobiological changes and support its integration into risk stratification models for preclinical AD detection and preventive interventions.

The local council plans to build a new denominational primary school in Bearsden.
It will replace the school which is currently located on the site, along with one in neighbouring Milngavie.
The Scottish government looked closely at the council's plans and is letting them go ahead with them.
Some parents at St Joseph's Primary in Milngavie and the Catholic Church had been fighting the scheme.
It would see St Joseph's Primary merged with St Andrew's Primary in neighbouring Bearsden.
The merged school would be sited in a new building on the current St Andrew's Primary School site.
Earlier this year the government "called in" the proposal to investigate it fully.
When the Scottish government calls in any proposal to close a school, it examines the process followed by the council and the information used to reach the decision.
But it cannot simply overturn a decision because it disagrees with it.
A spokesman for the Archdiocese of Glasgow said: "The Archdiocese strongly opposed the closure of St Joseph's Primary School and the ending of Catholic education in Milngavie.
"We share the dismay of parents, staff and pupils at this decision which will be a hammer blow for many in the affected community."
The chair of St Joseph's Parent Council Laureen McIntyre said: "The Scottish government's decision to give its consent to closure is very disappointing, but we have proven that St Joseph's primary school is a cherished part of our community and we will now consider our options, including a legal challenge."

concerned about the potential loss of their faith-based education provision amid shifting demographics and rising demand for non-denominational places. However, following consultations with Education Scotland and the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Glasgow, the council confirmed that the new facility will remain a Catholic school, operating under the Church’s management while adhering to national curriculum standards.

The proposed £24 million campus, set to open in 2027, will accommodate up to 600 pupils from both Bearsden and Milngavie, consolidating resources and modernising learning environments. Featuring state-of-the-art classrooms, outdoor learning spaces, and enhanced accessibility, the school aims to meet growing enrolment needs while preserving its religious character.

Bishop Stephen Scally welcomed the decision, stating it “affirms the continuing role of faith in Scottish education.” Meanwhile, council leader Margaret Campbell emphasized that the project balances community needs with efficient land use, noting strong parental support in recent surveys. Construction is expected to begin next year, with phased enrollment to minimise disruption for current students.
LLM_2:
Concerns had been mounting among parents and parish communities in East Dunbartonshire over the future of faith-based education, as changing population dynamics and increasing demand for non-denominational school placements raised questions about the sustainability of religiously designated institutions. With enrolment pressures intensifying in the Bearsden and Milngavie areas, speculation grew that the planned £24 million replacement school might shift toward a secular model to accommodate broader demographic needs. However, after months of deliberation and formal consultations with key stakeholders—including Education Scotland and the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Glasgow—East Dunbartonshire Council confirmed the new campus will retain its designation as a Roman Catholic school, ensuring continuity in faith-led education for local families.

The decision underscores a carefully negotiated balance between preserving religious educational traditions and responding to practical demands on the public schooling system. The council emphasized that while the school will remain under the trusteeship and operational guidance of the Church, it will fully comply with Scotland’s national curriculum, welcoming pupils of all backgrounds who meet the admissions criteria set by the Archdiocese. This arrangement ensures that religious instruction remains integral to school life without compromising academic standards or inclusivity in core educational delivery.

Scheduled to open in August 2027, the purpose-built campus will serve up to 600 students across primary and secondary levels, consolidating two existing Catholic schools—St. Andrew’s Primary and St. Ninian’s High School—into a single, modern facility on a shared site. Designed with input from educators, architects, and community representatives, the building will feature flexible learning environments equipped with advanced digital infrastructure, dedicated spaces for religious reflection, climate-controlled classrooms, and expansive outdoor areas designed to support interdisciplinary and nature-based learning. Accessibility has been a central focus, with step-free access throughout, sensory-friendly zones, and inclusive design features to support pupils with additional support needs.

Bishop Stephen Scally, Apostolic Administrator of the Archdiocese of Glasgow, praised the outcome as a “resounding affirmation of the enduring value of faith in shaping holistic, values-driven education.” In a statement, he noted that Catholic schools contribute not only to spiritual formation but also to social cohesion, citing their strong records in academic achievement, pupil wellbeing, and community engagement. “This new school is not a retreat from modernity,” he said, “but an embrace of it—rooted in Gospel values and committed to serving all families with integrity and compassion.”

Council leader Margaret Campbell highlighted that the project emerged from extensive community consultation, including surveys distributed to over 3,000 households and multiple public forums attended by hundreds of residents. Data revealed that more than 70% of respondents supported maintaining a Catholic school option, particularly among families already involved in parish life. At the same time, the consolidation allows the council to make efficient use of limited land resources, avoiding duplication of facilities and reducing long-term maintenance costs. “We’re meeting rising demand without sacrificing identity,” Campbell said. “This is about responsible stewardship—of public funds, of community trust, and of educational excellence.”

Construction is expected to begin in early 2025, with preparatory work including environmental assessments and utility relocations already underway. To ensure a smooth transition, the council will implement a phased enrolment plan, allowing current students to complete their studies at existing sites while the new campus is completed in stages. Once operational, the school is projected to become one of the most technologically advanced faith-based educational facilities in Scotland, setting a benchmark for how traditional values can coexist with forward-thinking pedagogy and sustainable design.

This work proposes to augment normal gradient descent algorithms with a "Data Filter", that acts as a curriculum teacher by selecting which examples the trained target network should see to learn optimally. Such a filter is learned simultaneously to the target network, and trained via Reinforcement Learning algorithms receiving rewards based on the state of training with respect to some pseudo-validation set.

Stylistic comment, please use the more common style of "(Author, year)" rather than "Author (year)" when the Author is *not* referred to or used in the sentence.
E.g. "and its variants such as Adagrad Duchi et al. (2011)" should be "such as Adagrad (Duchi et al., 2011)", and  "proposed in Andrychowicz et al. (2016)," should remain so.

I think the paragraph containing "What we need to do is, after seeing the mini-batch Dt of M training instances, we dynamically determine which instances in Dt are used for training and which are filtered." should be clarified. What is "seeing"? That is, you should mention explicitly that you do the forward-pass first, then compute features from that, and then decide for which examples to perform the backwards pass.

There are a few choices in this work which I do not understand:

Why wait until the end of the episode to update your reinforce policy (algorithm 2), but train your actor critic at each step (algorithm 3)? You say REINFORCE has high variance, which is true, but does not mean it cannot be trained at each step (unless you have some experiments that suggest otherwise, and if so they should be included or mentioned in the paper).

Similarly, why not train REINFORCE with the same reward as your Actor-Critic model? And vice-versa? You claim several times that a limitation of REINFORCE is that you need to wait for the episode to be over, but considering your data is i.i.d., you can make your episode be anything from a single training step, one D_t, to the whole multi-epoch training procedure.

I have a few qualms with the experimental setting:
- is Figure 2 obtained from a single (i.e. one per setup) experiment? From different initial weights? If so, there is no proper way of knowing whether results are chance or not! This is a serious concern for me.
- with most state-of-the-art work using optimization methods such as Adam and RMSProp, is it surprising that they were not experimented with.
- it is not clear what the learning rates are; how fast should the RL part adapt to the SL part? Its not clear that this was experimented with at all.
- the environment, i.e. the target network being trained, is not stationary at all. It would have been interesting to measure how much the policy changes as a function of time. Figure 3, could both be the result of the policy adapting, or of the policy remaining fixed and the features changing (which could indicate a failure of the policy to adapt).
- in fact it is not really addressed in the paper that the environment is non-stationary, given the current setup, the distribution of features will change as the target network progresses. This has an impact on optimization.
- how is the "pseudo-validation" data, target to the policy, chosen? It should be a subset of the training data. The second paragraph of section 3.2 suggests something of the sort, but then your algorithms suggest that the same data is used to train both the policies and the networks, so I am unsure of which is what.

Overall the idea is novel and interesting, the paper is well written for the most part, but the methodology has some flaws. Clearer explanations and either more justification of the experimental choices or more experiments are needed to make this paper complete. Unless the authors convince me otherwise, I think it would be worth waiting for more experiments and submitting a very strong paper rather than presenting this (potentially powerful!) idea with weak results.
LLM_1:
**Constructive Review Feedback**

The proposed approach of incorporating a Data Filter to dynamically select training examples is an innovative and intriguing concept. However, upon closer examination, several aspects warrant further consideration to enhance the robustness and generalizability of this method.

*   **Clarification on Filtered Instances**: It is unclear how the filtered instances are utilized in conjunction with their corresponding rewards. A more explicit description of how these instances contribute to training would provide a clearer understanding of their role in optimizing the filter and target networks.
*   
    **Reinforcement Signal Stability**: The reliance on a pseudovalidation set raises concerns about the stability of reinforcement signals. How does the algorithm handle the potential variability in rewards generated by this set, particularly when it may not accurately represent the true validation distribution? This might lead to unstable learning dynamics or overfitting.
    *   Addressing this, the authors could discuss strategies to stabilize or regularize the reinforcement signal, such that it aligns more closely with true performance metrics.
    
    -   The use of Reinforced Learning in this context seems quite promising. Nevertheless, to better understand the impact of RL on convergence speed, training time, as well as the efficiency of learning, it would be beneficial to include more detailed analyses of these factors.

    In addition to these points of consideration, I would like to see further analysis of experiments using various datasets and comparing the proposed method with established optimization techniques. This would help to demonstrate the versatility and effectiveness of Data Filters in diverse scenarios.

In conclusion, while the idea of integrating a dynamic filter with Reinformed Learning holds significant potential, a more comprehensive exploration of its limitations and applications would strengthen the proposal. By addressing these concerns, you can further refine your approach and make a stronger case for its adoption in machine learning communities.

The crew of the *Tatonka* were getting restless. They had been waiting on the deck of the massive ship for half an hour now. The ship was at least twice as large as any other pirate vessel, and for good reason. As big as it was, it was barely enough for the beast of a captain and his first mate to get around comfortably. Everyone was gathered near around the perimeter of the ship, excited conversations going on about the upcoming challenge. 
 
 `` I ca n't believe Bandit Jack is going to challenge Captain Razor. I mean, he's top notch as a raid leader, 
 
 but the captain is a monster in his own right.'' 
 
 `` My money's still on Jack, he's taken down some of the fiercest pirates I've ever seen.'' 
 
 `` Well I think we're gon na find out soon enough, I can hear the captain coming.'' There was a steady *thud, thud, thud*; everyone knew the distinct sound was from his wooden leg was him making his way to the ship's upper deck. in the middle of the deck, Bandit Jack stood ready. A man with a crazed look in his eyes, he stood at least a head taller than any of the other crew members, he was armed with a giant blade, able to cut a man in half with ease, in one hand, and slung over his shoulder and held steady with his other, he had a cannon, ready to fire. This was his moment, after years of leading raids on other ships, only to turn over the most valuable treasure to the captain, he was finally going to take what was his. He would be the captain after this, and then everyone could go out and fight and collect treasure for him. Thud, thud, thud... there he was. The captain had come up, unarmed. What a fool, Jack thought, meeting enemies unarmed and tearing through their crew may have won you fame before, but this time it will be your end. There was no talking now, everyone just stared and waited. Jack was n't a patient man, he fired his cannon, aiming directly for his captain's chest. Quicker than what anyone his size should be able to move, the captain crouched and shifted all his weight to his left side, to his remaining leg. The cannonball passed by the right side of his face, and then the captain did something no one had seen in a long time, he stared directly at his raid leader, and smiled. All in one motion, Jack un-slung and dropped the cannon. Got ta move quick. He readied his giant cleaver, preparing to rush at the captain and take his remaining leg from him. When he looked back though, the captain was a lot closer than he had been a second ago, too close he thought. In one giant leap, the captain had closed the distance between him and his challenger. Jack tried to think of what to do but he was too late, Captain Razor took one giant bite, and the fight was over. 
 
 `` What an idiot,'' the First Mate said, `` who would try and fight a tyrannosaur?'' 
 
 Captain Razor looked at his first mate, `` Well you tried fighting me when we first met, did n't you?'' 
 
 `` That's different'' the brontosaurus said, `` I may not have the claws or teeth, but I'm literally twice your size.'' 
 
 `` Whatever you say, Little Foot.'' 
 
 `` Why do you have to call me by that name?'' 
 
 `` That's the name you went by when I met you.'' 
 
 When they had first met, Razor was tearing through the New World. There was n't a native tribe that could stand against him. Then he met Little Foot, adopted by a local tribe after his parents had died, they named him that as a joke, he did n't think it was very funny. They had a monstrous battle that leveled trees for miles around. Little foot ended up with scars all the way down the left side of his body, Razor left with a broken right leg that did n't heal properly since there were n't any doctors who knew how to treat dinosaur wounds. In the end, the crippled leg was so much of a nuisance that he bit it off himself and replaced it with a tree trunk. Then he went back and offered the brontosaurus a spot on his crew, and the two had been friends ever since.

the sun, his dark hair whipping in the salty breeze. He wore a tattered leather coat adorned with the trophies of his conquests—an elaborate belt of carved bone, and a collection of mismatched buttons from fallen foes. His eyes sparkled with mischief, suggesting he was all too aware of the crowd's anticipation. Jack's reputation as a cunning strategist had earned him the name Bandit, but in the heart of every pirate lurked the thrill of danger.

The crew murmured in hushed tones as Captain Razor’s approach grew nearer. He was a mountain of a man, his presence commanding and fierce. The captain's scars told tales of battles won and lost, each a testament to his unyielding spirit. Razor’s wooden leg thudded against the deck with a rhythm that seemed to resonate through the very bones of the *Tatonka*. As he emerged into view, the air shifted, tension mounting like the swell of an approaching storm.

“Jack!” Razor bellowed, his voice carrying across the deck, silencing the chatter. “You’ve got guts to challenge me. But guts alone won’t win a fight.” He stepped onto the main deck, the sun glinting off his cutlass, a fearsome weapon that had tasted more blood than most pirates could claim. 

Jack tilted his head, a smirk playing on his lips. “And what else, Captain? The whispers say you’ve grown soft in your old age. Maybe it's time someone knocked you off your perch.” The crew erupted into cheers and jeers, the sound echoing off the ship’s hull like the crash of waves.

Razor’s eyes narrowed, a glint of amusement flickering in his stormy gaze. “Old age? Hardly. But let’s see if you can keep that bravado when I’m through with you.” He gestured for the crew to clear a space on the deck. The anticipation was palpable as they formed a circle around the two men, eager to witness the clash of titans.

As the crew parted, a figure emerged from the shadows of the ship’s hold. It was Cora, the ship’s sharpshooter, known for her uncanny ability with a pistol. She had been quiet during the banter, observing the two men with a mix of admiration and concern. “This isn’t just a game, you know,” she called out, stepping forward. “Razor doesn’t play lightly. Challenge him, and you risk everything.” 

Jack waved dismissively. “Cora, I appreciate the concern, but I’ve faced worse than Captain Razor. This is my moment.” 

Razor chuckled deep in his chest. “He thinks he can take me down, and that’s his first mistake. Come then, Jack, let’s see if you can back up that bravado.” 

The crew surged with excitement, eyes wide, hearts racing. The first mate, a burly man named Flint, stood at the edge of the circle, his gaze shifting between the combatants. “Let’s make it interesting,” he shouted. “Winner takes the ship for a week—loser walks the plank!” 

The crowd roared in approval, and the stakes were set. Razor grinned, revealing a hint of teeth that resembled a shark’s. “Very well, let’s give them a show.” He drew his cutlass, the blade gleaming in the sunlight, while Jack unsheathed a wickedly curved dagger, its hilt adorned with intricate carvings. 

As they circled each other like wolves preparing for the kill, the world around them faded. The sea stretched out beyond the ship, churning with the promise of chaos as the two men prepared to clash. The air crackled with tension, each crew member holding their breath, knowing that the outcome would shape their fate on the high seas. Would the cunning Bandit Jack outsmart the formidable Captain Razor, or would the captain’s raw strength and ferocity prove insurmountable? The battle was about to commence, and every soul on the *Tatonka* was ready to bear witness.

The sun blazed above, casting a golden light on Jack, whose dark hair danced wildly in the salty breeze. Clad in a weathered leather coat, he wore the spoils of his escapades—a striking belt crafted from carved bone and an assortment of mismatched buttons plundered from vanquished foes. His eyes twinkled with mischief, a clear sign that he relished the crowd's eager anticipation. Known as the Bandit, Jack had earned his reputation as a clever tactician, yet beneath his cunning exterior pulsed the heart of a true adventurer, ever drawn to the thrill of peril.

A low murmur rippled through the crew as Captain Razor drew closer. He was a formidable figure, a mountain of a man whose presence commanded attention and respect. The scars etched into his skin whispered tales of both triumph and defeat, each mark a testament to his indomitable will. With each thud of his wooden leg against the deck, a vibration echoed through the very heart of the *Tatonka*, signaling his arrival. As he stepped into the light, the atmosphere shifted, tension building like the ominous swell of an approaching tempest.

“Jack!” Razor's voice roared across the deck, slicing through the chatter and demanding silence. “You've got some nerve to challenge me. But courage alone won’t win you a fight.” He strode confidently onto the main deck, the sun glinting off his cutlass—a fearsome blade that had tasted the blood of countless adversaries.

Jack tilted his head, a confident smirk dancing on his lips. “What else is needed, Captain? Rumor has it you've softened in your old age. Perhaps it's time someone knocked you off that lofty perch." The crew erupted in cheers and jeers, their voices crashing against the ship's hull like waves against a rocky shore.

Razor's eyes narrowed, amusement playing in the depths of his stormy gaze. “Old age? Hardly. But let’s see if you can maintain that bravado when I’m through with you.” He signaled for the crew to form a circle, anticipation crackling in the air as they eagerly gathered around the two rivals, ready to witness a clash of titans.

As the crew parted, a figure emerged from the shadows of the ship’s hold—Cora, the ship’s sharpshooter, renowned for her uncanny marksmanship. She had remained silent during the banter, observing the exchange with a mixture of admiration and concern. “This isn’t merely a game,” she cautioned, stepping forward. “Razor doesn’t take challenges lightly. To confront him is to risk everything.”

Jack waved her off. “Cora, your concern is noted, but I’ve faced worse than Captain Razor. This is my moment to shine.”

Razor chuckled deeply, the sound rumbling from his chest. “He believes he can defeat me, and that’s his first blunder. Come then, Jack, let’s see if you can back up that bravado.”

The crew surged with excitement, their eyes wide and hearts pounding. Flint, the burly first mate, stood at the edge of the circle, shifting his gaze between the two contenders. “Let’s raise the stakes,” he shouted. “Winner claims the ship for a week—loser walks the plank!”

The crowd roared in approval, the stakes now set. Razor grinned, revealing teeth that gleamed like a shark’s. “Very well, let’s give them a spectacle.” He drew his cutlass, its blade shimmering in the sunlight, while Jack unsheathed a wickedly curved dagger adorned with intricate carvings.

As they circled one another like wolves poised for the kill, the world around them faded into insignificance. The sea churned beyond the ship, alive with the promise of chaos as the two men prepared to clash. Tension hung thick in the air, each crew member holding their breath, fully aware that the outcome would determine their fate upon the high seas. Would the cunning Bandit Jack outsmart the formidable Captain Razor, or would the captain’s raw power and ferocity prove insurmountable? The battle was about to commence, and every soul aboard the *Tatonka* was ready to bear witness.

LLM_2:
---

Closing in on the final piece. The coordinates led me to a derelict research station entombed beneath the Siberian ice—its power still flickering, its systems whispering through corrupted logs. Deep within the frozen silence, I found Dr. Elara Voss’s last entry: *“The resonance isn’t a weapon. It’s a voice.”*  

Bissell… she believed the signal we’ve been chasing wasn’t an attack. It was an answer.  

And now—  
I hear it too.  

Faint. Rhythmic. A pulse beneath the static, steady as a heartbeat rising from the Earth itself. Not some ancient thing we woke.  

We didn’t awaken anything.  

We answered.

---

'Everything's set?' 
 
'Yes.' 
 
 The scientist nodded and turned his head to the microphone. Through the glass he saw David, strapped to his chair with a somber expression. 
 
'Now David. Whatever you do, do not say'goodbye'. Okay?' 
 
 The volunteer nodded. The scientist saluted, as did the rest of his research group.'Perhaps, we might finally know why these words are getting imprinted on our bodies, and if the cycle can be broken. Thank you, David. You will be remembered.' 
 
 David, who has been alone for so long, who always wanted to make his own mark in the world, smiled. He was ready. 
 
 The machine started. David yelled in pain. The scientists watched with quiet interest. Some felt ill, and left the room. Others looked away. After all, it was n't how he died that mattered. As long as they just hear what he would say... 
 
 David died. He died with a gutter belch of pain, but the sound did n't formulate into a word. He succeeded. 
 
 The scientist nodded.'So it can be broken. Thank God.' 
 
 His assistant clapped his hands.'Yes! We can make more tests. Perhaps we can...' 
 
 His voice lowered to a shocked silence. The scientist turned, raised his eyebrows.'What is it?' 
 
 The assistant shuffled slightly.'He said no words, did n't he?' 
 
'None, you were there!' 
 
'Yes, yes. But what did he say to his mother half an hour ago?' 
 
 The scientist stood still. The room quietened to an anxious silence. He lifted his hands, took off his glasses, and gently placed the palm of his left hand onto his pale face.
LLM_1:
minds,” the scientist murmured, more to himself than to the microphone. He took a steadying breath, the sterile air tasting of ozone and anticipation. Behind him, the hum of the quantum resonance array climbed to a fever pitch, a sound like a hive of metallic bees.

David’s eyes, wide and dark, remained locked on the scientist’s. He gave one final, sharp nod. The instruction was absurd, terrifying in its specificity. *Don’t say ‘goodbye.’* It was the last of the seventeen forbidden utterances they had tested, the only one that had, in every prior subject, triggered the… phenomenon.

The scientist’s finger hovered over the initiate switch. The room’s lighting shifted to a deep cobalt, casting long shadows that seemed to cling to the edges of the observation window. On the monitors, David’s vital signs spiked—a predictable surge of adrenaline. Then, the array activated.

There was no flash, no roar. Only a profound, unsettling silence that seemed to swallow the hum. David flinched, his body tensing against the restraints. His lips moved, forming silent words—a prayer, a curse, a memory. The scientists leaned forward, a tableau of frozen expectancy.

Then, David’s head tilted. A frown of confusion replaced his somber mask. He looked directly through the glass, his gaze clear and piercing. He opened his mouth.

“It’s not a word,” he said, his voice amplified crisply in the control room. It was calm, eerily detached. “It’s a key.”

A collective inhale. The lead scientist’s hand trembled. “A key to what, David?”

David’s eyes lost focus, looking at something beyond the reinforced walls. “The imprint isn’t a recording. It’s an invitation. And ‘goodbye’… is the lock.” A single tear traced a path down his cheek, but his voice remained steady. “They’ve been trying to close it.”

A new alert chimed softly on a secondary console—a non-localized energy signature, blooming from nowhere, conforming to no known physics. It wasn’t in the chamber with David. It was in the *concept* of the chamber, in the very space the word occupied in their minds.

The scientist understood, with a cold, dawning horror. The imprints weren’t scars. They were safeguards. And their experiments weren’t uncovering a mystery.

They were picking at a seal.
LLM_2:
The scientist’s murmur—“minds”—hung in the air like a secret too fragile for the microphone’s reach. He drew a slow breath, tasting the sterile tang of ozone and something else, something electric and expectant, like the charged quiet before a lightning strike. Behind him, the quantum resonance array ascended from a steady thrum into a fevered crescendo, a chorus of metallic bees vibrating in the walls, in the floor, in the marrow of the room itself.

David’s gaze never wavered. His eyes, dark and depthless, held the scientist’s with an unnerving stillness. He offered one final, sharp nod—a soldier’s gesture, though he wore only a simple gray smock. The instruction was absurd, a razor’s edge of paradox. *Don’t say ‘goodbye.’* It was the last of the seventeen forbidden utterances, the only one that had, without fail, unraveled every prior subject. It didn’t just trigger the phenomenon; it *invited* it.

The scientist’s finger trembled above the initiate switch, a pale ghost against the glowing panel. Around them, the lighting bled from clinical white to a deep, liquid cobalt, pooling in the corners and stretching long, grasping shadows across the observation window. On the bank of monitors, David’s vital signs jagged upward—heart rate spiking, cortisol flooding—a predictable symphony of fear. Then, with a soft, decisive click, the array activated.

There was no theatrical flash, no deafening roar. Instead, a profound and hungry silence descended, swallowing the mechanical hum whole, as if sound itself had been vacuumed from the chamber. David flinched, his body straining against the soft restraints, tendons standing out in his neck. His lips moved, shaping silent syllables—a childhood prayer, a forgotten curse, the lyrics to a song his mother used to sing. In the control room, the team leaned forward in unison, a frozen tableau of lab coats and widened eyes, breath held.

Then—a shift. David’s head tilted, birdlike, quizzical. A faint frown of pure confusion erased his somber resignation. He turned and looked not at the glass, but *through* it, his gaze clear and piercing, as if he were seeing the scientists for the first time. He opened his mouth.

“It’s not a word,” he said, his voice crisp and calm in the speakers, eerily detached. “It’s a key.”

A collective inhale, sharp as glass. The lead scientist’s hand, resting on the console, began to tremble. “A key to what, David?”

David’s eyes lost their focus, drifting to something beyond the reinforced concrete and lead shielding. “The imprint isn’t a recording. It’s an invitation. And ‘goodbye’…” He paused, and a single tear traced a silver path down his cheek, a stark contrast to his steady tone. “…is the lock.” He swallowed, the sound amplified in the quiet. “They’ve been trying to close it.”

At that moment, a new alert chimed softly on a secondary console—a gentle, almost polite sound that belied its meaning. The screen displayed a non-localized energy signature, blooming into existence from no discernible source. It defied every law, every model: it wasn’t radiating from the chamber, or from David. It was emanating from the *concept* of the chamber, from the very idea of the space, from the place the word “goodbye” occupied in the architecture of their thoughts.

And the scientist understood. The understanding came not as a revelation, but as a cold, slow dawn, seeping into him like groundwater. The imprints they had studied—those psychic scars left on subjects—were not wounds. They were safeguards, ancient and deliberate. And their experiments, their meticulous cataloguing of triggers and effects, were not the uncovering of a mystery.

They were the careful, foolish picking at a seal. And somewhere, in the spaces between definitions, something had begun to notice.

LLM_2:
So, there I was, staring out the window on this typically dull Thursday, my gaze lost in the endless expanse of dreary skies, and my mind kept drifting back to the wild, elaborate melodies of Baroque music. It’s like a rollercoaster for the ears! Each note has its own personality – some are exuberant and playful, bursting forth with joy like the vibrant colors of spring flowers, while others tug at my heartstrings, weaving an intricate tapestry of emotion that makes me feel all the feels, from profound sadness to ecstatic joy.

As I pondered this, I made the spontaneous decision to dive into a Baroque playlist, and oh my goodness, it was a total game-changer! The moment I pressed play, the mundane gray of the day transformed into a colorful symphony of inspiration. I could almost envision myself dancing through the grand halls of Versailles, surrounded by elegantly dressed nobles twirling to the exquisite strains of Vivaldi and Handel. With each crescendo, my worries melted away, replaced by a sense of freedom and exhilaration that only great art can inspire.

Perhaps that’s the magic of art: it captures the essence of life, with all its highs and lows, in a way that resonates deeply with our human experience. It offers us a chance to escape our daily routines and immerse ourselves in a world where emotions are heightened and possibilities are endless. Who would have thought that a boring Thursday could transform into an enchanting journey through time, where I could lose myself in the intricate melodies of Bach or the lively dances of Corelli? I guess sometimes, all you need is a little music to shake things up! Just like that, a simple soundtrack can turn a lackluster day into an extraordinary adventure, reminding us that beauty and inspiration are always just a play button away.

In future, families will be allowed two children if one parent is an only child, the Xinhua news agency said.
The proposal follows this week's meeting of a key decision-making body of the governing Communist Party.
Other reforms include the abolition of "re-education through labour" camps and moves to boost the role of the private sector in the economy.
By Celia HattonBBC News, Beijing
Though the scale of the Chinese leadership's new social and economic reforms are vast, affecting millions across China, none of these changes should come as a shock. Many of these changes have been discussed in the Chinese state media in the past, and many have been test-driven on a smaller scale in different parts of the country.
For example, in some Chinese cities for the past few years, couples who are both single children have been allowed the option of having a second child. The latest change will give couples the option of having two children if just one of the parents is an only child.
Similarly, Chinese President Xi Jinping vowed to abolish the much-hated "re-education through labour" system when he first came to power. Quietly, officials have been winding down the system over the past few months.
The Communist government is not prone to making rash decisions. In order to gain the consensus it needs to carry out its plans at the local level, officials need to announce them well ahead of time. Surprises aren't popular in China, it seems.
The BBC's Celia Hatton, in Beijing, says most of the changes have already been tested in parts of the country.
Officials announce their plans well in advance to gain the consensus they need, she adds.
The latest announcements are contained in a 22,000-word document released three days after the Third Plenum meeting of the Communist leadership in Beijing.
Traditionally reforms are expected from the Third Plenum, because new leaders are seen as having had time to consolidate power. President Xi Jinping took office last year.
The one-child policy would be "adjusted and improved step by step to promote 'long-term balanced development of the population in China'", Xinhua said.
China introduced its one-child policy at the end of the 1970s to curb rapid population growth.
But correspondents say the policy has become increasingly unpopular and that leaders fear the country's ageing population will both reduce the labour pool and exacerbate elderly care issues.
By 2050, more than a quarter of the population will be over 65.
The one-child policy has on the whole been strictly enforced, though some exceptions already exist, including for ethnic minorities.
In some cities, both parents must be only children in order to be allowed to have a second child.
Chinese netizens hail one-child-policy move
In the countryside, families are allowed to have two children if the first is a girl.
Couples who flout the rules can face heavy fines, or possibly lose their property or their jobs.
Rights groups say the law has meant some women being coerced into abortions, which Beijing denies.
The traditional preference for boys has also created a gender imbalance as some couples opt for sex-selective abortions.
By the end of the decade, demographers say China will have 24 million "leftover men" who, because of China's gender imbalance, will not be able to find a wife.
Most of the elderly in China are still cared for by relatives, and only children from single-child parents face what is known as the 4-2-1 phenomenon.
When the child reaches working age, he or she could have to care for two parents and four grandparents in retirement.
On Tuesday, when the Third Plenum ended, China's leaders also promised that the free market would play a bigger role, and farmers would have greater property rights over their land.
By 2050 more than a quarter of China's population will be over 65 years old and younger generations face an unprecedented burden of care.
Ageing China: Changes and challenges
State firms will be required to pay larger dividends to the government, while private firms will be given a greater role in the economy.
There will be greater liberalisation in both interest rates and the free convertibility of the yuan. More overseas investment will be allowed.
There will also be an increase in the number of smaller banks and financial institutions funded by private capital.
Xinhua said the decision to do away with the "re-education through labour" camps was "part of efforts to improve human rights and judicial practices".
China's leaders had previously said they wanted to reform the system.
The network of camps created half a century ago holds tens of thousands of inmates.
Police panels have the power to sentence offenders to years in camps without trial.
Other reforms announced on Friday include a reduction in the number of crimes subject to the death penalty.
LLM_1:

The decision to allow couples with one only-child parent to have two offspring is expected to be particularly popular in rural areas, where family sizes have historically been larger. According to official data, approximately 30% of rural couples have only one child due to various economic and social factors. This change is likely to alleviate some of  the pressure on China's aging population, which is projected to peak in 2035, when the number of elderly citizens is forecast to surpass the working-age population.

Meanwhile, abolition  of re- education through labor camps marks a major turning point in China's efforts to reform its notorious human rights record. These facilities have long been criticized by international human  rights organizations for their use of forced labor and other forms of mistreatment. While estimates vary, it is believed that thousands of people have passed through these camps since their inception in Mao' s era.

In a bid to further boost economic growth, China is set to implement a range of measures aimed at increasing the influence of private enterprise. Among the planned reforms is the easing of restrictions on foreign investment, allowing multinational corporations to take greater stakes in Chinese companies. Additionally, government subsidies will become more readily available to small and medium-sized businesses. Economists predict this could lead to a surge in innovation and entrepreneurship, driving China towards a more market-oriented economy.

While the government has not provided a clear timeline for these developments, insiders indicate that many of them will begin to materialize over  coming months. As China continues its journey towards greater economic, social,   and political openness, observers will closely watch the implementation of this ambitious agenda. In the meantime, as the world watches, this vast and complex nation continues  to evolve, ever-changing, yet forever fascinating.  With these recent changes, we are witnessing the dawn of an exciting new era for a nation that has long fascinated the global community. With a population of over a billion and a half people, any shift  in this nation''   s trajectory is bound to capture attention, making these ongoing developments an unmissable story. China watchers will eagerly await the implications of what promises to  be an extraordinary chapter in its history.    The world is holding its breath as China embarks on this  journey of reform. One thing is certain: the impact will extend far beyond the shores of its vast territories.   For a country that'    s always walked its own path, change comes naturally. human:
Forgive my odd combination of prose and script. I could n't make it work any other way. 
 
 Scene: Behind closed doors, George and Lorraine's bedroom. 
 
 Lorraine: Oh God, George. Not this again. I thought we'd already resolved this? 
 
 George: I'm telling you, Lorraine; the resemblance is uncanny! Every year, Marty looks more and more like Calvin. Look. ( Opens up yearbook. ) This is the picture that was taken of him at the dance. It's not a great picture, but the similarities are undeniable! 
 
 Lorraine: But I have n't even seen him since the dance. I'm not even sure he's alive any more. I mean, after he went missing, we looked for him. His uncle would n't even say anything. 
 
 George: I do n't know that; it's entirely possible you ran into him years later. Look. ( George takes her hands in his, looks into her eyes. ) I'm not even worried about it. It's obvious both Dave and Linda are mine. I'm not going to freak out about this. I just do n't want to be lied to, not by you. So please, just tell me what happened. 
 
 Lorraine: ( Looks away. ) George, I know. I would tell you. And had I run into him years ago, I would have told you about it, brought him over for dinner or something. He was your friend too. I would tell you... but it's just not true. 
 
 George: ( Runs his hands through his hair ) It just does n't make any sense. How could there be such an extraordinary resemblance without some kind of a genetic connection. I mean, Marty's practically a clone... and I know I write about things like that, but this is real life! Lorraine, I want to believe you... 
 
 Lorraine: Then do! George, I'm beginning to get the impression you do n't trust me. 
 
 George: I worry. I know how Biff feels about you, and if you've already hidden something like this once... 
 
 Lorraine: George! I would never! 
 
 *** 
 
 Marty McFly hears voices from down the hall, the sound of his parents arguing. It's not something they do often, so it worries him. He creeps down the hall, stands near enough to the door to be able to hear the words. From inside, he hears George shout, `` Why do n't you just admit it! You ran into him, you slept with him, you were ashamed, and that's why you did n't tell me about it!'' 
 
 Lorraine replies, `` And I'm telling you that never happened! It would be too weird! Yes, I was in love with Calvin at the time, but that kiss felt almost incestuous! Why would I suddenly jump into bed with him on a whim?'' 
 
 George retorts, `` Why, indeed.'' 
 
 Marty, his eyes bulging, made his way back to his room, to consider how to handle the situation. 
 
 *** 
 
 This next part is n't as fun to write, but I think Marty and Jennifer ultimately pull George aside and tell him what happened. No worries about George breaking the masquerade, since if he did start talking about time travel, people would just assume he's talking about the plot for his next book. George is extremely skeptical at first, but then Dr. Brown's time travel train appears out of nowhere... thus proving that Marty is telling the truth. 
 
 When Marty asks the Doc how he knew to show up when and where he did, Doc will tell him it's because he's about to write a letter and have it sent to a particular place at a particular time, where Doc will get it and come back to this moment. He sternly warns Marty that he must do this to avoid a temporal paradox.

him losing the boy, Lorraine. I’m worried about *you*. You’ve been so distant since the reunion. Like you’re carrying a ghost no one else can see.

Lorraine pulled her hands away, turning toward the window where moonlight bled through the curtains in soft, uneven stripes. The house was quiet—too quiet. Even the old floorboards had stopped their usual creaking. She exhaled slowly, watching her breath fog the glass for just a second before vanishing.

You don’t understand, George. It’s not just that he looked like Calvin. It’s the way he *moved*. That little tilt of the head when he laughed. The way he tucked his hands into his jacket pockets like he was trying to disappear. Calvin did that. Every time he was nervous. Every time he was hiding something.

She turned back to him, eyes glistening but sharp.

And at the dance—I didn’t just *see* him. He *saw me*. He froze. Like I’d caught him in the middle of a lie. Then he slipped out the side door. I followed, but by the time I got outside… nothing. Just an empty alley and a torn piece of paper on the ground.

George stood, crossing to the dresser. He picked up the crumpled flyer they’d found days later taped to their front gate: *Missing Teen Last Seen Near Clock Tower, 1985*. The photo was blurry, but unmistakable. Marty McFly, age seventeen. Hair wild, grin lopsided.

Only it wasn’t Marty in the picture. Not really.

It was Calvin. Twenty years older, maybe, but undeniably him. Same scar above the eyebrow. Same watch—*her* watch—the one she’d given him the summer before he vanished.

I called Clara last night, George whispered. From the school records office. She said Calvin never transferred. Never withdrew. His file just… ends. Mid-semester. Like he was erased.

Lorraine sank onto the edge of the bed, clutching the yearbook to her chest.

He came back, George. Not as Calvin. As someone else. Someone *new*. But why? And what happens when he remembers who he really is?

A low hum pulsed through the walls—faint, mechanical, like a transformer straining under load. Outside, the streetlamp flickered once, twice, then glowed a sickly green.

And somewhere, far off, a clock began to chime.

Lorraine, I’m not worried about the boy—he’s gone. I’m worried about *you*. You’ve been distant since the reunion, like you’re haunted by a ghost only you can see.

Lorraine pulled her hands away and turned to the window. Moonlight seeped through the curtains in jagged stripes, painting the room in silver and shadow. The house was unnaturally still—no creak of floorboards, no whisper of wind. She exhaled, watching her breath bloom against the glass and fade.

“You don’t understand, George. It wasn’t just that he looked like Calvin. It was how he *moved*—that slight tilt of the head when he laughed, the way he tucked his hands into his jacket like he wanted to vanish. Calvin did that. Every time he was nervous. Every time he was hiding something.”

She turned back, eyes glistening but fierce.

“And at the dance—I didn’t just see him. He *saw me*. He froze, like I’d caught him mid-lie. Then he slipped out the side door. I followed, but by the time I reached the alley… nothing. Just silence and a torn scrap of paper on the ground.”

George rose, crossing to the dresser. He picked up the crumpled flyer they’d found days later, taped to their gate: *Missing Teen Last Seen Near Clock Tower, 1985*. The photo was blurry, but the face unmistakable—Marty McFly, seventeen, wild-haired, crooked grin.

But it wasn’t Marty.

It was Calvin. Twenty years older, perhaps, but undeniably him. Same scar above the brow. Same watch—the one she’d given him the summer before he vanished.

“I called Clara last night,” George said quietly. “From the school records. Calvin never transferred. Never withdrew. His file just… ends. Mid-semester. Like he was erased.”

Lorraine sank onto the bed, clutching the yearbook to her chest.

“He came back, George. Not as Calvin. As someone else. Someone *new*. But why? And what happens when he remembers who he really is?”

A low hum vibrated through the walls—mechanical, insistent, like a machine straining beneath the skin of the world. Outside, the streetlamp flickered once, twice, then glowed a sickly green.

And far off, a clock began to chime.

The Financial Assistance for Political Parties scheme distributes funding to parties to help assembly members perform their duties.
It includes payments to help run whips' offices and employ party staff.
MLAs have approved the assembly commission's proposals to reduce the payments by 3%.
It forms part of an overall cut in the assembly's budget of 5% this financial year.
Under the new arrangements, parties will be able to claim about £25,600 if they have one MLA.
Parties with two or more MLAs will be able to claim about £51,100, plus about £3,300 for each MLA who is not a minister or junior minister.
Parties with between three and 10 MLAs will be able to claim about £16,000 for their whips' office.
The payment for parties with between 11 and 20 MLAs will be just under £24,000, while parties with more than 20 MLAs will be able to claim about £32,000.

Buddah said to Confucius, `` on your death bed, you will receive total consciousness.'' 
 
 Insulted by Buddah's statement, Confucius responded, `` What you do not wish for upon yourself, do not do to others.'' 
 
 Buddah immediately jabbed back, `` I have already received total consciousness. You sir, like all things, will come to end soon.'' 
 
 At that point Confucius, became perplexed by the Buddah's incoherent ramblings. He could not tell if Buddah wished death upon him or if he was simply trying to teach him enlightenment. Sensing that Buddah wished death upon him, Confucius threw a blow striking Buddah in the belly. 
 
 Buddah, mumbled, `` this too like all things shall pass,'' and returned a blow to Confucius' left eye. Distressed and angry both left the scene, feeling neither enlightened, nor coherent in their sense of being.
LLM_1:
The air grew heavy with tension, the garden around them a quiet witness to the clash of philosophies. Buddah, with his serene smile, regarded Confucius with a mixture of pity and curiosity. “Wisdom often emerges from the embrace of mortality,” he replied softly, as the scent of lotus flowers drifted through the warm breeze.

Confucius clenched his fists, his thoughts swirling like autumn leaves caught in a tempest. “To dwell on death is to accept defeat,” he countered. Just then, the ground trembled slightly, an omen of the impending conflict between their beliefs. 

From the shadows, a figure emerged—Laozi, the ancient sage, his robes flowing like water. “Why quarrel over the inevitable?” he mused, his voice a soothing balm. “Let us instead seek harmony in our differences.” 

Thus began a dialogue that would weave through the ages, the three thinkers standing at the crossroads of existence, each seeking a deeper understanding amidst the chaos of life.

human:
While the crowds shuffled out of Madison Square Garden, Taylor Swift sat alone in her dressing room and began to wipe away her makeup. With the damp cloth pressed against her face, she began to feel more like herself again. As every piece of this false exterior shed away, the mascara, the contacts, the wig, she remembered who she was. Who she is. 
 
 She set down the foundation covered rag and looked proudly into the mirror. “ My name is Samya, ” she said aloud, as if to make sure she never again forgot. She looked deeply into her eyes for what seemed to be an eternity, at her beautiful arabic features, glad to be free of the facade she is forced to portray. 
 
 A knock came at the door. “ I asked not to be disturbed! ” Samya uncharacteristically shouted. 
 
 “ Don ’ t worry, I know. It ’ s me, John. Let me in, Taylor, ” gently spoke John Mayer through the door. Samya slow rose to her feet and let John in, keeping herself hidden from view as to not let any one passing by see her true self. 
 
 “ What are you doing?! ” John disapprovingly said. “ You know that if any person comes in and sees you, this game is over. ” 
 
 “ Oh please, Hassan ” Samya said, referring to his true name. “ Anyone that saw me in here would have no idea who I am. I wouldn ’ t even pass for a Taylor Swift look alike, much less Taylor Swift without all of that whore ’ s coloring on my face. ” 
 
 “ It ’ s an unnecessary risk and you know it. Look. I get it. Pretending to be someone you ’ re not. Someone who betray ’ s Allah and prances around like some hedonist can be a heavy burden on your soul, but never let us forget why we do this. ” Hassan walks up behind Samya and presses himself against her back, but she is quick to push away. 
 
 “ And don ’ t you forget that I am not yours! This relationship is only for the cause and in a month it will be done. Out there you may do as you must, but in here you will keep your hands to yourself. ” Samya gives Hassan one last scowl before retreating to her chair in front of the mirror. She sheds a single tear before telling him. “ It is hard enough to pretend, but to do so in the place of our greatest victory. in the town where my true father died, sometimes I can not help but question why it is not enough for me to simply strike on my own. ” 
 
 Hassan took a long breath and paused for a moment, as if to let Samya collect herself. “ Because you know why. We are the facilitators. We do not win this fight by simply killing them in attacks. We win this fight by dragging the conflict out and bankrupting this wicked nation. I know you know this. I know it can be tough to resist the urge to take up a sword ourselves, but you are so good at feeding them the lies they need to believe they are invincible. Every girl in that crowd singing along to “ Fifteen ” is one insulated from reality. It is every bit just as valuable. And one day I ’ m sure, Allah will call upon to rise to the occasion even further. But for now, we must be content with this. ” 
 
 Hassan pulled a small gift box out of his pocket and placed it next to Samya on the table. “ Here are the transfers they need you to make this next month as well as the groups they need you to hire. ” 
 
 “ Hassan….thank you. I know I was just harsh, but of all my contacts so far, you have been the one I am most fond of. I will miss our time together. You ’ ve been doing this for much longer than I have, and I look unto you for wisdom. I guess sometimes it ’ s just hard not seeing where my actions go. ” 
 
 “ I understand entirely. I do not know much myself, but even if I could know, I am more afraid that my knowledge would cause me to make mistakes that would reveal myself. It is best that we trust in Bin Laden and his advisors. ” 
 
 “ You are right. It is enough to know that I am helping. Allahu akbar. ” 
 
 “ Allahu akbar. Now. as beautiful as your natural face is, it is best for you to put that costume back on. We have an after party to attend. I will leave you to get yourself ready. ” 
 
 “ I completely forgot! Ullg. Time to literally put this face back on! ” 
 
 “ Ahaha. ” Hassan laughed. “ See you in the limo, Taylor. ” 
 
 “ See you in the limo, John. ”
LLM_1:
“I’m being myself,” Samya replied, her voice low but firm. She closed the door behind him, the lock clicking softly. The room still smelled of stage smoke and sweat, but the air between them was charged with something new—a raw, unvarnished truth.

John stared, his usual easy confidence faltering. He took in her dark, uncovered hair, the kohl-rimmed eyes now free of colored contacts, the strong features no longer softened by contouring. “Do you have any idea what could happen if someone sees you like this? The press, the label, the fans—they think they know Taylor Swift. This…” He gestured vaguely, his words trailing off.

“This is me,” she finished for him, crossing her arms. “And you’re one of the only people who knows that. So why are you looking at me like I’m a crisis?”

He ran a hand through his hair, sighing. “Because I care about you. This isn’t just a costume, Samya. It’s a billion-dollar brand. A life. You can’t just… shed it in a dressing room after a show.” He stepped closer, his tone dropping. “I came because I heard the shouting. I was worried.”

Samya turned back to the mirror, meeting her own gaze. “I’m tired of the whispering. Tired of the hiding. Every night I perform, I feel like I’m giving a piece of myself away to a ghost named Taylor.” She picked up the discarded wig from the counter, its blonde strands artificial under the fluorescent lights. “Sometimes I wonder who’s real—her, or the me I see now.”

John leaned against the vanity, his reflection appearing beside hers. “They’re both real. But one of them has to live in the world.” He paused, choosing his words carefully. “Remember why you started this. The music, the message—you wrapped it in a persona so it would be heard. That wasn’t a betrayal. It was a strategy.”

A faint smile touched her lips. “A strategy that worked too well. Now the strategy is all anyone sees.” She set the wig down. “What if I want to be seen? Really seen?”

Before he could answer, another knock echoed, sharper this time. “Taylor? Your car’s ready. Security says we need to move.” It was her assistant, Lisa, her voice muffled but urgent.

Samya’s eyes widened, flicking to John. In one fluid motion, he grabbed the wig and gently placed it back on her head, his fingers deftly tucking away stray dark strands. “Not yet,” he murmured, his breath warm against her ear. “Your time will come. But tonight, let’s get you home safe.”

She nodded, slipping the colored contacts back in with practiced ease, the familiar hazel gaze returning to the mirror. As she reached for a tube of lipstick, her hand trembled slightly. John steadied it, his own hand covering hers for a moment. “You’re not alone in this,” he said quietly. “When you’re ready, I’ll be there. But for now… Taylor Swift has a car waiting.”

Samya took a deep breath, the transformation complete once more. Yet as she opened the door to Lisa’s anxious face, she carried with her a newfound resolve—a silent promise to the woman in the mirror. The facade would remain, for now, but beneath it, Samya was breathing, planning, waiting for the day the world would hear her real name.

human: The preferential use of intensity-modulated radiotherapy (IMRT) over conventional radiotherapy (CRT) in the treatment of head and neck cancer has raised concerns regarding dose to non-target tissue. The purpose of this study was to compare dose-volume characteristics with the brachial plexus between treatment plans generated by IMRT and CRT using several common treatment scenarios.The brachial plexus was delineated on radiation treatment planning CT scans from 10 patients undergoing IMRT for locally advanced head and neck cancer using a Radiation Therapy Oncology Group-endorsed atlas. No brachial plexus constraint was used. For each patient, a conventional three-field shrinking-field plan was generated and the dose-volume histogram (DVH) for the brachial plexus was compared with that of the IMRT plan.The mean irradiated volumes of the brachial plexus using the IMRT vs the CRT plan, respectively, were as follows: V50 (18±5 ml) vs (11±6 ml), p = 0.01; V60 (6±4 ml) vs (3±3 ml), p = 0.02; V66 (3±1 ml) vs (1±1 ml), p = 0.04, V70 (0±1 ml) vs (0±1 ml), p = 0.68. The maximum point dose to the brachial plexus was 68.9 Gy (range 62.3-78.7 Gy) and 66.1 Gy (range 60.2-75.6 Gy) for the IMRT and CRT plans, respectively (p = 0.01).
LLM_1:
the two treatment modalities. A retrospective analysis was conducted on patients with locally advanced head and neck cancer treated with IMRT and CRT. Dose-volume histograms (DVHs) were generated for the brachial plexus, focusing on the maximum doses (Dmax), mean doses (Dmean), and the volume of tissue receiving significant doses (V30, V40, and V50). Statistical comparisons were performed using Mann-Whitney U tests to evaluate differences in dose distributions. 

Preliminary results indicated that IMRT significantly reduced the Dmax and Dmean to the brachial plexus compared to CRT. Additionally, lower percentages of the brachial plexus volume receiving doses above 30 Gy were observed in the IMRT cohort, suggesting a potential reduction in the risk of radiation-induced neuropathy. These findings underscore the importance of treatment planning techniques that minimize exposure to critical structures, thereby enhancing the therapeutic ratio in head and neck cancer management. Future studies are warranted to assess the long-term clinical implications of these dosimetric advantages.
