This study presents a comparative analysis of two treatment modalities for patients with locally advanced head and neck cancer: Intensity-Modulated Radiation Therapy (IMRT) and Conventional Radiotherapy (CRT). A retrospective analysis was performed, focusing on dose-volume histograms (DVHs) for the brachial plexus, which included assessments of maximum doses (Dmax), mean doses (Dmean), and the volume of tissue exposed to significant doses (V30, V40, and V50). Statistical comparisons were conducted using Mann-Whitney U tests to evaluate differences in dose distributions between the two modalities.

Preliminary results revealed that IMRT significantly reduced both Dmax and Dmean to the brachial plexus in comparison to CRT. Furthermore, a lower proportion of the brachial plexus volume receiving doses exceeding 30 Gy was noted in the IMRT cohort, indicating a potential decrease in the risk of radiation-induced neuropathy. These findings highlight the critical role of advanced treatment planning techniques in minimizing exposure to vital structures, thereby improving the therapeutic ratio in the management of head and neck cancer. Future studies are necessary to explore the long-term clinical implications associated with these dosimetric benefits.

human: Coronary heart disease (CHD) is a frequent medical condition in developed countries and is one of the most serious diseases threatening patients' lives. Perioperative myocardial infarction is the major cause of perioperative cardiac death and cardiac arrest, but is difficult to be precisely identified by observing clinical symptoms or assessing cardiac enzyme levels or by ECG examination. Therefore, assessment of patient prognosis requires reliable predictors. In this regard, we tested the prognostic value of serum troponin I (TnI) concentrations.98 patients undergoing elective simple off-pump coronary artery bypass grafting were recruited. Venous blood samples were collected within 3-5 hours, 18-24 hours, and 36-48 hours post-operation, and associations of TnI concentrations with early outcomes measures (duration of assisted ventilation, length of stay in the ICU, length of postoperative stay, administration of antihypotensive medications, use of intra-aortic balloon pump, and ECG abnormalities) were evaluated. Correlations of postoperative TnI concentrations with the outcomes measures were analyzed by using median TnI concentrations as the cut-off value.TnI concentrations assessed within 18-24 hours post-operation showed significant associations with most tested outcome measures (p < 0.05 for four out of five comparisons). Furthermore, after building ROC curves, the highest AUC values (> 0.9) were also observed for TnI1 concentrations assessed within this time frame. The optimal cutoff value for TnI concentration was 1.78 ng/ml.
LLM_1: due to overlapping biomarkers and nonspecific electrocardiographic changes in surgical settings. Recent advances in high-sensitivity cardiac troponin (hs-cTn) assays have improved early detection of myocardial injury, enabling more accurate differentiation between type I and type II myocardial infarction in the perioperative period. Furthermore, multimodal monitoring strategies incorporating echocardiography, hemodynamic assessment, and risk stratification using validated clinical scores such as the Revised Cardiac Risk Index (RCRI) and National Surgical Quality Improvement Program (NSQIP) metrics enhance preoperative risk prediction. Emerging evidence supports the role of coronary computed tomography angiography (CCTA) in selected high-risk patients to identify significant obstructive disease prior to non-cardiac surgery. Despite these tools, challenges remain in standardizing diagnostic criteria and implementing timely interventions. Ongoing research focuses on machine learning models that integrate real-time physiological data with clinical variables to predict acute coronary events intraoperatively. Additionally, perioperative management optimization through beta-blockade, statin therapy, and strict glycemic control shows potential in reducing adverse cardiac outcomes. Future directions emphasize personalized risk assessment and the development of consensus guidelines for uniform diagnosis and treatment protocols across surgical disciplines.

Multimodal monitoring strategies—incorporating echocardiography, hemodynamic assessment, and validated risk stratification tools such as the Revised Cardiac Risk Index (RCRI) and National Surgical Quality Improvement Program (NSQIP) metrics—have improved preoperative risk prediction. Future efforts should focus on personalized risk assessment and the development of consensus guidelines to establish uniform diagnostic and therapeutic protocols across surgical specialties.

human:
Tests for the genetic conditions Patau and Edward's syndromes currently take place at about 20 weeks of pregnancy.
But the UK National Screening Committee recommends blood tests and scans to detect the abnormalities should be carried out sooner.
Public health experts in England say they are now in discussions about when to roll out these procedures.
The conditions affect about two in every 10,000 births in the UK each year.
Patau's syndrome, also known as trisomy 13, can be fatal.  Babies with the condition may have a wide range of problems including heart defects and neurological abnormalities.
Some 75% of pregnancies affected by Edward's syndrome result in miscarriage or stillbirth. Babies with the syndrome often have severe developmental problems.
Dr Annie Mackie, of the UK National Screening Committee, said: "Over 700,000 women get pregnant in the UK every year and although over 95% of these pregnancies will be perfectly healthy, sadly in a few cases there are problems affecting the baby's development.
"This recommendation would give those women access to support and enable them to make important choices at an earlier stage of their pregnancy."
Ministers in England have approved the move and it is likely the rest of the UK will follow these recommendations.
LLM_1:
the potential implementation of earlier screening methods. This shift aims to provide expectant parents with crucial information as early as the first trimester, allowing for informed decision-making regarding their pregnancies.

Experts believe that by introducing blood tests and ultrasounds at an earlier stage, healthcare providers can not only enhance detection rates for these serious genetic conditions but also improve the overall management of prenatal care. Early diagnosis can facilitate timely interventions and support for families, who may choose to pursue various options based on the results.

The recommendation comes amid growing awareness of the psychological and emotional toll that late-stage diagnoses can impose on families. Many parents report feelings of anxiety and helplessness when faced with such crucial decisions later in their pregnancy. By addressing these concerns, public health officials hope to alleviate some of the associated stress and ensure that parents have adequate time to consider their choices.

As discussions continue, the committee is also exploring how these changes could be implemented effectively across the National Health Service, including training for healthcare professionals and ensuring equitable access to these new screening protocols.
LLM_2:
**Early Screening Methods for Expectant Parents: A New Approach**

In a significant policy shift, healthcare experts are advocating for the earlier implementation of screening methods for expectant parents, aiming to provide vital information during the first trimester. This initiative is designed to empower families to make informed decisions about their pregnancies from the outset.

Medical professionals assert that by introducing blood tests and ultrasounds at an earlier stage, the healthcare system can significantly increase detection rates for serious genetic conditions, while also enhancing the overall management of prenatal care. Early diagnosis not only allows for timely interventions but also offers families the chance to explore various options based on the results.

This recommendation emerges in response to the growing recognition of the psychological and emotional challenges posed by late-stage diagnoses. Many parents report experiencing heightened anxiety and feelings of helplessness when confronted with critical decisions later in their pregnancy. By prioritizing early screening, public health officials aim to mitigate some of this stress and provide parents with adequate time to consider their choices thoughtfully.

As these discussions progress, the committee is also examining strategies for effectively integrating these changes within the National Health Service. This includes plans for training healthcare professionals and ensuring that access to the new screening protocols is equitable across all communities.

human:
This paper proposes an approach to neural MT in which the joint (source, target) distribution is modeled as an average over two different factorizations: target given source and source given target. This gives rise to four distributions - two language models and two translation models - which are parameterized separately but conditioned on a common variational latent variable. The model is trained on parallel data using a standard VAE approach. It can additionally be trained on non-parallel data in an approach similar to iterated back-translation at sentence-level granularity, but with language and translation model probabilities for observed sentences coupled by the latent variable. Inference iterates between sampling a latent variable given the current best hypothesis, and using beam search plus rescoring to find a new best hypothesis given the current latent variable. The approach is evaluated in several different scenarios (low- and high-resource, domain adaptation - trained on parallel data only or parallel plus monolingual data) and found to generally outperform previous work on generative NMT and iterated back-translation.

Strengths: clearly written, well motivated, very comprehensive experiments comparing to relevant baselines.

Weaknesses: somewhat incremental relative to Shah and Barber (Neurips 2018), results are only marginally positive, framework is probably too cumbersome to justify widespread adoption based on the results.

I think the paper should be accepted. Although it’s not highly original, it ties together three strands of work in a principled way: joint models, variational approaches, and back-translation / dual learning. The increment over Shah and Barber is bolstered by the addition of back-translation, which gives substantial improvements when using non-parallel data; and to a lesser extent by the argument about the advantage of separate models for distant language pairs. Using all possible LMs and TMs coupled with a latent variable feels like an area that was inevitably going to get explored, and this paper does a good job of it. Although the gains over the baselines are not overly compelling, they are quite systematic, indicating that the advantage is probably real, albeit slight. The authors are also to be commended on their use of not just the Shah and Barber baseline, but also the back-translation-based techniques, which are generally stronger competitors when monolingual data is incorporated.

Further comments/questions:

Why are there no results for Transformer+Dual in table 4? This omission looks odd, since Transformer+Dual was the strongest baseline in table 3.

Please add implementation details for the Transformer+{BT,JBT,Dual} baselines.

It was surprising not to see robustness experiments like Shah and Barber’s dropped source words, since robustness to source noise could be one of the advantages of having an explicit model of the source sentence.

A few additional suggestions for related work: noisy channel approaches (eg, The Neural Noisy Channel, Yu et al, ICLR 2017); decipherment (eg, Beyond parallel data: Joint word alignment and decipherment improves machine translation, EMNLP 2014 - yes, from SMT days, but still); other joint modeling work (KERMIT: Generative Insertion-Based Modeling for Sequences, Chan et al, 2019).

Consider dropping the “1+1 > 2” metaphor. It’s not clear to me exactly what it means, or what it adds to the paper.

“deviation” is used in a couple places where you probably meant “derivation”?

Line 6 in algorithm 2 should use both forward and backward scores for rescoring.
LLM_1:
By symmetrically modeling both source-to-target and target-to-source conditionals under a shared latent space, the method introduces a form of implicit consistency regularization that may contribute to improved generalization, particularly in low-resource settings. This design choice is theoretically well-motivated and aligns with recent trends in leveraging dual learning principles for sequence transduction tasks.

- One notable strength lies in the model’s ability to exploit monolingual data through a mechanism that couples language modeling and translation components via the latent variable. Unlike standard back-translation, which treats synthetic translations as ground truth, this approach maintains probabilistic coherence by preserving the joint distribution structure during training on unpaired sentences. This could lead to more robust updates when incorporating noisy or imperfectly generated data, potentially mitigating error propagation commonly observed in iterative methods.

- The inference procedure—alternating between latent variable sampling and hypothesis refinement via beam search and rescoring—introduces an interesting dynamic between latent representation and output generation. This iterative decoding strategy resembles expectation-maximization-style optimization over the latent space and may allow the model to escape poor local modes in the output distribution. However, it also raises questions about computational efficiency and convergence behavior during inference, especially when compared to standard single-pass autoregressive decoding.

- A critical aspect requiring further clarification is the extent to which the two translation models (source→target and target→source) share parameters or architectural components. While the paper emphasizes separate parameterization, any degree of weight sharing or architectural symmetry between these components could significantly influence both performance and training dynamics. A detailed ablation on parameter sharing configurations would strengthen the empirical analysis.

- The use of a common variational latent variable to tie together four distinct distributions introduces a high-dimensional bottleneck that may affect representational capacity. It would be informative to examine how the dimensionality of the latent space impacts translation quality, particularly in terms of fluency versus adequacy. Additionally, sensitivity analyses on the choice of prior (e.g., isotropic Gaussian vs. more flexible priors) and the impact of KL regularization strength could provide deeper insights into the trade-offs involved in latent-variable modeling for MT.

- While the training objective appears to follow standard evidence lower bound (ELBO) maximization, the precise formulation of the multi-component loss function—especially how the parallel and non-parallel data contributions are balanced—deserves more explicit treatment. In particular, the weighting scheme between supervised and unsupervised objectives may have a substantial effect on convergence and final performance, especially when monolingual data vastly outnumbers parallel examples.

- Empirical evaluation should include comparisons against strong baselines such as dual supervised training, knowledge distillation from ensembles, and other latent-variable-based MT models like VAE-MT or aligned variational autoencoders. Without such comparisons, it is difficult to assess whether the improvements stem specifically from the proposed architecture or simply from effective use of additional data and training signals.

- The paper would benefit from a qualitative analysis of the latent space, including visualization of latent representations across different sentence pairs or examination of how posterior samples influence translation hypotheses. Such analysis could reveal whether the latent variable captures meaningful semantic or syntactic alignments, discourse-level features, or other abstract properties beyond simple word-level correspondences.

- An important practical consideration is the scalability of the method to larger datasets and multilingual scenarios. Given that the model relies on coordinated updates across multiple components and latent variables, its training stability and memory footprint on large-scale corpora remain open questions. Evaluation on diverse language pairs with varying typological divergence would help establish the generality of the approach.

- The current description lacks details regarding initialization strategies for the latent variables and how posterior collapse—a known issue in VAEs applied to sequence modeling—is mitigated. Techniques such as KL annealing, auxiliary losses, or modified inference networks are commonly employed in related work; specifying whether such measures are used and their effectiveness in this setup is essential for reproducibility.

- From a modeling perspective, it would be valuable to explore whether the averaging over factorizations can be generalized beyond equal weighting. Learning a mixture coefficient dynamically—either globally or at the instance level—might allow the model to adaptively favor one direction based on input characteristics, potentially improving robustness in asymmetric translation scenarios (e.g., morphologically rich to analytic languages).

- The interaction between beam search and latent sampling during inference warrants further investigation. Specifically, the number of iterations, sampling variance, and criteria for termination could all influence final output quality. Providing ablation studies on these hyperparameters would clarify the reliability and sensitivity of the decoding process.

- Although the method is framed within the VAE paradigm, the reliance on reparameterized gradients assumes continuous latent variables. Exploring discrete latent structures—perhaps using Gumbel-Softmax relaxation or hybrid discrete-continuous spaces—could offer complementary advantages in capturing categorical linguistic phenomena such as tense, register, or domain shifts.

- The potential for transfer learning or domain adaptation via the latent space remains underexplored. If the latent variable encodes cross-lingual meaning independently of surface form, then it might serve as a basis for zero-shot translation or adaptation to new domains with limited supervision. Even preliminary experiments in this direction would enhance the paper’s impact.

- Error analysis should go beyond BLEU scores to examine specific failure modes. For instance, does the model reduce hallucination or inconsistency in named entities and quantities due to the dual consistency constraints? Are there measurable improvements in rare word translation or handling of long-range dependencies compared to baseline systems?

- Another area for expansion involves the treatment of uncertainty quantification. Since the model produces a distribution over latent variables and outputs, it may naturally support confidence estimation for translation candidates. Demonstrating calibrated uncertainty scores or applications in human-in-the-loop translation could broaden the method’s applicability.

- The paper would gain depth by situating its contributions relative to prior work on joint distribution modeling in MT, such as IBM Model 2's symmetry assumptions or more recent efforts like CMLM (Conditional Masked Language Modeling) and EMU. Clarifying what distinguishes the current formulation—beyond the use of variational inference—would sharpen the technical narrative.

- Training stability across different stages (supervised, semi-supervised, iterative refinement) should be documented. For example, do the language models dominate early training phases, delaying useful signal for translation components? Monitoring component-wise gradient magnitudes or loss trajectories could illuminate such dynamics.

- The role of the latent variable in enabling cross-modal alignment—should the framework be extended to multimodal MT—could be briefly discussed as a forward-looking remark. Its current design already supports structured coupling between modalities through shared latent structure, making it a promising candidate for future extensions.

- Implementation details such as optimization schedules, batch construction strategies (e.g., mixing parallel and monolingual batches), and gradient clipping practices should be clearly reported. These factors often critically affect performance in complex multi-objective setups and are necessary for replication.

- Consideration should be given to whether the gains attributed to the model architecture persist under stronger pretraining baselines, such as those initialized from large multilingual encoders (e.g., mBART, M2M-100). Demonstrating improvement over such strong starting points would underscore the added value of the proposed approach.

- The paper could benefit from analyzing the correlation between reconstruction accuracy in both directions and final translation performance. High fidelity in reverse translation (target → source) might indicate better semantic preservation, and measuring this link could validate the core assumption underlying the dual modeling strategy.

- Runtime profiling of the training and inference pipelines is recommended. Given the increased complexity from multiple models and iterative decoding, understanding throughput and latency implications is crucial for real-world deployment considerations.

- Finally, while the conceptual framework is compelling, ensuring sufficient empirical rigor through statistical significance testing, multiple random seeds, and diverse test sets will be key to establishing credibility. Small improvements on standard benchmarks can sometimes vanish under tighter experimental control, so robust validation is essential.

human: Visual Restorative function training aims to decrease visual field defect size after acquired brain damage. Some chronic stroke patients regain permission to drive a car after training. This points to a concomitant change in oculomotor behavior, because visual field enlargement is hardly ever large enough for legal driving. This study investigated vRFT-induced changes in oculomotor behavior, using a driving simulator.Driving performance and oculomotor behavior were measured before and after training in 6 hemianopia patients who had trained 65 hours with vRFT on a PC at home.Two patients showed negligible visual field enlargement (VFE) and four showed moderate to substantial VFE. Because less visual cortex is devoted to the processing of peripheral than central visual field the same VFE corresponds to less functional restoration of cortex when the defect is at high eccentricity. When this is taken into account, then precisely the two patients that showed the largest cortical gains made significantly more eye movements in the direction of their visual field defect after training.
LLM_1:
Our research group has been investigating the efficacy of visual restorative training in enhancing oculo-motor functions among chronic brain-injured patients. Notably, preliminary findings suggest a significant correlation between improvements in visual perception and adaptive changes in eye movement patterns. To elucidate the neural mechanisms underlying this phenomenon, we employed functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) to examine alterations in brain activity associated with visual processing and oculate behavior in patients undergoing restoratory training.

human: Umbilical cord blood (UCB) is a source of stem cells used for allogeneic transplantation, in addition to bone marrow and peripheral blood. Limited numbers of stem cells in a single UCB unit is associated with slow haematopoietic recovery and high risk of graft failure, particularly in adult patients. UCB stem cells can be expanded ex vivo; however, rapid differentiation reduces their regenerative potential. We have recently shown that Wnt/β-catenin signalling is down-regulated in ex vivo-expanded stem cells; therefore, we propose that re-activation of Wnt signalling using GSK-3β inhibition may act to improve regenerative potential of these ex vivo-expanded stem cells.Immunocompromised mice were employed in transplantation studies to determine stem-cell engraftment. Flow cytometry was used to phenotype the engrafted human cells. Retroviral gene transfer was used to examine the role of Myc gene up-regulated by GSK-3β inhibition, in ex vivo-expanded stem cells.Treatment with GSK-3β inhibitor, 6-bromoindirubin 3'-oxime (BIO) improved early human cell engraftment in the mice and elevated the numbers of myeloid progenitor cells in cytokine-stimulated culture. BIO up-regulated β-catenin and c-myc in ex vivo-expanded stem cells. Ectopic expression of Myc acted to increase clonogenic potential and to delay differentiation of haematopoietic progenitor cells, suggesting the potential mechanism to improve regenerative potential of ex vivo-expanded grafts.
LLM_1:
expansion techniques often yield heterogeneous cell populations, complicating their clinical applicability. Recent advances in bioreactor technologies and optimized culture conditions have shown promise in enhancing the yield and functionality of UCB-derived stem cells. These methodologies aim to maintain a balance between self-renewal and differentiation, thus preserving the stem cell characteristics while promoting sufficient expansion rates.

Moreover, the incorporation of specific growth factors and cytokines has been investigated to improve the hematopoietic potential of expanded UCB stem cells. Studies have indicated that the use of feeder layers and extracellular matrix components can further enhance cell proliferation and maintain lineage-specific differentiation capabilities. 

In parallel, ongoing research into the genetic and epigenetic modulation of these cells may provide insights into overcoming the limitations associated with UCB transplantations. This approach could facilitate the development of personalized therapies that optimize engraftment and enhance patient outcomes. Collectively, these strategies hold the potential to transform UCB into a more viable option for treating hematological malignancies in adult populations, addressing the critical issue of cell availability and function in transplantation settings.
LLM_2:
The utilization of expansion techniques frequently results in heterogeneous populations of cells, which poses challenges for their clinical implementation. Recent advancements in bioreactor technology and refined culture conditions have demonstrated potential in improving both the yield and functionality of umbilical cord blood (UCB)-derived stem cells. These innovative methodologies strive to achieve a balance between self-renewal and differentiation, thereby preserving the fundamental characteristics of stem cells while ensuring adequate expansion rates.

Additionally, research has focused on the integration of specific growth factors and cytokines to enhance the hematopoietic potential of expanded UCB stem cells. Evidence suggests that employing feeder layers and extracellular matrix components can further promote cell proliferation and sustain lineage-specific differentiation capabilities.

Simultaneously, ongoing investigations into the genetic and epigenetic modulation of these cells may yield valuable insights into addressing the limitations associated with UCB transplantation. This strategy could pave the way for personalized therapeutic approaches that optimize engraftment and improve patient outcomes. Collectively, these methodologies possess the potential to redefine UCB as a more feasible option for the treatment of hematological malignancies in adult populations, thereby tackling the pressing concerns of cell availability and functionality in transplantation contexts.

They’ve both found peace in their separate lives—something I never thought possible when I was growing up.  

Mom has moved closer to the coast and has returned to painting after decades of setting her brushes aside. There’s a new lightness in her voice, a rekindled joy that shows in the way she talks about color and light.  

Dad, meanwhile, has taken up hiking with unexpected enthusiasm—and even adopted a rescue dog named Scout, who now accompanies him on weekend trails. He looks more at ease than I’ve seen him in years.  

My sister is engaged, and we’re planning a small summer wedding in the mountains. Just the thought of it feels like a celebration not just of love, but of resilience.  

For the first time in years, our family gatherings don’t carry that old undercurrent of tension. We laugh more freely. We listen—really listen—to one another.  

The past hasn’t disappeared. It left its marks, as such things do. But healing, I’ve come to realize, doesn’t always look like closure or dramatic resolution. Sometimes, it’s quieter: a gradual rebuilding, done with patience, honesty, and care.  

And somehow, against all odds, we’re finding our way there.

The two-time Grammy winner said he had written Always on My Mind in 10 minutes at his kitchen table in Missouri.
The song gained two further writers, Johnny Christopher and Mark James, when Carson was asked to write an additional bridge section in the recording studio.
Carson had numerous health issues, including diabetes and heart problems, according to his wife Wyndi Harp Head.
"Our music community has lost an immense talent much too soon," said Recording Academy president Neil Portnow.
Born Wayne Carson Thompson in Denver, the writer's parents were professional musicians who played under the name Shorty and Sue Thompson.
Carson picked up a guitar when he was about 14 after hearing a recording by Merle Travis, and soon began composing his own songs.
One of those compositions, Somebody Like Me, found its way to producer Chet Atkins who played it to country star Eddy Arnold. Arnold liked the song, but thought it was too short - and phoned Carson to ask him to write another verse.
"So I said, 'Well, the third verse goes like this' and I just wrote it right there over the phone," Carson recalled.
Arnold took the song to number one on the US country charts in 1966, after which Carson became a sought-after writer in Nashville.
He wrote The Letter, Soul Deep and Neon Rainbow for The Box Tops; No Love At All for BJ Thomas and A Horse Called Music for Willie Nelson.
Always on my Mind was originally recorded by Gwen McCrae and Brenda Lee, but it was Presley's 1972 version - recorded during his divorce from Priscilla - that became a standard.
A decade later, Willie Nelson took the love-lorn ballad to the top of the country charts, winning Carson his two Grammy awards - for song of the year and best country song.
Nelson's version proved so popular that Always on My Mind was named the Country Music Association's song of the year in both 1982 and 1983, leading the organisation to change its voting procedures so that a song could win the award only once.
The Pet Shop Boys' electronic version of the song was the UK's Christmas number one in 1987.
Carson came up with the bridge in an office above the recording studio in Memphis, after being asked to add a few lines to the song by producer Chips Moman.
He called on Christopher and James, two writers working out of Moman's studio, for assistance and they came up with the famous line: "Tell me, tell me that your sweet love hasn't died".
The writer was philosophical about sharing the credit for his most famous song, observing: "Hell, a hit's a hit."
Among the other artists to record Carson's songs were Conway Twitty, the Beach Boys, Randy Travis, Waylon Jennings and Tina Turner.
BJ Thomas was among the musicians paying tribute, writing on Twitter: "RIP Wayne Carson. My close friend and brother. One of the great writers. Was loved by all and will be missed."
Fellow Nashville composer Casey Kelly wrote on Facebook: "I doubt the world will ever know another of his calibre, and I am beyond saddened for our loss."
Carson was inducted into the Nashville Songwriters Hall of Fame in 1997.
He is survived by his wife and their son.
LLM_1:
early compositions eventually led to his first major break when he co-wrote “Soul Deep,” recorded by The Box Tops in 1969. That success opened doors in Nashville, where Carson relocated to pursue songwriting full time. His ability to distill complex emotions into simple, resonant lyrics quickly earned him respect among peers and producers alike.

In addition to “Always on My Mind,” which became a defining ballad of the 20th century after Elvis Presley’s 1972 recording, Willie Nelson’s 1982 rendition cemented the song as a country classic, winning multiple Grammy Awards and topping charts worldwide. Carson’s work also included hits like “The Letter,” famously performed by The Box Tops, and “Neon Rainbow,” showcasing his versatility across genres from soul to country-rock.

Colleagues often praised Carson’s unassuming nature and instinctive melodic sense. “Wayne had this quiet way of walking into a room, but once he picked up a guitar, everyone just stopped talking,” said fellow songwriter Bobby Braddock. “He didn’t need flash. The songs spoke for themselves.”

Despite his success, Carson remained rooted in the Midwest ethos of humility and hard work. He continued writing well into the 2000s, mentoring younger artists and participating in Nashville’s songwriting circles even as his health declined. In interviews, he often reflected on the serendipity of creativity, describing inspiration as “something that sneaks up on you when you’re not trying too hard.”

Carson is survived by his wife Wyndi, three children, and a legacy woven into the fabric of American music. A private memorial service is planned for family and close friends, with a public tribute concert expected later this year, organized by the Country Music Hall of Fame. Tributes have poured in from artists across generations, including Rosanne Cash and Chris Stapleton, both of whom cited Carson’s craftsmanship as foundational to their own approach to songwriting.

The Songwriters Hall of Fame, which inducted Carson in 2004, released a statement honoring his “profound contribution to the emotional depth of popular music.” As radio stations across the U.S. continue to play his timeless melodies, Wayne Carson’s voice—soft-spoken in life, enduring in art—remains, fittingly, always on our minds.

Hello! This is my first time answering a prompt! Please enjoy. 
 
 & nbsp; 
 
 
 My ship, I call her the *Rhoda May* ( after me mother ), she and I ’ ve been through quite a bit, but nothing, and I mean nothing, compares to that one appointment we had last summer. 
 
 It was a slow day that day, and I was ‘ bout ready to ‘ ead home, but then I got the call: ‘ twas a wee bairn, who ’ d been diagnosed with a stage II *glioblastoma multiforme* ( that ’ s a particularly nasty sort of brain cancer, for you laymen ). Now, most of the time, the calls we get usually involve a wee cold or some such, but cancer? 
 
 Thas ’ a rarity, ‘ tis. Especially, nowadays. 
 
 So, with a much shorter time frame than I ’ d normally like, me and me crew suited up for a long night. Me crew holds a special place in me heart. We ’ ve been making old Hippocrates smile for about thirty years now and it ’ s been a wonderful time: there ’ s Otto van Kjell, the cardiologist ( a damn good one ); Kensey Thompson, our endocrinologist ( she ’ s a bit of a wise ass ); Roger Wolpert, neurologist ( and resident bampot ). I ’ m the oncologist and ( proud to be ) the Captain of the *Rhoda May*. 
 
 Oh, and then there ’ s Gerry Edison. He ’ s our psychiatrist. Nobody really listen anything he has to say. 
 
 Now, back to the story. We had suited up and had gone through decontamination. Then, we had to go through the Dobson process. Really nasty your first time ( Wolpert puked himself silly, but you didn ’ t hear from me ) but after a few more times ya ’ get used ta ’ it. I won ’ t bother explainin ’ how, but the long-and-short of it is: the thing shrinks ya. 
 
 After we ’ d gone through that nonsense, we boarded the Rhoda May as usual and were injected into the bairn ’ s head, near enough to the tumor as would allow. We were in the thick of it, now. 
 
 I ’ ll tell ya, you never forget the first time ya lay eyes on a big stinkin ’ tumor. Maybe its the size of the thin ’, but it nevar ceases to amaze me. Imagine, if ya will, a great black mass stretchin ’ in all directions. The Rhoda May ’ s a bit smaller than a red blood cell, to give ya a sense of scale. Anyway, we treated the tumor with this fast-acting drug that some cocksure twenty-year old prodigy cooked up in a Harvard lab. It was supposed to work, it had been approved for use on humans. 
 
 I emphasize that, it was supposed to work.

The UK has paid a total of £1.26bn in interest on these bonds since then.
The debt has not been paid off before because of the relatively low interest it incurs.
The Treasury plans to cut the annual cost of the debt by re-borrowing money at current market rates.  It is the first such move for 67 years.
The bonds that Chancellor George Osborne has acquired have a lower rate than the 4% interest on the debt.
The continued existence of the war bond debt illustrates the lasting shadow cast by World War One.
According to the UK Treasury there are currently 11,200 registered holders of the bonds.
Winston Churchill first issued "4% Consols" in 1927 when he was Chancellor partly to refinance bonds from the First World War.
In addition to the war bonds, some of the debt being refinanced by the Treasury dates back to the 18th Century.
One of these bonds was issued by William Gladstone in 1853 to consolidate the capital stock of the South Sea Company, which was founded in 1711.
The South Sea Company collapsed during the South Sea Bubble financial crisis of 1720, leaving behind it a lot of debt.
In 1932 Chancellor Neville Chamberlain converted some war bonds into "perpetuals". This gave the government the right not to pay back the loans, as long as they continued paying 3.5% interest on them.
Perpetual bonds, as the name suggests, pay a steady stream of interest forever.

This historic move marks a significant shift in the UK's borrowing strategy, which has been in place since the 1950s. Under the current system, the Treasury has traditionally re-invested the returns from maturing bonds into new debt, rather than using the funds to pay off the existing debt. However, with interest rates at historic lows and the country's economic recovery gathering pace, Osborne believes that now is an ideal time to reap the benefits of this new approach.

The plan involves re-financing approximately £3.3 billion worth of existing bonds at market-determined rates, resulting in an estimated annual saving of around £200 million. This reduction in debt servicing costs will provide a welcome boost to public finances, allowing the government to redirect funds towards key areas such as infrastructure development, education, healthcare,  and welfare.

Critics have welcomed the move, arguing that it demonstrates a much-needed shift towards more prudent fiscal management. "This is a positive step towards a more sustainable borrowing model," said Rachel Reeves, Shadow Chief Secretary to HM Treasury. While some experts have expressed concerns about the potential impact on market volatility, most economists agree that this carefully timed intervention will ultimately benefit the economy. As the nation's finances continue to recover, it remains to be seen how this bold move will shape the future of UK borrowing. With the re-finance plan set to begin in 2019, all eyes will be on Osborne's administration as they navigate this significant change. 

The government's decision to break with 68 years of tradition reflects its commitment to responsible financial stewardship. By embracing this innovative approach, they aim to create a stronger, more resilient economy for the long-term.  As one observer noted, "It's a vital step in modernizing our debt management strategy."

The former Wales scrum-half has agreed a two-year deal to take up a role as an assistant coach with the province.
Ulster confirmed the appointment of Peel, who is currently coaching at Premiership club Bristol, on Wednesday.
Earlier in the week it was announced that New Zealander Jonno Gibbes would take over as head coach in the summer.
Former All Black Gibbes is presently forwards coach at Clermont, having previously occupied a similar role at Leinster.
During a distinguished playing career, Peel was capped 76 times for Wales and was a member of the Grand Slam teams of 2005 and 2008.
The 35-year-old joined Bristol in 2014 but an ongoing shoulder injury forced him into premature retirement last March and he became backs and skills coach ahead of their promotion to the Premiership this season.
Peel toured New Zealand with the British and Irish Lions in 2005 and captained Wales at the 2007 Rugby World Cup.
The former Wales international is expected to be responsible for Ulster's backline and also oversee their attacking strategy.
Ulster director of rugby Les Kiss indicated on Tuesday that he had been given the go-ahead to make changes to his coaching staff with the support of the Ulster Professional Game Board.
Peel says he is excited by a new challenge in Belfast and "delighted to have this opportunity".
"Ulster is one of the big clubs in European rugby and I'm looking forward to working with a large contingent of quality players," he said.
"Coaching was always a natural progression for me and I'm really enjoying my role with Bristol.
"Over the years I've spent time in different environments trying to pick things up that will benefit my career and this move to Belfast is another step in the right direction.
"I've talked with Les (Kiss) a lot over the past couple of weeks and it's exciting for me to work with someone of his calibre.
"I'm looking forward to getting started in the summer, but my focus will be with Bristol until the end of the season."
Kiss added: "I'm very pleased that Dwayne will join us from next season. He's a talented coach who has a great understanding of the game and I'm really excited by what he will bring to our environment.
"It was obvious through my discussions with Dwayne that he has an exceptional coaching eye and he will provide us with refreshing insight and ideas.
"After Jono (Gibbes) agreed to join us, it was clear that Dwayne was going to be a great fit for our coaching group for next season."
LLM_1:
Bristol as a player in 2016 before transitioning into a coaching capacity with the club, where he has been credited with developing their attacking structure and nurturing young half-back talent.

His move to Kingspan Stadium is seen as a strategic addition to Gibbes’ new-look coaching team, bringing a fresh perspective on backline play and breakdown strategy. Peel’s experience in the high-tempo English Premiership is expected to complement Gibbes’ forward-oriented expertise, creating a balanced management duo aimed at revitalizing Ulster’s fortunes in the United Rugby Championship and European competitions.

Ulster’s CEO, Jonny Petrie, expressed enthusiasm about the appointment, stating that Peel’s proven track record and deep understanding of the modern game made him an ideal fit for the province’s ambitions. “His insights as a world-class scrum-half and his recent coaching achievements align perfectly with our strategic vision,” Petrie remarked.

The reshuffle follows a period of evaluation for Ulster, who have sought to build a dynamic coaching panel capable of elevating the squad’s performance. Supporters will be eager to see how Peel’s influence manifests, particularly in the development of emerging scrum-halves like Nathan Doak and the overall sharpness of the back division.

Peel is scheduled to commence his duties in Belfast ahead of the 2023-24 preseason, concluding his tenure with Bristol at the end of the current campaign. His arrival signals a clear intent from the province to blend proven international pedigree with innovative coaching, fostering a new era under Gibbes’ leadership.

human: Glucocorticoids are effective drugs for controlling symptoms and airway inflammation in respiratory diseases such as asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. However, the mechanisms behind their effects are not fully understood. We have recently demonstrated that prolonged exposure to the pro-inflammatory mediator tumour necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-alpha) markedly enhanced contractile responses to des-Arg9-bradykinin (selective bradykinin B1 receptor agonist) and bradykinin (selective bradykinin B2 receptor agonist) in murine airways. This increase was paralleled with elevated mRNA levels for bradykinin B1 and B2 receptors, a process involving intracellular mitogen-activated protein kinase pathways.To investigate the effects of glucocorticoids on the TNF-alpha up-regulated bradykinin B1 and B2 receptor response.Tracheal segments from BALB/c J mice were cultured with and without TNF-alpha, in the absence and presence of the transcriptional inhibitor actinomycin D or the glucocorticoid, dexamethasone. The contractile response induced by des-Arg9-bradykinin and bradykinin was subsequently assessed in a myograph system and mRNA for bradykinin B1 and B2 receptors was quantified using real-time polymerase chain reaction.Actinomycin D abolished and dexamethasone concentration-dependently suppressed the TNF-alpha-induced enhancement of the des-Arg9-bradykinin and bradykinin responses. This was paralleled by a reduction of the mRNA expression for the bradykinin B1 and B2 receptors.
LLM_1: inhibits glucocorticoid receptor (GR) nuclear translocation and transcriptional activity in human airway epithelial cells, suggesting a potential mechanism for glucocorticoid resistance in chronic inflammatory states. To further elucidate this interaction, we investigated the molecular pathways through which TNF-α impairs GR function. Using chromatin immunoprecipitation and luciferase reporter assays, we found that sustained TNF-α exposure induces persistent activation of p38 MAPK and NF-κB, leading to serine phosphorylation of the GR and subsequent promotion of GR exportin-1-mediated nuclear export. This cytoplasmic sequestration was reversed upon pharmacological inhibition of p38 MAPK. Furthermore, RNA sequencing revealed that TNF-α pre-treatment alters the transcriptomic response to dexamethasone, significantly blunting the expression of anti-inflammatory genes such as MKP-1 and GILZ, while enhancing a subset of pro-apoptotic genes. Our data identify a novel crosstalk mechanism wherein chronic TNF-α signaling reprograms GR cellular dynamics and target gene specificity, providing a molecular basis for the reduced therapeutic efficacy of glucocorticoids in severe, TNF-α-high inflammatory airway diseases.
LLM_2: Chronic inflammation is associated with glucocorticoid resistance, a phenomenon observed in conditions such as severe asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Previous studies have shown that tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α) inhibits glucocorticoid receptor (GR) nuclear translocation and transcriptional activity in human airway epithelial cells, suggesting a potential mechanism underlying glucocorticoid insensitivity in chronic inflammatory states. To further elucidate this interaction, we investigated the molecular pathways through which TNF-α impairs GR function. Using chromatin immunoprecipitation and luciferase reporter assays, we demonstrated that sustained TNF-α exposure induces persistent activation of p38 mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) and nuclear factor-kappa B (NF-κB), leading to serine phosphorylation of the GR and subsequent promotion of GR exportin-1-mediated nuclear export. This cytoplasmic sequestration was reversed upon pharmacological inhibition of p38 MAPK. Furthermore, RNA sequencing revealed that TNF-α pre-treatment alters the transcriptomic response to dexamethasone, significantly blunting the expression of anti-inflammatory genes such as mitogen-activated protein kinase phosphatase-1 (MKP-1) and glucocorticoid-induced leucine zipper (GILZ), while enhancing a subset of pro-apoptotic genes. Our findings identify a novel crosstalk mechanism wherein chronic TNF-α signaling reprograms GR cellular dynamics and target gene specificity, providing a molecular basis for the reduced therapeutic efficacy of glucocorticoids in severe, TNF-α-high inflammatory airway diseases.

This paper describes the curation efforts to create a QA dataset on COVID-19. It collected 2,200 question-answer pairs from popular websites. Then it extracted 27, 000 unanswered questions from tweets, identified the most similar questions in the collection and provided top 5 answers. Then the provided answers were further manually annotated (whether they are relevant). Please see my comments below.

For the 27, 000 unanswered questions, it seems that only the questions similar to the existing questions in the collection can be kept. If an unanswered question is a new topic of COVID-19, the top retrieved answers will be irrelevant, and health experts will not provide new answers based on the description. Therefore, many new questions will be potentially missed. And what is the motivation of only annotating the questions that are similar to the existing questions in the collection? Critically, the questions that are significantly different from the existing questions are more valuable and need the power of manual curation. Adding these questions will enrich the datasets. In contrast, if a question is similar to the existing questions, adding it will just have one more similar instance. 

Second, the study needs to explain how to use this dataset in detail. For instance, the statement 'Over 18, 000 examples were judged to be less than 1% relevant, indicating that the majority of the questions extracted from twitter are irrelevant to the answered questions in our dataset' seems that most of the questions do not have a precise answer yet. How to train a QA model in this case?

Third, from the methodology level, while BM25 is effective, it does not capture the semantics of the questions. Did the study also try to use other methods to calculate the semantic similarity between the questions such as using word or sentence embedding?

Also importantly, the dataset is not public for now. More specific comments cannot be made.
LLM_1:
- The selection criteria for the 2,200 initial question-answer pairs from popular websites are not sufficiently detailed. It is unclear how these sources were vetted for reliability, whether they represent a diverse range of perspectives (e.g., public health agencies, academic institutions, medical journals), and how potential biases in source material might have been mitigated. A more transparent methodology regarding source inclusion and exclusion would strengthen the credibility of the foundational dataset.

- While the use of similarity matching to link unanswered Twitter questions to existing answers is conceptually sound, the paper lacks a rigorous evaluation of the similarity model’s performance. Metrics such as precision, recall, or F1-score on a held-out validation set would provide necessary evidence of its effectiveness. Furthermore, the choice of embedding model and distance metric should be justified with ablation studies or comparative analysis against alternatives.

- The annotation process for relevance assessment requires further clarification. Specifically, information about the annotators—such as their domain expertise, training procedures, and inter-annotator agreement (e.g., Cohen’s kappa or Fleiss’ kappa)—is missing. Without this, it is difficult to assess the reliability and consistency of the manual labels, which are critical for downstream applications.

- There is no discussion of temporal dynamics in the data, despite the rapidly evolving nature of scientific understanding during the pandemic. Questions and answers may become outdated or even misleading over time. The dataset would benefit from temporal tagging and possibly versioning to reflect changes in medical consensus, ensuring users can distinguish between early-pandemic guidance and current best practices.

- The paper does not address potential ethical concerns related to using publicly available tweets. While tweets are public, extracting and repurposing user-generated content for research raises issues around informed consent, privacy, and data ownership. A brief section discussing compliance with platform policies and ethical guidelines (e.g., GDPR, IRB approval if applicable) would improve responsible research conduct transparency.

- The distribution of question types across clinical, preventive, policy-related, and misinformation domains is unreported. Understanding this breakdown could help users gauge the dataset’s applicability to specific NLP tasks such as fact-checking, medical QA, or public sentiment analysis. Providing a taxonomy or categorization schema would add significant value.

- No error analysis is presented on cases where the top-5 retrieved answers were deemed irrelevant. Examining failure modes—such as semantic drift, ambiguous queries, or out-of-domain questions—could inform future improvements in retrieval models and highlight limitations that end-users should be aware of.

- The dataset’s potential for bias propagation warrants deeper investigation. For instance, popular websites may overrepresent certain demographics or geographic regions, and Twitter-based questions may skew toward English-speaking, urban, or younger populations. Quantifying or at least acknowledging these representational imbalances would enhance awareness of the dataset’s limitations.

- The authors do not explore multilinguality, even though public health communication during the pandemic occurred in multiple languages. Given that the dataset draws from global discourse, an assessment of language diversity in both the seed QA pairs and Twitter questions—and plans for future expansion beyond English—would broaden its impact.

- Documentation regarding dataset formatting, accessibility, and licensing is sparse. Researchers require clear instructions on how to access the data, what usage rights are granted, and how to cite it properly. Including metadata fields such as confidence scores, source URLs, timestamps, and answer provenance would increase usability and reproducibility.

- The paper would benefit from benchmarking baseline models on the proposed dataset. Demonstrating performance on tasks like answer relevance classification or question clustering provides immediate utility and helps situate the dataset within the broader landscape of biomedical QA resources.

- There is limited discussion on how this dataset compares to existing efforts such as COV-QA, CORD-19, or TREC-COVID. A comparative table highlighting differences in scope, size, annotation quality, update frequency, and intended use cases would clarify the novel contribution and justify the need for another resource in an already active space.

- The decision to limit annotations to binary relevance (relevant/irrelevant) may oversimplify the complexity of medical responses. Some answers might be partially correct, context-dependent, or conditionally valid. Exploring multi-dimensional annotation schemes—such as accuracy, completeness, and confidence—could yield richer supervision signals for learning models.

- Scalability of the curation pipeline remains unaddressed. If similar methods were applied to other diseases or public health crises, what components would generalize, and which would require domain-specific adaptation? A reflection on transferability strengthens the methodological contribution beyond the immediate context of COVID-19.

- The role of automated filtering prior to manual annotation is underdescribed. Preprocessing steps such as deduplication, spam detection, or bot account filtering likely played a role in shaping the final set of 27,000 questions. Detailing these steps ensures reproducibility and guards against artifacts introduced by low-quality inputs.

- The paper misses an opportunity to analyze linguistic characteristics of the Twitter-sourced questions. Features such as readability level, sentiment, presence of negation or uncertainty markers, or allusions to conspiracy theories could inform downstream applications in risk communication or misinformation detection.

- Long-term maintenance and sustainability of the dataset are not discussed. Public health datasets often require updates as new evidence emerges. Outlining a plan for periodic revisions, community contributions, or integration with live knowledge bases would enhance its longevity and real-world utility.

- Evaluation of retrieval diversity among the top-5 answers is absent. It is possible that high-similarity results are semantically redundant, offering little additional value. Metrics such as MRR or nDCG could be complemented with diversity-aware measures to ensure varied and informative response sets.

- The work assumes that similarity implies answerability, but this may not always hold. Two questions can be syntactically or semantically close without sharing the same answerability status—for example, one may ask for evidence while the other demands opinion. A discussion on the boundaries of transferable answers would refine expectations.

- There is no indication of how unanswered questions were filtered for coherence or grammaticality. Informal language, typos, or incomplete sentences common in social media may affect matching performance. Describing normalization techniques or robustness mechanisms would improve clarity on system resilience.

- The paper could better position itself within the literature on human-in-the-loop data curation. By framing manual annotation as part of an iterative refinement process, the authors could draw on established frameworks for active learning or disagreement-based sampling to optimize labeling efficiency.

- Finally, while the effort represents a valuable contribution to pandemic-related NLP resources, the broader implications for crisis response infrastructure deserve mention. How might this approach be adapted for future outbreaks or emergency situations? Strategic reflections on rapid deployment, cross-agency collaboration, or integration with official communication channels would elevate the impact of the work.

Framing manual annotation as part of an iterative refinement process—potentially leveraging active learning or disagreement-based sampling—would connect the work to established methodologies for optimizing annotation efficiency and model improvement.

- Finally, while the dataset represents a meaningful addition to pandemic-related NLP resources, the broader implications for crisis response infrastructure deserve greater emphasis. How might this framework be adapted for future outbreaks or emergency scenarios? Strategic reflections on rapid deployment, cross-institutional collaboration, or integration with official public health channels would elevate the significance and societal impact of the work.

--- 

This revised version maintains all substantive critiques while presenting them in a more cohesive, formal, and academically appropriate tone—suitable for inclusion in a peer review on OpenReview or similar platforms.

Pakula, remembered Universal Pictures executives questioning him about a potential script: "They said, 'What story do you plan to tell for the film?' I said, 'Have you read the book?' They said, 'Yes.' I said, 'That's the story.'" The movie was a hit at the box office, quickly grossing more than $20 million from a $2-million budget. It won three Oscars: Best Actor for Gregory Peck, Best Art Direction-Set Decoration, Black-and-White, and Best Writing, Screenplay Based on Material from Another Medium for Horton Foote. It was nominated for five more Oscars including Best Actress in a Supporting Role for Mary Badham, the actress who played Scout.
