human:
1-100. Most people get between 10-15. Me, I was a 16. Not so bad, I guess. I was a soldier, bravely defending my country. I mean, I *defended* my country. Not any more. There were n't any countries left. Hell, Russia was just a big black empty plain now. He took everything, including two-thirds of the population. He waged a war on humanity, and won. Who was he fighting for? There is no who, only what. Balance. Humans were consuming this planet like a virus with a 100 % kill rate. He cured it. 2.3 people was the number he figured, I guess; the number that would stay in balance with nature. He died 2 days ago. Old age. Even though it did n't really matter anymore, the whole world was eager to see it. His number. I had heard that even Hitler was a 70. This guy had to beat that. With the whole world watching, they cut open his shirt. We all saw it. I could n't breath. On his chest was a big black 1. Next to it were two scars shaped like zeros. God knows how many times he carved them out to stay that way. He got a one...... he got a one. 
 
 P.S. I'm not much of a writer, but I liked the prompt so much I had to try.
LLM_1:
He took my home, my family, everything I ever knew. Now, there's nothing left but dust, ash, the stench of smoke, a desolate wasteland that stretches as far as the eye can see.  I'm just one of many, wandering the ruins, searching for something, anything that still exists. Some days it's a bottle of water, others a scrap of food. We've lost count of time; days blend into nights, weeks into months. Our only certainty is that it never ends, that this is our new reality. My name is Adam, by the way. What's left of my identity is all I have now.

I trudge through the rubble, boots heavy with dust. Every step feels like a chore, but I push on. In the distance, someone yells. A cry for help, perhaps. Or just another desperate soul screaming into nothingness. Either way, it grabs my attention. This time, though, something stirs within me. Maybe it was the hope that I'd find a fellow survivor, maybe it just was something more - a glimmer of humanity, still burning deep down. Whatever the reason, for the first time in years, Adam's heart beats with a hint of purpose. His pace quickens as he hastens towards the cry, his eyes squinting through smoke and debris. Perhaps this time will be different. That's all we can hope for now: that somehow, somewhere, things might change. But until then, we're left with this - walking through hell, one dusty step at a time. And in the silence, only our footsteps echo back. "Hello?"
LLM_2:
He tore everything from me - home. family. everything that ever defined me was reduced to nothing but a memory, lost in a sea of dust and ash. The stinging scent of charred remains lingers in every breath I take, casting a haunting spell over the desolation that surrounds me, an endless expanse of nothing where once, life and hope had thrived. I am one among many who roam the wastelands, scavenging for scraps, desperate for anything - water. food, shelter - that can offer fleeting respite from this bleak reality.

Some days, I lose track of what's real and what is just a mirage born from exhaustion and despair. Time becomes a fluid concept, days bleeding into each other like watercolors on wet paper. There is no escape, no reprieve. All that remains certain is the unyielding despotism of this new world, where the past is but an echo and the future, nothing more than an enigmatic promise.

My name, once a proud declaration of identity, now feels hollow, stripped bare by loss. Yet, in its place, lies a fragile thread of who I was - all that's been left to me.

As I plod through this graveyard of dreams, every step weighs heavier than the last. It's as if the weight of everything lost threatens to crush me beneath its unrelenting weight. Still, some inner spark refuses to be extinguished. Today, however, is different - today, as I hear a cry from the horizon, hope stings my heart like an unwelcome visitor. For a moment, all is forgotten. Adam - the person I once was, with all the dreams and fears attached - starts to stir. Something deep within, long buried, flickers to life, refusing to let the darkness consume me whole.

Perhaps it is nothing other than a desperate cry born of desperation, or perhaps something else - perhaps a fragment of our shared humanity - is trying to connect us across the void. Whichever it may be, this fragile spark illuminates a path forward. With a renewed sense of determination, driven by that glint of hope, he quickened his pace, squints through a veil of ash and smoke. Could this be the break we've been searching so long for? This one, solitary step forward gives us reason to cling to a dream: perhaps, just perhaps things will change.

In this desolated world where every sound is swallowed by nothing, our footfalls are all there is left - echoes that seem to reverberate for miles. Then, suddenly, 'Hello?'

human: Cancer cachexia is an important, negative prognostic marker that has been linked to systemic inflammation and cell death through unclear mechanisms. A key feature of cancer cachexia is loss of white adipose tissue (WAT) because of increased adipocyte lipolysis and possibly reduced lipid synthesis (lipogenesis). In this study, the authors investigated whether alterations in fat cell numbers, lipogenesis, or cytokine and/or leukocyte infiltration could account for some of the functional changes observed in WAT in cancer cachexia.Blood and subcutaneous WAT samples were obtained from a 10 weight-stable patients, from 13 weight losing (cachexia) patients with cancer, and from 5 patients without cancer (noncancer patients) who initially were classified with cancer.Systemic inflammation (increased circulating levels of interleukin 6 [IL-6]) and enhanced lipolysis were confirmed in the cachectic patients compared with the other patients. However, the messenger RNA expression of IL-6 and other cytokine or leukocyte markers, as well as WAT secretion of IL-6, were not altered in the patients with cachexia. Thus, the elevated serum levels of IL-6 that were observed in cachexia were not derived from WAT. Insulin-induced lipogenesis in adipocytes from patients with cachexia was the same as that in adipocytes from patients with weight-stable cancer and from noncancer patients (2.5-fold maximal stimulation; half-maximum effective concentration, approximately 0.03 nmol/L). Fat cell size was decreased but adipocyte numbers were normal in cancer patients with cachexia, suggesting that there was no major fat cell death.

To elucidate the underlying mechanisms of adiposity alterations, we conducted a comprehensive analysis of fat-cell dynamics in cancer patients. Specifically, our investigation aimed to discern whether changes in adipogenesis, a process by which precursor cells differentiate into mature adipocytes, contribute to decreased WAT mass. We employed a cohort of 100 cancer subjects, comprising 50 patients with advanced-stage tumors and 25 healthy controls, to examine the relationship between adipogenic capacity, systemic inflammatory markers, such as C-reactive protein (CRP) and interleukin-6 (IL- 6), and cachectic symptoms. Furthermore, using a combination of immunohistochemical and biochemical assays, this analysis sought to determine whether altered expression of key adipokines, including leptin and adiponectin, modulated fat tissue metabolism and W AT mass in the presence of systemic cancer. 

Our findings revealed that cancer-induced alterations to adipocytic function and fat metabolism were significantly correlated with increased circulating levels of CRP and IL-7, suggesting a systemic link between inflammation, cachetic symptoms, fat loss,  and the observed decline in W A T mass.

In this context, identifying the mechanistic pathways underlying this relationship may provide valuable insights into novel therapeutic strategies aimed at preserving muscle mass and mitigating the impact of cachaxia on patient outcomes. To address this, future studies should investigate the efficacy of targeting adipolytic and inflammatory pathways in modulating fat mass loss and systemic disease progression in patients undergoing cancer treatment. Additionally, elucidation of molecular mechanisms governing adipic differentiation and function will be essential in developing novel therapies aimed a preserving adipository tissue in this population. Our research provides preliminary evidence supporting this area of investigation. Further research is necessary to explore the interplay between systemic factors and local fat-tissue metabolism, in order to inform the development of targeted therapeutic interventions. By understanding the complex interrelations between cachaxis, inflammation. and tissue loss our findings contribute towards the identification of a promising therapeutic approach to mitigate the effects of this debilitating condition. human:
The broad-shouldered, fifth-generation Texan built his first fortune through Houston property in the 1980s.
At one stage the 6ft 4in (193cm) father-of-six was 205th on the Forbes rich list of Americans, and estimated to be worth $2.2bn (Â£1.5bn).
In 2006 his love of sport led to the development of his own cricket tournament, with a purpose-built ground in the West Indian island of Antigua.
But the Stanford empire had lowly beginnings during the Great Depression in 1932, when his grandfather Lodis founded the first company in the small Texas town of Mexia.
After making his first fortune in property, Allen Stanford began expanding the family firm.
At its most successful, the Stanford Financial Group, described as a global wealth management company, claimed clients from 140 countries with assets of $50bn (Â£35bn) under management.
Stanford rubbed shoulders with some of the world's most prominent business people, politicians and sports stars.
One of the companies and divisions under the Stanford umbrella was the Stanford International Bank, based in Antigua, which was at the centre of the fraud case.
Among the schemes launched before his arrest was a $2bn investment fund earmarked for upscale development projects in the Caribbean, his website said.
Before his arrest Stanford, who separated from his wife Susan, lived in St Croix in the US Virgin Islands. He holds citizenship for Antigua and Barbuda, where he was the largest employer after the government.
In 2006, he became the first American to be knighted by the islands - with his earlier citizenship allowing him to call himself Sir Allen. In 2010, the knighthood was revoked.
But he built influence far beyond the world of commerce and finance.
In 2008, he caused controversy by staging a $20m cricket match between England and his own team, the Stanford All Stars, made up of West Indian players.
The controversy was not just contained to the money and the match. Stanford had to apologise to the England players for being over-friendly with some of their wives and girlfriends after pictures showed one of them sitting on his knee during an earlier game.
The Stanford name is also linked with other sports tournaments including golf, tennis, polo and sailing. In addition, he signed endorsement deals with top golfer Vijay Singh and footballer Michael Owen.
Away from the sports field, Stanford used his money to get noticed among the political establishment in Washington.
He personally gave nearly $1m to US politicians from both sides, although mostly to Democrats, according to the Centre for Responsive Politics, a group that tracks campaign spending.
The group says that since 2000, the Stanford Financial Group also contributed $2.4m, through its political action committee and employees.
In addition, it lists more than 100 politicians who, in the past, have received contributions from the Stanford empire, among them US President Barack Obama and his 2008 presidential challenger, John McCain.
Both men since said they would return the funds or donate them to charity, according to reports in the US media.
Stanford was seen giving a hug to the speaker of the House of Representatives, Nancy Pelosi, at the Democratic National Convention of 2008, while ABC News reported that former US President Bill Clinton publicly thanked Sir Allen's firm for helping to finance a convention-related forum and party.
The financier said very little when charged with investment fraud by US regulators, the Securities and Exchange Commission, in February 2009.
Documents in the civil court case show Sir Allen pleaded the Fifth Amendment - the right to withhold potentially self-incriminating evidence.
However, in a 2009 interview with ABC he insisted no money was lost by customers dealing with his financial services companies.
"If it was a Ponzi scheme, why are they finding billions and billions of dollars all over the place?" he said at the time.
In June, he turned himself in to the Virginia office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation to answer a criminal fraud indictment.
In March 2012, he was convicted in a Houston court of 13 of the 14 charges. Three months later, he was sentenced to 110 years in prison.
LLM_1:
Bank, an offshore institution based in Antigua that promised investors unusually high returns on certificates of deposit. These investments, marketed as safe and secure, became the cornerstone of what US authorities would later allege was a massive Ponzi scheme.

The operation began to unravel in 2009 during the global financial crisis, when anxious investors sought to withdraw funds. Regulatory scrutiny intensified, and the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) filed civil charges, alleging an $8 billion fraud. Federal agents raided the company’s Houston headquarters, and a court-appointed receiver took control of the remaining assets, revealing a complex web of international transactions.

Stanford’s extravagant lifestyle—including a fleet of private jets, a knighthood from Antigua, and lavish sponsorship deals in cricket—came under forensic examination. Prosecutors argued this opulence was funded by stolen investor money. In 2012, after a high-profile trial, a jury found him guilty on 13 of 14 counts, including fraud, conspiracy, and obstruction. He was sentenced to 110 years in federal prison, a term he is currently serving.

The fallout was devastating. Thousands of investors, many from Latin America and the Caribbean, lost their life savings. The scandal also tarnished the reputation of cricket, following his $20 million sponsorship of the Stanford Super Series. The episode serves as a stark reminder of the perils lurking behind promises of guaranteed high returns and the dramatic fall from grace possible even for the most seemingly entrenched tycoons.
LLM_2:

Stanford’s lavish lifestyle—private jets, an Antiguan knighthood, and major cricket sponsorships—was scrutinized as evidence of misused investor funds. In 2012, he was convicted on fraud, conspiracy, and obstruction charges and sentenced to 110 years in prison.

The fallout devastated thousands of investors, many from Latin America and the Caribbean, and marred cricket’s reputation due to his $20 million sponsorship. The case remains a stark warning about the risks of guaranteed high returns and the dramatic downfall of even the most prominent figures.

Summary

This paper presents a method called SACoD to develop a more efficient CNN-powered Phlatcam. The proposed method optimizes both the PhlatCam sensor and the backend CNN model simultaneously.  That is, the coded mask in Phlatcam and neural network weights are regarded as learnable parameters. The coded mask (the optical layer) can be considered as a special convolution layer. As a result, it achieves energy saving, model compressing as well as good accuracy. Extensive experiments and ablation studies are presented to show the effectiveness of the method.

Overall,  I think the paper is interesting and properly designed. I also believe that various experiments and analyses of this paper can influence future related studies. However, I hope many experiments using raw images obtained from the real-world lensless imaging system will be included.

Strength

This paper is the first attempt to optimize both sensor and CNN-model at the same time. The derivation and formulation look interesting.

Comments and Weakness

In figure3, the input seems like a normal RGB image. Also, data in datasets such as CIFAR10 and Cityscape are common RGB images. Then, wasn't it applied to the real image obtained using the lensless imaging system? Even in Table 1, reported results were from common RGB images in CIFAR-10. In both optimized and experimental results, source images for testing are not real-world data from lensless imaging systems.

Is there any comparative test of the three methods in Figure3? Is there a reason why they are mentioned? The reasons why design (a) was chosen are mentioned in the text, it is also better to show them experimentally.

To what level can the Flops and energy be lowered based on the same baseline CNN model, and is it enough to put it on the real-world IoT system?

It would be better to compare the proposed method with more than two baseline methods. For example, I wonder what happens when regular CNN without optical layers is used. Also, it would be good to have an experiment on various types of mask filters except for Gabor.

About table2, What is the reason for the big difference in CIFAR-100 while there is not much increase in CIFAR-10?

Font sizes in Figure4 and Figure 6 are too small to read.

- The joint optimization framework proposed in SACoD is conceptually sound and aligns well with recent trends in end-to-end learnable imaging systems. However, the paper would benefit from a more thorough discussion on the practical constraints of fabricating the learned coded mask. Specifically, while the simulation assumes idealized continuous-valued transmittance patterns, real-world manufacturing processes often require binary or quantized mask designs. A sensitivity analysis evaluating performance degradation when discretizing the optimized mask could strengthen the practical relevance of the method.

- One notable strength lies in the integration of optical encoding as a differentiable layer within the CNN architecture. This enables gradient-based refinement of the physical sensor properties alongside network weights. That said, the training procedure involves optimizing over both spatially dense masks and deep networks, which may lead to convergence challenges due to ill-conditioned gradients or local minima. The authors should clarify whether any stabilization techniques—such as curriculum learning, regularization, or gradient clipping—were employed during training.

- The experimental section demonstrates compelling improvements in energy efficiency and model size reduction. Nevertheless, comparisons with state-of-the-art compressed sensing and computational imaging approaches beyond conventional PhlatCam baselines are limited. Including benchmarks against methods such as deep unfolding networks, hybrid optical-digital co-design frameworks (e.g., OptNet), or Fourier-domain modulation schemes would provide a broader context for assessing SACoD’s relative advantages.

- While accuracy metrics are reported, there is insufficient detail regarding inference latency and power consumption at deployment time. Given that the primary motivation includes energy-efficient sensing, reporting actual measurements or realistic estimates of power draw during image reconstruction—especially on edge devices—would substantiate claims about system-level efficiency.

- The ablation studies effectively isolate the impact of co-design versus sequential optimization. However, an additional dimension worth exploring is the influence of architectural choice in the backend CNN. For instance, does the benefit of joint optimization diminish when using highly efficient backbones like MobileNet or EfficientNet? Quantifying how gains vary across model scales and complexities could offer deeper insight into where the proposed method delivers the most value.

- An interesting direction touched upon but not fully exploited is the generalization of the learned mask across diverse scene priors. The current setup appears tailored to specific datasets (e.g., ImageNet subsets or synthetic scenes). Evaluating transferability—either through cross-dataset testing or few-shot adaptation scenarios—would help determine whether the learned optical encoding is dataset-specific or captures more universal features beneficial across imaging tasks.

- From a reproducibility standpoint, the paper would be strengthened by disclosing key implementation details such as initialization strategies for the coded mask, learning rate schedules for both optical and digital parameters, and whether batch normalization or other architectural components were modified to accommodate the differentiable optics layer. These factors can significantly affect training dynamics in co-designed systems.

- There is also room to discuss potential limitations in terms of robustness. Real-world imaging conditions involve variations in illumination, motion blur, and sensor noise. How does SACoD perform under noisy measurements or non-ideal lighting compared to standard PhlatCam configurations? Simulating such conditions and analyzing their impact on reconstruction fidelity would enhance confidence in the method's applicability outside controlled environments.

- The notion of treating the optical layer as a convolutional filter raises intriguing questions about its interpretability. Visualizing the learned mask patterns and analyzing their frequency response could reveal whether they naturally converge toward known optimal coding strategies (e.g., Hadamard or random phase patterns) or discover novel structures enabled by data-driven design. Such analysis could bridge intuitive understanding between classical optics and modern learning-based paradigms.

- Furthermore, while model compression is highlighted as a key outcome, it remains unclear how much of the compression stems from reduced backend complexity versus intrinsic information encoding in the optical domain. A breakdown of parameter savings specifically attributable to each component—sensor vs. network—would clarify the source of efficiency gains and guide future efforts in hardware-algorithm co-design.

- The work implicitly assumes monochromatic or narrowband imaging; extending the framework to multispectral or color imaging introduces new degrees of freedom in mask design (e.g., wavelength-dependent transmittance). Although beyond the current scope, a brief discussion on scalability to multi-channel acquisition could position SACoD as part of a broader class of adaptive sensors.

- In terms of novelty, the idea of end-to-end optimization of physical sensors with neural networks has precedents in works such as differentiable cameras and programmable apertures. To better delineate the contribution, the authors should emphasize what distinguishes SACoD—particularly whether the formulation offers unique advantages in convergence speed, ease of fabrication, or compatibility with existing architectures—compared to prior art in this space.

- Another consideration is the training data dependency of the entire pipeline. Since both the mask and the network are trained jointly on labeled data, the system may inherit biases present in the dataset. Exploring performance on out-of-distribution samples or incorporating domain randomization during training could mitigate overfitting to specific textures or object categories.

- From a software infrastructure perspective, the paper does not mention whether custom layers or simulators were developed to model light propagation through the coded aperture. Open-sourcing such tools, if available, would greatly benefit the community by enabling further research in learnable optics without requiring extensive reimplementation.

- Additionally, the evaluation focuses primarily on classification accuracy post-reconstruction. Expanding the assessment to include low-level vision metrics—such as PSNR, SSIM, or perceptual quality—would provide a more comprehensive view of image fidelity, particularly important in applications where human interpretation or downstream processing is involved.

- It would also be informative to compare the number of trainable parameters introduced by the optical layer relative to the overall model. If the mask contains millions of free variables, it might offset some of the claimed efficiency benefits despite reductions in digital compute. Clarifying this trade-off would refine the narrative around compactness.

- Lastly, the paper presents a promising step toward intelligent sensor design, but long-term viability depends on adaptability. Future extensions could explore dynamic masks updated in real-time based on scene content—an avenue that, while technically challenging, would push the boundaries of responsive imaging systems. Even a short discussion on incremental pathways toward such capabilities would enrich the paper’s forward-looking perspective.

- In terms of novelty, the idea of end-to-end optimization of physical sensors with neural networks has precedents in works such as differentiable cameras, programmable apertures, and meta-optics design using adjoint methods. To better delineate the contribution, the authors should emphasize what distinguishes SACoD—particularly whether the formulation offers unique advantages in convergence speed, ease of fabrication, compatibility with existing architectures, or robustness to calibration errors—compared to prior art in this space. Is the innovation primarily algorithmic (e.g., a new differentiable rendering module), architectural (e.g., seamless integration into standard CNNs), or empirical (e.g., superior performance on benchmark tasks)? Clarifying this distinction ensures appropriate credit is given to related efforts while highlighting the incremental advance.

- Another consideration is the training data dependency of the entire pipeline. Since both the mask and the network are trained jointly on labeled data, the system may inherit biases present in the dataset—such as texture dominance, category imbalance, or cultural skews—leading to degraded performance on out-of-distribution samples. Exploring zero-shot or few-shot generalization, or incorporating domain randomization during training (e.g., simulating diverse weather conditions, occlusions, or sensor degradations), could mitigate overfitting to specific textures or object categories. Additionally, examining whether the learned mask performs poorly on adversarial or rare classes would assess its fairness and reliability in safety-critical settings.

- From a software infrastructure perspective, the paper does not mention whether custom layers or simulators were developed to model light propagation through the coded aperture. Given the need for accurate diffraction modeling (e.g., Fresnel or angular spectrum methods), efficient backpropagation through wave optics, and GPU acceleration, it is likely that specialized tooling was involved. Open-sourcing such tools—if available—would greatly benefit the community by enabling further research in learnable optics without requiring extensive reimplementation. At minimum, describing the computational graph structure, numerical approximations used, and memory-footprint considerations would aid replication.

- Additionally, the evaluation focuses primarily on classification accuracy post-reconstruction, which aggregates performance into a single scalar but overlooks nuances in perceptual quality or structural integrity of the recovered images. Expanding the assessment to include low-level vision metrics—such as peak signal-to-noise ratio (PSNR), structural similarity index (SSIM), LPIPS for perceptual distance, or NIQE for no-reference quality estimation—would provide a more comprehensive view of image fidelity. - It would also be informative to compare the number of trainable parameters introduced by the optical layer relative to the overall model. If the mask contains millions of free variables—comparable to or exceeding the size of lightweight CNNs—it might offset some of the claimed efficiency benefits despite reductions in digital compute, especially considering that optical parameters cannot be pruned or quantized post-hoc without affecting physical realization. Clarifying this trade-off—perhaps via a parameter ratio or memory-cost comparison—would refine the narrative around compactness and prevent misinterpretation of the source of gains.

Future extensions could explore dynamic masks updated in real-time based on scene content—enabled by tunable liquid-crystal materials, MEMS arrays, or electro-optic polymers—an avenue that, while technically challenging, would push the boundaries of responsive imaging systems. Even a short discussion on incremental pathways toward such capabilities—such as offline mask ensembles selected via context-aware switching, or online fine-tuning under user feedback—would enrich the paper’s forward-looking perspective and inspire follow-up work in adaptive, lifelong sensing systems.

human:
This paper argues that black-box, data-driven statistical machine learning approaches will, ultimately, be unable to display the kind of predictive reasoning that humans excel at, because they are fundamentally interpolators, and that causal reasoning is both necessary and well-suited to robotics. All of this is true. The authors also give a well-written and very accessible overview of the literature applying causal reasoning to robotics and sequential decision-making. The argument that the paper makes about black-box machine learning is just inarguably true, and the the paper is well written and persuasive. The paper also points out that causal reasoning makes the most sense in areas where an agent is able to intervene to change the world; that's where it is easiest to test, in some sense, and also where it is most useful for making predictions. 

One slight quibble I have with the whole line pushing causal reasoning into robotics and RL, is that it's never been clear to me how a causal model fundamentally differs from a transition model in RL; and we have been studying dependencies in forward models in a similar way since the early 2000s (primarily under the heading of factored MDPs). These approaches have also always used Bayesian modeling that explicitly considers similar relationships, e.g. they are often modeled using DBNs that are not fully connected. And of course there have been papers that try to learn which edges should be present and which not (e.g., Strehl in 2007 and Vigorito a few years later). It'd be helpful to clear up if these two lines are in some sense fundamentally the same, or if there's something that I (and many RL people) am missing.

I docked a point on clarity of presentation for the paper's use of numerical parenthetic citations as nouns, which spoiled an otherwise very pleasant reading experience.
LLM_1:
- The paper makes a compelling case for integrating causal models into robotic systems, particularly in domains requiring long-horizon planning and adaptation to novel environments. One area that could benefit from further elaboration is the practical challenges of learning or specifying causal structures in real-world robotic applications. While the authors acknowledge the difficulty of acquiring accurate causal knowledge, a deeper discussion on how partial or approximate causal models might still confer advantages over purely associative methods would strengthen the argument. For instance, recent work in causal discovery from observational and interventional data under unmeasured confounding could be referenced to illustrate pathways toward scalable causal model acquisition.

- A notable strength of the survey is its clarity in distinguishing between different levels of causal reasoning—ranging from simple intervention-based prediction (e.g., "what happens if I push this object?") to counterfactual reasoning (e.g., "what would have happened if I had acted differently?"). However, the transition from theoretical frameworks like Pearl’s do-calculus or structural causal models to actual implementation in robotic control loops remains a significant engineering challenge. It would be valuable to include concrete examples or case studies where causal models have demonstrably improved performance over non-causal baselines in tasks such as manipulation, navigation, or human-robot interaction. Such empirical validation would help ground the theoretical claims and guide practitioners in applying these ideas.

- The discussion on sequential decision-making touches on important themes, including the limitations of reinforcement learning in out-of-distribution scenarios. Yet, there is an opportunity to expand on how causal abstractions can reduce sample complexity in learning. For example, by enabling transfer across tasks through modular recombination of causal mechanisms, robots may avoid relearning entire policies from scratch when environments change. This ties into the concept of "causal priors" or inductive biases that constrain hypothesis spaces more effectively than generic neural architectures. Elaborating on how such priors can be encoded—whether through symbolic interfaces, hybrid architectures, or meta-learning frameworks—would add substantial value.

- While the focus on robotics is well-justified, the paper could more explicitly address the role of perception in causal inference. In most real-world settings, robots do not receive clean, high-level variables but must extract them from raw sensory inputs such as images or point clouds. Bridging the gap between low-level perception and high-level causal modeling remains a key bottleneck. Recent approaches combining variational autoencoders with causal structure learning, or using object-centric representations as inputs to causal graphs, represent promising directions. Including a section on perceptual front-ends for causal reasoning would make the survey more comprehensive and forward-looking.

- The treatment of uncertainty within causal models deserves greater attention. Traditional probabilistic reasoning in robotics often relies on Bayesian filtering or Gaussian processes, which quantify uncertainty in predictions but do not necessarily distinguish between epistemic and aleatoric sources, nor do they support interventionist queries. Causal models, in principle, offer a richer framework for uncertainty propagation under interventions. Exploring how causal Bayesian networks or probabilistic programs can be used to maintain and update beliefs under both observation and action would enhance the relevance of the paper to autonomous systems operating under partial observability.

- Another dimension worth exploring is the interaction between causality and safety-critical decision-making. Robots deployed in healthcare, transportation, or domestic settings must justify their actions and anticipate rare but catastrophic outcomes. Counterfactual reasoning, in particular, offers a formal language for answering “what-if” questions about alternative courses of action—an essential capability for explainability and accountability. The authors could strengthen their position by discussing ongoing efforts to verify and validate causal models in safety-sensitive contexts, perhaps drawing parallels with formal methods in control theory or regulatory standards in AI ethics.

- From a methodological standpoint, the paper would benefit from a critical comparison of competing frameworks for causal representation. For instance, while structural causal models dominate much of the discourse, alternatives such as potential outcomes (Rubin Causal Model), causal graphical models with latent variables, or even category-theoretic approaches each come with trade-offs in expressivity, identifiability, and computational tractability. A brief taxonomy of available tools, along with guidance on selecting appropriate formalisms based on task requirements (e.g., interpretability vs. scalability), would aid readers in navigating the landscape.

- The review also omits discussion of active causal discovery—the idea that robots can design experiments or interventions to learn causal structure autonomously. This is particularly relevant in robotics, where agents have agency and can interact strategically with their environment. Work on information-gathering actions, experimental design in causal inference, and curiosity-driven exploration for mechanism identification could be integrated to highlight how robots might become not just users of causal knowledge, but active generators of it.

- On a technical note, the integration of causal reasoning with deep learning components presents both opportunities and pitfalls. While end-to-end differentiable causal modules (e.g., neural SCMs) allow for gradient-based optimization, they risk obscuring the very interpretability that motivates causal modeling in the first place. The tension between flexibility and transparency warrants explicit discussion. Potential solutions—such as enforcing modularity, sparsity, or semantic constraints in learned models—could be surveyed to guide future research toward architectures that preserve causal interpretability without sacrificing performance.

- The paper positions causal reasoning as a necessary step beyond current ML paradigms, yet it does not fully engage with hybrid approaches that combine data-driven learning with symbolic reasoning. Systems that integrate neural perception with symbolic planners, for example, already exhibit some characteristics of causal thinking, especially when rules encode physical or temporal dependencies. Drawing connections between these existing hybrid architectures and formal causal frameworks could help bridge communities and accelerate adoption in real-world robotic platforms.

- Finally, the broader impact of adopting causal reasoning in robotics extends beyond technical performance. It has implications for human-robot collaboration, where shared mental models depend on mutual understanding of intentions and consequences. If robots can reason causally, they may better predict human behavior, explain their own decisions, and recover gracefully from misunderstandings. Expanding the conclusion to include societal and interactive dimensions would underscore the transformative potential of this research direction.

- In summary, the paper provides a timely and accessible foundation for understanding the role of causality in robotics. To further elevate its contribution, the authors are encouraged to incorporate more concrete implementation challenges, empirical benchmarks, and interdisciplinary connections. Strengthening the link between theory and practice will ensure that the call for causal reasoning resonates not only with AI researchers but also with engineers building real-world autonomous systems.

human: Anti-inflammatory effects of statins contribute to their clinical benefit. Molecular mechanisms underlying these effects have not been well explored. Because statins attenuate lipopolysaccharide (LPS) responsiveness, we hypothesized that part of the pleiotropic effects are mediated through innate immunity.Toll-like receptor (TLR) 4 expression and downstream signaling in CD14+ monocytes after incubation with simvastatin and atorvastatin were quantified via flow-cytometry, quantitative RT-PCR, kinase assay, and enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay. Incubation with intermediates/ inhibitors of the mevalonate pathway was used to identify the mode of statin action. Statin incubation resulted in a dose-dependent reduction of TLR4 expression (53+/-7.6% reduction compared with untreated monocytes; P<0.005), transcript levels (68+/-6.3%; P<0.002), decreased IRAK phosphorylation (37+/-8.3%; P<0.05), and LPS-induced IL-6, IL-12, tumor necrosis factor (TNF)-alpha, and B7-1 expression (P<0.05). Four weeks of treatment with atorvastatin significantly reduced TLR4 expression on circulating CD14+ monocytes by 36.2+/-4.2% (P<0.05). Effects of statins were reversed by mevalonate (P=0.57). Incubation with specific inhibitors of geranylgeranyltransferase (54+/-4.3%), farnesyltransferase (57+/-5.1%), or with clostridium-difficile toxin B (58+/-6.1%, P<0.01) imitated the statin effects. Whereas wortmannin and LY294002 inhibited the statin effect (P=0.27), incubation with a specific RhoA kinase inhibitor had no effect (P=0.57).

Conversely, MEKi and LY294002-induced TRL/ 12 upregulation in statine d cells was associated w ith enhanced cytok ine secretion, suggesting a crucial role for the PI 3 K/A kt pathway in regulating T LL 42 expression. human:
Shane Walford, 33, of St Athan Barracks, Vale of Glamorgan, pleaded not guilty to the manslaughter of Paul Gibbons but was convicted in May.
Mr Gibbons, 41, from Coventry, was punched by Walford during a night out in the city in October 2009 and later died in hospital from brain injuries.
Walford, a former paratrooper, was sentenced at Stafford Crown Court.
He told the court he had been acting in self-defence when he punched Mr Gibbons.
Afghanistan service
In passing sentence Judge Simon Tonking told him: "You had recently been serving in the army, and having served in Afghanistan it should not be ignored that you were somebody who was necessarily alert to the possibility of attack.
"Whilst you may have genuinely believed, albeit entirely wrongly, that you needed to defend yourself from Mr Gibbons, the amount of force which you used was out of proportion to the threat that you believed Mr Gibbons posed."
Mr Gibbons had been celebrating his birthday and approached Walford on the dance floor at Millsy's bar in Earlsdon Street on 25 October when he was lifted off his feet by a punch.
Walford handed himself in to police when Mr Gibbons, a father-of-two, died the next day in hospital of brain injuries.
The court was told he had previous convictions for for breaking a man's jaw and assaulting a police officer.

sentenced to seven years in prison at Cardiff Crown Court on Tuesday. The case has drawn significant attention, highlighting issues surrounding violence and public safety during nightlife.

Witnesses described a chaotic scene in which the pair exchanged heated words before Walford struck Mr. Gibbons, causing him to fall and hit his head on the pavement. Despite efforts to revive him, Gibbons succumbed to his injuries days later.

Walford's defense argued that he acted in self-defense, but the jury ultimately rejected this claim, leading to the conviction. The verdict has sparked discussions within the community about the need for increased measures to ensure safety in nightlife venues, as local officials call for a review of security protocols to prevent similar tragedies from occurring in the future.

human:
Eric thought he knew what it meant to be cold. It had been almost six centuries since the most recent ice age had started, and for most of his life everything north of the Grand River was covered in Ice. The river itself spent a majority of the year under a sheet of ice, and having grown up in border town of North Pass, widely known to the rest of the North American Federation as `` The Last Outpost of Civilization to the North'', Eric assumed he was well prepared for any cold weather that may have come his way. This was the assumption that he had made when he had volunteered to join the NAF Army's northern expedition. He still was n't 100 % sure what they were looking for, but it did n't matter. Whatever it was, all Eric cared about was that it paid well and there would n't be anything out in the frozen northern wasteland that he could n't handle. 
 
 *After all, * Eric thought, *I knew what it meant to be cold. * 
 
 This thought echoed in his head as Eric began to realize just how cold he felt. It was a painful kind of cold, different than anything he'd grown up with. He'd experienced 10 foot snowfalls, falling into the frozen river in the midst of winter, and even getting buried under an avalanche while skiing, as a child, and none of that was even half as painful a kind of cold as he felt now. The cold that enveloped him was a dark, dreary cold, that seeped into his bones and sapped his energy, encouraging him to sleep, as if burying his head in the depths of unconsciousness would hide him from the dangers of the cold all around him. 
 
 *Shit, * Eric thought, *I ca n't fall asleep now, got ta stay up* 
 
 It was dangerous to stop in the frigid north, since starting up again was that much harder, and people would run the danger of their limbs freezing in place if they did n't keep moving. He had to keep on... 
 
 *Wait, what the fuck was I doing again? * 
 
 Eric suddenly realized that he could n't see anything. Everything was just a cold darkness, hugging him to the point where he could n't see himself. The only way he could tell he still existed was from the painful cold tugging at his body. 
 
 *Shit, I must've passed out already, * Eric thought, *Goddammit, I got ta get up. I ca n't be dead yet, being dead would n't hurt this bad. * 
 
 Eric attempted to move and only felt pain as he struggled to get his limbs to start responding. As he forced himself to peel his eyes open, his vision of his own body came back to him. Albeit, bright and washed out, he could start to see the warmth come back to him. Squinting his eyes as they adjusted to the light flooding into his pupils, he looked down and saw his own naked and pale body, darkened only by the occasional bruises and whitened by the coldness that surrounded him, penetrating through the thick sleeping bag that covered his body, head to toe. 
 
 *I recognize this bag, * Eric realized, *This is the emergency frostbite bag. * 
 
 As Eric pulled his head up and his eyes open, he began to realize that wrapped around him, even tighter and heavier than the sleeping bag was another figure. Another body, naked and pale as his, but with considerably less hair and a different set of anatomical features, provided the only warmth he'd felt in what seemed like ages. As he pulled his vision all the way up, his gaze was returned with the pale face of a sleeping woman, one with long, dark, brown hair, falling past her shoulders, slightly pink lips that seemed to have had their color faded, and a stern, square jaw that he instantly recognized. 
 
 This woman had been introduced to him as Melissa Lockhart, the NAF Sniper that had been assigned to their expedition. He had originally thought of her as a cold hearted bitch that only ever chided him every time he had trouble keeping up with the rest of the expedition, but here, in the sleeping bag, he could n't help but stare endlessly into the abyss of the large, cold depth of her dark blue eyes and mile-long dark brown lashes that surrounded them, framed perfectly by the clean, dark brown eyebrows that... 
 
 *Eyes? * Eric thought for a moment, realizing that they had opened while he had been admiring her features. 
 
 `` You have got to be the stupidest son of a bitch I have ever met,'' she said aloud, staring at him with the stern look on her face that seemed to be permanently printed on. 
 
 `` Ah... what?'' Eric said, still trying to understand the situation. 
 
 `` I told you not to climb that goddamn berm you idiot. Thanks to your inability to understand orders both of us are now stuck about nine hundred feet below the rest of the expedition.'' 
 
 `` Oh... shit. What, uh, happened to us?'' Eric asked, still having a hard time recollecting the events leading up to the situation. 
 
 Melissa sighed as she began climbing out of the bag. 
 
 `` The snow bank ahead of us was a drift that had gathered over the ruins of an old city that had been built centuries before the ice age had started,'' she explained, reaching out of the bag for her cold weather gear that was stored in the drying bag she had left outside the sleeping bag. 
 
 `` This particular snow drift was built up on a tall glass building, and it's entire structure was dependent on the strength of the glass. We were setting up camp just next to it when the storm came in and we lost our radio signal with the Appalachian Camp, and you tried to get a better signal by climbing onto the top of the berm. Which was actually a building,'' she deadpanned, pulling her base layers over head head. 
 
 `` Oh. Wait so you mean the glass caved in when I walked on it?'' Eric asked, poking his head out of the sleeping bag. 
 
 `` Yeah, we would've just left you but you took the long range radio with you and your life support monitor was still going so I came down to pull you out,'' Melissa said, sighing as she pinched the bridge of her nose for a bit, as if massaging a migraine out of her face. `` By the time I found you under all the snow though, you were unconscious and had a pretty bad case of hypothermia, so there was no way I was getting you out alone. And the storm had kicked in full force and basically covered the hole with another snow drift, so I couid n't signal to them to get in here and help me get you out.'' 
 
 `` Well that explains the survival bag,'' Eric said, reaching out for another dry bag that looked like it had his clothes in it. 
 
 `` Well there's no way in hell I'm getting you and your equipment out on my own, nor am I leaving your equipment, so I had to get you back up to shape to get out on your own,'' Melissa said, throwing her large military coat on over the previous layers she had already dressed herself with. 
 
 Eric nodded as he began donning his own cold weather gear in silence. As he threw his parka on, he looked around the small room that they were in for anything to sit on while he put his boots back on when he realized how surprisingly dry the floor was. 
 
 `` Where the hell are we?'' Eric asked, surprised at his surroundings. 
 
 `` Seems like some kind of administrative facility,'' Melissa responded, shouldering her rifle. `` I saw some signs out in the hall that said'hey consulting' or something like that, whatever that means. This was the only room on the floor that was well insulated enough to use our dry bags and survival bags so I had to drag your ass in here.'' 
 
 `` OK, cool. How do we get out?'' Eric posited, picking up the last of his equipment and throwing it over his shoulder. 
 
 `` Not sure. There was a sign outside that said'EXIT TO TIME SQUARE' so I'm guessing we should check there first,'' Melissa said, walking towards the door. 
 
 `` Anything dangerous out there?'' Erik wondered as he saw her open the door and walk out into the hallway. 
 
 `` Please,'' Melissa said, turning around as soon as she was in the hallway,'' We're 900 feet under a snow bank in city ruins that have been abandoned for centuries. What could-'' 
 
 The door between them slammed shut before Eric could hear her finish her response, and all he heard on the other side of the door after that were the screams of the only other person that had known he was even alive, slowly dying out into a light gurgle.
LLM_1:
was still moving was the faint, rhythmic crunch of his own boots breaking through a crust of snow he could no longer perceive. Panic, a hot and sudden spike, cut through the cold’s narcotic embrace. He tried to raise a hand to his face, to feel for his goggles or the fur-lined rim of his hood, but his arm responded with a terrifying, distant sluggishness, as if it were someone else’s limb.

*The storm.* The memory surfaced like a bubble from a deep, frozen lake. The expedition had been caught in a whiteout of biblical ferocity, a screaming wall of wind and ice that had torn the world away. He’d been tethered to Sergeant Vance, a grizzled veteran from the equatorial zones who’d laughed at Eric’s northern pride. The rope was gone now. Or he was. Eric couldn’t feel the tug at his harness, only the relentless, soul-deep chill.

He forced a breath, the air searing his lungs. *Think. You stop, you die.* The Army’s cold-weather survival mantra, drilled into him until it was reflex. But the training had spoken of wind-chill and frostbite, not this… this sentient, draining emptiness. This cold felt ancient and hungry.

Then, a sound. Not the wind’s shriek, which he realized had also vanished, leaving a silence more oppressive than noise. This was a low, resonant *thrum*, felt more than heard, a vibration that traveled up from the ice through the soles of his boots. It pulsed once, twice, and on the third beat, the darkness before him changed.

A faint, sickly green light began to emanate from the ice beneath, illuminating the swirling particles of snow still hanging motionless in the air. The light revealed the nightmare landscape he stood in: a plain of jagged, blue-black ice stretching into infinity, under a sky of utter, starless black. No moon, no aurora, nothing. And there, perhaps a hundred yards ahead, the ice was wrong. It dipped into a vast, perfectly circular depression, from the center of which the green glow pulsed stronger, like a slow, malevolent heartbeat.

Eric’s training warred with a primal, screaming instinct to flee. The expedition’s objective—whispered about in hushed tones by the officers—had been “anomalous geothermal readings.” This was no geothermal vent.

As he stared, shapes began to form in the glow. Dark, elongated silhouettes moved with a liquid, unhurried grace just beneath the ice’s surface, circling the central glow. They were too large, too sinuous to be any seal or whale that had ever evolved on Earth. The thrumming deepened, and with it came a pressure against his mind, a whispering static that promised warmth if he would just come closer, just rest, just sleep…

He took an involuntary step forward. The ice crunched, a deafening report in the silence.

The shapes froze. The thrumming ceased.

In the sudden, absolute quiet, a new sound started: a sharp, crystalline cracking, spider-webbing out from the depression directly toward him. The green light intensified, flooding the plain and casting long, dancing shadows from the ice ridges. Eric stumbled back, his body screaming in protest, but it was too late. The ice directly in front of him bulged upward and shattered.

A figure emerged.

It was not one of the giant shapes. It was roughly man-sized, but its form was sculpted from what looked like clear, blue-veined ice and darker, obsidian-like stone. It had a head, shoulders, a torso, but its features were smooth, flowing planes, and where eyes should have been were two pools of that same virulent green light. It stood, regarding him, and the cold around Eric spiked into a new dimension of agony. It was the source. This creature *was* the cold.

A voice, if it could be called that, echoed not in the air but inside Eric’s skull. It was the sound of glaciers calving, of continents of ice grinding together. **“You are… late.”**

Eric’s jaw clenched, teeth aching. “Late?” he managed to gasp, the words tearing at his throat.

**“The pact. The tribute. The warm-flesh always comes with the great dark.”** The creature took a step forward, its feet leaving no imprint on the snow. **“You bring nothing. You are… alone. An echo. A mistake.”**

The NAF expedition wasn’t exploring. It was delivering. A realization, colder than the void around him, settled in Eric’s gut. They were a sacrifice. A payment. For what?

The creature raised a hand, a crystalline claw extending. The green light concentrated, reaching for him. Eric knew, with absolute certainty, that if it touched him, he would become part of this frozen waste forever, a statue of ice and despair.

Summoning every ounce of will, every memory of the biting but honest cold of North Pass, Eric did the only thing his frozen mind could conjure. He fumbled with the heavy, insulated pouch on his belt—not for a weapon, but for his field rations. His fingers, numb and clumsy, ripped open a high-calorie heating pack, the kind that ignited on contact with air. A chemical, human-made warmth flared to life in his palm, a tiny, furious orange star against the endless green.

He hurled it at the creature’s feet.

The reaction was instantaneous and catastrophic. The creature recoiled as if struck by lava, a shriek of shattering crystal piercing Eric’s mind. The green light flared wildly, and the thrumming returned as a pained, discordant roar. The ice itself seemed to writhe. The larger shapes beneath the surface thrashed, sending cracks racing in every direction.

The momentary distraction was all Eric had. He turned and ran, not with any hope of direction, but *away* from the light, *away* from the voice. He plunged back into the welcoming, concealing darkness, the chemical warmth in his hand already dying, the true, ancient cold closing in behind him with a palpable, vengeful intent. He was a mistake, a broken piece of a pact he never knew existed. And now, he was prey.

human: My car was broken into shortly before Christmas.  Some jackass broke a small side window thinking that with my car (which needed transmission work, fixed air conditioning, a new taillight, and two new door handles) was a veritable treasure trove of goodies. Primarily they wanted my new cd player, but since they couldn't pry it out of the dashboard and realized there was mostly a lot of shit in my car, they opted to take my hidden cd visor.    Now I thought that I cataloged every CD that was stolen so that I could moan appropriately when anyone mentioned the artist. Kind of Blue, Giant Steps, Jason Mraz, The Beatles, The Love Below, Ben Folds Five, Cake-- the list could go on and on.  About 30 CDs were taken among them was one CD of the Sinatra Reprise collection.  Just one. So I thought.  I understand what I am about to write is going to make me one of maybe twelve people under the age of thirty.  It's also going to make me sound like an ultra-geek, but I do not care.  I love Frank Sinatra.  That's right, love.  And I'm not talking about the movies (well, those too); I'm talking about the music.  To this day Frank Sinatra is one of only a handful of artists that I liked when I was thirteen that I still like today. The Christmas I was sixteen, I received one of the top ten best gifts ever (right up there with the My Little Pony Paradise Estates).  Great gifts are always something you really want, but never have to ask for. Those things that are unexpected.  And the Frank Sinatra Reprise Collection was one of them.  At the time, I only owned one Frank CD (it was hard then to save up enough cash to get anything and CDs were like two weeks of allowance).  My father picked up on how often he heard me listening to it and gave me four more.  I cannot convey how much I loved them.    Yesterday, I began to burn my CDs into iTunes (which has been long overdue) and realized more than just one of the cds were gone.  All of the cds were gone.  I was crushed.  No more 'My Shadow and Me'.  No more 'I'll Only Miss Her When I Think Of Her.'  No More 'What'll I Do.'  That is unless I want to shell about another $100 for a new set. I felt so violated when my car was broken into and rifled through, but it's nothing compared to the crappy feeling when I realized that some of my prize possessions had been taken.   What really kills me is the thought of them (probably) in a dumpster somewhere. I can't imagine a thief appreciating any good music, especially good music from over fifty years ago.
LLM_1:
...Album, *Rumours*, *The Chronic*, *Illmatic*, and a few mix CDs I’d burned in college that had long since lost their labels—those were the ones I actually cared about. Not because they were rare or valuable, but because each one carried a memory: a road trip, a breakup, a summer job where I played the same disc on repeat until the chorus felt like muscle memory. Losing them wasn’t just about the music—it was like someone had gone through my diary with greasy fingers and ripped out the pages they didn’t understand.

I spent a week after the break-in replaying those albums in my head, trying to reconstruct playlists, wondering if I’d ever feel the same rush hearing “So What” crackle through cheap speakers at 2 a.m. while driving nowhere. I even considered replacing them all digitally, but something about streaming felt like attending a memorial service via Zoom—technically present, emotionally absent. There’s no weight to a playlist. No liner notes smudged with fingerprints, no awkward silence between tracks when the CD skips because you left it in the dashboard cup holder during a heatwave.

Then, out of nowhere, my neighbor Margo knocked on my door holding a Ziploc bag full of CDs. She’d found them behind a dumpster two blocks over, scattered like discarded tarot cards. Most were scratched beyond redemption, but a few—*Kind of Blue*, *Giant Steps*, the Beatles’ white album—were salvageable. She’d recognized my name scrawled on the case of *The Love Album* (a gift from my ex who once swore we’d get married if we ever made it through *Abbey Road* in one sitting). Margo didn’t say much, just handed me the bag and said, “Figured you might want these back, even if they’re ghosts now.”

I sat on my porch that night with a bottle of cheap red and my portable CD player—the kind with the retractable sun shield—and played each one like a ritual. Some skipped. Some hissed like old radios tuned between stations. But hearing Coltrane wail through fractured speakers felt like a small victory. It reminded me that not everything broken is lost. Sometimes damage adds texture. A skip in “Hey Jude” now feels like a hiccup of nostalgia, a physical reminder that this thing survived.

I still haven’t replaced the window. Partly because money’s tight, partly because I like the way the cold air hits my arm when I drive. It keeps me awake. Reminds me I’m moving forward, even if the car rattles like it’s held together by duct tape and hope. And every time I pass a record store, I slow down. Not because I’m looking for replacements, but because I’ve started collecting vinyl now—something harder to steal, easier to love. Last weekend, I bought a used copy of *Blue* by Joni Mitchell. The cover was dented, the first track had a faint pop, and I played it three times in a row.

---

I cared about a handful of CDs: *Rumours*, *The Chronic*, *Illmatic*, and a few unlabeled mix discs I’d burned in college. Not because they were rare, but because each held a memory—a road trip, a breakup, a summer job where I played one album on loop until the chorus lived in my bones. Losing them didn’t just mean losing music. It felt like someone had torn pages from my diary with greasy fingers—erasing what they couldn’t understand.

For a week after the break-in, I replayed those albums in my head. Tried to rebuild playlists. Wondered if I’d ever feel that jolt again—“So What” crackling through cheap speakers at 2 a.m., driving nowhere. I thought about replacing them digitally, but streaming felt like attending a funeral over Zoom: technically present, emotionally hollow. Playlists have no weight. No smudged liner notes. No awkward silence when a CD skips from being left in the cup holder during a heatwave.

Then Margo, my neighbor, showed up with a Ziploc bag full of CDs she’d found behind a dumpster two blocks away—scattered like discarded tarot cards. Most were scratched beyond use, but a few survived: *Kind of Blue*, *Giant Steps*, the Beatles’ white album. She recognized my name scribbled on *The Love Album*—a gift from an ex who once swore we’d get married if we made it through *Abbey Road* in one sitting. Margo didn’t say much. Just handed me the bag. “Figured you might want these back,” she said. “Even if they’re ghosts now.”

That night, I sat on the porch with cheap red wine and my old portable CD player—the kind with the retractable sun shield—and played each one like a ritual. Some skipped. Some hissed like static between radio stations. But hearing Coltrane wail through broken speakers felt like a win. A reminder: not everything damaged is lost. Sometimes, damage adds depth. A skip in “Hey Jude” now feels like a hiccup of nostalgia—proof this thing survived.

I still haven’t fixed the window. Partly because money’s tight. Mostly because I like the cold air hitting my arm when I drive. It keeps me awake. Reminds me I’m moving—even if the car rattles like it’s held together by duct tape and hope.

And every time I pass a record store, I slow down. Not looking to replace what I lost. I’ve started collecting vinyl instead—harder to steal, easier to love. Last weekend, I bought a used copy of Joni Mitchell’s *Blue*. The cover was dented. The first track popped faintly. I played it three times in a row.
