human: Pyrrolidine dithiocarbamate (PDTC) is a low-molecular thiol antioxidant and potent inhibitor of nuclear factor-kappaB (NF-kappaB) activation. It has been shown to attenuate local harmful effects of ischemia/reperfusion (I/R) injury in many organs. In this study, we aimed to study the effect of PDTC on lung reperfusion injury induced by superior mesenteric occlusion.Male Wistar-albino rats randomized into three groups: (1) sham-operated control group (n = 12), laparotomy without I/R injury; (2) intestinal ischemia/reperfusion (I/R) group (n = 12), 60 min of ischemia by superior mesenteric occlusion followed by 2 h of reperfusion; and (3) I/R+PDTC-treated group (n = 12), 100 mg/kg injection of PDTC intravenously, 30 min after the commencement of reperfusion. Evans blue dye was injected to half of rats in all groups before the induction of I/R. We assessed the degree of pulmonary tissue injury biochemically by measuring malondialdehyde (MDA), glutathione (GSH), and nitric oxide (NO) levels, and histopathologically by establishing pulmonary neutrophil sequestration and acute lung injury scoring. Pulmonary edema was evaluated by Evans blue dye extravasation, as well as lung tissue wet/dry weight ratios.Pyrrolidine dithiocarbamate treatment significantly reduced the MDA and NO levels, and increased the GSH levels in the lung parenchyma, biochemically (p < 0.05), and atteneuated the pulmonary parenchymal damage, histopathologically (p < 0.05). However, pulmonary neutrophil sequestration was not affected by postischemic treatment with PDTC (p > 0.05). Pyrrolidine dithiocarbamate administration also significantly alleviated the formation of pulmonary edema, as evidenced by the decreased Evans blue dye extravasation and organ wet/dry weight ratios (p < 0.05).
LLM_1: (2) I/R injury model, and (3) PDTC-treated I/R injury model. After 60 minutes of superior mesenteric artery occlusion, the rats were subjected to 120 minutes of reperfusion. Lung tissues were harvested for histopathological examination, measurement of inflammatory cytokines, and assessment of oxidative stress markers. The severity of lung injury was evaluated using histological scores, while levels of tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α) and interleukin-6 (IL-6) were quantified via enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA). Oxidative stress was assessed by measuring malondialdehyde (MDA) levels and superoxide dismutase (SOD) activity. Our results demonstrated that PDTC administration significantly reduced inflammatory cytokine levels and oxidative stress markers compared to the I/R group. Histological analysis revealed marked improvements in lung architecture and reduced edema in the PDTC-treated group. These findings suggest that PDTC exerts a protective effect against lung reperfusion injury following mesenteric occlusion, likely through its role in inhibiting NF-kappaB activation and reducing oxidative stress. This study highlights the potential therapeutic application of PDTC in mitigating organ damage during I/R events. Further investigations are warranted to elucidate the underlying mechanisms of PDTC’s protective effects and its clinical relevance in surgical settings.

human:
It also wants to promote greater competition between banks, so that customers get a better deal.
"The Commission's aim is to promote effective competition, in which banks compete to serve customers well rather than exploiting lack of customer awareness or poor regulation," the report says.
How will that happen?
The ICB's report puts forward three main ideas to enhance competition.
The first is that much more effort should be put into establishing a large new bank on the UK's High Streets, to compete with the shrinking number of existing ones.
Lloyds has already been told by the European Commission to sell at least 600 branches by November 2013, as the price for being bailed out by the UK government during the banking crisis.
The Vickers report suggests Lloyds, which expanded hugely by taking over HBOS in 2009 in a government inspired rescue takeover, should in fact "substantially enhance" this sell-off.
It wants the government to ensure that the new bank that emerges, based on the 632 branches now being sold by Lloyds, should have at least 6% of the personal current accounts held by UK banks, up from the 4.6% of UK's current accounts that the sell-off would currently involve.
This would create "a strong and effective new challenger", the report says.
What about switching accounts?
Making people and businesses confident about switching their current accounts has long been seen as the key to introducing meaningful competition among High Street banks.
To this end, the Vickers report suggests that by 2013, there should be a new industry-wide account redirection service that would be free to customers.
This would, it says, make the switching of current accounts a smooth process, by redirecting all payments in and out of an old account into a new one, within seven working days.
The service would operate for 13 months for each account switched and should "be seamless for the customer, so that throughout the process they have complete, problem-free use of their banking services and are not inconvenienced by debits or credits going to the wrong account".
It should also come with a guarantee against any losses from mistakes.
And the third big idea?
That the forthcoming Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) be given the explicit job of promoting competition and transparency in the banking industry.
For customers, that would mean being told on annual statements how much potential interest they had foregone by putting money on deposit.
This is the effective charge most people pay for having an account, as they gain little or no interest while their money is on deposit, while the banks lend it to borrowers at a substantial margin.
Other measures for the FCA to consider include forcing banks to supply enough data for price comparison websites to compare the accounts on offer from different banks.
Will this cost me more as a bank customer?
The report suggests the overall costs to the banking industry of the reforms would be between Â£4bn and Â£7bn a year.
That would be made up partly of higher day-to-day operational costs and the higher costs to the banks of funding themselves by borrowing more expensively in the financial markets.
The report says this "would be borne by some combination of banks' shareholders, employees, creditors and borrowers".
However, it doubts that much of this will feed through to High Street customers in the form of higher borrowing charges.
Most of the costs would, in fact, fall on the running of the investment banking businesses.
"Given the international nature of competition in wholesale/investment banking, the degree to which private cost increases could pass through to customers in the UK economy should be relatively small," the report says.
LLM_1:
the creation of a “challenger bank” with sufficient scale, infrastructure, and market presence to genuinely rival the dominant players—Barclays, HSBC, NatWest, and Lloyds itself. The proposed entity would not merely be a rebranded offshoot but a fully independent institution, equipped with its own branding, digital platforms, and customer service operations. Analysts suggest that such a move could inject much-needed dynamism into a retail banking sector where four institutions currently account for over 70% of personal current accounts.

The second recommendation focuses on empowering consumers through greater transparency and data portability. The ICB advocates for a standardized format enabling customers to transfer their transaction history securely between banks, allowing comparison tools to generate personalized recommendations based on actual spending behavior. This "open banking" framework—predating the later regulatory push by several years—aims to dismantle inertia among consumers, who often remain with underperforming banks simply because switching seems complex or risky.

Additionally, the report calls for clearer presentation of fees, interest rates, and service terms in everyday banking products. Drawing parallels with energy bill comparisons, it envisions a future where annual cost summaries are presented in plain language, helping users identify poor-value accounts at a glance. Regulators would have the authority to mandate changes in product design if widespread mis-selling or confusion is detected.

Thirdly, the commission emphasizes reforming the way small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) access banking services. A key proposal is the introduction of a mandatory referral system: if a business loan application is rejected by one bank, the applicant must be offered the option to have their details forwarded to alternative lenders, including non-bank financial institutions and emerging fintech firms. This aims to break down gatekeeping practices and expand credit opportunities beyond traditional channels.

The Treasury has welcomed the report’s findings, with Chancellor George Osborne stating that “competition is the best antidote to complacency.” However, industry responses have been mixed. While some independent banking executives praise the ambition, senior figures within major banks warn that forced divestitures could destabilize financial recovery efforts. Lloyds has acknowledged its obligations but stressed that an expanded branch sale must be managed carefully to avoid job losses and service disruption.

Implementation timelines remain under discussion, though officials expect legislation to begin rolling out within two years. If enacted, these measures could reshape the UK’s banking landscape, fostering a more competitive, transparent, and customer-centric market—precisely the outcome regulators insist is long overdue.

**UK Banking Reform Proposals Aim to Boost Competition and Consumer Power**

A major shake-up of the UK retail banking sector could be on the horizon, following a sweeping set of recommendations designed to challenge the dominance of the country’s largest banks. At the heart of the proposal is the creation of a new, independently operated “challenger bank” with the scale and infrastructure to compete directly with industry giants Barclays, HSBC, NatWest, and Lloyds.

Unlike previous spin-offs or rebranded subsidiaries, this new institution would operate as a fully standalone entity—complete with its own branding, digital platforms, and customer service framework. Analysts believe such a move could introduce much-needed competition into a market where four banks currently control more than 70% of personal current accounts, long criticized for stagnation and lack of innovation.

In a second key recommendation, the Independent Commission on Banking (ICB) has called for greater transparency and data mobility to empower consumers. The report proposes a standardized system allowing customers to securely transfer their transaction history between financial institutions. This early vision of an “open banking” model—predating later regulatory initiatives by several years—would enable comparison tools to offer tailored product suggestions based on real spending patterns, helping users make informed choices and overcome the inertia that often keeps them tied to underperforming accounts.

The ICB also recommends clearer, more accessible disclosure of fees, interest rates, and terms across everyday banking products. Drawing inspiration from energy bill comparisons, the plan envisions annual cost summaries presented in plain language, allowing customers to quickly identify poor-value services. Regulators would be granted authority to intervene and require changes to product design if evidence emerges of widespread consumer confusion or mis-selling.

For small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), the report outlines reforms aimed at improving access to finance. A central measure is the introduction of a mandatory referral system: when a business loan application is declined, the applicant would have the right to request that their information be shared with alternative lenders—including non-bank institutions and fintech companies. The goal is to dismantle entrenched gatekeeping practices and open up credit opportunities beyond traditional banking channels.

The Treasury has endorsed the findings, with Chancellor George Osborne stating, “Competition is the best antidote to complacency.” However, reactions from the banking industry have been divided. While some leaders in the independent banking sector have welcomed the bold vision, senior executives at major institutions have raised concerns that forced divestitures could undermine ongoing financial stability efforts.

Lloyds Banking Group, which would likely be affected by any branch sale requirements, acknowledged its responsibilities but emphasized the need for careful implementation to protect jobs and maintain service quality.

While formal timelines remain under discussion, government officials anticipate that legislation could begin taking effect within two years. If adopted in full, the reforms stand to transform the UK’s banking environment—ushering in a more competitive, transparent, and customer-focused market, a shift regulators say has been overdue for decades.

human: The homeodomain transcription factor, PITX2, is at the apex of a genetic pathway required for corneal development, but the critical effector genes regulated by the PITX2 remain unknown. The purpose of this study was to discover and validate PITX2-dependent mechanisms required for specifying cell lineages and establishing angiogenic privilege within the developing cornea.Microarrays were used to compare gene expression in corneas isolated from temporal Pitx2 knockout embryos and control littermates. Quantitative RT-PCR and immunohistochemistry was used to further validate Tfap2b expression differences in Pitx2 knockout versus control corneas. In situ hybridization and protein immunohistochemistry were used to assay eyes of a Tfap2b allelic series of embryos to identify differentiated cellular lineages in the cornea, blood vessel endothelium, or lymphatic vessel endothelium.We show that PITX2 is required for the expression of Tfap2b, encoding the AP-2β transcription factor, in the neural crest during corneal development. Markers of differentiated corneal epithelium and stroma are expressed in the absence of AP-2β. In contrast, markers of differentiated corneal endothelium are not expressed in the absence of AP-2β. Endomucin+ blood vessels are present throughout the developing corneal stroma in the absence of AP-2β, whereas LYVE1+ lymphatic vessels are not found.

To elucidate the downstream targets of PITIX2 during cornea development and angiogenesis, we employed a combination of bioinformatic and molecular biology approaches. We analyzed the genomic locus of 34 known and predicted effctor genes that were putatively regulated directly or indirectly by PITXI2 binding motifs. Of these, 17 genes exhibited significant enrichment of conserved PITI2-binding sites within their proximal promoter regions, suggesting direct regulation by this transcriptional activator. 

We next validated the regulatory relationships between PITII2 and 5 selected effactor genes using chromatin immunoprecipitation sequencing (ChIP-seq) and luciferase reporter assays. Our results revealed that PITTI2 binds directly to consenved motifs within intronic and promoter elements of these target genes, thereby regulating their expression in both human corncal epithelial cells and mouse embryonic fibroblasts. Furthermore, ectopic expression of selected target gene, VEGFR2 significantly enhanced angiogenetic sprouting in vitro, underscoring the role of PIIXI dependent mechanisms in establishing the angiopgenetic privilege of corneas. In contrast, suppression of target gnee expression using RNA interference resulted in diminished angiogentic response, highlighting the importance of PTITI-dependent regulation in corinal development. These findings collectively suggest that PTIII directly regulates a subset of effcator genes critical for angiogeneic privilege and corlnal vascularization. Future studies will investigate the transcriptiona regulation of additional PTIII2 effacor genes and their role in disease states characterized by corial angiognesis. This work expands our understanding of genetic pathways controlling corina development an angiogneic privilage. Further investigation into PTIX-dependent mechansims may uncover new therapeutic avenues for treating correal vascular diseases.

Notably, this observation suggested direct regulatory interactions between Pitix2 activators and the corresponding target mRNAs.

To validate the molecular relationships, chromosomal immunolocalization sequencing and luminescence-based reporter gene assays were employed to examine the Pitii2-dependent regulatory mechanisms governing the expression levels of five selected effecter genes in human epithelia and murine fibrosarcoma cells. Biochemical analyses revealed Pitiii2 direct binding to evolutionary consaved motifs localized within the introns and promoters of its target effecters, thus controlling their transcription in these cell types. Conversely, silencing of Pititi2-target effecting expression through RNA-mediated interference led to diminished vascular response. Collectively, these results underscored the significance of direct Pititt regulation on a distinct subset effect of genes responsible for corining angiopathic privilege. human:
This paper proposes a new MCMC transition kernel. This kernel is parameterized by neural networks and is optimized through an objective maximizing the proposal entropy. Specifically, the authors use a combination of a flow model and non-volume preserving flow in [Dinh et al., 2016] as the neural network parameterized kernel. Then they use the objective in [Titsias & Dellaportas, 2019] which maximizes the proposal entropy to optimize the kernel. The proposed method is tested on synthetic datasets, Bayesian logistic regression and a deep energy-based model.

The problem of improving the exploration efficiency of MCMC kernel is important. The proposed method is well-motivated. As far as I understand, the proposed method appears to be technically sound. 

However, I have the following concerns about the paper.

-	The connection and the difference to previous work are not very clear. If I understand it correctly, the proposed method seems a combination of L2HMC and [Titsias & Dellaportas, 2019] with some slight modification (a flow model) since the naïve combination did not work well (as stated in Section 4). I think it would improve the clarity a lot if the authors explain more clearly how the proposed method differs from previous work. 
-	Since the use of a flow model is the main difference compared to the naïve combination of two previous methods, the authors should explain more about this choice. Currently, it is not clear why this helps and there is no explanation on why the naïve combination fails. 
-	The proposed method seems to use more neural networks (e.g. an additional network R to handle gradient) than previous neural network MCMC. I wonder how the method performs if considering the cost. For example, the authors may instead show ESS per second on the experiments in Section 5.1. Though the authors mentioned the difficulty of computing ESS per second in the paper, I’m not entirely convinced. As the experiments in Section 5.1 are all very small-scale, is it really necessary to use GPUs? 

-	The baselines vary from experiments to experiments for no reason. For example, the authors compare their method to L2HMC on ill-conditioned Gaussian and strongly correlated Gaussian, to Neutra on Funnel distribution, and to MALA on EBM. I think this experiment design needs explanation. Also, there is no empirical comparison to [Titsias & Dellaportas, 2019] which is closely related to the proposed method.

Some minor comments:

-	A.1 intends to show the benefit of using gradient information. But Variant 2 also uses gradient. What is the point of showing it? 
-	It is not clear to me how to interpret the empirical results in Section 5.2. For example, how does Figure 3 show that the proposed method needs less sampling steps? 
-	The color of points in figure 1 is hard to read.
LLM_1:
- **Novelty and Contribution**: The integration of neural networks into MCMC transition kernels is a notable advancement, as it leverages the strengths of deep learning to enhance sampling efficiency. The proposed method represents a significant contribution to the field, especially given the challenges associated with optimizing MCMC methods in high-dimensional spaces.

- **Methodology**: The use of flow models alongside non-volume preserving flows is an interesting choice that could potentially improve the adaptability of the kernel. However, the authors should provide a clearer explanation of how these elements interact within the optimization process, especially for readers who may not be familiar with the technical specifics of flow-based models.

- **Experimental Validation**: The experiments conducted on synthetic datasets and practical models such as Bayesian logistic regression are well-chosen to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed kernel. However, additional benchmarks against state-of-the-art MCMC methods would strengthen the empirical evaluation. Including comparisons with established algorithms like Hamiltonian Monte Carlo or other modern adaptive MCMC techniques might provide a more comprehensive understanding of the proposed method's performance.

- **Clarity and Presentation**: The paper is generally well-structured, but some sections could benefit from clearer explanations. For instance, the rationale behind the choice of objective function for optimizing proposal entropy may not be immediately evident to all readers. A more detailed discussion of the theoretical underpinnings of this choice would enhance the paper's accessibility.

- **Discussion of Results**: While the results are promising, the authors should elaborate on the implications of their findings. A discussion regarding the trade-offs between exploration and exploitation in the context of the proposed kernel would add depth to the analysis. Additionally, any limitations observed during the experiments should be acknowledged, as this would present a balanced view of the method’s applicability.

- **Future Work**: The paper briefly touches on future work, but a more detailed outline of potential extensions could be beneficial. Suggestions for exploring additional types of neural architectures or investigating different entropy-based objectives could inspire further research in this domain.

- **Conclusion**: Overall, the paper presents a compelling approach to enhancing MCMC sampling through a novel neural network parameterized kernel. The work is timely and addresses a critical area in Bayesian inference. With minor revisions and additional clarifications as suggested, this paper has the potential to make a significant impact on the field.

It’s not about the grilled burgers, though Ian does make a mean one. It’s about the story that gets written in real-time, the one you’ll be gasping through laughter to retell for months.

Think about it. A perfectly executed, GPS-guided trip yields zero anecdotes. “We arrived.” Snore. But a journey involving a confused old man puffing on a cigarette like a chimney, who may or may not have been a retired sea captain judging by his thousand-yard stare, while we’re banging on the window like escaped fugitives? That’s pure, unscripted comedy gold. It’s the shared, slightly unhinged memory that cements friendship. Karen and I now have a shorthand—just yelling “CLAUSS!” or “OLD GUY” will send us into fits.

It’s a reminder that life’s best moments often live in the messy detours, not the pristine highways. The wrong turns force you to look up, to interact with the world in its weird, wonderful randomness. You become participants, not just passengers. So here’s to more ill-advised U-turns, more frantic waving, and more bewildered strangers who become legendary side characters in our personal road trip saga. The destination is just the excuse; the glorious, chaotic journey is the whole point. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I need to go study a map… or maybe not.

In April it emerged that a council-owned car park was set to be sold and used for older people's accommodation.
Last year the Shoreline Housing Partnership, which owned six nearby high rise blocks, made a decision to demolish the buildings, moving hundreds of people out.
Shoreline now say the new development is "not financially feasible".
Designs for 46 one and two-bedroom apartments were presented to residents for consultation in January.
Tony Bramley, of Shoreline, said: "We thoroughly explored this proposal [for the so-called Nelson Court] commissioning local architects to draw up designs, looking at prospective locations and carrying out consultation with affected high rise residents.
"While we've always been clear that funding and a location would need to be sought, we genuinely hoped that we would be able to make it work but it's simply not financially feasible and we've been unable to gain the level of funding required to support the scheme something that is particularly challenging at a time when public subsidy is so tight.
"This may come as a disappointment to some residents but we remain committed to helping them find accommodation that meets their needs and preferences."
Shoreline said it had appointed a firm to lead on proposals for the regeneration of the cleared site and immediate surrounding area.
LLM_1:
viable at this time due to rising construction costs and funding shortfalls,” a spokesperson confirmed. The proposed 72-unit senior living complex, which was expected to include on-site care facilities and communal spaces, has been placed on indefinite hold. Local residents expressed disappointment, noting that the project was seen as a crucial step in addressing the growing demand for age-appropriate housing in the area.

Community leaders had previously praised the initiative as a sustainable solution to both urban regeneration and social care needs, particularly after the demolition of the high-rise flats left a gap in available housing. Many former residents were relocated outside the borough, severing long-standing community ties.

Councillor Elaine Marsh, speaking at a recent town hall meeting, acknowledged the setback but urged patience. “We’re working closely with Shoreline and other housing agencies to explore alternative funding models, including public-private partnerships and grant applications through national ageing initiatives.”

Meanwhile, advocacy groups warn that delays could exacerbate the housing crisis for older adults, especially those with mobility issues or chronic health conditions. “Every month this stalls, vulnerable people are left in unsuitable homes,” said Mark Tranter of AgeAction East. “We need action, not announcements.”

Shoreline has committed to releasing a revised strategy by early autumn, though no guarantees have been made about reinstating the car park development.

Shoreline plans to release a revised strategy by early autumn, though there is no guarantee the car park redevelopment will proceed.

human:
## Originality 
As far as I know, coarse-to-fine pipeline is very common in human pose and shape estimation area, and GCN is well investigated for human body or hand prediction. A refinement stage could certainly reduce the reconstruction error. So, the overall novelty of this paper seems low. 
However, it is the first time for me to see an encoder-decoder GCN structure, and the authors prove its ability in their ablation study.

## Quality 
This paper is easy to read except some spelling mistake (e.g. L.144, feed -> fed). They do a lot of experiments to show the effectiveness of each part of their pipeline. Their quantitative results achieve the best.
LLM_1:
- The proposed architecture integrates a refinement module that leverages residual graph message passing to enhance joint-level detail in later stages. While this design choice aligns with standard practices, the specific formulation of edge weighting based on geodesic distances on the mesh surface offers a nuanced improvement over isotropic neighborhood aggregation. This geometric sensitivity could contribute meaningfully to preserving anatomical plausibility during fine-grained prediction.

- One notable strength lies in the use of multi-scale feature fusion across refinement stages. By maintaining access to intermediate backbone features and incorporating them adaptively into graph updates, the model mitigates potential information loss common in cascaded frameworks. This mechanism appears effective, particularly in challenging occlusion scenarios where low-level cues are critical for disambiguation.

- The ablation studies provide reasonable justification for key design decisions, including the number of refinement steps and the inclusion of cross-stage feature integration. However, a more detailed analysis comparing alternative graph topologies—such as fully connected vs. kinematically constrained graphs—would strengthen the empirical foundation of the claims.

- Evaluation is conducted on widely recognized benchmarks (e.g., Human3.6M, MPI-INF-3DHP), which enhances the credibility of the reported results. Performance gains over prior work are modest but consistent, particularly in per-joint error metrics. These improvements, while incremental, may still be valuable in applications requiring high localization precision.

- A limitation worth noting is the reliance on 2D pose estimators as input. Although this is standard in the field, it introduces potential error propagation that is not thoroughly analyzed. A sensitivity study quantifying the impact of 2D detection inaccuracies on final 3D output would provide deeper insight into real-world robustness.

- The method assumes a fixed body topology throughout the refinement process, which limits its applicability to dynamic changes in clothing or significant body deformations due to interaction. Exploring adaptive mesh connectivity or learned local topology modulation could be promising directions for future work.

- Computational efficiency is not explicitly discussed, despite the sequential nature of the coarse-to-fine pipeline. Given that GCN-based models can become bottlenecks in real-time systems, reporting inference latency or offering optimization strategies would improve practical utility.

- The paper would benefit from visualizations beyond qualitative mesh overlays. For instance, heatmaps showing confidence calibration, error distribution across body parts, or attention weights in the refinement stages could offer richer interpretation of model behavior.

- Lastly, while the technical contribution leans toward engineering rather than theoretical innovation, the thoughtful combination of existing components into a cohesive and effective pipeline represents a valid form of advancement in applied settings. The clarity of implementation details also facilitates reproducibility, which is commendable.
LLM_2:
- The proposed architecture incorporates a refinement module based on residual graph message passing, which enhances joint-level detail in later stages. While the overall design follows established coarse-to-fine paradigms, the use of geodesic distance-based edge weighting introduces a geometrically informed inductive bias that improves upon isotropic neighborhood aggregation. This modification likely contributes to better preservation of anatomical plausibility during fine-grained 3D pose estimation.

- A key strength is the multi-scale feature fusion mechanism, which adaptively integrates intermediate backbone features into successive graph updates. This helps preserve low-level spatial cues and mitigates information degradation common in cascaded architectures, particularly under challenging conditions such as occlusion where fine details are critical for accurate reconstruction.

- The ablation studies reasonably justify major design choices, including the number of refinement iterations and the inclusion of cross-stage feature integration. However, a more comprehensive evaluation of alternative graph topologies—such as comparing kinematically constrained graphs with fully connected or learned variants—would strengthen the empirical analysis and provide deeper insight into architectural sensitivity.

- Evaluation is performed on standard benchmarks (Human3.6M, MPI-INF-3DHP), lending credibility to the results. Performance improvements over prior methods are modest but consistent, especially in per-joint error metrics. While incremental, these gains may be meaningful in applications requiring high localization accuracy.

- The method depends on 2D pose estimates as input—a common practice, yet one that risks propagating detection errors into the 3D prediction. The paper does not analyze this dependency; a sensitivity study quantifying how 2D estimation inaccuracies affect final output would enhance understanding of the model’s robustness in real-world scenarios.

- The assumption of fixed body topology limits generalization to cases involving dynamic clothing changes or significant non-rigid deformations due to interaction. Future work could explore adaptive mesh connectivity or learned local topology modulation to improve flexibility under such conditions.

- Computational efficiency is not discussed, despite the sequential nature of the refinement pipeline. Given the potential latency of GCN-based models in real-time settings, reporting inference speed or suggesting optimization strategies would improve the method’s practical relevance.

- Beyond qualitative mesh visualizations, additional interpretability tools—such as heatmaps of prediction confidence, per-joint error distributions, or attention weights across refinement stages—would provide richer insights into model behavior and decision-making dynamics.

- Although the contribution is primarily engineering-oriented rather than theoretically novel, the effective integration of existing components into a coherent, well-structured pipeline constitutes a valid advancement in applied 3D human pose estimation. The clear presentation of implementation details further supports reproducibility, which is a notable strength.

And so, as the light filtered down through the autumn leaves and danced upon the ground, we set about our task. My grandfather had offered to show me how to start a fire by rubbing two sticks together. I was excited to see how this wondrous feat might be accomplished. I was pretty young at the time. 
 
 After we had chosen what we considered to be the two most perfect sticks to use in this venture, he sent me off to gather kindling for our fire. I returned a short time later, my arms full of twigs. After we had set up our tepee of sticks and wadded newspaper, he set out to accomplish what to me, was nothing short of magical. As he vigorously rubbed the two sticks together, there suddenly came a burst of flames from beneath them! I was completely astounded! 
 
 As he touched the flame to the paper and kindling, our fire sprang to life. All that night, I sat by the crackling fire with the two sticks, trying to replicate the miracle of fire. I could never get the same result he did, though I noted that the sticks *did* feel a bit warm. 
 
 Years passed and I grew older. One summer night, my grandfather and I were sitting on the front steps watching the fireflies. We sat mostly in silence, listening to the night sounds. He suddenly asked me, out of the blue, if I remembered how he had shown me how to light a fire by rubbing two sticks together. Of course I did! I could see his mischievous smile even in the near darkness. 
 
 “ Just remember, ” he said, “ if you ever expect to light a fire by rubbing two sticks together, you had better make darn sure one of them is a match. ”
LLM_1:
As we stood in the forest, the air crisp with autumn's chill, my grandfather's eyes sparkled with a knowing glint. He handed me one of our chosen sticks, its length about the width of my palm, with one end slightly pointed. "This is the drill," he explained, his voice low and soothing. His own stick, slightly thicker, he held in his calloused hand. With a gentle smile, I took my position beside him, our sticks almost touching, forming a small triangle.

"Remember, it's all about friction," my grandmother's voice chimed in from behind us. She stood on a nearby log, her eyes shining with interest. Her silver hair was tied back in an effortless knot, a hint of a smile on her lips. We exchanged a look, both of us knowing that this was her way of saying, 'I'll be watching.' My father had taught her this skill, she told me once, during their own camping trips when I wasn't born yet.

With the sticks in place, Grandfather began to demonstrate the movement – a smooth, back-and-forth motion, applying gentle pressure. Sweat broke out on his forehead as he persisted, but his movements remained fluid. As I mimicked his actions, watching the stick in my hand closely, tiny sparks started to appear between the friction points. Our sticks creaked and groaned, producing an almost musical sound. Grandmother walked closer, observing my technique with an encouraging nod.

The air around us grew charged with anticipation, each of these small moments suspended in time, much like the leaves suspended above us, glowing in vibrant hues. Suddenly, in that fleeting instant, one spark caught my eye. A tiny flame burst forth, dancing wildly before being gently coaxed into a steady, golden flame. Exhilaration coursed through me as my eyes met Grandpa's triumphant grin. For that one magical moment, everything else faded into nothingness – the trees, leaves, even the world beyond our tiny clearing. There, standing with my loved ones, amidst the crackling fire we'd co-created, was pure, unadulterated joy. And as I stood there, taking it all in, time seemed to stand still, frozen in its most enchanting moment.
LLM_2:
In the heart of autumn, where the rustling leaves danced in every hue, we found ourselves amidst a serene forest glade. My grandfather, eyes aglow with the wisdom of years, handed over a slender stick – its delicate length nestled comfortably within the span of one palm. 'This,' he said, as the breeze carried the gentle lilt of his words, "is the spark that ignites the flame." The stick he chose for himself, sturdy and dependable, rested within his rugged hand, an extension of himself. I accepted my place beside his, sticks poised like a tiny, symmetrical triangle, awaiting the magic that would unfold.

A soft, encouraging voice drifted from the nearby outcropping of logs, carrying the words of wisdom from my other grandmother. Silver threads danced through her tied-back hair, hinting at the secret smile she wore on the edge of her features. It was a subtle sign, like an unspoken promise, that she would be observing from her vantage point. This skill had been passed down to her from our father, who had first taught it to them on camping excursions long before I was born.

As Granddad began the demonstration, guiding the smooth motion of friction, sweat broke on brow and stick cleft in perfect harmony. Following his example, mimicking the delicate dance, sparks erupted into being, suspended like diamonds between our moving sticks. Each gentle touch produced a melodious cackle, echoing through the stillness. Nodding encouragement, Grandma drew closer to examine the intricate dance of sticks and friction.

Time itself hung suspended, locked within a moment like autumn leaves – suspended high above, vibrant and full of life. In the blink of an eye, then, all the universe seemed reduced to this tiny sphere of joy, fire, love. One spark stood out, catching the eye like gold on fire. Then, swift as a breath, another burst, this time steady and unyielding. Joy, pure and untainted, couraged through every cell. That moment stood frozen, no longer than a heartbeat – yet, for those watching, forever a memory that could be revisited. Standing beside those I loved, cradled in warmth of fire and love, there was only, only the present – an enchantment locked forever. Time itself stood still.

A door opens and light floods down the stairs into a windowless concrete room. It smells like sweat and mildew, probably because it hasn ’ t been opened in weeks. Two men walk down the stairs, both of them carrying several large bottles of bleach. They walked towards the back of the room where there was a large, blood stained tile pit. 
 
 “ You sure we should be doing this in the day time? ” one man said. 
 
 “ I dunno, but I ’ m not gon na argue with Derek. ” The other replied as he opened one of his bottles. He began pouring the bleach all over the floor and splashing the walls. “ Looks like they haven ’ t been here yet, but they nicked Mickey and Jeff yesterday. Only a matter of time before one of those numbnuts flips, and this place will be crawling with cops. ” 
 
 “ Yeah, I guess I just don ’ t like being on clean up. We should hurry. ” 
 
 “ Agreed. ” 
 
 The two men poured bleach over all the surfaces in the room, starting on the far wall and working back towards the open door. They worked silently for a few minutes before the first man spoke up again. 
 
 “ You know what gets me most? What are we going to do with the dogs? ” 
 
 “ What do you mean? They all got taken in the raid. ” 
 
 “ Not all of them. Derek had a pregnant bitch remember? She had the litter last week up at his sister ’ s house. Five puppies. Cops don ’ t know nothing ‘ bout those dogs. ” 
 
 “ Well, shit. I dunno. What can we do? Not like we can bring them here. And we certainly can ’ t fight train them at Derek ’ s sister ’ s house. ” 
 
 “ That ’ s true. Mighty huge shame though. ” 
 
 Both men went back to cleanup. The empty bottles of bleach were piling up near the front door. They were starting to speed up as the stench of cleaner choked at their throats. 
 
 “ What if we didn ’ t fight them? ” 
 
 “ What do you mean? ” 
 
 “ I dunno. We don ’ t need to fight them right? Police won ’ t care as long as we don ’ t fight them. ” 
 
 “ Well what do you suggest? ” 
 
 “ I ’ m not sure. Long as we can bet on it I really don ’ t care. We could race them. ” 
 
 “ Naw, dog racing is still illegal. ” 
 
 The two men finished up. They collected the empty bottles and left the room. As they were locking up the concrete room the first man turned to the second and said “ Well, there ’ s no law that says we can ’ t make the dogs play basketball… ”
LLM_1:
like someone had a party in here,” he muttered, the acrid chemical scent already clawing at the back of his throat.

His partner, a wiry man named Leo, didn’t answer. He was staring at a dark, ragged smear near the drain grate. It wasn’t just blood; something fibrous and pale was caught in the metal teeth. He nudged it with his boot, then wished he hadn’t. A low, guttural sound echoed from the far corner, where the light from the stairs didn’t quite reach.

Both men froze. The bottle in Leo’s hand stopped pouring, the bleach pooling silently on the tile.

“The hell was that?” the first man, Paul, whispered. His knuckles were white around his own bottle.

“Rat,” Leo said, too quickly. “Big one. Keep pouring.”

But the sound came again—a wet, rhythmic scrape, like something heavy being dragged. It was followed by a soft, shuddering breath. There was no mistaking it for an animal.

Paul took a step back toward the stairs. “Derek didn’t say nothing about… about anyone being down here.”

Before Leo could reply, a figure detached itself from the shadows. It was a man, or what was left of one, propped against the wall. One side of his face was a ruin of dried blood and swelling, but his one visible eye was open, tracking them with a terrifying lucidity. His clothes were dark with old stains, and his left leg was bent at a sickening angle.

“He’s alive,” Paul breathed, horror diluting his fear.

The man in the corner tried to speak, but only a cracked whisper emerged. He lifted a trembling hand, not in threat, but in a desperate, wordless plea.

Leo looked from the ruined man to the bleach in his hand, then to the stairs where Derek’s authority loomed. The instructions had been explicit: *Scour it. Make it like nothing ever happened.* The unspoken part now hung in the chemical-laden air.

Paul dropped his bottle. It cracked on the tile, sending a river of bleach toward the drain. “We can’t. We gotta get him out.”

“And tell Derek what?” Leo hissed, but his own resolve was crumbling. The professional cleanup had just become a moral crime scene. The bleach wasn’t for stains anymore; it was for evidence. For a man.

The injured man’s eye fixed on Leo, and in that moment, the simple, brutal order from above shattered against the raw reality on the floor. The clean, antiseptic smell of the bleach now seemed like the worst kind of lie, masking a truth that was still, agonizingly, breathing.

Leo didn’t answer. He was fixed on a dark, ragged streak near the drain—not just blood, but something pale and fibrous caught in the grate. He nudged it with the toe of his boot, then stiffened. A low, guttural noise echoed from the far corner, where the light from the stairs frayed into shadow.

Both men went still. The bottle in Leo’s hand stopped pouring, bleach pooling soundlessly on the tile.

“What was that?” Paul whispered, his knuckles bone-white around his own container.

“Rat,” Leo said, too fast. “A big one. Keep going.”

But the sound came again—a wet, dragging scrape, like weight over rough concrete. Then a soft, shuddering breath. This was no animal.

Paul retreated a step toward the stairs. “Derek didn’t say… didn’t say anyone was down here.”

Before Leo could answer, a shape peeled away from the darkness. A man—or what remained of one—propped against the wall. Half his face was a mask of dried blood and swollen flesh, but one eye was open, clear and terribly aware, following their every move. His clothes were stiff with old stains, one leg bent at a nauseating angle.

“He’s alive,” Paul breathed, horror seeping into his fear.

The man in the corner tried to speak. Only a fractured whisper escaped. He raised a trembling hand—not a threat, but a silent, desperate plea.

Leo’s gaze jumped from the broken man to the bleach in his grip, then up toward the stairs where Derek’s word was law. The orders had been clear: *Scour it clean. Make it like nothing was ever here.* The unspoken part now hung thick in the chemical air.

Paul’s bottle slipped from his fingers. It cracked against the tile, bleach rushing toward the drain like a hurried secret. “We can’t do this. We have to get him out.”

“And say what to Derek?” Leo hissed, but his certainty was already crumbling. This wasn’t a cleanup job anymore—it was a crime, laid bare on the cold floor. The bleach wasn’t for stains now. It was for evidence. For a man.

The injured man’s eye held Leo’s, and in that raw, silent moment, the clean, brutal order from above shattered against the living truth before them. The sharp scent of bleach no longer smelled sterile—it smelled like a lie, thin and desperate, trying to cover something that wouldn’t stop breathing.

Phil Verster, who has been in the post since May 2015, is to become managing director of the East West rail project between Oxford and Cambridge.
The 53-year-old has been facing intense pressure in recent months, because of the rail service's failure to meet targets on punctuality and reliability.
The identity of his successor will be announced in the coming days.
Earlier this week, Mr Verster sparked a row at Holyrood over who would pay for free travel for season ticket holders as compensation for ScotRail train delays.
ScotRail Alliance was formed as a partnership involving Abellio ScotRail and Network Rail, intended to improve performance through cooperation between the rail operator and the rail infrastructure company.
Mr Verster said: "Over the last two years I have worked with my team to launch the ScotRail Alliance, delivering hundreds of commitments and laying the ground for the exciting new train fleets that will start to arrive later this year.
"The opportunity to build on these same principles with the creation of a new business such as East West Rail is great for me and my family, and I wish the ScotRail Alliance team all the best for the future."
Mark Carne, the chief executive of Network Rail, said: "Phil has done a great job setting up the ScotRail Alliance and overseeing the delivery of one of the largest programmes of rail modernisation in Scotland since Victorian times.
"I am delighted that a leader of Phil's calibre will be heading up the new East West rail project.
"We have agreed a replacement to succeed Phil and will be making an announcement shortly."
During Mr Verster's time in charge, Abellio ScotRail has faced calls for it to be stripped of the Â£7bn 10-year franchise.
Transport Scotland ordered ScotRail to put in place an improvement plan after 2016 saw its performance slip below contracted standards.
Mr Verster has previously been Network Rail's managing director for London North East and deputy chief executive officer at Irish Rail.
At the time of his appointment, Dutch contract holder Abellio said his track record on improvement and safety made him an "ideal candidate".

human: We investigated whether dipyridamole and various calcium channel blockers are inhibitors and/or substrates of breast cancer resistance protein (BCRP).The effect of dipyridamole and the calcium channel blockers on mitoxantrone efflux by BCRP-overexpressing human embryonic kidney (HEK) cells was determined by flow cytometry. The ability of some of these compounds to reverse BCRP-mediated mitoxantrone resistance was measured by cytotoxicity assays. Transport studies were performed using radiolabeled compounds.Dipyridamole, nicardipine, nitrendipine, and nimodipine effectively inhibited BCRP-mediated mitoxantrone efflux; however, bepridil, diltiazem, and verapamil had no significant effect. Nifedipine is a much weaker BCRP inhibitor compared with other dihydropyridines tested. Nicardipine and dipyridamole were the most potent BCRP inhibitors among the compounds tested with IC50 values of 4.8 +/- 1.3 and 6.4 +/- 0.9 microM, respectively. Nicardipine and dipyridamole also effectively reversed BCRP-mediated mitoxantrone resistance in HEK cells. [3H]Nitrendipine was found not to be transported by BCRP. However, the transport of [3H]dipyridamole by BCRP was observed in both HEK and Madin-Darby canine kidney cells stably expressing the transporter, and this transport was completely abolished by fumitremorgin C, a known BCRP inhibitor.

In addition, we investigated the impact of verapamil, nifedipine, diltiazem, nicardipin, felodipne, isradipinel and nimodin on BCRY mediated efflusion of Mitozantron. Islamic State group: The full story
IS seized control of Falluja in January 2014. The government launched an operation to retake it in May.
At least 1,800 militants were killed in the operation, the Iraqi army said.
If the capture of the Golan neighbourhood marks the end of the battle for Falluja, then this is a significant moment.
The IS militants have lost a city of much symbolic and strategic importance just an hour's drive from Baghdad.
But this victory came at a high cost for Falluja's people. They have faced extraordinary danger and hardship during the fight for the city. And securing a military triumph was only part of the challenge that the government faced in Falluja.
If there is to be long-term calm and stability there, the city's Sunni Muslims will need to be made to feel that the predominantly Shia authorities in Baghdad are listening to them, and taking into account their security, economic and other concerns.
Tens of thousands of people fled the fighting and some - including elderly people, women and children - remain camped out in the open in the summer heat, the Norwegian Refugee Council said.
Falluja, a major city in the western Anbar Province, was the first Iraqi city to fall to IS.
The jihadist group also managed to seize large swathes of territory in northern and western Iraq and eastern Syria in 2014, establishing a self-declared "Islamic Caliphate" in the territories it captured.
In recent weeks, the militants have lost control over several territories in both countries.

**Iraqi Forces Declare Falluja Liberated Amid Ongoing Humanitarian Concerns**

FALLUJA, Iraq — "This victory belongs to the Iraqi people, achieved by the courage of our troops and the steadfast support of our citizens," declared Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi in a solemn address from the shattered streets of Falluja, where smoke still curled from rubble-strewn neighborhoods devastated by weeks of relentless fighting.

The recapture of Falluja marks a significant turning point in Iraq’s campaign against the Islamic State (IS), delivering a major strategic blow to the extremist group. Once a stronghold and critical supply node for IS operations across Anbar province, the city has now been reclaimed by Iraqi security forces, aided by U.S.-led coalition airstrikes and allied Sunni tribal fighters.

In the hours following the announcement, civilians began emerging from basements and hidden shelters—pale, emaciated, and deeply scarred by months of oppressive rule. Under IS control, residents faced public executions, forced enlistment, and draconian restrictions on movement. Now, humanitarian organizations are racing to deliver emergency aid, distributing food, clean water, and medical supplies to thousands in need.

Engineering units have begun the dangerous task of clearing improvised explosive devices (IEDs) and booby traps planted throughout homes, mosques, and roadways—remnants of a brutal occupation designed to delay liberation and inflict maximum casualties.

Military analysts say the success in Falluja could serve as a crucial momentum builder ahead of the anticipated offensive on Mosul, Iraq’s second-largest city, where more than 100,000 civilians remain trapped under IS control. Elite Counter-Terrorism Service units are already advancing on multiple fronts to the north, encountering fierce resistance and the complex challenges of urban combat.

The international community has welcomed the development. The United Nations urged immediate and unfettered humanitarian access to affected areas, warning of an escalating crisis if relief efforts are delayed. “Victory must be measured not only in territory regained but in lives restored,” said a UN spokesperson. “True success will require reconciliation, reconstruction, and justice for all.”

As darkness fell over the war-ravaged city, Iraqi soldiers raised the national flag atop the ruins of the provincial government complex—an image broadcast nationwide, symbolizing resilience and hard-won progress.

Yet officials stress that while the fall of Falluja is a pivotal milestone, the broader campaign to eradicate IS from Iraq continues. “The mission is not over,” one military commander said. “But today, we have struck a decisive blow.”

human:
This paper studies the problem of differentially private data generator. Inspired by the general GAN framework and the PATE mechanism, the authors propose a new differentially private training algorithm for data generator. The problem of training data generator with privacy guarantee considered in this paper is very interesting, and the proposed algorithm looks novel. However, there are lots of unclear statements in the current paper, and I cannot tell whether the proposed algorithm is indeed better than previous methods. Following are my major concerns:
1. It is unclear what are the loss functions used in equation (1) and (2). Please define k when introducing equation (2).
2. The training framework introduced in section 3.1 is different from the traditional GAN framework, and thus my concern is that whether this framework will give us good generated samples. Because the performance of GAN has been proved in both theory and practice. The authors should at least empirically show the performance of the proposed framework in the nonprivate setting.
3. There is no introduction of the $(\epsilon,\delta)$-differential privacy before introducing the Definition 1.
4. There is no definition of Renyi differential privacy, so the statement of Theorem 2 is unclear. In addition, what is data-dependent Renyi differential privacy?
5. The privacy guarantee of Algorithm 2 is not very clear. Because there are lots of parameters in Algorithm 1 and 2 which may affect the privacy guarantee, and Theorem 3 does not state such requirements. For example, how to choose $\sigma_1,\sigma_2$? In Theorem 7, there are some constraints on different parameters, will them be satisfied by your algorithm?
6. How will the number of teacher models affect the privacy guarantee?
7. Why you choose random projection matrix with variance $1/k$, and what is the projection dimension for different algorithms?
8. In Table 1, the results of non private GAN are different from the results of non private GAN reported in PATE-GAN paper. Since the baseline results are much better in the current than the results reported in the PATE-GAN paper, it seems to me that the improvements of the proposed method comes from the stronger baseline.

Other comments:
1. $\lambda>1$ in Theorem 3.
2. Algorithm 2 should be moved to main context.
3. The last sentence in section 3.2 is not convincing.
4. Typo "differnet" in the caption of Table 1.

**Structured Point-by-Point Review Feedback**

**Major Concerns and Suggestions:**

1\. **Loss Function Clarity**: The paper lacks explicit details on how the custom loss functions (e.g., reconstruction loss, privacy loss) are defined and integrated into their proposed G-DP-GAN algorithm. A clear and concise explanation of these loss components would strengthen the paper's technical foundation.

2\.  **Training Procedure**: I found the description of their iterative training procedure to be somewhat ambiguous. For instance, it's unclear how they balance the trade-off between privacy and generator performance in each iteration. Providing a step-by-step training process and a more detailed explanation would help readers better comprehend the algorithm's inner workings.

3\.   **Evaluation Metrics**: While the author mentions the use of various metrics (accuracy, F1-score, etc.) to evaluate their algorithm, a comprehensive comparison with existing state-of-the-art methods is necessary to demonstrate the superiority of G- DP-Gan. Including more evaluation metrics or a thorough discussion of why their chosen metrics are most relevant would improve the credibility of this research.

4\.    **Implementation Details**: A more explicit description or code snippet illustrating the practical implementation of key components (such as the differential privacy mechanism) would facilitate easier understanding and reproduction of results by interested researchers.

5\.     **Theoretical Analysis**: Although the introduction highlights the importance of differential private algorithms, I felt that theoretical analysis could be further explored to solidify the advantages of proposed method and establish its soundness in real-world applications.

6\.      **Conclusion and Future Work**: In the final section, discussing future research directions and potential applications, such as scalability, practical deployment, would not only enhance the reader's understanding but also provide a clearer roadmap for future studies in differential privately trained data generators. Furthermore, summarizing the key findings and implications of current research would provide an effective conclusion to the discussion.

7\.       **Minor Typographical Errors**: Lastly, upon a close reading, several minor typographical errors were observed throughout the manuscript, which should ideally be corrected to ensure a polished and professional final product.

By addressing these concerns and suggestions, you can further refine the clarity, coherence, completeness, of your research, making it a valuable contribution to this area. I look forward to reading the revised manuscript. Please address these points and provide further clarification on any areas of concern. Thank you for your attention to these matters. 

**Recommendation for Future Research**:

This research area, with its increasing importance and applications in data-driven decision-making and AI systems, promises exciting avenues for exploration. Future work could investigate the application of other privacy mechanisms or novel architectures that might improve upon the performance of generator models while maintaining differential-private guarantees. Additionally, exploring the integration of privacy-preserving techniques with other machine learning paradigms (like reinforcement learning) could reveal new insights into more robust and efficient algorithms. Investigating the challenges and opportunities of deploying such algorithms in practical settings will also be a worthwhile direction. With further refinements and explorations, this line of research holds significant promise for advancing our understanding of and capabilities in differentiable private machine-learning systems. **Please provide the corrected manuscript for further review.**

human: The surgical procedures used until now to rebuild the conjunctiva in patients affected by ocular cicatricial pemphigoid (OCP) have not demonstrated appreciable anatomical and functional success. This study reports the postoperative clinical and cytological outcomes of a human amniotic membrane transplantation (AMT) to rebuild the conjunctiva in a case of late stage OCP.We present a 75-year-old woman with a severe form of pemphigoid with entropion, trichiasis, symblepharon and blunting of the fornices, who underwent excision of the scarred and inflamed tissue covering the ocular surface and AMT.Our data show an improvement of the ocular surface condition, with reacquired fornix depth, reduced inflammation and presence of goblet cells at each follow-up.
LLM_1: This study evaluates a novel autologous cultivated conjunctival epithelial sheet transplantation technique using fibrin carriers in 15 patients with advanced OCP. Preoperative immunosuppressive therapy was standardized, and postoperative success was assessed via anatomical restoration, visual acuity improvement, symptom reduction, and absence of recurrence over a 24-month follow-up. Immunohistochemical analysis confirmed phenotypic stability of transplanted cells. Results demonstrated sustained epithelial integrity in 87% of cases, significant reduction in fibrosis, and improved tear film parameters. This approach shows promise for durable ocular surface reconstruction in autoimmune conjunctival disorders.
LLM_2: This study evaluates a novel autologous cultivated conjunctival epithelial sheet transplantation technique using fibrin carriers in 15 patients with advanced ocular cicatricial pemphigoid (OCP). Standardized preoperative immunosuppressive therapy was administered, and outcomes were assessed over a 24-month follow-up based on anatomical restoration, visual acuity, symptom relief, and recurrence. Immunohistochemical analysis confirmed phenotypic stability of the transplanted epithelium. Sustained epithelial integrity was achieved in 87% of cases, with significant reductions in fibrosis and improved tear film parameters. The findings indicate that this technique offers a promising approach for durable ocular surface reconstruction in autoimmune conjunctival disorders.

human: Dog behavior is the internally coordinated responses (actions or inactions) of the domestic dog (individuals or groups) to internal and/or external stimuli. As the oldest domesticated species, with estimates ranging from 9,000–30,000 years BCE, the minds of dogs inevitably have been shaped by millennia of contact with humans. As a result of this physical and social evolution, dogs, more than any other species, have acquired the ability to understand and communicate with humans and they are uniquely attuned to our behaviors. Behavioral scientists have uncovered a surprising set of social-cognitive abilities in the otherwise humble domestic dog. These abilities are not possessed by the dog's closest canine relatives nor by other highly intelligent mammals such as great apes. Rather, these skills parallel some of the social-cognitive skills of human children.

to be over 14,000 years, dogs exhibit a remarkable range of behaviors shaped by their evolutionary history, social structures, and interactions with humans. These behaviors can be categorized into various types, such as instinctual, learned, and social behaviors. 

Instinctual behaviors are innate responses that have developed over generations, including hunting, herding, and protective instincts. Learned behaviors arise from experiences and training, often influenced by the environment and human guidance. Social behaviors encompass communication methods, such as barking, body language, and facial expressions, which facilitate interactions both within canine groups and between dogs and humans.

Understanding these behaviors is essential for effective training, animal welfare, and fostering positive relationships between dogs and their owners. Researchers continue to study dog behavior to gain insights into canine cognition and the emotional lives of these animals, further enhancing our ability to nurture and support them in domestic settings.
LLM_2:
Dogs have been our companions for over 14,000 years, a testament to their adaptability and deep-rooted connection with humans. This extensive history has led to a remarkable range of behaviors shaped by their evolutionary journey, complex social structures, and diverse interactions with people. These behaviors can be categorized into several types, including instinctual, learned, and social behaviors, each playing a critical role in how dogs navigate their environment and engage with us.

**Instinctual behaviors** are innate responses that have developed over generations through natural selection. For instance, breeds like the Greyhound display exceptional hunting instincts, honed for speed and agility to chase down prey. Similarly, herding breeds such as Border Collies exhibit strong herding instincts, often seen guiding sheep or cattle with impressive precision. Protective instincts are also prevalent, as many dogs instinctively defend their territory and loved ones, showcasing behaviors like barking or standing their ground when they sense a potential threat. These instinctual behaviors not only reflect the dogs' ancestry but also highlight their roles in human society, such as working dogs in various fields like search and rescue or law enforcement.

**Learned behaviors**, on the other hand, arise from individual experiences and training, significantly influenced by the environment and guidance provided by humans. For example, a dog may learn to sit on command through positive reinforcement techniques, such as treats or praise, which not only fosters good manners but also strengthens the bond between the dog and its owner. Moreover, dogs can adapt to various situations, learning to navigate their surroundings by observing and imitating human actions. This adaptability is particularly evident in therapy and service dogs, which undergo specialized training to assist individuals with disabilities, showcasing their ability to learn and respond to complex cues.

**Social behaviors** encompass the myriad ways dogs communicate with one another and with humans. They employ a range of communication methods, such as barking, growling, and whining, which can signify everything from excitement and playfulness to fear or distress. Body language plays an equally critical role; for instance, a wagging tail can indicate happiness, while raised hackles may suggest aggression or anxiety. Facial expressions, too, contribute to their social interactions, with dogs often using their eyes and mouth to convey emotions. Understanding these social cues is vital for fostering harmonious relationships between dogs and their owners, as it allows for better communication and reduces the likelihood of misunderstandings.

Understanding these behaviors is essential for effective training, promoting animal welfare, and nurturing positive relationships between dogs and their owners. By comprehensively recognizing the nuances of dog behavior, we can create environments that cater to their needs and enhance their well-being. Researchers continue to delve into the complexities of dog behavior, seeking insights into canine cognition and the emotional lives of these remarkable animals. This ongoing exploration not only enriches our understanding of dogs but also enhances our ability to nurture and support them in domestic settings, fostering a deeper, more empathetic bond that benefits both dogs and their human companions. With each new discovery, we are reminded of the profound connection we share with these animals and the importance of respecting and understanding their unique perspectives.

human: This study was designed to test the hypothesis that normal thyroid function is associated with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) in euthyroid general subjects.A total of 739 euthyroid subjects were enrolled in this cross-sectional study. Using ultrasound, a diagnosis of NAFLD was made in subjects without a history of excessive alcohol consumption or liver diseases. Fasting serum samples were collected for determining thyroid function [thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), free thyroxine (FT4), and free triiodothyronine (FT3) levels] and other biochemical parameters.Among the enrolled subjects, 196 (26.5%) satisfied the diagnostic criteria for NAFLD. Subjects with NAFLD had significantly higher TSH levels and lower FT4 levels than those without NAFLD (p < 0.01 for both). NAFLD prevalence increased gradually with increasing quartiles of TSH levels and decreasing quartiles of FT4 levels. After adjustment for gender and age, TSH levels were found to correlate positively with body mass index (BMI), waist circumference (WC), and LDL-cholesterol levels (p < 0.05 for all) and negatively with HDL-cholesterol levels (p < 0.01). FT4 levels correlated negatively with both BMI and WC (p < 0.05 for both). Multiple logistic regression analysis showed that TSH and FT4 levels were independent risk factors for NAFLD [odds ratio (OR): 2.21, 95% confidence interval (CI): 1.21-4.02, p = 0.01, for TSH levels; OR: 0.39, 95% CI: 0.17-0.87, p = 0.02, for FT4 levels].
LLM_1:
function and were evaluated for their thyroid hormone levels. Biochemical analyses included serum free thyroxine (FT4), free triiodothyronine (FT3), and thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) measurements. The presence of NAFLD was correlated with thyroid function parameters, adjusting for confounding variables such as age, sex, body mass index (BMI), and metabolic syndrome components.

Results indicated that participants diagnosed with NAFLD exhibited significantly altered thyroid hormone profiles compared to those without liver disease. Specifically, lower FT4 levels were observed in the NAFLD cohort, while TSH levels remained within normal ranges. Multivariate regression analyses demonstrated that lower FT4 was independently associated with a higher prevalence of NAFLD, suggesting a potential link between thyroid hormone dysfunction and hepatic lipid accumulation.

These findings underscore the importance of considering thyroid function in the evaluation of patients with NAFLD, even in the absence of overt thyroid disease. Further longitudinal studies are warranted to elucidate the causal relationship and underlying mechanisms connecting thyroid hormones and liver metabolism, which may pave the way for novel therapeutic strategies targeting both conditions.
LLM_2:
---

**Abstract**

This study investigates the relationship between thyroid hormone levels and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). Biochemical analyses included measurements of serum free thyroxine (FT4), free triiodothyronine (FT3), and thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH). The association between NAFLD and thyroid function parameters was evaluated after adjusting for confounding variables, including age, sex, body mass index (BMI), and components of metabolic syndrome.

The results revealed that participants diagnosed with NAFLD exhibited significantly altered thyroid hormone profiles compared to those without liver disease. Specifically, the NAFLD cohort demonstrated lower FT4 levels, while TSH levels remained within normal ranges. Multivariate regression analyses indicated that lower FT4 levels were independently associated with a higher prevalence of NAFLD, suggesting a potential link between thyroid hormone dysfunction and hepatic lipid accumulation.

These findings highlight the importance of assessing thyroid function in patients with NAFLD, even in the absence of overt thyroid disease. Further longitudinal studies are necessary to elucidate the causal relationship and underlying mechanisms connecting thyroid hormones and liver metabolism, which may facilitate the development of novel therapeutic strategies targeting both conditions.

human:
This position is mind numbing... I have stood guard over the Gates of Hell for 12 centuries now, but I wish to do so no longer. Everyday, hundreds of thousands of souls pass my watch without hindrance, but I was bred to be a warrior, not some guard hound... This is disgraceful. 
 
 The Great War has long since been finished in the eyes of the Makers. Each of them have been lax in their governing and it disgusts me to the core. They have assumed their `` rightful'' positions in the Universe, each reigning over their realms and leaving the others alone. `` Out of sight, out of mind'' is a human proverb, but we *demons* have our own, `` the war is n't over until the realms run red''. 
 
 When each human soul passes my garrison, they never look at me. Their heads are down, sunken into their shoulders, walking along like cattle, contemplating their vile lives of gluttony and revulsion... such weak creatures. Never have a seen a soul proud to be in this domain. Never have I seen a soul proud of ones exploits. 
 
 My vigilant eyes scan the endless horde of feeble mortals... they all look the same. 
 
 `` Hey, big guy!'' 
 
 I look down. The earthly mans head barley reaches my chest plate. My sword is as tall as he. 
 
 `` Are you listening to me?!'' 
 
 Wait... He is speaking to me, looking at me... 
 
 `` I need to find a weapon on sorts, do you have a dagger or another falchion on you? I'm not going to get very far if I can not protect myself.'' 
 
 `` Human'', my voice booms and he shutters in awe. `` You have entered the realm of the dead. Follow your brethren and you will find your eternal place among the forsaken.'' It is amazing he is talking at all, let alone looking at me... Never have I met a mortal with such an inquisitive aura. 
 
 He looks up at me with a curious stare. `` Right. Well if you're not going to help me'' he gawks at my sword `` may I use this?'' 
 
 `` Foolish mortal, you would never be able to lift my weapon. This sword was forged from the core of your world. You do not weigh half as much as it. But you are a peculiar critter, so I will grant you an attempt.'' 
 
 His eyes narrow, he believes me wrong. He grasps the hilt, his knuckles turning white in the anticipation of weight to come. My sword wildly lifts off the ground. He clutches the massive sword in one hand, glaring at me in distaste. 
 
 `` You know you should have more faith in me, I've never died in an MMORPG, like ever. If you want to join my party you can. A big guy like you might come in handy down the road.'' 
 
 *What the fuck* 
 
 How is he holding my sword up, let alone steady, and with a single hand! `` Who are you mortal?'' 
 
 `` I'm Otis, but you can call me by my gamer tag, Omega.'' He tosses the sword from hand to hand like a small pebble. 
 
 `` This is inconceivable! Otis, where do you hale from?.... Wait. Did you say gamer tag?'' He can not possibly believe himself currently residing in a video game. 
 
 `` Yeah, gamer tag.'' He does not look at my anymore. His watchful eyes now peer beyond the Gates and into the Abyss. `` Do you want to join my party or what? I want to get this started slaying already!'' 
 
 This is impossible. He does not know he is in hell, unlike every other soul, yet he is producing unimaginable feats before my very eyes... And he said he wants to start slaying already...? He has a blood lust, I can feel it deep inside his being. This may be my chance to leave this post... To bring my own onslaught of rage upon the realms... 
 
 `` You do not know what lies ahead of you Otis. Many demons like myself lie in wait...'' 
 
 `` Call me Omega, I told you already.'' 
 
 He interrupted me... He has grit... `` Alright Omega. I will join your crusade through Hell.'' I swipe my sword back from his grip, difficult as it was... `` We will find you another.'' I reach for my waist, grabber a blade and toss it to him. `` You will need my guidance through the treacherous passages...'' 
 
 `` Yeah, I get it.'' He beings to walk away from me. `` Tell me along the way.'' 
 
 I look at him in wonderment. I like him.
