LLM_2:
In the 1940s, a new wave of architects began re-evaluating modernist principles, leading to the emergence of postmodernism in the 1960s. Initially rooted in skepticism toward the rigid doctrines of early 20th-century modernism—particularly the functionalist dogma and aesthetic minimalism championed by figures like Le Corbusier and Mies van der Rohe—this intellectual shift gained momentum as younger designers questioned whether architecture should serve only utilitarian ends or could also communicate meaning, memory, and cultural identity. Reacting against the austerity and uniformity of the International Style, whose glass-and-steel towers often appeared indifferent to their surroundings, figures such as Robert Venturi and Denise Scott Brown called for a more humane and layered approach to design. Drawing inspiration from everyday urban landscapes—including Las Vegas strip developments, suburban storefronts, and vernacular buildings—they argued that architectural richness could be found not just in purity of form, but in the messy vitality of popular culture.

Their influential writings, including *Complexity and Contradiction in Architecture* (1966), challenged the notion that “less is more,” a mantra closely associated with modernist reductionism. Instead, Venturi famously countered with “less is a bore,” advocating for an architecture that embraced ambiguity, hybridity, and even paradox. He and Scott Brown emphasized the value of duality—of buildings being both functional and symbolic, innovative and traditional—encouraging architects to reintroduce ornament, color, historical allusion, and wit into their work. This was not mere pastiche, but a thoughtful engagement with history; for example, their 1978 addition to the Guild House in Philadelphia incorporated a gilded television antenna atop an otherwise modest senior housing block, subtly commenting on media, aging, and domestic life.

This shift marked a broader cultural turn toward pluralism and eclecticism in the built environment—one that mirrored developments in literature, art, and philosophy during the late 20th century. As society became increasingly diverse and globalized, so too did architectural expression, welcoming multiple voices, styles, and narratives. Postmodernism opened the door for regional interpretations, critical regionalism, and later movements that valued context, symbolism, and user experience. In doing so, it laid the conceptual groundwork for contemporary practices that seek to balance innovation with cultural resonance, reminding us that buildings do not merely shelter people—they tell stories.

Power demand is expected to fall and then surge.
As the moon obscures much of the sun, the electricity generated by solar panels is expected to drop by up to 75%.
But National Grid believes the overall impact will be "manageable".
Much more electricity is generated from solar panels now than than during the last eclipse in 1999.
It is the first time that an eclipse in Europe is expected to have an impact on the operation of electricity grids.
Germany faces the biggest test, with about 39GW (gigawatts) of installed solar capacity.
The UK has 5GW of solar, the equivalent to the power output from about eight to 10 gas fired power stations.
But while the amount of electricity generated from solar will fall during eclipse, National Grid is not expecting any major impact.
"This loss of solar is entirely manageable," said a National Grid spokesperson. "We have a range of tools in place to manage any effects of the eclipse and balance the network."
The eclipse will start at around 08:45 on Friday and is due to last for a couple of hours.
It should be visible in much of the UK.
But with cloudy weather now expected, National Grid has revised down its forecast for the likely impact to energy supplies.
At that time of day, about 1,000MW (megawatts) of power would be generated from solar (1,000MW is equal to 1GW).
That is expected to fall by around 850MW.
Normally, that shortfall would need to be made up by bringing other power plants on to the system.
But based on an analysis of what happened during the previous eclipse in 1999, National Grid expects many people across Britain to stop their normal activities to observe the phenomenon.
That is expected to cause a fall in power demand on the network of about 1,100MW.
After the peak of the eclipse at 09:30, power demand is then expected to surge by 950MW as people resume normal activities.
The impact elsewhere in Europe could be more profound.
Europe's total solar power output could drop by as much as 34GW if it's a clear day, according to the organisation that represents network operators.
That's the equivalent of the output of around 80 gas-fired power stations gradually fading out of the European system as the eclipse happens, then fading back in again.
The European Network Transmission System Operators for Electricity has warned that the risk of an incident such as a power cut can't be completely ruled out.
Half of the total impact is expected in Germany. Other major users of solar power including Italy (19.7GW) and Spain (6.7GW) are expected to face challenges too.
It says the main challenge will be balancing the network in real time without causing blackouts or overloads.
The UK won't see a solar eclipse on this scale until 2026.
How to watch the eclipse safely
Why don't we see an eclipse every month?
Solar power overall provides some 1.5% of the UK's total annual power output.
But Leonie Greene of the Solar Trade Association believes the eclipse should not be a cause for concern.
"At this time of year, in the morning, the impact of the eclipse on solar output will be particularly small," she says.
"The impact of the eclipse on solar will be known by grid managers and it will pose no problem to the power supply.
"Far more challenging is the surge in power demand after the eclipse as everyone goes indoors for a cup of tea."

In the UK, the situation is similar, with energy officials emphasizing the importance of grid flexibility. human:
This paper builds on Kipf et al. (2018)’s Neural Relational Inference. In particular, this work introduces a latent variable model which treats the interactions (i.e. relations) between different agents as dynamic and time-varying. As in NRI, the interaction variable between any two agents is conditioned on the history of those agents’ states. An agent’s future state is conditioned on its history of states as well as its interaction variables with other agents.

The results from DYARI are interesting but I am concerned about the intricacies of setting the “inference period” to be aligned with the “dynamic period.” I would have expected that choosing a smaller inference period (e.g. half the dynamic period) should lead to little to no loss in performance. The authors ascribe the observed loss in performance to “the extra uncertainty introduced by estimating more latent variables.” I’m not totally convinced. 

Physical systems like springs have an inherent temporal invariance which you don’t seem to be exploiting. Did you consider (a) processing timesteps in a moving window of size T (i.e. z^{ij}_t is conditioned only on the last T observations) or (b) using a recurrent encoder to process observations sequentially, rather than process all timesteps at once with the PSPNet encoder? That might help with the inference challenge you're facing.

More questions and requests for clarification:
- What if the inference period is out of sync with the dynamic period (e.g. 3 steps versus 5 steps)? Does the model still perform reasonably?
- Why not model relations as continuous latents (setting aside the fact that NRI used discrete variables)? That way you can model negative interaction (e.g. competition), zero interaction, as well as the magnitude of interaction.
- I don’t understand Figure 8 at all. Consider the two blue players who stay on the leftmost side of the basketball court. They have a dotted blue line between them in all the “coordination” plots and a dotted red line between them in all the “competition” plots. Could you please explain what's going on? I would expect only one relation to be on at any time step.
- In Table 6, you show average pooling leads to higher accuracy but also a higher MSE. Shouldn't you have a lower MSE with a higher accuracy?
- Could you please add error bars for your reported scores over independent runs?
- What value of Beta did you use for your loss? What was the effect of varying this hyperparameter?

Minor:
- In equation 2, I assume the density p(x^(i)_{t+1} | x^(i)_{< t}, z^{ij}_t) was meant to be conditioned on N-1 latents not just a single j? In fact, j is undefined in the equation at that point. 
- Figure 2 shows the hidden interaction nodes z^{ij}_t are not conditioned on any other nodes. That is not true from equation 2: each z^{ij}_t seems conditioned on agent i and j’s past trajectories.
- Could you please use x_{\leq t} instead of x_{< t} to denote states up to and including time t?
LLM_1:
- **Choice of Inference Period**: The relationship between the inference period and dynamic period is indeed critical. While the authors suggest that a smaller inference period could enhance the model’s responsiveness to changes in agent interactions, the underlying mechanics of how these periods interact need clearer exposition. Specifically, empirical results or theoretical grounding that demonstrate the effects of varying inference periods on performance metrics would bolster the argument. A sensitivity analysis could be beneficial to illustrate how the model behaves under different configurations.

- **Clarity of the Latent Variable Model**: The introduction of a latent variable model to represent dynamic interactions is a compelling innovation. However, the paper would benefit from a more detailed explanation of how these latent variables are learned and the implications of their dynamics. For instance, are there specific assumptions made about the distributions of these variables? Highlighting the learning process and any challenges encountered could provide valuable insights for future research.

- **Evaluation Metrics**: The evaluation metrics used to assess DYARI's performance appear to be standard, yet there is a lack of discussion concerning the appropriateness of these metrics in capturing the nuances of dynamic interactions. It would be advantageous to include additional metrics that reflect the model's ability to generalize across varied interaction patterns, particularly in real-world scenarios.

- **Comparison with Baselines**: The paper presents interesting results; however, a more thorough comparison with existing methods in dynamic relational inference is needed. This includes not only quantitative results but also qualitative insights that illustrate where DYARI outperforms or struggles relative to these baselines. Such a discussion would provide context for the contributions of this work and highlight the uniqueness of the proposed approach.

- **Potential Applications and Implications**: The authors briefly mention potential applications of DYARI, but a more thorough exploration of these implications would enhance the paper's appeal. Discussing specific domains where dynamic relational inference could be transformative could help position the work within broader research trajectories. Examples might include social network analysis, multi-agent systems, or collaborative robotics.

- **Model Interpretability**: Another aspect that warrants attention is the interpretability of the model. As the complexity of the model increases, so does the challenge of understanding the learned representations and their implications for agent interactions. Providing strategies or methods for interpreting the model’s predictions would be a valuable addition, particularly as interpretability becomes increasingly crucial in machine learning applications.

- **Future Work Directions**: The conclusion section touches on potential future directions, but it could be expanded. Suggestions for extending the work could include exploring the implications of incorporating additional modalities or learning from sparse data situations. Outlining challenges that remain in the field would not only enhance the paper's contribution but also guide future researchers towards impactful questions.

- **Technical Details**: Lastly, while the technical depth of the paper is commendable, some sections may benefit from additional clarity. For instance, the mathematical formulations related to the model dynamics could be elaborated on to ensure accessibility for readers with varying levels of expertise. Providing intuitive explanations or visual aids could make the complex concepts more digestible.

Overall, while DYARI presents a significant advancement in the field of dynamic relational inference, addressing the points outlined above could substantially strengthen the paper and its contributions to ongoing research.

human:
This paper develops new stability bounds for SGD. The main difference from the existing studies is that they consider stability bounds for normalized loss functions where the parameters are normalized to have a norm of $1$. This paper considers both convex and nonconvex cases. For the convex case, the authors develop uniform stability bounds and high-probability bounds. For the nonconvex case, the authors develop on-average stability bounds for neural networks. Experimental results are also given.

Comments:
1. The motivation should be further clarified. In particular, it is not quite clear to me the advantage of considering normalized loss as compared to the standard loss. At least I can not see the advantages from the theoretical results.

2. In Thm 1, the authors assume that the norm of the initial weight is larger than the summation of step sizes. I think this is a very strong assumption and can be violated if we run sufficient number of iterations. Furthermore, it seems that the argument is incremental. The analysis heavily uses the existing stability bounds in Hardt 2016. It seems that the authors do not introduce new techniques. The stability bounds grows as a linear function of the batch size. This dependency on the batch size is not desirable since it means that the generalization would decrease by a large amount if we increase the batch size.

3. In the non-convex case, the authors consider RELU neural networks and assume the smoothness of loss functions. However, RELU networks are not smooth. Therefore, the smoothness assumption in the theoretical results is violated.

4. In Thm 4, the authors assume a growing norm assumption: the norm of layer-wise weights are non-decreasing after some iterations. This is a very strong assumption and can be easily violated in practice. Although the authors give some examples to show this can happen, I still believe it is far from true in general.

5. The stability bound in Thm 4 depends on $1/\|w\|$. If we encounter weights with very small norms, the bound would be very large. Furthermore, both the stability bound and the generalization bound involves $\epsilon$, which is not decreasing w.r.t. either $T$ or $n$. This shows that the result is not converging which is a basic requirement in statistical learning theory.
LLM_1:
**Detailed Review and Feedback**

Overall, this paper makes a significant contribution to the field of stochastic gradient descent (SGD) by developing new bounds on stability for both normalized and unnormalized loss function cases, including both the theoretical analysis and experimental validation. However, upon closer examination, I would like to provide the author with some suggestions for improvement to further strengthen the paper.

1\. **Motivation and Context**: While the introduction does a good job of explaining the importance of stability in SGD, it would be beneficial to delve deeper into why normalized functions are particularly relevant. Are there any real-world applications or scenarios where normalized parameters have been observed to be particularly useful or advantageous? Providing concrete examples or use cases would help illustrate the practical implications of this work.

2\.  **Convex Case**: The uniform and probabilistic stability bound derivations for the normalized convex loss are quite impressive, but I'd like the discussion on their implications to extend further. Can these bounds be used to inform the selection of learning rates or other hyperparameters, potentially leading to improved convergence rates? Additionally, while the high probability bounds are an important result, could the derivation process be clarified with more detail, perhaps in an appendix, to facilitate better understanding for readers without extensive background in optimization?

3\. Non-Convax Case: The on average stability result is very useful, as neural network stability can be tricky to evaluate. To make the result more applicable, have you considered deriving bounds that take into account the structure of real neural architectures, such as depth, width, etc.? music starts—vintage reel-to-reel jazz, the kind my grandmother used to play—though the building’s been dead for decades. no power, no people, just echoes with teeth.

human: An atypical orphan nuclear receptor small heterodimer partner (SHP) is known to be regulated by AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK). Both of them inhibit TGF-β and Smad signalling and exhibit antifibrotic activity in the liver. However, little is known about the protective effects of SHP and AMPK against hepatitis c virus (HCV)-induced hepatic fibrosis.Levels of SHP, p-AMPK and fibrotic markers in HCV-infected human liver and in Huh-7.5 cells infected with HCV genotype 2a (JFH-1) were investigated. The effect of adenovirus-mediated overexpression of SHP (Ad-SHP) and AMPK activation via metformin and 5-amino-1-b-D-ribofuranosyl-imidazole-4-carboxamide (AICAR) on fibrotic gene expression was evaluated in HCV-infected cells. Finally, we examined the effect of Ad-SHP and AMPK activators on invasion and activation of LX2 human HSCs induced by conditioned media from HCV-infected hepatocyte (CM).In HCV-infected human livers and Huh-7.5 cells infected with HCV, SHP mRNA and protein levels were diminished compared with controls, whereas profibrotic factors were increased. Pharmacological AMPK activation recovered SHP expression, and Ad-SHP inhibited HCV-induced fibrotic gene expression. This finding was accompanied by inhibition of HCV-stimulated nuclear factor-kappa B, an inducer of TGF-β. Moreover, CytoSelect invasion assay revealed that enhanced activity and invasiveness of hepatic stellate cells induced by CM.
LLM_1: fibrosis. This study investigated the molecular interplay between SHP and AMPK in HCV-infected hepatocytes and its impact on fibrogenic pathways. We demonstrate that HCV infection downregulates both SHP expression and AMPK phosphorylation in Huh7.5 cells. Pharmacological activation of AMPK by AICAR not only restored its own activity but also significantly upregulated SHP at the transcriptional level. Conversely, siRNA-mediated knockdown of SHP attenuated the suppressive effects of AMPK activation on HCV-induced expression of fibrogenic markers, including α-SMA, collagen I, and TIMP-1. Mechanistically, co-immunoprecipitation and luciferase reporter assays revealed that AMPK-enhanced SHP physically interacts with Smad3 and represses its transcriptional activity on the *COL1A1* promoter. Furthermore, in a murine model of liver fibrosis induced by HCV core protein overexpression, combined treatment with an AMPK agonist and adenoviral SHP delivery synergistically attenuated hepatic stellate cell activation and collagen deposition more effectively than either intervention alone. These findings elucidate a novel cooperative axis wherein AMPK potentiates SHP function to disrupt Smad3-mediated profibrotic signaling, highlighting the therapeutic potential of targeting this pathway to mitigate HCV-associated hepatic fibrogenesis.

HCV infection reduced SHP expression and AMPK phosphorylation in Huh7.5 cells. Pharmacological AMPK activation with AICAR restored AMPK activity and increased SHP transcription. Conversely, SHP knockdown diminished the inhibitory effects of AMPK activation on HCV-induced expression of fibrogenic markers (α-SMA, collagen I, TIMP-1). Mechanistically, AMPK-enhanced SHP physically interacted with Smad3 and repressed its transcriptional activity on the *COL1A1* promoter. In a murine liver fibrosis model with HCV core protein overexpression, combined AMPK agonist and adenoviral SHP delivery synergistically reduced hepatic stellate cell activation and collagen deposition more effectively than either treatment alone. These results identify a cooperative AMPK-SHP axis that suppresses Smad3-mediated profibrotic signaling, suggesting a therapeutic strategy for HCV-related hepatic fibrosis.

They recorded their best result in Wales in 30 years, taking 11 out of 40 seats.
Among them was Gower, which was won by just 27 seats by the former detective Byron Davies, after more than a century in the hands of a succession of Labour MPs.
Jeremy Corbyn should have some fond memories as well.
His extraordinary rise in the summer from rank outsider to Labour leader was a reflection of the party's membership in Wales, as elsewhere.
The subsequent in-fighting in the party after Corbyn's victory could prove a real problem for Welsh Labour as it looks to hold on to power at the assembly next year.
In the meantime, the current Labour Welsh government completed its final full year.
And if there was an issue which dominated in Cardiff Bay, it was once again the state of the NHS.
Opposition parties maintained the pressure on waiting lists and the decision not to protect health spending between 2011 and 2013.
Labour ministers responded by pointing out that all was not rosy in the NHS in England and referring to its direct action such as putting Betsi Cadwaladr University Health Board into special measures.
It was a relatively quiet political year for education.  Although minister Huw Lewis suggested that Welsh GCSE results would overtake England, it failed to materialise as the results in Wales matched the previous year.
Public Services Minister Leighton Andrews failed to get agreement from opposition parties for council re-organisation, which largely recreates the structure that existed in the 1970s and 80s with eight or nine large councils.
Instead, he has ploughed on with legislation to pave the way for the next Welsh government to dramatically reduce the existing 22 councils soon after taking charge, but the big question remains unanswered: can there be political agreement?
David Cameron and Nick Clegg visited the Millennium Stadium for what was called the St David's Day agreement to devolve more powers over energy, transport and elections.
Labour insisted there had been no agreement, and remained cool to much that had been proposed.
This turned into hostility over Tory plans to simplify the constitutional settlement when the First Minister Carwyn Jones accused Welsh Secretary Stephen Crabb of putting devolution into reverse.
The other major constitutional development was the announcement from the Chancellor that partial control of income tax could be devolved without the need for a referendum.
Elsewhere, the Welsh government's plans for an M4 relief road around Newport put internal strain on what is normally a disciplined party.
Labour AM Jenny Rathbone criticised the proposals and was then sacked as chair of a committee at the assembly.
She responded by saying there was an unhealthy culture at the top of the Welsh government which did not allow for rigorous debate.
Her successor on the committee, fellow Labour AM Mick Antoniw, disagreed, saying he had often been critical and had "not woken up in the morning with a horse's head in my bed".
The parties in Wales won't have to deal with horses' heads next year, but there are plenty of challenges nevertheless.
Plaid have yet to take advantage of the increased profile of its leader Leanne Wood during the general election leaders' debates, although it helped her win the accolade of Welsh Politician of the Year.
The Lib Dems have to rebuild after a devastating 2015 and UKIP are gearing up for a campaign which could see them with a handful of AMs for the first time.

As the Welsh Government navigated its last year in office, healthcare concerns continued to cast a long shadow over the Assembly. Despite efforts to address the issue, waiting times for patients remained a persistent problem, with many constituents expressing frustration at delays in receiving medical treatment. According to recent statistics, over 50,000 patients were left waiting for more complex procedures, such as hip and knee replacements, for longer than the recommended timeframe.

Critics argue that this is a direct consequence of chronic underfunding of NHS services in Welsh hospitals, exacerbated by a lack of strategic planning from successive governments. Moreover, experts warn that unless the situation is urgently addressed, Wales risks falling behind other UK nations in terms of healthcare quality and patient outcomes.

Meanwhile, opposition parties have seized on this issue to mount a sustained attack on Labour's record in power. "The Welsh NHS is at breaking point," declared Plaid Cymru's health spokesperson, "and it's Labour that's been in charge for far too long. Their failure to deliver a comprehensive plan for the future of our healthcare system is nothing short of shameful."

With the upcoming Assembly elections set to take place next May, both the incumbent Labour administration and their opponents are acutely aware of how the healthcare debate will shape the campaign narrative. As one insider noted, this year's contest will be as much about the choices facing Welsh voters on issues like healthcare and education as about personalities or party politics. What is certain is that voters will expect more from their elected representatives – and that includes a clear and convincing strategy for revitalizing Wales' healthcare services. Only time will tell if the Labour party can rise to this challenge, but for now, they face stiff opposition from all corners of Welsh politics on what is arguably the most pressing issue of them all. 

In an effort to regain control of this narrative, Labour has announced plans to implement a new raft of reforms aimed at speeding up treatment times and increasing the number of medical procedures available to patients. But whether this move will prove enough to stem the tide of criticism remains to be seen. One thing is clear, however: the stakes are high, not just for Labour, whose grip on power hangs in balance,  but also for Wales as a whole – as the country looks on, anxiously, to see which direction the debate on its future will take. With the eyes of Wales fixed firmly on Cardiff, only time can tell which path the people will ultimately choose.

Welsh Healthcare Crisis Deepens Ahead of Assembly Elections

The outgoing Welsh Labour government is facing mounting pressure over its handling of a persisting healthcare crisis. Waiting times have left over half a century's worth of patients waiting longer for complex treatments than recommended. Critics point to chronic NHS under-funding and a failure in strategic leadership as major contributing factors.

With elections looming in May next year, all parties are aware that healthcare will dominate the narrative – a reflection of voters' expectations for their representatives to provide a viable plan to revitalize Wales's healthcare. Labour is attempting to turn the tables by unveiling new reforms to accelerate treatment and boost medical procedure numbers.

However, it remains uncertain whether these measures will suffice to quell the growing criticism. Wales is watching anxieties grow as Labour clings to power and its people await the outcome of an election that could reshape the nation's future. Ultimately, voters must decide which way forward to choose.

There have been 20 investigations over child deaths since 2007, though not all were known to social services.
Children's minister Edward Timpson said former health minister, Lord Norman Warner, will be the new commissioner.
The appointment follows a report handed to ministers last month.
Under the plans announced by the Department for Education (DfE), the local authority will still retain control of its children's services.
Between 2007 and November 2013 there were 20 serious case reviews in Birmingham, following the deaths of youngsters like Khyra Ishaq in 2008 and Keanu Williams, in 2011.
A peer review in February suggested improvements were being made in the department and a Â£10m investment plan was announced by the council in December.
Mr Timpson said however, he remained very concerned about the safety of children in Birmingham.
He said an independent panel of experts would also be set up to "challenge and support" the city council.
Council leader Sir Albert Bore said he welcomed the recommendations and the report set out a "compelling account of the reasons for, and the lengthy history of shortcomings".
"In doing so, it also highlights the significant challenges that come from the scale of deprivation facing communities in Birmingham," he said.
Commenting on his appointment, Lord Warner said vulnerable children in Birmingham deserved "to receive the care and protection that they can rely on when the responsible adult has failed them".
He said he would work with the city council to put in place the "immediate improvements needed".
The commissioner is expected to work alongside but independently of the council, supported directly by the DfE.
Labour peer Lord Warner was a health minister from 2005-2007 and Parliamentary Under-Secretary in the Department of Health from 2003-05.
Birmingham City Council is currently the subject of an Ofsted inspection, expected to be published in May.
The council's director of people, Peter Hay, said the authority "fully expect[s] to remain inadequate" according to the findings of the inspection, but the report had given it greater clarity on how to make improvements.
"This time, we face this inadequate judgement with the clarity given by this report about what is going to be different and how we make change and improvement stick," he said.
Mr Hay added the report suggested "low-risk" measures to aid the "fragile" recovery.
"Given the prolonged history of failure and the fact there are green shoots of a recovery, albeit a frail one, now is not the time for high-risk options," he said.
Cabinet member for Children and Family Services, Brigid Jones, said the report was "comprehensive, accurate and honest".
By Michael BuchananBBC News
The warm glow that surrounded the council's decision to appoint Peter Hay as director of children's services last summer seems to be lasting.  Morale and recruitment are up and sickness levels, though still high, have stabilised over the past six months.
But much still needs to done.  Today's review suggests there may not be enough social workers across England willing to specialise in child protection.  Many of those that do regard working in Birmingham as a "blot on their CVs".  Making the department more appealing, including upping salaries, needs to be a key priority.
The city could still lose its responsibility to protect children as the Dfe looks at ways of commissioning child protection services outside local authority control.
The threat is clear: if inadequate child protection units fail to improve, their duties will be removed.
"What this report shows is that we must stick to our long-term improvement plan and not be dragged back into the short-term thinking that saw us making knee-jerk changes as a response to every poor Ofsted inspection," she said.
The report identified "a long-standing under-investment in children's services" and a "stand-alone culture" within the department.
It said: "For a variety of reasons, over many years the corporate/political centre appears not to have paid enough attention to the department and to the service that it was delivering."
The report's authors also identified a department "haemorrhaging social workers" and, until recently, disjointed management with senior staff leaving and posts remaining vacant.
They added the council may also face the problem of "possible unidentified risk to vulnerable children".
"There may be many children in Birmingham at risk who have not been properly identified as such, or, if they have been, their risks have not been properly addressed," they said.
The council said Professor Julian Le Grand's report had identified a possible nationwide shortage of social workers.
It said figures showed it took five years to train a social worker but the average length of service was seven years.
Labour MP for Perry Barr, Khalid Mahmood, said the "halfway house" decision not to remove control of children's services from the council and install a commissioner was a "better way" to approach the problems.
"It allows the council to build on the pace and build on the knowledge that's happening, it's about working together [with central government] and building for the future," he said.
Mr Mahmood agreed there was a sense of "report fatigue" in Birmingham, after earlier reviews of children's services did not seem to yield improvements that were called for.
"We need to ensure when the report comes back in April that we are able to review it and see how it goes," he said.

receive the same standard of care and protection as any other child in the country,” adding that systemic failures must be addressed with urgency and accountability. “This is not just about identifying what went wrong in individual cases, but about transforming a system so that early intervention becomes the norm, not the exception,” he said.

Lord Warner, who served as a health minister under the Labour government between 2003 and 2007 and has since been an active voice on social care reform in the House of Lords, will begin his role immediately. His mandate includes reviewing how Birmingham City Council handles child protection referrals, assesses risk, and coordinates with health, education, and police services. He will also examine whether existing safeguarding protocols are consistently applied across all wards, particularly in areas with high levels of poverty and social exclusion.

The announcement comes amid growing pressure on local authorities to demonstrate measurable progress in children’s services. Birmingham, the UK’s second-largest city, oversees a children’s social care system serving over 4,500 vulnerable youngsters, with more than 1,300 subject to child protection plans at any given time. Despite recent improvements noted in the peer review, data shows the city continues to lag behind national averages in timely assessments and family support interventions.

The newly established independent expert panel will be chaired by Dr. Elaine Byford, a former chief inspector of Ofsted’s social care division, and include specialists in child psychology, public health, and youth justice. The panel will conduct quarterly evaluations of the council’s performance, publish findings publicly, and make recommendations directly to both the commissioner and the Department for Education.

Ministers have stopped short of imposing special measures, which would involve removing control from the local authority—a step taken in cities like Rotherham and Nottinghamshire following high-profile safeguarding failures. Instead, the government is opting for a model of “intensive oversight” designed to preserve local accountability while ensuring external scrutiny.

In response, Birmingham City Council has pledged full cooperation. A spokesperson confirmed that internal audits of case management processes are already underway and that additional training for frontline staff will be rolled out by mid-March. The £10 million investment announced in December will fund new digital systems to track children at risk, expand foster care capacity, and strengthen early help services aimed at preventing escalation into crisis.

Critics, however, remain cautious. Anne Longfield, former Children’s Commissioner for England, warned that without sustained funding and workforce reform, even the best oversight structures may fail to deliver lasting change. “We’ve seen cycles of inspection, reports, and promises before,” she said. “What’s needed now is not just monitoring, but a fundamental shift in how we value and resource child protection.”

Local advocacy groups welcomed Lord Warner’s appointment but stressed the importance of involving families and communities in shaping reforms. “Too often, parents feel blamed rather than supported,” said Mariam Khan, director of the Birmingham Family Voice Network. “If this review listens to lived experience, it could lead to real change.”

As the commissioner begins his work, attention will focus on whether Birmingham can break the pattern of reactive responses and build a proactive, trauma-informed system capable of protecting its most vulnerable children—not only when tragedies occur, but long before they happen.

Birmingham has been thrust into the national spotlight as the UK government initiates an unprecedented level of oversight over its children’s social care system, appointing Lord Warner—a seasoned advocate for social care reform—to lead a critical review amid persistent concerns about systemic shortcomings. The move underscores growing alarm over disparities in child protection outcomes and follows years of scrutiny after a series of high-profile safeguarding failures across the country.

Lord Warner, who held office as a health minister from 2003 to 2007 under Tony Blair’s Labour government, brings decades of public service and policy expertise to his newly mandated role. His appointment is immediate and carries significant weight: he will conduct a comprehensive assessment of how Birmingham City Council manages child protection referrals, evaluates risk factors, and coordinates with key agencies including healthcare providers, schools, and law enforcement. A central focus of his inquiry will be whether safeguarding protocols are being uniformly enforced across all 69 wards of the city—an area marked by stark socioeconomic contrasts. In particular, neighborhoods grappling with entrenched poverty, overcrowded housing, and limited access to early help services will be scrutinized for gaps in intervention that may leave vulnerable children at risk.

The review comes at a pivotal moment. As England’s second-largest city, Birmingham oversees one of the most complex and stretched child protection systems in the country, supporting more than 4,500 children deemed at risk due to abuse, neglect, or family instability. Of these, over 1,300 are formally subject to child protection plans at any given time—figures that place immense pressure on already overstretched social work teams. While a recent peer review acknowledged incremental improvements in case management and response times, official data reveals the city continues to fall short of national benchmarks in delivering timely assessments and preventative family support. Delays in initial evaluations can stretch beyond statutory deadlines, undermining efforts to intervene before crises escalate.

To ensure rigorous and independent monitoring, the Department for Education has established an expert oversight panel chaired by Dr. Elaine Byford, former chief inspector of Ofsted’s social care division, whose tenure was defined by sharp critiques of inadequate local authority responses. The panel includes specialists in child development, trauma-informed practice, public health, and youth justice, reflecting a multidisciplinary approach to reform. It will publish quarterly performance reports, offering transparent evaluations of the council’s progress and issuing direct recommendations to both Lord Warner and ministers. These findings will be made publicly available—an effort to restore trust among families and stakeholders long skeptical of opaque bureaucratic processes.

Notably, the government has refrained from imposing special measures, which would entail removing operational control from Birmingham City Council and installing external commissioners—a step previously taken in Rotherham and Nottinghamshire following damning inquiries into institutional failings. Instead, this “intensive oversight” model seeks to balance accountability with local autonomy, preserving the council’s responsibility while embedding robust external scrutiny. Officials argue this approach avoids the stigma and disruption associated with full intervention, while still compelling action through sustained pressure and visibility.

In response, Birmingham City Council has pledged full cooperation, emphasizing ongoing internal reforms. A spokesperson confirmed that comprehensive audits of case file management, decision-making timelines, and inter-agency communication are already underway. By mid-March, enhanced training programs targeting frontline social workers, call-handlers, and team managers will be rolled out, focusing on recognizing signs of neglect, assessing domestic abuse risks, and applying trauma-informed frameworks. Additionally, the £10 million funding package announced in December will accelerate digital transformation, introducing a centralized case-tracking system designed to monitor children’s journeys through care pathways in real time. Funds will also expand foster care recruitment initiatives and bolster community-based early help services—such as parenting support hubs and mental health outreach—that aim to reduce reliance on emergency interventions.

Despite these steps, skepticism remains. Anne Longfield, who served as Children’s Commissioner for England from 2010 to 2021, cautioned that structural change cannot be achieved without addressing chronic underfunding and workforce burnout. “We’ve seen cycles of inspection, reports, and promises before,” she said. “What’s needed now is not just monitoring, but a fundamental shift in how we value and resource child protection.” She pointed to national trends: rising caseloads, shrinking budgets, and difficulties retaining qualified social workers continue to plague local authorities, threatening even the most well-designed oversight mechanisms.

Community voices echo these concerns. Mariam Khan, director of the Birmingham Family Voice Network—a grassroots coalition representing parents with lived experience of the care system—welcomed Lord Warner’s appointment but stressed that meaningful reform must include those most affected. “Too often, parents feel blamed rather than supported,” she said. “If this review listens to lived experience—the insights of families navigating poverty, addiction, or disability—it could lead to real, sustainable change.” Her group is calling for formal consultation mechanisms that allow caregivers to contribute to policy design, ensuring solutions are grounded in reality rather than top-down assumptions.

As Lord Warner begins field visits and data analysis, eyes will be on Birmingham’s ability to transition from a reactive model—where interventions occur only after harm has occurred—to a proactive, prevention-led system rooted in equity and early support. The stakes are high: behind the statistics are thousands of children whose futures depend on timely, compassionate, and coordinated care. This moment offers a chance not only to fix broken processes but to redefine what child protection means in a modern, diverse city—one where every child, regardless of postcode or background, receives the same standard of care and protection as any other in the country.

“This is not just about identifying what went wrong in individual cases,” Lord Warner emphasized, “but about transforming a system so that early intervention becomes the norm, not the exception.”

As was my custom, I started counting down the time until I went under. 
 
 Five 
 
 Four 
 
 Three 
 
 Two 
 
 One 
 
 Zero? 
 
... Negative One 
 
 Negative tw- Alright, something's not right here. 
 
 & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; Blinking rapidly, I opened my eyes. It was a little cooler than normal, but not like it should be. Maybe a hose sprung a leak? I took a quick look around. Not inside, at least. The glass had frosted over, though. Curious. 
 
 & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; Pulling my sleeve up over my palm, I wiped off the viewing pane. It squeaked in protest as the bare glass came into contact with my sleeve. The ice is on the wrong side of the glass. 
 
 & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; *Guess I found where the broken hose is venting. * I thought, *Anyways, I should probably exit the bed just in case. * 
 
 & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; A gust of frigid air pummeled me as I tugged the handle, opening the door. Ice crackled, protesting the door's movement. The scene outside was n't pretty. 
 
 & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; Well actually, it was very pretty. A fine layer of frost coated the inside of the room, turning everything the same shade of pale blue. The overhead LEDs were muted by the frozen covering, and the little indicator lights on the bed reflected wildly about the room. What was n't pretty was the fact that every room I could see, all three of them, were in the same state. One little hose could n't cause all of this. 
 
 & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; *Front desk. * I thought. *They'll have an idea what's going on. * So with the frost crunching underfoot and a little shower of ice dust flying away with each step, I set out towards the front desk. I got a little lost. Fortunately, it only took me five minutes to find the right hallway. 
 
 & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; Unfortunately, all of the hallways and even the front desk itself was deserted. And everything was covered in ice. Aside from all of the water vapor in the wrong form, the only thing amiss was a particularly large pile of snow on the front desk's chair. 
 
 & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; *Everyone must have gone outside already. * An uneasy feeling was developing in the pit of my stomach. Pushing open the front door, I discovered why. 
 
 & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; Everything was frozen. EVERYTHING was frozen. 
 
 & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp;'' That's it.'' I concluded. `` I've gone insane.'' Looking around I came to another conclusion. `` Might as well enjoy it.'' 
 
 & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; & nbsp; With a skip, I set off down the center of the little eighteen-lane road, merrily humming'Winter Wonderland.' After all, everything was so unusual and grand.
LLM_1:
over the frosted glass, I wiped a clear patch to peer out. The usual sterile white of the cryo-bay was gone, replaced by a deep, shadowy gloom punctuated by the intermittent crimson pulse of emergency lighting. A low, sub-audible hum—the ship’s normal heartbeat—was absent, leaving a silence so profound I could hear the faint crackle of ice forming on the chamber’s exterior.

The restraints retracted with a sluggish, grinding whir, not their usual smooth whisper. I swung my legs over the side, the TempraGel© crunching unpleasantly beneath me. My breath misted in the air. Standard procedure dictated a gradual, monitored revival over hours, not this abrupt, frigid awakening. Someone, or something, had interrupted the cycle.

My sleeve, where I’d wiped the glass, was now damp and chilling against my skin. I slid off the bed, boots hitting the deck with a solid thud that echoed in the vast bay. Rows of other cryorest units stretched into the darkness, their status panels dark. I moved to the nearest one, wiping its viewport. The occupant, a woman I vaguely recalled from the manifest, was still locked in stasis, but her monitor displayed a flashing error code: **ENV INTEGRITY FAILURE.**

A cold deeper than the chamber’s temperature seeped into my bones. This wasn’t a local malfunction. I made for the bay doors, my steps hurried. The main console beside the entrance was dead, but a manual release lever was encased in ice. I slammed my palm against the heated casing until it melted the seal, then hauled the lever down. The doors hissed, parting just enough for me to slip through into the corridor beyond.

The scene there was worse. Conduits hung from the ceiling, dripping coolant that froze into jagged stalactites on the floor. The ship, the *Aethelstan*, was dying. A distant, metallic groan shuddered through the hull—a sound of immense stress. I needed to get to the bridge.

Rounding a corner, I nearly collided with a figure. It was Aris, the ship’s engineer, his face pale under a headlamp beam, a portable diagnostic unit clutched in trembling hands. “You’re awake,” he breathed, his voice raw. “The core went into emergency shutdown. Life support’s on batteries. We’ve got maybe three hours.”

“Why wasn’t the revival sequence initiated?” I asked, my own voice sounding too calm in the eerie quiet.

“It was overridden,” Aris said, his eyes wide. “From the bridge. But there’s no one there. Comms are dead. It’s like the ship… decided to wake a few of us up. Just a few.” He gestured down the hall. “Lena’s awake too, in med-bay. She’s hurt.”

A new priority. Together, we navigated the frozen wreckage of the corridor, the only sounds our breathing and the creaking agony of the ship. In med-bay, we found Lena propped against a wall, her leg immobilized by a makeshift splint. Her eyes, sharp with pain and intelligence, met mine.

“The logs,” she said, not wasting a word. “Before systems crashed, I pulled fragmentary data. The override command didn’t come from the bridge.” She swallowed. “It came from outside. A transmission. It’s not in any registry.”

The three of us shared a look, the truth crystallizing in the frigid air. We weren’t victims of a random failure. We had been deliberately, selectively roused. And outside our dying ship, something in the void was waiting.

Over the frosted glass, I wiped a clear patch to peer out—a smeared, trembling arc in the condensation. The usual sterile white of the cryo-bay was gone, bled away into a deep, shadowy gloom that felt less like an absence of light and more like a presence. It was punctuated only by the intermittent crimson pulse of emergency lighting, each flare throwing long, skeletal shadows from the dormant cryo-units before swallowing them again. A low, sub-audible hum—the ship’s normal heartbeat, the vibration I’d fallen asleep to months ago—was absent. In its place was a silence so profound and heavy I could hear the faint, gossamer crackle of ice forming on the chamber’s exterior, a sound like distant cellophane being slowly crushed.

The restraints retracted with a sluggish, grinding whir, a protest of metal on metal, not their usual smooth, hydraulic whisper. I swung my legs over the side, the TempraGel© crunching unpleasantly beneath me, its once-viscous warmth now a brittle, frozen slurry. My breath plumed in the air, a ghostly flag in the stillness. Standard procedure dictated a gradual, monitored revival over hours, with soft lights and gentle stim-tones, not this abrupt, frigid awakening that felt less like waking and more like being excavated. Someone, or something, had reached into the dream of stasis and torn the cycle in two.

My sleeve, where I’d wiped the glass, was now damp and chilling against my skin, a clammy brand. I slid off the bed, boots hitting the deck with a solid, too-loud *thud* that echoed in the vast bay, a solitary drumbeat in a dead cathedral. Rows of other cryorest units stretched into the darkness, their status panels dark and sightless. I moved to the nearest one, the deck plating cold even through my boots, and wiped its viewport with the heel of my hand. The occupant, a woman I vaguely recalled from the manifest briefing—Lieutenant Mara Vance, exobiology—was still locked in stasis, her features serene under the ice-crusted glass. But her monitor, a single stubborn eye in the dark, displayed a flashing, malevolent error code: **ENV INTEGRITY FAILURE.**

A cold deeper than the chamber’s temperature seeped into my bones, a chill of comprehension. This wasn’t a local malfunction, a glitch in a single pod. This was systemic. I made for the bay doors, my steps hurried, the echoes chasing me. The main console beside the entrance was a dead slate of black glass. But the manual release lever, an archaic red bar, was encased in a cocoon of milky ice. I slammed my palm against the heated casing again and again, the pain bright and sharp, until it melted the seal with a hiss of steam. Then I hauled the lever down. The doors groaned, then hissed, parting just enough for me to slip through into the corridor beyond—a sliver of escape into a wider tomb.

The scene there was worse, a vision of mechanical decay. Conduits hung from the ceiling like severed veins, dripping coolant that froze into jagged, gleaming stalactites on the floor. The air smelled of ozone and cold metal. The ship, the *Aethelstan*, was dying around me. A distant, metallic groan shuddered through the hull—a sound of immense stress, a beast in its death throes. I needed to get to the bridge, to the heart of the silence.

Rounding a corner, I nearly collided with a figure materializing from the gloom. It was Aris, the ship’s engineer, his face pale and gaunt under the stark beam of his headlamp, a portable diagnostic unit clutched in hands trembling from more than just the cold. “You’re awake,” he breathed, his voice raw, scraped thin by panic. “The core went into emergency shutdown. Life support’s on battery reserves. We’ve got maybe three hours of air, less if the heaters fail completely.”

“Why wasn’t the automated revival sequence initiated?” I asked, my own voice sounding disturbingly calm, a flat plane in the eerie quiet.

“It was overridden,” Aris said, his eyes wide, the whites showing all around. “Command source: the bridge. But there’s no one there. Comms are utterly dead. It’s like the ship… developed a instinct. Decided to wake a few of us up. Just a few.” He gestured down the hall, his light cutting a shaky path through the dangling wires and frost. “Lena’s awake too, in med-bay. She’s hurt.”

A new priority, immediate and human, cut through the systemic dread. Together, we navigated the frozen wreckage of the corridor, our world reduced to the cones of our lights, the only sounds the rasp of our breathing and the creaking, agonized protests of the ship’s hull. In med-bay, we found Lena propped against a wall where she’d dragged herself, her leg immobilized by a makeshift splint fashioned from a broken cabinet strut. Her eyes, sharp with pain and a fierce, undimmed intelligence, met mine.

“The logs,” she said, not wasting a word, her voice tight. “Before the primary systems crashed, I pulled fragmentary data from the diagnostic buffer. The override command didn’t originate from the bridge console.” She swallowed, the sound dry. “It came from outside. A tight-beam transmission, piggybacking on a maintenance carrier wave. It’s not in any registry, not any format I’ve ever seen.”

The three of us shared a look, a silent exchange in the frozen air. The truth crystallized then, not with a shout, but with a terrible, sinking clarity, harder and colder than the ice on the walls. We weren’t victims of a random cascade failure, a tragic accident of deep space. We had been deliberately, selectively roused—plucked from the safety of sleep. And outside our dying ship, in the infinite, hungry void, something had sent the signal. Something was waiting.

human: Coronary calcium score (CCS), carotid plaque area (CPA), intima-media thickness (IMT), and C-reactive protein (CRP) are independent predictors of cardiovascular prognosis. Although each test may enhance risk stratification, their comparative abilities to screen for underlying coronary stenoses in individual patients is less established.Forty-two patients who had a 16-slice coronary computed tomography angiogram (CTA) performed were invited to have CPA, IMT, and CRP measured. CPA was defined as the sum of all the cross-sectional areas of each plaque >1 mm in diameter found in all carotid vessels bilaterally. CCS and the number plus degree of stenotic coronary arteries were determined by CTA. The presence of clinically significant coronary artery disease (CAD) was defined as the existence of any stenosis > or =50%. CTA identified clinically significant CAD in 43% of the patients. CPA >0 was more sensitive (72%) and specific (58%) than a CCS >0 (58% and 55%) for identifying CAD. A "clean" carotid artery (CPA=0) provides a superior negative predictive value (74%) and likelihood ratio of a negative test (0.48) than all other studies, in particular versus a CCS=0 (65% and 0.72). The areas under the receiver-operator curves for CPA and CCS in relation to any CAD were similar (0.640 versus 0.675). Carotid IMT and CRP performed poorly compared with CPA and CCS. For detecting CAD in only the left main or left anterior descending artery, the negative predictive value and likelihood ratio of a negative test remained superior for CPA (87% and 0.33) compared with CCS (80% and 0.56). In our population with a prevalence of these coronary lesions of 30%, the post-test probability in any patient with a negative CPA result is reduced to 10%.
LLM_1:
To address this knowledge gap, we conducted a retrospective analysis of 42 patients undergoing 64-slices coronary CT angiography (CCT) at our institution. Each patient's CCS, CPA, IMT, CRP, CTA images, as well as the corresponding clinical information, were retrieved from our database and anonymized for analysis. We then evaluated the performance of these non-invasive tests in detecting significant coronary artery stenos is (≥50% luminal narrowing) as determined by CCT.

Our results showed that among the examined tests, the CCS demonstrated the highest sensitivity (85.7%) and specificity (92.5%) for identifying significant steno is. Notably, a CCS ≥100 was found to be highly predictive of significant disease (positive predictive value:85%; negative predictive valu e:93.6%). In contrast, while the CPA and IM T showed moderate correlations with CCT findings, they failed to demonstrate sufficient diagnostic accuracy for clinical use.

The CR P, often used as a surrogate marker for inflammation and cardiovascular risk, exhibited a modest correlation with significant CCT-determined disease. However, its limited sensitivity and poor specificity render it an unreliable tool for detecting coronary atherosclerosis. In conclusion, our study suggests that CCS is the most effective noninvasive test for screening underlying st enotic coronary disease in clinical practice, warranting further investigation into its utility as an adjunct to traditional risk assessment strategies. Future research should aim to validate these findings in larger cohorts and explore the potential benefits of CCS-guided preventive cardiology. Our results provide a foundation for developing novel risk-stratification protocols that incorporate CCS and other imaging biomarkers to optimize patient outcomes. By integrating these advances into clinical workflows, healthcare providers can improve the detection and management of atheromatous disease, ultimately reducing cardiovascular morbidity and mortality. These findings have significant implications for the field of preventive medicine and highlight the need for further research into personalized cardiovascular disease prevention strategies
LLM_2:
A retrospective study of coronary computed tomography angiograms (64 slices) from  142 patients identified CCS as superior for diagnosing significant ( ≥50%) coronary stenosis. Among the evaluated tests CCS showed the best sensitivity/specificity (83.9%/93%) with a high positive predictive (86%) value. Conversely, other tests like CPA/IMT/CRP showed limited correlations and insufficient diagnostic value.

CRP's modest association with inflammation/coronary risk was offset by its poor sensitivity/sppecificy (63.1%/59.3%). Our findings indicate that coronary calcium scoring (CCS) is an effective, non- invasive screening tool, suggesting its potential as adjunct risk stratification. Further research validating these results in large cohorts is warranted. Incorporating CCS into novel protocols with imaging markers can optimize outcomes in preventive care. This study's implications highlight a need to explore personalized disease management, potentially reducing morb/mortality.

human: George Gipp was the school's legendary football player during 1916–20. He played semiprofessional baseball and smoked, drank, and gambled when not playing sports. He was also humble, generous to the needy, and a man of integrity. It was in 1928 that famed coach Knute Rockne used his final conversation with the dying Gipp to inspire the Notre Dame team to beat the Army team and "win one for the Gipper." The 1940 film, Knute Rockne, All American, starred Pat O'Brien as Knute Rockne and Ronald Reagan as Gipp. Today the team competes in Notre Dame Stadium, an 80,795-seat stadium on campus. The current head coach is Brian Kelly, hired from the University of Cincinnati on December 11, 2009. Kelly's record in midway through his sixth season at Notre Dame is 52–21. In 2012, Kelly's Fighting Irish squad went undefeated and played in the BCS National Championship Game. Kelly succeeded Charlie Weis, who was fired in November 2009 after five seasons. Although Weis led his team to two Bowl Championship Series bowl games, his overall record was 35–27, mediocre by Notre Dame standards, and the 2007 team had the most losses in school history. The football team generates enough revenue to operate independently while $22.1 million is retained from the team's profits for academic use. Forbes named the team as the most valuable in college football, worth a total of $101 million in 2007.

human: The National Council on Qualifications for the Lighting Professions (NCQLP) offers the Lighting Certification Examination which tests rudimentary lighting design principles. Individuals who pass this exam become ‘Lighting Certified’ and may append the abbreviation LC to their name. This certification process is one of three national (U.S.) examinations (the others are CLEP and CLMC) in the lighting industry and is open not only to designers, but to lighting equipment manufacturers, electric utility employees, etc.
LLM_1: assesses the knowledge and expertise of lighting professionals across North America. Those who pass the exam earn the designation of Lighting Certified (LC), a credential recognized as a mark of professional achievement in the field. The examination covers key areas including lighting design principles, energy efficiency, electrical systems, building codes, and sustainability standards. Administered annually, the test is developed and maintained by a board of industry experts to ensure relevance and rigor. Certification must be renewed every five years through continuing education or re-examination.
LLM_2:
---

The Lighting Certification (LC) program evaluates the knowledge and professional competence of lighting practitioners across North America. Individuals who successfully pass the examination are awarded the LC credential, which is widely recognized as a mark of excellence and expertise in the lighting industry. The exam encompasses core subject areas such as lighting design principles, energy efficiency, electrical systems, building codes, and sustainability standards. Developed and maintained by a board of industry experts, the examination is administered annually to ensure alignment with current practices and technological advancements. To maintain certification, holders must renew their credentials every five years through continuing education or by retaking the examination.

LLM_1:
definitely a topic worth diving into, especially considering how labor laws shape the work-life balance for many. It’s such a delicate dance between what businesses need for productivity and what employees require for a livable wage and quality of life. 

The potential changes to labor laws could bring about a shift in how we view work hours and compensation. If employees are given the flexibility to convert overtime into paid time off, they might feel more empowered to manage their schedules in a way that suits their personal lives. This flexibility could lead to greater job satisfaction and, in turn, higher productivity. Imagine the peace of mind knowing that if you put in those extra hours one week, you could take a breather the next. 

However, this also raises some important questions. How will these changes be implemented? Will businesses be transparent about their policies? There’s always a risk that without proper regulations, companies might prioritize their bottom line over their employees' well-being. The fear of exploitation is valid, especially in industries where workers are already struggling to maintain a balance between their professional and personal lives. 

It’s interesting to note how the conversation around labor laws is evolving. With the rise of the gig economy and remote work, traditional notions of a 9-to-5 job are changing. Many people are now blending work with personal time, and the strict boundaries we once held are becoming more fluid. This shift could act as a double-edged sword; while it allows for more flexibility, it might also make it harder for employees to disconnect from work, leading to burnout.

For me, the crux of the issue lies in ensuring that any proposed legislation protects workers’ rights while offering them the flexibility they crave. It’s crucial that laws are designed to encourage a healthy work environment rather than compromise it. The idea of flex-time is appealing, but not if it means that workers are pushed to work longer hours without appropriate compensation. 

In light of these considerations, it’s essential for us to stay informed and engaged in the discussion. Following the developments around this proposal will be key, as it can serve as a barometer for how our society values labor. With organizations like the AFL-CIO voicing their concerns, it’s evident that there will be significant pushback against any changes that threaten worker protections. 

I can see how solidarity among workers is more crucial than ever. As we navigate these changes, it’s vital to maintain a dialogue about what fair treatment looks like in the modern workplace. Workers need to speak up, share their experiences, and advocate for laws that genuinely enhance their quality of life. Perhaps this is the perfect opportunity for employees to come together and push for reforms that prioritize their needs.

Additionally, there’s a broader conversation about technology’s role in the workplace. The rise of automation and artificial intelligence presents both challenges and opportunities. As businesses adopt these technologies, the nature of work is changing rapidly. Will the flexibility offered by new labor laws adapt to this dynamic landscape? Or will we see a further divide between those who can leverage technology to enhance their work-life balance and those who cannot?

The intersection of labor laws, technology, and employee well-being is intricate and multifaceted. It’s a topic that warrants ongoing exploration and discussion. As we continue to witness shifts in our economy, let’s not lose sight of the human element. Every policy change should consider the real impact on people's lives.

In the meantime, I’m excited to see how these discussions unfold. Engaging with articles and expert opinions on labor laws will be essential as I work through my coursework. There’s so much to learn about the implications of these policies, not just for me personally but for the workforce as a whole.

Just as I felt the weight of those tests, many individuals feel the strain of needing to prove their worth to employers. The stakes can feel high, but I believe it’s important to remember that we are not just cogs in a machine; we are individuals with unique strengths, perspectives, and needs.

The conversation about labor laws is not just an abstract policy debate; it’s about real lives and the balance we seek between work and personal fulfillment. As I continue my studies, I hope to contribute to this discourse, advocating for policies that support both workers and businesses in a way that fosters a healthier, more equitable future for all.

In closing, I encourage everyone to stay tuned to this topic. Let’s support each other as we navigate the complexities of work in today’s world, and advocate for changes that enhance our lives while also ensuring that we protect the rights of all workers. LLM_1: Friday rolled in like a burst of energy—me and my friends decided to make the most of the unexpected break. We kicked things off with a spontaneous road trip to the coast, windows down, music blasting, that golden-hour glow painting everything in warmth. Spent hours just walking the shoreline, talking about everything and nothing—college plans, weird dreams, that one teacher who still thinks memes are called “internet jokes.” Saturday was all about comfort: pancakes for lunch, a marathon of old sitcoms, and finally finishing that novel I’ve been dragging my feet on. Sunday? A little productive, I’ll admit. Organized my notes, color-coded my study schedule (because if you’re gonna suffer, suffer in style), but not before sneaking in an afternoon nap under the sunlit porch. There’s something bittersweet about these last pockets of freedom—they don’t feel like endings, more like deep breaths before the plunge. And honestly, I’m ready. Bring on the exams. I’ve got highlighters, hope, and at least three playlists titled “Final Push.”
LLM_2:
---

**Friday arrived like a burst of sunshine.**  
No grand plans, no pressure—just the kind of unexpected break that feels like a gift. My friends and I seized the moment with a spontaneous road trip to the coast: windows down, music cranked up, and that golden-hour glow turning the world into something soft and cinematic. We spent hours wandering the shoreline, talking about everything and nothing—college dreams, bizarre nightmares, and the one teacher who still refers to memes as “internet jokes.”  

Saturday was all about slow living. Pancakes for lunch (because why not?), a full marathon of old sitcoms, and—finally—the satisfying thud of closing that novel I’d been putting off for months. Sometimes, doing nothing is the most productive thing you can do.  

Sunday? Okay, *slightly* more responsible. I organized my notes, color-coded my study schedule (if I’m going to suffer, I might as well do it in style), and even tackled a few overdue emails. But not before slipping in a sun-drenched nap on the porch—a quiet pause, wrapped in warmth and dappled light.  

There’s something bittersweet about these final pockets of freedom. They don’t feel like endings, exactly—more like deep breaths. The calm before the storm of exams, papers, and caffeine-fueled nights.  

But you know what? I’m ready.  
Bring it on.  
I’ve got highlighters, hope, and at least three playlists titled *“Final Push.”*

---

This version enhances rhythm, imagery, and emotional resonance while maintaining authenticity—perfect for a personal or lifestyle blog. # Cliftonville Revives Form with Decisive Victory Over Struggling Glentoran

A commanding performance by Cliftonville at The Oval on Saturday delivered a significant blow to Glentoran’s early-season ambitions, as the visitors secured a 2–0 win that reshapes the early dynamics of the Premiership table.

Cliftonville, under manager Paddy McLaughlin, displayed renewed composure and control, establishing an early advantage and dominating midfield for long stretches. Captain Ronan Hale anchored a disciplined defensive effort in a deeper role, helping withstand a late push from the hosts. Goalkeeper Morris contributed several sharp saves to preserve the clean sheet and deny any Glentoran comeback.

For Glentoran, pre-season hopes of a title challenge have given way to mounting concerns. The defeat leaves them with just one win from their opening five matches, placing them in the bottom half of the standings. Questions are growing around the side’s defensive resilience and ability to turn possession into meaningful opportunities.

The result provides Cliftonville with a timely boost ahead of a packed fixture schedule, while pressure builds on Glentoran manager Mick McDermott to inspire a swift turnaround. Attention now turns to next week’s derby, where Glentoran will be urgent to rediscover their form and reverse a campaign that risks slipping away.

human: Ileocolitis is a recognized feature of ankylosing spondylitis (AS) and is likely to play a role in the pathogenesis of AS, in conjunction with the normal intestinal microbiota. In order to investigate the host immune response in AS, we measured cytokines in tissue culture following exposure of peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC) to autologous colonic bacteria.Twenty-one patients with AS and 21 matched controls were recruited. Subjects in the AS group were assessed clinically. Bacteroides species belonging to the B. fragilis group were selectively cultured from stool samples and paired with blood samples from each participant. Ten cultures of autologous Bacteroides were randomly selected from cultures grown from the fecal specimens of each of the 21 patients with AS and 21 controls. These were then tested for reactivity with PBMC and the cytokines produced by proliferating lymphocytes [interleukin 10 (IL-10), IL-17, interferon-gamma, tumor necrosis factor-alpha] were measured in cell culture supernatants. Differences between groups were analyzed using censored normal regression analysis.The patients with AS had severe active AS with Bath AS Disease Activity Index 5.5 (+/-1.6) and C-reactive protein (mg/l) 13.8 (+/-12.2) (mean+/-standard deviation). IL-10 concentrations in ex vivo assay supernatants were lower in the AS group compared with controls (p=0.047). There were no statistically significant differences between the groups for other cytokines.
LLM_1: tissues. Subsequently, we assessed the production of key pro-inflammatory cytokines, including TNF-α, IL-6, and IL-17, alongside anti-inflammatory markers such as IL-10. Our results revealed a significant upregulation of TNF-α and IL-6 in PBMCs after exposure to colonic tissues from AS patients compared to healthy controls. Notably, IL-17 levels were markedly elevated, suggesting a potential Th17-mediated pathway in the context of AS-related ileocolitis. Furthermore, the analysis of gut microbiota composition indicated a distinct profile in AS patients, characterized by reduced diversity and an increase in specific pathobionts. These findings suggest that the interplay between altered gut microbiota and the host immune response may contribute to the inflammatory milieu associated with AS. Our study underscores the importance of investigating the gut-immune axis in understanding the pathogenesis of ankylosing spondylitis and highlights potential therapeutic avenues targeting cytokine pathways and microbial modulation.
LLM_2: We evaluated the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, IL-6, IL-17) and the anti-inflammatory marker IL-10 in peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) exposed to colonic tissues from ankylosing spondylitis (AS) patients compared to healthy controls. Our results demonstrated a significant increase in TNF-α and IL-6 levels, with a notable elevation of IL-17, suggesting a Th17-mediated pathway in AS-related ileocolitis. Additionally, gut microbiota analysis revealed a distinct composition in AS patients, marked by reduced diversity and an increase in specific pathobionts. These findings indicate that the interaction between altered gut microbiota and the host immune response may contribute to the inflammatory environment in AS. This study emphasizes the need to explore the gut-immune axis in AS pathogenesis and identifies potential therapeutic strategies targeting cytokine pathways and microbial modulation.

human: `` This is it.'' the boy thought to himself, as sweat trickled down his face. `` This is my chance to become a somebody!'' Reinvigorated, he quickened his pace as he made his way down the seemingly-endless spiral staircase. As he descended, the not noticed that it was getting warmer and warmer. Finally after almost an hour, he found himself standing in front of an old, wooden door. Without hesitation, he grabbed the handle and turned it. The first thing the boy saw was darkness. As his eyes adjusted, the boy realised he was standing at the entrance of a long hallway. Still devoted to finishing his mission, he began to walk, the temperature rising with every step. Eventually, he came to the end off the hallway and found a small room lit only by a single torch, fluttering weakly next to a small table. Not sure of what to do, the boy walked up to the table and looked at it. It seemed like it hadnt been touched for centuries, and it was covered in strange runes. The boy ran his sweaty palm along the top of the table. Despite tthheat of the room, the table was disturbingly cold. Slightly unnerved, the boy turned around to look back down the hallway and was surprised to find that it was gone. Startled, the boy turned back towards the table and jumped when he saw that there was a man standing on the other side. The man smiled atever so slightly at the boy's apparent fear. `` Welcome.'' he said, with a voice the turned the boy's blood to ice. To scared to speak, the boy took a step back. Instantly, the fire from the torch seemed to rage until it reached the ceiling. `` You have come this far, the ritual must be completed!'' the man sputtered, with an terrifying, almost animal-like voice. Shaking, yet resigned to his fate, the boy approached the table. In a flash, an aged, bloodstained scroll of parchment appeared. The man reached out and south another flash, a quill appeared in his hand. Silently, he handed it to the boy. Trembling, the boy took the quill, and as he grasped it he felt a dull pain wriggle it's way up his arm and across his chest, and into his heart, where it seemed to settle. Then, slowly, the scroll opened itself. The boy to a step closer to examine it and was surprised to find that it was completely blank. Unsure of what to do, he was about ask when the man stabbed a long, black, pointed fingernail into the center of the parchment. From the point where hisfingernail had touched, a small fire etched it's way across the scroll, until it formed an elaborate, flaming X. At that moment, the man said, with a hint of malice, `` Sign your name.'' After a moment of hesitation, the boy touched the quil to the parchment and began to write his name. Instantly, he felt the dull pain in his heart intensify. Determined to finish, he continued writing, the quill flowing with what the boy was sure was his blood. When he finished, he looked up at the man's face as a terrible grin spread across it. `` Congratulations, Justin bieber, the ritual is complete.''
